name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the European Council and Commission declarations on the conclusions of the European Council of 22-23 March (2018/2550 (RSP)).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, let me brief the House on the outcome of the March European Council, where leaders tackled a number of issues ranging from Russia and Turkey to trade, taxation and Brexit. The European Council agreed with the UK Government’s assessment that it is highly likely that the Russian Federation is responsible for the nerve agent attack in Salisbury. We expressed full solidarity with the United Kingdom by condemning this attack and, as a response, many leaders decided to expel Russian diplomats. The EU ambassador to Moscow was recalled for consultations. Speaking about Russia, I should mention last weekend’s targeted airstrikes by France, the United Kingdom and the United States against Syrian chemical weapons facilities. The use of chemical weapons, anywhere in the world, must not become normalised. Nor can it be without consequences. The airstrikes were necessary and proportionate to deter further use of chemical weapons by the Syrian regime to kill its own people. It is urgent that all parties in Syria engage in the UN-led political process to end this tragedy. Above all, Russia and Iran should stop playing games and seriously engage in finding a responsible and peaceful solution. The European Council discussed trade and called for a permanent EU exemption from the US tariffs on steel and aluminium. We strongly supported the steps taken by the Commission to ensure that the interests of the Union are fully protected. If there is no permanent exemption for the EU, we will have no choice but to react. We wish to avoid this route, which is why I called for a dialogue that will bring more trade between the US and the EU, not less. Free and fair trade is one of the most powerful engines for growth and jobs, and we should make full use of it. It is simply in everyone’s interest. Leaders also discussed the digital economy, which is a great opportunity but also a challenge for tax systems. There was a clear understanding that we need to make our tax systems fit for the digital era. A global tax regime would certainly be most welcome, but many felt that it would take too much time to prepare. The discussion confirmed the leaders’ desire to work towards an effective and fair solution among EU Member States. In the context of the digital economy, we also discussed recent revelations related to Facebook and Cambridge Analytica. The European Council called on social networks and digital platforms to guarantee transparent practices and full protection of citizens’ privacy and personal data. EU and national legislation must be respected and enforced. This important matter, together with other issues relating to Digital Europe, will be discussed by the leaders at the informal meeting in Sofia in May. During the euro summit, leaders exchanged views on long-term challenges ahead of the EMU. The EU economy is back to pre-crisis growth rates, which makes this a very good time to reflect strategically on our ambitions. Many of the themes we discussed – like a fiscal capacity for the euro area – are difficult, but I see avenues to be explored. As we agreed in December, the most urgent political priority remains strengthening the banking union and further developing the European Stability Mechanism. This remains my goal, even though I am not a blind optimist. In June we will aim to take a first set of decisions and provide additional guidance on the way forward. On Brexit, the EU27 adopted guidelines for the future EU-UK relationship and welcomed the progress made on the withdrawal agreement. We want to use the positive momentum in these negotiations to finally settle outstanding issues such as the solution to avoid a hard border between Ireland and Northern Ireland. The UK’s decision on Brexit has caused the problem, and the UK will have to help solve it. Without a solution, there will be no withdrawal agreement and no transition. Leaders will assess the negotiations in June. In parallel, we will start our first talks about the future EU-UK relationship. Finally, on Turkey. Despite many controversies, we agreed that the EU-Turkey meeting should go ahead. I met President Erdoğan in Varna, together with Jean-Claude and Prime Minister Borissov. We took stock of where things now stand in our relationship and set out some parameters for the future. We expressed clearly different views on democratic standards, Turkey’s involvement in Syria and its illegal actions in the eastern Mediterranean as well as the Aegean Sea. However, we decided to keep the lines of communication open. We will also continue to work closely together on issues such as migration and terrorism. Before concluding, let me say a few words about the Western Balkans, where I will travel next week to prepare the EU-Western Balkans summit in Sofia on 17 May. The message to our friends is clear: the European Union is, and will continue to be, the most reliable partner for the entire region, as the biggest investor, the biggest donor, the biggest trading market and the best promise for a better future for citizens. Our summit should reaffirm the European perspective of the region. And, more importantly, it should improve, in concrete terms, connections with and within the region.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Mr President, for taking stock of Syria with regard to the Council's initiatives and the positions you have taken. Parliament yesterday and Monday discussed the Syrian issue at length, condemning the use of chemical weapons but also expressing the desire for European policy to be a protagonist for the peacebuilding in the Middle East and in the battered Syria. As far as own resources are concerned, as I told the Council, we insist on web tax, because we believe it is right that those who do not pay taxes in Europe then eventually pay them. It is one of the proposals put forward by the European Parliament, and therefore for us the issue of own resources and web tax, as one of the solutions to disposing of own resources, is of great importance, similarly the CO2 tax and the speculative financial transaction tax.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of Europäischen Commission. — Herr President, Herr Ratspräsident, meine sehr verehrten Damen und Herren! Donald Tusk hat flächendeckend über die letzte Sitzung of the Europäischen Rates berichtet. En gibt dem Weniges hinzuzufügen, es sei denn, dass ich noch einmal darauf hinweisen möchte, dass, was unsere Handelsbeziehungen mit den Vereinigten Staaten von Amerika anbelangt, wir strikt auf dem Standpunkt beharren, dass diese Ausnahmebestimmestim Mungen, die wir übergangsmäßig von der amerkanischen Seite erhalten haben, für uns, damit dies ein System wird, das Bestand hat, in the auernde Ausnahmebestimmungen übergeführt werden müssen. I would like to add, in a word as in a thousand, since Donald Tusk spoke about the summit with the Western Balkans, which the Commission proposed at yesterday's meeting to open accession negotiations with Albania and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. The opening of negotiations is not a decision which is the responsibility of the Commission alone; of course, a Council decision must be taken to that effect. The opening of negotiations does not mean that negotiations will begin tomorrow, nor that a date would be set for the end of these negotiations. All candidate countries will be judged on the basis of their own merit and we will see in the coming months and semesters what the Council's decision will be, which I would not like to anticipate. However, we agreed in this Chamber that the Western Balkans need the European perspective so that the tragedy we witnessed during the 1990s does not recur. It is therefore the responsibility of the States concerned to prepare for and make progress. Some have made substantial progress, others have made more modest progress. The future will demonstrate whether the States concerned are able to become members of the Union, but this is a process that will take a long time. With respect to other Council decisions I would like to see that, by June, we will be able to make significant progress in improving the banking union, including all related tax matters.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Mr President, on behalf of the PPE Group. A warm welcome to the European Parliament! Dear Donald Tusk, if we were to put a heading on the last European Council, you would say that we will achieve results again by the next Council. This means that many topics have been retaliated once again. Nonetheless, there are issues that move us and that move us around. On the subject of migration, we have now concluded two major elections in Europe. Voting was held in Italy and elected in Hungary. We in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats believe that the window of view is now on migration, the most important substantive issue for this continent. We have seen in the election campaigns how people are working to move forward now and to find solutions on this most important issue. The points are on the table. We need external border management, we need quotas to take in people in a structured way in the future, and we need a Marshall Plan for Africa. My group and, incidentally, Parliament as a whole have already taken clear decisions on this. We are ready. We are ready to conclude and we hope that the Council will finally move forward. The second major issue is the reform of the euro. It is therefore legitimate — even if I look towards Berlin — to define national positions. This is quite normal in European domestic policy. But now is no longer the time for national positions, but now is the time to seek the compromise to reach out to each other. That is why I hope that we will really get going on the euro reform by the June summit. The big message here is that, with the European Monetary Fund, we will become independent of the International Monetary Fund in the future. I do not want to be dependent on Donald Trump in future crises in order to sharpen this politically. We have to solve our problems ourselves. Last but not least for the Brexit: We have a strong united European Union there. Thank you for the work. Ireland is the open question. We are all Irish in this regard. We have a clear message to convey that we are behind our Irish friends. And yet the last few weeks have shown that we are partners — on Syria, on the issue of dealing with Russia — and will continue to work in partnership with each other, including the UK, even though we are now going to go our separate ways in the European Union. On Russia, perhaps the final idea. How about we bundle, analyse, and analyse, the activities that Russia is now practicing on European territory? A few weeks ago, Theresa May gave a noteworthy speech in Parliament in London, where she spoke about the influence of fake news, the influence of Russian propaganda. We have reports in El Pais, Spain, which show how Russia has influenced the Catalonia conflict. We know that Russia has financed the Front National, thereby supporting far-right parties in Europe. I would find it exciting as a mandate for the Commission to present an overall record, where we have Russian influence everywhere. To solve the problem, we need to identify the problem. That is why we must be aware that we now have aggressive behaviour in Russia that is challenging Europe.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we are one year ahead of the next European elections, and we feel this is the right moment to address the President of the European Council, as someone presenting a leader’s agenda, and the President of the Commission, as someone presenting a road map for the European Union, in the following terms: we need, once and for all, to have a full match between our vision, our ambition and the means we deliver to meet this ambition. This is not happening yet and this European Council was, once again, clear evidence of this.  We should ask whether it is possible for Europe to become a leading continent in energy transition, in making the best of the digital revolution with full respect of privacy, and turning these into more and better jobs. Yes it is possible for Europe to be the leading continent, but is this being delivered to all regions and cities of Europe? No, this is not the case.  Then we should ask whether there is a lack of resources to meet this ambition. No, there is not a lack of resources: we need to go to the new sources of taxation. All the discussion on digital tax makes a lot of sense, and we do not understand why we are still hesitating about that. We need to move forward, because the sources are there.  The first test will be the level of ambition to be set for the next Multiannual Financial Framework, the Community budget, because of course we need to address the new needs of external action. Stronger means, including defence. But this should not be done by sacrificing the commitment with cohesion policy, which must remain strong in Europe.  But let me tell you that the bigger test will be about the eurozone, because once and for all – this is the heart of the problem in Europe now – we cannot have a eurozone where the possibilities to invest in the future are completely different. This is creating great inequality, so we need to provide not only a completed banking union – yes, we need to complete that – but we need to integrate the European Stability Mechanism into the Community framework. This is the moment to move in this direction. We need to provide the fiscal capacity to enable all members of the eurozone to invest in the future and create better jobs. If you do not address this problem, the ground is there for populist nationalist forces to go on growing all over Europe. So we need to go to the heart of the problem, to overcome the eurozone crisis once and for all, and to enable Europe to bring real European solutions for European citizens. We believe that now is the time to move – before the European elections.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, when the EU27 adopted the framework for a future relationship with the UK I’m sure there was a sigh of relief on both sides of the negotiating table, for now we can start, stop talking about the past, and focus on the future. You mentioned, Mr Tusk, how important free trade is. I have one request, and I speak also for the rapporteurs from the other two or three big political groups: we are concerned that while there is a focus on EU-Japan, which is absolutely correct, please do not demote the importance of the EU-Singapore agreement. We should have signed this in the last Parliament but we delayed it on the EU side, and we really owe it to the Singaporeans to get on with that trade agreement. Let us also focus on a trade agreement between the EU, the world’s largest trade bloc, and the UK, the world’s 5th or 6th largest economy. As Manfred himself has said, as we look at the global challenges there will be occasions when it is in both the EU’s and the UK’s interests to work together. As the Salisbury attack and the ensuing intervention has shown, let us also resolve to continue cooperating in those important areas of security and intelligence, because many of the challenges we face are not just European challenges but global challenges. My hope is that, as we look to the future, we will see both an outward-looking European Union and a truly global Britain.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all, I want to say to Donald Tusk, the President of the Council, that for the European Parliament, even now with the withdrawal agreement now, things are not over. We still need to have the citizens’ rights completed, because certainly after the Windrush scandal in Britain, we want to be sure that the same is not happening to our European citizens and that there will be no bureaucratic nightmare for them. So on 24 April next week we will organise a special session on these rights between the Home Office and five of our committees involved in this. And if there are changes needed, we will communicate to the negotiator, David Davis and to Michel Barnier what modifications are needed to avoid real problems for our EU citizens. My second point is on the coming Council. As Manfred Weber has said, there are three points needed on your agenda. First of all, a breakthrough in the migration package. Sorry, but the European Parliament has a position; we are ready to negotiate this migration package. It is absolutely needed. The proposals of the Commission are very clear. And so my request to you is: when is the Council going to have a position so that we can drastically reform the migration policy of the Union? This is absolutely needed. The second is breakthrough in eurozone reform; we also need this. The four presidents’ report, the five presidents’ report, the recommendations of Mario Draghi; when will the Council tackle this problem? It is almost nine years after the outbreak of the financial crisis, and we are still not capable of concluding on this. My third suggestion, Mr Tusk, would be that you put the cases of Hungary and Poland on the agenda of the Council. I have here the report of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) about the elections in Hungary. You have read it, I hope? It’s incredible – we can say that – that access to information as well as the freedoms of the media and association have been restricted in Hungary. They are saying there was intimidating xenophobic rhetoric during the election. There was media bias, there was opaque campaign financing. I think it’s time that you put this on the agenda of the European Council. Can you go forward – can we go forward – with the Member States with such a report of the OSCE after their elections? And the same is happening for Poland. My fear – and I hope that I am wrong – is that there will be only cosmetic changes, and secondary legislation in Poland, and that the main problem which is the independence of the Constitutional Court is still not solved. I hope it is time to act, Mr Tusk, and to put these three points on the agenda of the Council in June.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Yes, very briefly in response to what you said, Mr Weber: dear Presidents, it is good that you have made a clear statement here again about the European Monetary Fund. I have to say, however, that it is a sign of poverty when the stop sign is now set up from the country that benefits most from the euro from the Bundestag faction of the CDU/CSU. The requirement that this Monetary Fund, unlike what the Commission has put forward, can only come through a treaty amendment means nothing more than the need for referendums to postpone the whole for years. No, we will not get the European Monetary Fund like this — not in time. And that's why it's the task to clean up. However, with regard to the Council meeting, I would like to say the following: if you look at the conclusions, then it is also about the pillar of social rights, it is about poverty, about education. And it says that there remains a common commitment to implement these social rights in Europe. However, the monitoring of implementation should take place with due regard to competences. This means nothing more than: in the case of poverty, education, and many other issues, the Commission should be reluctful of looking to see if the relevant progress has now been made. What do we see at the same time? Throughout Europe, people are demonstrating with regard to the European treaties and often with the European flag in hand. Let us look to Hungary, Romania, Malta, where two corrupt ministers are still in the government. Look to Slovakia or Germany, where people are trying to enforce their right to clean air with regard to the European treaties. But Member States say: corruption, fundamental social rights, the rule of law — that is not the competence of the EU. But that is a breach of the fundamental European rights laid down in the Treaties. However, Article 7 is such a sharp sword that we cannot enforce it. I would therefore like to make a proposal to you, Mr Juncker, to respond to Member States' refusal to work on this issue. Specify a rule of law mechanism that regularly monitors right there. Let us ensure that you actually present the annual report on corruption that was once planned, and that does not sweep it under the carpet during the European Semester. Don't let the butter be taken off your bread, present sharp annual implementation reports on progress in the Pillar of Fundamental Social Rights! Last but not least, we are waiting — and Daphne Galizia would have earned this too — for your consideration of the shortcomings of the rule of law in Malta. We'll wait for them. So please, if the Council does not act, do it. The people on the roads in Europe expect this.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (EL) Mr President, the increasing disparities within the European Union, social and regional, are threatening both social cohesion and democracy itself. That is why, Mr Tusk, there is no room for permanent postponements by the Council. Citizens are calling for a strong social pillar, not wishful thinking, they are calling for an ambitious European budget with new own resources, capable of supporting social cohesion, growth and innovation. They are calling for a European Union as a leading player in the defence of democracy and human rights. The Council cannot close a blind eye to what is happening in Hungary or Poland and postpone it. Mr Juncker, the Orthodox Easter has passed and the two Greek officers have not been released, even though you and Mr Tusk have requested it, quite rightly so. Tomorrow the European Parliament will vote unanimously on a resolution calling on the Erdoğan leadership for the immediate release of the two Greek military officers guarding the Euro-Turkish border. We are asking you not just positive statements, but pressure, initiatives, measures, so that the two Greek military men who defend European policy and European borders in accordance with international law can return directly to their homeland, to the Greek army and to their families. It is not only Greece that is asking for this, the European Union is unanimously calling for it, Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker, and you must prove that by deeds and by escalating pressure.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, for Brexit voters this whole thing is a slow, endless agony. We didn’t vote for a transition deal, we voted to leave. Now, I’m not the least bit surprised by the intransigence of Mr Barnier and the EU’s negotiating team. They have got to defend their empire, which is coming under sustained assault from voters everywhere, in particular the recent wonderful results in Hungary. But in the face of all of this the British have blinked, and you get the impression that the Prime Minister doesn’t really believe in Brexit, she’s just carrying out the will of the people. I’m concerned that we’re headed for a really very bad deal from a British perspective. We’ve already conceded too much money, too much authority for the European Court of Justice and we’re betraying our fishing communities. And open-door immigration, the primary reason we voted Brexit, continues with no end in sight. We’re headed for Brexit in name only, so I’m pretty frustrated and I think 17.5 million people are too, but there is one bit of really good news. The George Soros-funded attempt, headed up by Tony Blair and others, to get the British to have a second referendum – you know, the old trick that was tried on Denmark and Ireland in the past – that has now run into the ground. There isn’t going to be a second referendum and we are going to leave on 29 March next year. The historic break is coming, and once we’re a sovereign country once again we will be able to unpick this mess. So there’s more good news than bad news.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. Against the background of the current Council discussion, I would like to highlight two points. The first is Syria, where I already feel unwell in me when large parts of the House applaud that it has taken place, and we all know that it has taken place against international law and even without a UN mandate. If this European Union claims to be based on a common set of values, these important basic principles should be followed accordingly. The same goes for Salisbury. It may be that the Russians are behind this, it may be that the Russians are not behind it. But here, too, a serious diplomatic measure is justified only if it really happens on the basis of undoubted evidence, and not if it is based only on mere suspicion. We hosted French President Emmanuel Macron here yesterday. With all due respect to the way he envores the European Union, as an Austrian representative, I would like to stress one thing here: this European Union is based on 28, soon 27 members, and it cannot be the case that a dominance of France and Germany sets the tone and the direction to which this European European Union will set the tone and direction unification project. I believe that there are 28 and 27 equal partners at the table — from Eastern Europe to Western Europe, from southern Europe to northern Europe. This is the spirit that could make a European unification project correspondingly strong, namely to have equal partners and not a dominance of a few adults and the small ones, who only have to understand what big ones are pretending.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Mr. President! The European Council's conclusions include job creation in the first place. It expects the free trade agreements to be concluded to create millions of new jobs. That's wrong! It is enough to look at the example of the North American Free Trade Agreement: trade between the US, Canada and Mexico has boosted, large US corporations have created supply chains across the region. Their global competitiveness improved, they became the winners, but job creation failed. In the world of global enterprises, this is not even an end. In order to create a large number of quality jobs, the local economy needs to be developed, focusing not on the raw interest of profit alone, but on increasing the welfare and security of local societies.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - Mr President! From the many conclusions of the last Council, I choose a positive and relevant thread in the era of Brexit, which is an unequivocal declaration of solidarity between the Member States with the UK after the Salisbury attack. This grim incident is a fragment of a larger whole. Whatever the Brexit, Europe as a whole must confront the challenge of Putin's neo-imperial Russia, which treats some NATO member countries and the European Union as a zone of its own influence and which has developed a whole new arsenal of hybrid warfare. Europe wasn't prepared to deal with it. Modern Russia does not offer its citizens prosperity, but it can offer a sense of regained powers and hence the route of this Russia it is Georgia, this is Donbas, this is Crimea, it is engagement in the most volcanic and unstable area of the world that is the Middle East, and this after side of the dictator, who also reaches for chemical weapons. And in terms of European policy, of course — weakening European cohesion, so we look forward to answering this challenge (we'll probably know it at the summit in June) from the European Commission.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Mr President, I will refer first to Salisbury: the Salisbury chemical attack brings many elements of great concern. It was not only the first use of chemical weapons on European soil since World War II, but it also showed that the perpetrators had no problem in exposing a high number of civilians to the deadly effects of Novichok. Let us be clear: not only the UK was targeted by the attack; the attack showed that we could all be targeted at any moment. This needed a strong response, and I welcome the united position of the Council. On the Western Balkans, finally let me say a few words on this event, which is of historical importance for the region. Yesterday, recommendations which were benedicted by the Council before for Albania and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia to open up the negotiations represent a well-deserved step forward and a clear signal for the whole Western Balkans region, which requires in the future additional efforts. We have always said that the Union includes all its components, and the Western Balkans is an intrinsic part of the Union. For that reason, I again welcome very much the wisdom and the wise decision of the Council. On Syria, I have only two points. First, I think it is important for the EU to cooperate through its security members to guarantee a political solution for Syria and the strategy for the post-war phase. Second – and it is very urgent on the UN Security decision – to rapidly establish an independent attribution mechanism to ensure accountability for the perpetrators of chemical attacks.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: – Mr President, let me take this opportunity to reflect on the speech of the French President of yesterday: he developed a vision of Europe, a vision of a centralised Europe, and it is exactly that vision which drove the United Kingdom out of the European Union.  I would suggest that the Council and the Commission change their policy and make an offer to Britain: an offer which enables Britain to get what they always wanted without Brexit. Let us stop this ridiculous situation where two trains are running on the same track against each other. Brexit is a lose-lose situation and a disaster for both Britain and the European Union.  So I expect you, Mr Juncker, and you, Mr Tusk, to have the courage and take the initiative and make an offer to Britain which enables the Remainers to stay and enables the Brexiteers to save face and stay in the Union by getting what they always wanted.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: — Yesterday, here in this room, I heard President E. Macron. I quote: 'The future of Europe is decided here in the European Parliament'. If so, Mr Tajani, please put an end to the hopelessly late and no longer emanating debate on the former March Summit. Replace the debate with the requirement for a new Summit meeting, which finally gives an answer to the questions of concern to everyone: Does military action no longer require a United Nations mandate? Are the military actions of the two members of the Community consistent with a single European defence policy? Is this a new European or global order?

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Mr President, in the UK, trade, the economy and jobs are booming. You are welcome to your high taxation policies. We can, and will, compete with you. You want the Socialists’ idea of a corporate tax hike and harmonisation, digital taxes, green taxes, and a financial transaction tax. Go ahead. It will be another nail in your coffin. No competition means low tax and growth and prosperity and, as you say, a non—Member State cannot have the same rights as a Member State. Excellent. We don’t want to be a vassal state in a protectionist trade racket that is moving to the abolition of the nation state.  On Syria and Russia your solidarity is fake. You know full well there is no conclusive proof of what happened in Salisbury and Douma. Just admit it: you actually hate and fear Russia.  On populism, I wonder how you think you can stop this. The people have votes. Do you want to curtail that right and freedom too? The voters are rejecting your policies across the EU and this Parliament will have a very different make—up in 2019. In here, most of you are dinosaurs, and you know what happened to them!

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, the deal reached in the March Council on Brexit represents an important staging post in delivering the referendum result. The transition offers some clarity to businesses and paves the way for key talks in future trade. But it is far from perfect, not least for British fishermen. We have made progress, but we are not past the point of no return for a no-deal scenario. Those who talk up a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland cannot rationally claim that the answer is a new vastly more problematic border between Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The DUP is clear: there will be no barriers within the United Kingdom’s internal market. The EU must move away from the notion of special treatment to smart solutions. An ambitious free-trade deal and customs partnerships can remove the vast majority of friction at every land and sea border between the UK and the EU.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, it’s opportune that I come straight after my good friend and colleague Ms Dodds. Indeed, I will reference Brexit, and I thank Donald Tusk for the very clear presentation here this morning about what is at stake – and that – as we both, I hope, desire – if there is not a solution to the Irish border question, there will be no withdrawal agreement and no transition. And that – Mr Farage, as you look me in the eye – is a very stark proposition.  I would invite those of you who have not been to the border region to join me someday and listen to the people on the ground, who are very anxious about this. No one in the European Union is talking up a hard border, and I certainly do not want to cross one when I travel to Donegal to visit my constituency. I hope, Ms Dodds, you will share that aspiration with me.  On the other hand, you have to understand that, when you want to be a third country, there are consequences for it. But, tragically, in the referendum you forgot about Northern Ireland. Europe has not forgotten and will not forget.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Council reaffirmed its commitment to an open multilateral trading system, but it should be thought of how to strengthen compliance with the commitments made by third countries. It serves, in essence, a more incisive trade policy. It is essential that we step up efforts to achieve the Single Market Strategy, Digital Single Market Strategy, the Action Plan and the creation of the Capital Markets Union and the Union of energy. The Commission should ensure full protection of the interests of the European Union and safeguard the right to respond to future US measures regarding tariffs on imports of steel and aluminum, measures that cannot be justified on national security grounds and are in fact an inadequate remedy to America's real overcapacity problems. There has also been talk of digital Europe. In this area, in the light of the Cambridge Analytica and Facebook scandal, the European Union must implement a strategy for social networks and digital platforms and impose transparent practices on them, that ensure the full protection of the privacy of citizens and the personal data thereof.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Dear Chairman, the European Union Summit and the countries of the so-called Western Balkans, to be held in Sofia in mid-May, should provide plenty of answers to questions about the path of non-integrated Southeast European countries towards membership in the Union. The main thing is that the goals set out are realistic and that geopolitical arguments this time be secondary to clear negotiating criteria. The fact is that most candidate and potential candidate countries are still nowhere near meeting the criteria and that, regardless of the mood towards further expansion within the Union, their path to membership will be long and challenging. The Union has enough of its problems to importing someone else's. Attitudes towards our neighbours should be constructive and supportive because we want them to progress, but without fundamental changes in these countries and successful resolution of open issues with the members of the Union, there must be no new enlargement.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: Mr President, first of all I want to convey a complaint, because it does not seem logical to me that in this Parliament, in a debate with the Presidents of the European Commission and of the Council, this should be so empty. There are not even 40 Members present and that is a disgrace to this House. Having said that, and this formal complaint has been made to the President, and I know you certainly think the same as I do, I want to express my concern, for the citizenship of my country, the situation of financial cuts and in this case to pass on all the movements that are in relation to pensions. We are talking about financial investments, we are talking about all these conditionalities of European funds, but we also need to talk about secret meetings of the International Monetary Fund with the Council to put more pressure on Spain to cut pensions more. Can Mr Tusk confirm this matter?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the condemnation by the European Council of Turkey for its illegal actions in the Aegean Sea, for preventing the Republic of Cyprus from exercising its sovereign rights and the exploitation of its natural resources, for the continued detention of the two Greek military personnel could determine to a significant extent further developments in relations with Turkey. I use the expression 'could' because, as has been shown, it has been decided to continue talks with Turkey. This is a high level of hypocrisy which offends the intelligence not only of Greeks, but also of all intelligent and prudent citizens of every state of the European Union. If the leading group of the European Union really wanted the problems with Turkey to be resolved, it would have to discontinue all contact with Turkey until it decides to release the two Greek soldiers and behave consistently and sincerely.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. My patience is almost tearing. We constantly see a huge contradiction between Macron's speech yesterday and the outcome of the Council today, between the Commission's objectives and the Council's objectives and decisions, between Parliament's decisions and developments in the Member States. We need a new dynamic in the Council to reach decisions that will make the European Union more effective and efficient. The contradiction between European objectives and European challenges and needs and results is blatant — thanks to the election results and the election campaign in Hungary, the election result and the election campaign in Italy, the events in Poland, the contradiction between our decisions in the migration package and the results, between the needs of the financial perspective and the declarations of the Member States, the need for a European Monetary Fund and your response to continue intergovernmentalism. I expect the Council to come back as a European legislator and will not see itself as a nationalist organisation within Europe. There must be an end to the umbilical examination. Measure your results after yesterday's declarations: strengthening European democracy, creating European sovereignty! Without these results, we will not receive an increased turnout on 26 May 2019.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: Mr President, Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker, unfortunately I cannot speak on other issues such as the economy or the banking union, but I will concentrate on Turkey. For several years we have been using the same policy towards Turkey, a policy called 'engaging policy' but in fact it is a pet policy. The results are well known and we all know, the occupation of Cyprus continues, Turkey threatens to intervene and has already intervened in the Eastern Mediterranean and is blocking the energy plans that serve the European Union, threatens Greece with war, intervened militarily with the invasion of Afrin and, especially within Turkey, the peoples are suffering and things are more than three times. In other cases, and you know what I mean, we imposed sanctions. Whenever we propose any policy other than petting, you reject it. You tell us what policy we have to pursue today in order to work. One final word: we have many politicians in the European Union, what we need are leaders, and for the difficult things, this will write you down in history.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker, the European Council of 22 and 23 March took important decisions: it condemned Turkey's aggression towards Greece, condemned Turkey's illegal action against the Republic of Cyprus, called for the release of the two of our military who are illegally detained in Turkish prisons. You, Mr Juncker, quite rightly, called for the release of the two Greek military troops by Easter. Of course, you can see that nothing changes, Turkey continues the violations in the Aegean Sea, Turkey threatens Greece with war, Turkey does not release our two soldiers. So what practical measures will you take? Sanctions must be imposed on Turkey, there must be a halt in negotiations, there must be a freeze on European funds, there must be an embargo on Turkish agricultural products imported into the European Union. Take similar measures to those you took against Russia, freeze the personal accounts of the Turkish leadership, freeze all activities. Yes, Mr. Juncker, that's what you have to do! You can't caress Turkey. Erdoğan doesn't understand words.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: Mr President, yesterday the President of the French Republic, Mr Macron, proposed to us the creation of European sovereignty and I cannot agree any more with this idea: we need European sovereignty in order to make better use of the positive effects of globalisation, combat negative ones, preserve and update the European social model, combat tax evasion and social dumping. But we also need this sovereignty for something else: in order to effectively safeguard fundamental, civil and political rights throughout the Union and to intervene when there are States that move away from these fundamental rights and the founding values of the Union; and also to intervene and help to find a political and political solution. democratic conflict to complex conflicts within the Union and which neither judges nor repression are going to solve. Mr Juncker, Mr Tusk, Mr Tajani: be courageous, exercise leadership; show us that you are at the forefront of a political Europe and help find a political solution in dialogue to the conflict between Catalonia and Spain.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: — Mr President, the European Council confirmed that the Union's response to the intensification of imperialist competitions, with trade wars with America, Russia and China, which result in military interventions, such as in Syria, to control energy and markets, with an immediate risk of danger generalization, is the deepening of European unification by intensification of exploitation, the militarization of the Union in alliance with its competitors, America and NATO, to encircle Russia. This also serves the Commission's rush to open accession negotiations with the Western Balkan countries Albania and Skopje, with a substantial agreement of the Syriza government, to continue its bargaining with Turkey. It is not a policy of popular prosperity, peace and security, as the Commission says. They are intensifying exploitation, sparking war rivalries with the people, as the history of the European Union and NATO in the Balkans shows, where they starred in bloody border changes. So no illusions, popular counterattack everywhere against the imperialist barbarity of the European Union and NATO!

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, firstly, as Brexit makes its way slowly to its inevitable deadline of 29 March 2019, I have to compliment all the major players who have taken Irish concerns on board. We have heard the phrase ‘we are all Irish’ on this one, and we appreciate that. But, as the deadline approaches, people in Ireland are becoming more and more concerned that the commitments given will actually be upheld when the final deadline arrives, especially in relation to a seamless border, the agricultural sector – which exports 50% of its products to the United Kingdom – and the haulage sector going from Rosslare to Fishguard, Fishguard to Dover, Dover to Calais. How are we going to maintain the present position so that there will not be major disruption? These are the practical implications of the United Kingdom leaving the European Union, and it will take goodwill and practicality from all sides to ensure that we can have a non-disruptive exit by the United Kingdom.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, President Tusk, President Juncker, I would like to refer to the conclusions that Mr Tusk very briefly told us. You're optimistic, Mr. President, and I'm glad. A leader must be optimistic, but you also have to look down. Do you think that we here, and especially the citizens of our country, our countries, are equally optimistic? We have one year away from the election to the European Parliament. Let us give people reason to believe in the European project. Everything you have said as topics discussed at the Council is very important, but if it is not based on social cohesion, on a better life, on citizens' security and without differences, not as one State President here said yesterday that yes, two countries must lead and the rest ... so, to obey. That is not the message we need to bring to our countries. Mr Macron's message was also heard in my country and other countries, not only in France and Germany. Mr President, I ask you, in the Council, talk, to come up with messages for which citizens will align themselves with this project of the European Union which is extremely important to us, for all of us.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, President Tusk, key debate in the European Parliament, Council conclusions and yet we have heard very low profile, routine speeches. Back to normal? Not at all. It is simply to avoid the thorny issues of each of the issues that have been dealt with. In Turkey: Greek prisoners, illegally held. In the Digital Agenda: how to get the giants to pay taxes on the net. In the social pact: how to unlock it by the Council. And, above all, in the tax pact: to achieve once corporate tax harmonization takes place. The most striking thing is the total absence of the migration issue, having passionately debated as we discussed yesterday the Global Compact, denied by President Trump and, within the European Union, by Member States of the European Union; as in Turkey, with the absence of legal avenues for a safe migration route and ignoring the demand of humanitarian visas.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: President of the European Commission. — Mr President. A few brief conclusions: as always, I have listened carefully to Mr Giegold, including what he said about rule of law review procedures. I very much agree with him and draw attention to the fact that when we presented the Western Balkans Strategy on 6 February this year, we announced that we will present an initiative in October to strengthen enforcement in the field of the rule of law. We will do the same, and I am glad that we already know Parliament's support. With regard to the rest of the Western Balkans strategy, I would like to say that I have no question — as President Macron said yesterday — that we must deepen the European Union and speed integration before further accession. I have in mind — this is not new — that we use the Treaty article, which states that the European Council can decide unanimously on the areas of competence of the European Union to be decided by qualified majority in the future. It won't be different. It is rightly stated in some German daily newspapers today that, in the way the European Union now works, it will not be able to continue to function if further accession occurs. In this respect, we are all called upon to ensure that all possible initiatives are taken on the basis of existing Treaty articles to make the European Union more assertive and more decisive. With regard to the Greek officers who were detained in Turkey, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, during the press conference in Varna after the summit with Turkey, in the presence of Mr Erdoğan, I drew attention to the fact that we did not accept this and expressed the wish that before the Orthodox Easter celebrations these two men who have no evil in the shield, be released. It is ridiculous to say that two Greek officers who have actually lost their way around the border are a threat to Turkey. This is ridiculously ridiculous, and I'm not gonna take it. As far as social Europe is concerned, the social pillar will be implemented slowly but surely. We are in the process of doing this. We have made this clear in the area of the Posting of Workers Directive, including with the help of the European Parliament. As far as Brexit is Concerned — answering a question by Mr Henkel — I would like to draw your attention to the fact that, in a previous debate in this House, President Tusk and myself were offering to Britain to review the decision Britain has taken. The answer from London was' нет ', as the British are saying.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Thank you, Mr President of the European Commission. As far as the Greek military is concerned, I agree with your position.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, just two remarks. First, the Commission is in dialogue with the Polish Government, as you know, and everybody is hoping – or at least I am hoping – for positive changes in Poland and in Polish legislation. This is why I do not foresee for now a discussion on this issue at the European Council in June. I trust the Commission here. I feel shocked but, for the first time, I must agree with Mr Farage. You are right, Mr Farage, Brexit will not bring any good to anyone. Mr Kamall said that free trade with Japan and Singapore is one of the priorities and that we should treat free trade with the UK – I mean our future free trade agreement with the UK – in the same way. The only problem is that we are strengthening and easing trade and other relations with Japan and Singapore, while Brexit is, by nature, by definition, about weakening and worsening trade and everything else. This is why I think it is difficult to compare these two different issues.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I would like to thank the President of the European Council for taking part in the debate. I also greet the President of the Court of Auditors, Klaus-Heiner Lehne, who has been our colleague for many years, and thank him for his presence here today. The discussion is closed. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. — We are one year away from the forthcoming European elections and we need, once and for all, a future project for the EU and the means to achieve it. Unfortunately, the European Council's lack of response to the challenges facing the Union is evident. In migration: how to ensure legal avenues for a safe migration route In the Eurozone: how to provide a fiscal capacity to invest in job creation In the Digital Agenda: how to get the giants to pay taxes on the net. In the social pact: how to unlock it by the Council. And above all, in the tax pact: how to achieve once corporate tax harmonization occurs. The next challenge will be the negotiation of the multiannual financial framework from 2020. Of course we need to meet the new needs of our External Action. But not through the sacrifice of the CAP and cohesion policy, which must be maintained as priority areas. If the European agenda does not abandon its state of paralysis, nationalist and populist forces will continue to gain ground. We therefore need a Union capable of providing European solutions to European citizens.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: in writing. — Point 5 of the conclusions of 22 March 2018 refers to social issues and mentions that it is a “common political commitment and responsibility of the EU and its Member States to achieve results in the European Pillar of Social Rights.” will be more prominent in the European Semester. However, the non-binding implementation remains intact! The European Pillar of Social Rights aims to achieve comprehensive reforms in terms of equal opportunities, access to the labour market, fair working conditions and social inclusion. Making real progress here would strengthen the fundamental foundation of a social Europe! I would like to ask the Commission to be more binding and not continue to make non-binding recommendations to the Member States. Only binding minimum social standards at a high level of protection can strengthen social cohesion in Europe!

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - The conclusions of the last EIT meeting reflect the important package of resolutions decided by the EU's main political body on important matters such as economic harmonisation, European semesters, digital Europe, relations with our Balkans and Turkish partners, salisbury i assassination, or 28th round of the joint Brexit strategy. While fully acknowledging the importance of the EIT's decisions, I would like to highlight the anomalies in communicating the European summits, the shortcomings of post-EIT information which will further remove our citizens from the EU. It is natural that the leaders commented on the decisions of the eIT in their own countries with slightly different stresses. However, it is unacceptable, and as a top body of the EU, it also undermines the authority of the European Council, so that the entire population of a Member State receives a liar, not even reflecting the agenda, information about the summit. I can say that 90 percent of the Hungarian population still knows about the March EIT, that there was only one issue (which is not actually on the agenda), illegal migration, where Prime Minister Orbán defended his people in a hard fight and defeated the EU's “forced resettlement” partners. This is it: through the government press monopoly, as part of Orbán's election campaign, Hungarians received this absurd picture of this important EIT meeting. I would therefore like to draw the attention of the President of the EIT that, as the example of Hungary highlighted, EU communication after the EIT urgently needs to be made more efficient, unified and more close to citizens.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: Madam President, I just wanted to say before we start the debate — because it has nothing to do with the debate itself — my protest at the time of this debate: it cannot be that the work of all Members for a whole year — not just the rapporteurs, who will be able to speak, but the alternate rapporteurs — is, with such effort, summarized, in the case of my group, in a single minute in the debate. I ask you — and I take advantage of the fact that the Secretary-General is here — that, of course, this will not be repeated; that the shadow rapporteurs, who have been working with all the hearings for a whole year, etc., have time at their disposal to be able to speak in this debate. I think they deserve it, that we deserve it, and that, of course, the European Union, in this exercise of control, also deserves it. Therefore, I ask you not to happen this situation again.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Thank you Ms Ayala Sender. We take note of your comments and indeed colleagues have worked really hard on these important reports. Let me continue, as we move into our debate, and welcome Mr Klaus—Heiner Lehne, President of the Court of Auditors. Commissioner Oettinger is also joining us.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, Mr Klaus-Heiner Lehne, President of the Court of Auditors, Commissioner Günther Oettinger, ladies and gentlemen. First of all, my sincere thanks to the Court of Auditors for the annual report on the implementation of the budget for 2016 and, of course, to the Directors-General of the Commission for their annual reports, which for us laid the basis for our parliamentary work. I also join my thanks to the staff of the Secretariats and our offices, as well as my heartfelt thanks to all shadow rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs for a wide range of consultations. Seven months of work is now behind us, and I can already anticipate the positive result: the Commission can be granted discharge for the implementation of the 2016 general budget. It is also positive that we have succeeded in reducing the estimated error rates, although in most cases in the area of shared management has not yet fully managed to achieve the self-chosen target of an error rate of two percent. However, even in very few cases more than five percent of the investigated processes were considered to be fraught with errors. However, it can also be noted that many errors could be fixed after corrections in the project and program execution. This should pay particular attention to whether the objectives that should be achieved with the use of the European budget have actually been achieved, because we owe this to the European taxpayer who feeds our budget with his contributions. Compliance remains important, but performance should become more important. In doing so, we must also highlight some of the weaknesses that have been identified in programming and execution. 2016 was the third year in the new funding period, but the implementation of programmes and the absorption of programmes and the absorption of With regard to cohesion policy funding, we were just beginning this year. In order to avoid further delays and avoid the risk of significant overpayments at the end of the funding period, the Commission and the Member States need to step up their efforts and speed up the implementation of the programme in order to effectively create this important instrument for creating growth and jobs in the regions. to be letting. In agricultural policy, new instruments such as greening and the programme for young farmers have far from achieving their objectives. Migration policy and the integration of migrants, as well as the protection of Europe's external borders, are new challenges that require a separate budget chapter. Until now, the funds for this have had to be removed from various other budget approaches. The increase in trust funds and a variety of financial instruments obscure transparency and impede parliamentary control of the implementation of the budget. Care must be taken here to ensure that Parliament is able to carry out its control tasks in full. The EU is the largest donor of development aid. In order to better assess the achievement of targets, however, we need more meaningful indicators than before. The EU Delegations' annual monitoring reports should also finally be publicly available. In 387 articles, Parliament has formulated its observations and proposals for the implementation of the 2016 budget. Most committees have delivered their opinions. On this basis, I hope that we can continue the discussion on this basis, including with regard to the new multiannual financial framework.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: rapporteur. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner Oettinger, Mr Lehne. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to express my sincere thanks both for the preparatory work carried out by the Court of Auditors and for the excellent cooperation with the shadow rapporteurs. I would also like to thank all the staff who have worked on this report. The European Development Fund is, as you all know, the Union's main financial instrument for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific countries, as well as the overseas territories. This cooperation is based on the Cotonou Agreement and the Overseas Association Decision. The main objective of the Cotonou Agreement is to combat poverty, in line with the means of sustainable development and the gradual integration of these countries into the global economy. The agreement will expire in February 2020. Negotiations on a new agreement will have to start by August this year at the latest. The Council is expected to adopt an enabling decision in the first half of 2018. All this against the backdrop of new global challenges that will change the way in which development cooperation funds are provided. All relevant stakeholders are already working on new support policies and a reorientation of the current framework for external assistance. This will also have an impact on the impact and activities of the European Development Fund. The report addresses these new challenges, both in the chapter entitled 'Reacting to the new world, world of development priorities' and in the chapter on the new ACP partnership, which provides, inter alia, that the EDF will be included in the general budget. The financial dimension of the European Development Fund is tall. The 11th European Development Fund alone has a portfolio of €30.5 billion for the period 2017-2020. For 2016, commitments for all the Union's trust funds amounted to €5 billion, €2.4 billion, or almost half of them, were allocated to the Trust Fund for Africa and the Bêkou Trust Fund, which is funded by the EDF is managed. Budget support payments were €644 million in 2016 and €914 million went to international organisations as part of the deeper cooperation. In the area of migration and development alone, 106 projects totalling EUR 1.5 billion were approved in 2016, EUR 594 million were contracted and EUR 175 million was paid out. Under the Statement of Assurance, the Court of Auditors noted a positive trend for 2016. The target for the expired contracts, namely the reduction, was only slightly exceeded at 15.15%. Similarly, the target of -25 was only marginal for all old open pre-financing. The old outstanding commitments were reduced by 36%. Overall, the error rate was 3.3%, which is a slight decrease. The residual error rate was 1.7%, which is below the major threshold of two percent. EUR 14.16 million of unjustified payments was recovered. The cost of control amounted to 4.26% of the total cost. Nevertheless, the Court of Auditors notes that some of the supervisory and control systems are still partly ineffective, and the report, too, is quite critical in its broad lines of funding and supervision, which is in the nature of the matter. Development aid is provided in a difficult and unstable geopolitical environment and is affected by problems such as weak government formation, corruption, social and economic instability, armed conflict or crisis. — which means, particularly in the field of budget support activities, that the risk of diverting resources remains high because of the risk of corruption and fraud, due to the risk of corruption and fraud, to mobilise more domestic revenues in developing countries to reduce dependency on development aid, and in particular: calls for enhanced cooperation with the European Union in the field of combating tax fraud and aggressive tax planning. In spite of all this, according to the Court of Auditors, the audit of the European Development Fund is reliable, as is the legality and regularity of transactions. A discharge of the Fund for the financial year 2016 is therefore foreseen and has already been approved by the CONT Committee.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I will talk on Parliament’s discharge. First of all, I wanted to thank all the shadows and the staff involved in the discharge. At the start, I wanted also to say that there have been improvements in the performance of Parliament’s own budget. There was a positive report from the Court of Auditors on Heading 5, and spending was not affected by material error. In terms of individual improvements in the budget, we’ve seen the driver service being brought in-house successfully, and we’ve had lots of comments about the improvements made there. We now have a road map for gender equality. The gym in Brussels has been reopened after a long closure. On harassment, the Secretary-General has agreed to set up a network of confidential counsellors which is welcome. An MEP portal has been established. There’s a new ICT project improving services for Members and local assistants. Work on improving security in and around Parliament has been undertaken and an environmental policy covering Parliament has been accepted by the Bureau. All good things, and all things we should welcome. However, there remain some concerns. There were lots of amendments submitted on Parliament’s voluntary pension fund. We’ve seen those amendments. Some of those amendments were realistic, some were not so realistic, and on this we are awaiting the Bureau’s response to the Secretary-General’s proposal. And on this difficult issue, I think we need to spend a little bit more time considering the options which are available to us. We are also aware that the Bureau set up a working group to talk about the issue of general expenditure allowance (GEA), an issue we talk about every single year in the discharge process and on this again we await the Bureau’s final proposal and an agreement. But as a minimum, the policy should include having separate accounts for the GEA whose seats should be kept, and unspent amounts of the GEA should be returned at the end of the Member’s mandate. We should insist that these are at least the minimum which should be required. We also still of the difficult issue of the single seat, although recently Parliament has voted to have a single seat, many, many times, and no doubt Parliament will continue to vote to have a single seat, and we await some action on that. In addition to that, we need a proper building strategy, particularly for the PHS building in Brussels. We understand it is not easy. It is a difficult issue and the matter of the building policy is made even more difficult by the issue of Brexit. On accredited assistants, there are some who missed out on EU pensions because they have not been employed for ten years. They feel particularly badly treated, and this issue deserves some attention. Also trainees who don’t get up but up-front mission payments is another issue. This seems particularly unfair to the lowest paid, and again, we need to see some action on this. Finally, we need to address the delays in pay and expenses to local assistants. Hopefully, all these issues will be addressed in the near future. I would say, perhaps, just in conclusion, that in the Committee on Budget Control we had a long debate on Parliament’s own discharge, and thanks to the Secretary-General for his input into it. We emerged from that debate with a widespread consensus. There was great cooperation amongst the groups, or most of the groups, and this was reflected in the big majority in the Committee to grant discharge for Parliament’s own budget. I hope later today we will again see a large majority to give Parliament’s budget discharge.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: rapporteur. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Court of Auditors. Above all, I would like to extend a very warm welcome to the Presidency of the Council, our former colleague, Monika Panayotova. We are pleased that you are here because we can not always count on your presence. But you, as the second arm of legislation, are of course very necessary to discuss the improvements that we want to achieve with you afterwards. We would really be delighted if we could make progress at one point in particular, namely the Council discharge. I am a little confused because I should have taken over Mr Valli's reports on the other seven institutions. I assume he is speaking about the reports themselves, so I can actually concentrate on the integrity report, on the resolution, which is also before us today with discharge. First of all, however, I would also like to thank the President. I do not know how long ago we were allowed to discuss the financial management of the EU here at prime time and in the morning. It's been forever. And that is why I have to say: it is a new experience that you can discuss here fresh and rested, and not only from 11.30 pm to 1.30 in the morning, as is usually the case. I see any nodding. So thank you for your preference. As chairman of the committee, I would like to compliment my fellow Members. Beyond party political ideas, we have always succeeded in finding factual agreements together. The resolution on the Commission's integrity policy has put this normally objective cooperation on a new basis and we are used to this. Nonetheless, we have so far succeeded in presenting something that already has a common breath. That is why the vote today is also very important. There are again, tabling amendments which are a no-go for my group, for example. I am talking here about Amendments Nos 1, 6, 7 and 13, which are policy votes for the Group of the European People of Europe. If these were adopted, then the Group of the European People's Party would vote against it, and I would then also withdraw my name from this resolution. I say this quite frankly because I believe that it is important for everyone involved to know this. I do not wish to use the extensive speaking time to continue commenting on the resolution. I would just like to warn against further tightening up a resolution that is already clear and which is actually to the limit. That's not necessary. We believe that everything is in it—in a friendly tone, without mentioning names, and those who are meant know perfectly well that they are meant. Therefore, it is not necessary to clarify clear things even more. It would only harm us all and would do nothing at all. I would particularly like to thank Mr Valli for his work, because his work will bear my name afterwards, which I find unfair. Usually it's always the other way around. I would like to tell you that I find it a pity that you are withdrawing your name because of one point, namely Brexit — an amendment has been adopted to regret Brexit — because I think you have worked well and you have done a really remarkable job. I would like to thank you very much for this. I would also like to thank the Court of Auditors for a point that is important in Mr Valli's report on the other institutions, namely the Court's special report. I believe that we have a real job here. And when I see that the Court of Justice does have astonishing shortcomings — and the best legal system is useless if it takes too long to get your right — then I believe that we have a common have a task. I would like to turn to the Council again. I believe that it is time to set up the Council Discharge Working Group, and I would like to sincerely ask you, as the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council, which can approach old conflicts with renewed vigour and vigor. We need to move forward on this issue. We cannot come up with the same procedure from year to year. We're ready to sort this out together. Be it too, please.

name: Marco VALLI
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Grässle for her words about my work and the work we have done. It is certainly a great job, where we highlight several critical points and also give many suggestions to other institutions to work at their best. I am sorry to have had to remove the name but, for political needs, I cannot accept that we regret the choice of citizens on a referendum that — as much as I myself may not agree on the outcome — was while always a popular vote and therefore we should never deplore the vote of citizens. As far as the report on the European External Action Service is concerned, I remain rapporteur and I would like to say that the Service embraces important and often urgent issues: but it must still be accompanied by excellent management of human and financial resources. The report revealed the issues relating to the management of delegations, especially in foreign and difficult areas, as well as the management of real estate and procurement procedures. Both points are critical and we must ensure that they do not affect the budget and the proper functioning of the institutions. On buildings, although some progress has been achieved in this field in recent years, there is still ample room for improvement, especially within the rental and purchase procedures for delegations. As for the budget of the latter, it has emerged that more than 40% of expenditure is related to real estate: the costs are still too high. We must therefore encourage solutions such as co-rentals to reduce expenditure and ensure that the procedures for buying buildings are transparent and lead to real cost optimization. It is also necessary to simplify the budget of delegations in order to improve their management and efficiency. At the same time you can reach a level of higher transparency and ensure that citizens are aware of the expenses incurred. Considering procurement, persistent weaknesses in procedures under EUR 60 000 were found in 2016 and shortcomings relating to internal control rules. The European External Action Service must therefore improve monitoring activities and must ensure that the procedures meet the fees required, even in difficult situations. Healthy practices are needed to avoid mistakes and irregularities. I remember that human resources must remain in the foreground: work must still be done to prevent harassment, to promote gender balance at all levels and to safeguard whistleblowers. Finally, economically support trainees and ensure that they have a finally meritocratic internship access procedure. I therefore strongly call for a transparent, rational and efficient budget. The reporting must be timely and precise, both for the expenses faced by the delegations and for the costs of the missions of the members of the Service. In this regard, within the merits of expenditure on the missions of the High Representative: beyond the issues of costs, which nevertheless remains an important point, the node was Parliament's request that costs of missions were published. So far only the costs of missions from the first two months of 2016 have been made public. Documentation on these missions must be easily accessible, according to the requests of Parliament itself; it is an act due to the citizens of the Union who must continue to have confidence in Institutions. I will now leave the floor to my colleagues for their considerations and thank the president again for taking my reports and for the kind words addressed to me.

name: Bart STAES
text: rapporteur. — (NL) Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Lehne, Mrs Panayotova, I am rapporteur for the agencies, for all agencies except one: the food safety agency EFSA, for which Indrek Tarand is the rapporteur. My work started in July last year after the Strasbourg session. I then travelled to Parma, to the Food Safety Agency, where at that time all the agencies, the Directors-Generals and their delegates met to coordinate their work. And right away, that is my first comment: there is a coordinating secretariat that coordinates the work of all the agencies. That needs the staff worthy of that name. Parliament is ready to grant one full-time equivalent to that coordinating secretariat. The Council refuses that. Mrs Panayotova, I would ask you to ask the Council to ensure that this single post is protected from that coordinating agency. I would like to emphasise very emphatically: the agencies are generally doing very good work. They are needed, and they are also very alert in the work they do. The resolutions deal with the influence of Brexit. For a number of agencies, this is quite essential, for example in the relocation of EMA, we heard that relocation to certain countries would be quite catastrophic. This applies to large agencies such as the Medicines Agency. But that also applies to smaller agencies, such as the agency dealing with Galileo. So that's a point of attention. In this context, there is also another focus, namely the whole system of salary coefficient, whereby wages are adjusted according to the location of an agency. For some agencies, this is a fairly urgent solution; for example, Frontex in Poland cannot implement serious personnel policy because of the low salary coefficient. So that's where the resolutions call attention for. I have, of course, focused on avoiding conflicts of interest in all agencies. Avoiding conflicts of interest is incredibly important. In most agencies, that is in the right direction. In any case, there are no excuses to invent, no excuses to publish, for example, the resumes of the members of the management board of agencies, to provide a comprehensive overview of the conflicts of interest that may be possible with staff or experts who are employed on a temporary basis in those agencies. That must therefore be kept under consideration. The anti-corruption policy is also very important in this respect. I have also paid attention to equality between men and women. We see that more and more women are going to work in the agencies too. Unfortunately, this is all too often in executive positions and not in management positions. You will read in each resolution what the situation is and which agencies really need to make an effort to get more women into management positions. Attention has also been paid to the well-being of the staff. Teambuilding activities, a policy against harassment, harassment that unfortunately still occur within certain work situations. So there are 32 critical resolutions ahead, and I recommend discharge for all agencies except one agency, EASO, the Asylum Agency. I do not want to say that the Asylum Agency does not do any important work or does not do a good job. I think that this agency works very well and that the staff, often in difficult circumstances, under time pressure in Italy and Greece, do so brilliantly. Let that be said. But let us also acknowledge that there is currently an OLAF investigation into the internal dynamics within EASO. As long as this OLAF investigation is ongoing, I believe that we cannot grant discharge, that we should postpone that discharge. We will see, once the OLAF investigation is over, which is expected by the end of the summer, the state of affairs then and then we may be able to grant discharge in October. I would like to say a few words about the Commission's discharge resolution. I thank Mr Ziller for his work. We have tabled a number of amendments to this in relation to problems of integrity. The fact that Commissioner Cañete is taking a voluntary pension from here, from the European Parliament, from the meeting between Mr Barroso and Mr Katainen, and finally Selmayr, is a separate resolution on this subject. I'm happy with the work we did there. We have tabled a limited number of amendments and I hope that we will all be able to reach a balanced choice, a balanced resolution on the Selmayr case.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I am rapporteur on the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) file only, and there is a delicate border between the report as such and the ongoing court case. My hope is that the agency will act in accordance with the Court’s decision, when it is made. Mr Url has promised me that he will do so, and I have no reason to doubt his word. I think that we will do fine with the EFSA discharge report. As a shadow rapporteur on Commission discharges, I would like to bring up two issues.
