First, we all know that that some Commissioners are getting pensions from the – soon to be insolvent, perhaps – voluntary pension fund. As a token of sympathy and an act of goodwill, I will not mention the names of the Commissioners. But I ask Commissioner Oettinger to ask his colleague whether he is aware of why Bismarck invented pensions. He invented pensions so that, after long decades of hard work, the person who has lost his ability to work will have the means to survive in his elderly days. Pensions are not meant to be paid out to people with the full ability to do an important job. Second – and I am not harsh because it is the EPP Group, if it was a Green Commissioner I would be twice as harsh – let me go to ALDE, and this brings me to the issue of special advisers. There is a huge number of special advisers – with the wrong gender balance: one woman to three and a half men – but the problem is that some of them are former Commissioners. They appear to be lobbyists, entering with their badges and working for private companies during their cooling-off period, ignoring the ethical code of the Commission. When I asked a question in 2015, the Commission failed to answer in time and, again, as a gesture of goodwill I did not pursue it. I appreciate that the Commission has made changes in this particular case, but the rule as such has not been changed. I call on the Commission to look very clearly into this matter so that citizens can understand what kind of advice a former Commissioner, now governor of a small village in Estonia, is giving to Vice-President Dombrovskis on eurozone economies. I mean, why does Mr Dombrovskis need that? It is suspicious. Having said that, on the positive side, I heard dear colleague Ms Ayala Sender complaining that there is too little speaking time. President Sassoli, if you could cut my second intervention by 50% I could donate my minute to Ms Ayala Sender and that would be good, I think, for the debate in plenary. If I can cut my speaking time by 50% I see no difficulty for the Commission to cut special advisers in the same way, by 50%. Send them home, we need them there. Having said that, I would like to thank all the rapporteurs, shadows and colleagues from the Budgetary Control Committee. It has been a real privilege to be in this enlightened bunch of Members. Thank you very much.

name: Brian HAYES
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, firstly, I want to thank all of my colleagues who have worked with me on the eight joint undertakings reports which we have looked at for 2016. This has been a collaborative piece of work between Members of the Committee on Budgetary Control, colleagues and, especially, the Court of Auditors for the annual joint undertakings that they produce and the excellent reports that have been produced by the Court of Auditors, which I want to recognise. I also recognise the work done by the Commission; Commissioner Oettinger and his team, in terms of this very important part of the annual budget. The discharge procedure is an important procedure. First and foremost, because it shines a light on public expenditure that we vote through in the seven-year multiannual framework expenditure. Shining a light not just on the expenditure itself, but shining a light on the outcome of that expenditure in the various joint undertakings, which do such an important task. Why is it important? First and foremost, it is important because we need more research and innovation across the European Union. It’s crucial for jobs, it’s crucial for growth and it’s crucial for Europe’s fightback after the crisis. So investing with industry in key areas is good for jobs and good for the economy. We are talking here looking back in 2016 and the reports that have been produced by the Court of expenditure of about EUR 1.8 billion in terms of collaboration with the private sector. That’s about 1.3% of the total budget. It is a crucial part of the public and private mix, so the public expenditure – the EUR 1.8 billion in expenditure in 2016 – unlocks much more private expenditure which can then be used in industry for the purposes of innovation and research. I think it is important, and I have said this at the committee on all of the hearings we have had, that we demonstrate to the public what we get for this money and how industry across all of the different facets of the European Union is making a difference. And that’s what is important in terms of the projects which we are looking at. I also think it is important, and this was a key part of the texts that we put through in all of the reports, that we highlight that SMEs especially should gain a portion of this in terms of their work with the joint undertakings. And that’s crucial for the supply chains and for industries right the way across the European Union. So, of the reports we have seven unqualified opinions and we have one qualified opinion. As I suggested at the committee, I am proposing discharge in all cases. This has been unanimously accepted by the committee. I think good progress has been shown this year in terms of improvements on internal controls; an improvement also on in-kind contributions. We are beginning to see some improvement on project completion and the timelines therein, ex ante controls have been improved and the error rate reduction, I think, has to be welcomed in all of the reports. The four joint undertakings we asked to come before our committee were: Shift2Rail, because it was the first year; Innovative Medicines, because of payment issues concerning their lag between where the average payments were across other joint undertakings. As for ECSEL the qualified opinion referred to the control systems, which have been highlighted by the Court, but I think good explanations have been given by the joint undertakings, so I am not suggesting in that case the discharge be not granted. And then the annual questions on Fusion for Energy, which are really around delays in the project. It is a very significant project that has been delayed up until 2035. There were also questions about the decommissioning of the site and the future costs of this, which have been flagged in previous reports. So, I am suggesting, with the support of the House, that we would grant discharge on all eight joint undertakings which have been assessed for expenditure in 2016.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it is a real pleasure for me to participate today in this important debate on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2016 in the context of the annual discharge procedure, as foreseen in Article 319 of the Treaty. The efficient use of EU funds in full respect of the principle of sound financial management is of utmost importance. The delivery of good results is particularly important. Indeed, it reassures citizens that every single euro spent on an action financed by the EU budget is spent properly and effectively. I would like to respond to the question of Ms Gräßle, I would like to confirm that the preparatory bodies have examined how we can progress on the EP proposal for a procedure of cooperation between our two institutions during the discharge procedure. The Council will soon adopt a mandate to start the discussions with the European Parliament. On 26 February, my colleague, Bulgarian Deputy Minister of Finance, Ms Petrova, has had the honour of presenting the Council recommendation to grant discharge to the Commission in front of the Committee on Budgetary Control. Tomorrow, I believe this plenary will confirm the vote of the committee and grant discharge to the Commission. I am glad to note that the European Parliament and the Council are able to agree on this important issue. The Council welcomes the fact that, for the first time since the Court started providing a statement of assurance, in 1994, the Court has given a qualified opinion on the legality and regularity of payments. Additionally, the Council welcomes the gradual reduction of the overall estimated level of error reported by the Court during the last years. Nevertheless, the Council regrets that the overall estimated level of error reported by the Council for 2016 payments at 3.1% is above the benchmark of 2%. The Council, therefore, reiterates its wish to see further improvements in the financial management systems and in the estimated level of error across all policy areas. One must recognise what has already been achieved and, in this context, the Council appreciates the efforts and actions taken by the Commission and the Member States. The Council notes with satisfaction that the market and direct support expenditure in heading 2 was not affected by material error in 2016. This positive result is particularly relevant as market and direct support represents three-quarters of the expenditure of the heading. But there is still work to be done. The Council calls upon both the Commission and the Member States to implement the Council’s recommendations. It also calls on Member States to continue cooperating with the Commission and to prioritise an increase in the quality, rather than quantity, of first-level checks in order to prevent, detect and correct errors. The Council also stresses the fact that controls are not without cost, taking into account the complexity of policies and programmes. Therefore, a balance has to be found between the risk of error and the cost of control and audit, focusing on better controls rather than more controls. The Council agrees with the Parliament that simplification of rules remains paramount in reducing the error rates. Simplification and improved guidance not only reduces the administrative burden on the beneficiaries and respective authorities, but also allows for efficient and less costly controls. We reached a political agreement on the revision of the Financial Regulation three weeks ago, and this revision should have a positive impact. I would like to emphasise that prevention is always better than correction. The Commission should apply preventive measures, such as interruption and suspension of payments, strictly in line with the relevant rules. The Council also reiterates the need to continue to apply financial corrections and recoveries rigorously, in line with the relevant rules, in order to protect the EU budget. In this context, the Council regrets that not all actors involved made full use of the available information to prevent, detect and correct a significant proportion of the errors. This could have substantially reduced the estimated level of error, bringing it closer to the materiality threshold across all chapters of expenditure. Mr President, honourable Members, let me now turn to budgetary and financial management, and the predictability of EU funding. The Council takes note that the gap between adopted and used payment appropriations increased in 2016. We acknowledge that the pressure on payments can be expected to increase in the coming years. Therefore, we call on the Commission to anticipate an orderly disbursement of payments in order to avoid any shortage of appropriations. The Council is concerned about the Court’s observation that the outstanding commitments are increasing. It calls on the Commission to continue monitoring this matter and to ensure an orderly balance between commitment and payment appropriations. The Council takes note of the Court’s observation on the increasing financial exposure of the EU budget, due to long-term liabilities, guarantees and legal obligations. The Council calls on the Commission to closely monitor their development and the associated financial risk. The Council calls on the Commission to improve the transparency, simplicity and accountability of all EU budgetary instruments. To conclude, let me recall that the pressure on the EU and national finances is still a reality in the current economic outlook. This will require, from all institutions and stakeholders, a more careful management of EU funds, as well as better forecasting of long-term funding requirements. Let us ensure that EU money is used to achieve results that could not be achieved as efficiently or effectively by other means. We have to send a clear signal to European citizens and taxpayers that European Union funds are used in a responsible and accountable manner.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: Member of the Commission. — Mr President, Minister, Mr Lehne, Mr Lazarou, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen. Mr President, I would like to begin by paying tribute to the varied and valuable work of all the rapporteurs. I believe that we can have an excellent illumination of European budgets through you and through joint control work, so that we can tell taxpayers: yes, we know what is going properly, where we can make improvements, what went or is going wrong. For me, the procedure for granting discharge for 2016 is, on the one hand, a review of the current budget implementation, but above all a guide for the next financial framework. We see your critical proposals first and foremost constructive advice on what can be done better in the next period 2021-2027. To this end, we will present our package on 2 May, and the implementing rules will follow in the weeks thereafter and will hopefully be a constructive basis for you — Parliament and the Council — to invest our citizens' resources even better, to avoid even more misinvestments. The Committee on Budgetary Control has consulted many of my colleagues — Commissioners managing and responsible for larger budget volumes. There were also written questions and we made every effort to answer everything constructively, openly and transparently. We're not happy, but we're happy. For the tenth consecutive year, we have received an unqualified opinion on the reliability of the European Union's accounts. The Court of Auditors found that the error rate for around half of the EU budget was below 2%, and for the first time there was a limited opinion on this and therefore. We have significant improvements in the area of management scored. The error rate decreased from 3.8% in 2015 to 3.1%. At the same time, we have to note that there are also less good assessments. We have significant delays in the implementation of our programmes for the period 2014-2020, and the discharge procedure may take too long. We do not yet have sufficient budgetary flexibility to respond properly with financial assistance to unexpected developments, events — migration, disasters. They are asking us to respond to this. I tell you that the Commission will deal with all your expectations and demands and will also report back to you in a few months' time on the measures we have proposed and taken. I believe that this will give us a chance to further optimise the European budget and the added value that this is to create and creates. At the moment, as I said, we are working on preparing the next budgetary framework for the next decade. Your current demands and the recommendations of the Court of Auditors will be fully taken into account. We are crucially concerned with added value. Every euro invested in Europe, every project, every programme, needs to demonstrate that there is added value. Otherwise, the European investment would be subordinate to national, regional or local investment. We will follow this in the next budgetary framework. We want to give you an even better and more transparent and informative report on our services. We will have to examine the role of N+2 in cohesion policy. And we want to make it much easier, from horizon to CAP to cohesion our rules are too complex, discouraged some citizens, some applicants, require too much time of too many who are busy with it when processing applications, accounting and monitoring. The issue of the agencies was also mentioned. Agencies take an outstanding Work true — decentralised in the spirit of the European project. We very much see that we also need to increase the proportion of women in management functions here. I'm recording this with this. We are concerned about the grade structure as well as in general. We have a grade framework that applies to Brussels, Luxembourg, Sofia and Athens. And we will then have appropriate corrective mechanisms to ensure that only two thirds of Brussels's salary is obtained in some parts of Europe. If someone is transferred from Brussels to Sofia, but bought an apartment here and has to pay it, he has a fixed cost. It's not just about the cost in Sofia, it's about his standard of living, which hardly changes. This has to do with our Staff Regulations. We take note of this. Perhaps we need to modernise and reform our staff statute in the foreseeable future. But I tell you, if some members of the Council then call for further staff reductions, then I am reluctant to open the box. Because Parliament is even more difficult than we are to make further staff reductions. We are now at the lower limit of what we need to perform the task. The issue of commitments and payments was mentioned. An open word on this too: the current budgetary framework was adopted too late. I am addressing Parliament and the Council here. We will present the budgetary framework on 2 May. My request is to take the next budgetary framework as our common priority from 3 May. Because we now have the sixth budgetary framework that we are going to present, and we have never had a European choice between presentation by the Commission and its entry into force. Either this Parliament is willing to discuss the budget for the next decade, and the Council and the Presidency of Bulgaria, Austria and Romania are ready to see this as a priority. Then we can have a adopt budgetary frameworks. I tell you quite frankly: I am grateful that Parliament's rapporteurs have declared this priority. I do not yet see the recognition of the budgetary framework as a priority from many Heads of State or Government, whom I adore. Some people think the later the better. And if we discuss the budgetary framework until 2020, we will repeat the same mistake as in 2013: to adopt too late. This means that we have lost time ahead of us again and again we will not get a stable development between commitments and payments. That is to say, Minister, my request would be — and your Prime Minister, Mr Borissov, is prepared to do so: please tell his colleagues: from 3 May, let us also see this as a priority in the European Council, including among our leaders. Then we can make the very criticism that has come out today, which rightly came, avoidable for the future. Our target must remain below 2%. But I am grateful that the error rate is no longer the only Bible, but that the focus is on success, performance evaluation, value added. In this sense, I believe that between the Court of Auditors, the Committee on Budgetary Control, Parliament and the Council and the Commission, an important and proper development for taxpayers has begun and needs to be developed further.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: Court of Auditors. — (DE) Mr President, honourable Members, Minister, Commissioner. Also on behalf of Mr Lazaros S. Lazarou, the Member of the Court responsible for the annual report, who is accompanying me today and is sitting behind me, I would like to begin by thanking the Committee on Budgetary Control, its chairman, Mrs Gräßle, and the various rapporteurs, in particular Mr Zeller, and to express my explicit Recognition for their commitment to successfully concluding this year's discharge procedure. Commissioner Oettinger has already mentioned that once again this year the Court gave an unqualified opinion on the reliability of the 2016 accounts. This is nothing new now. What is new is that, for the first time, the Court gave a limited opinion on the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the annual accounts for the financial year 2016. Claim-based payments have not been materially affected by errors. We expect an estimated error rate of 1.3%. However, refund-based payments still have an error rate above the materiality threshold of an estimated 4.8%. This limited opinion has certainly created a different and new dynamic that has contributed to the completion of this year's discharge procedure. However, it should again be noted that the estimated error rate could have been even lower if the Commission or other bodies, including the bodies responsible for the management of European funds in the Member States, had made proper use of the information available to: prevent, detect and correct errors prior to recognition of expenditure. This alone shows that there is still clear potential for further improvements. How do you know, in addition to its general annual report, the Court publishes specific annual reports on all EU agencies. I would just like to mention one agency, and this was also mentioned before the debate, namely the Asylum Support Office, for which the Court has not been able to give a positive opinion on the legality and regularity of the underlying payments this time. This is due in particular to the fact that there have been problems with this office and this agency in carrying out procurement procedures. I understand from the motion for a resolution that Parliament is likely to postpone discharge until the results of further investigations are available and that the matter is kept in mind. Mr President, Mr Staes has already announced this. The discharge procedure is about looking back. In many cases, however, your comments will have an impact on the future and, of course, the future Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). In this context, the Court has and will make a wide range of contributions to policy-makers on the basis of its audit findings, on the basis of its audit findings, on which they can rely in the course of their discussions. Over the past two months, we have adopted a first series of thematic papers on the future of European finance, the future of the common agricultural policy and research funding after 2020. We are also working on a thematic paper on simplifying the European structures of the investment funds in cohesion policy. We will continue to take up this issue in formal opinions on the Commission's legislative proposals on the next medium-term financial framework and on the main expenditure programmes. We believe it is essential to be able to gain insights from the previous generation of programs before deciding on the next generation of programs Program generation are waiting and getting hit. In this context, I would also like to point out that outstanding commitments are projected to reach EUR 262 billion by 2020. It is extremely important to deal with this issue in the next MFF, and I was pleased to note that all three bodies involved in legislation have expressed a positive opinion in this regard. With regard to the future annual reports, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to take this opportunity to stress that our next annual report will already take an approach that we are currently testing in our audit of cohesion expenditure. For the financial year 2017, we have begun to assess the reliability of the information provided by the Commission on the legality and regularity of cohesion expenditure. This is done by examining audit files and by carrying out on-the-spot checks carried out by the Commission and the Member State authorities. The objective is clear: to test systems and, as has already been said, to carry out fewer tests, but as a result. These work results will also be incorporated in our overall opinion on the legality and regularity of EU spending. We at the Court of Auditors attach great importance to this new approach because we believe that it provides an opportunity to better provide information to our stakeholders, as well as citizens, by creating more capacity for better auditing. Mr. Writer Zeller has just brought this to the central sentence: “Compliance remains important, but performance is becoming increasingly important.” And for this we also need free resources within the Court of Auditors. Finally, let me briefly refer to the institution of which I have the honour of being President, because the Court is, of course, also a member of the Court subject to the discharge procedure. The Court welcomes the support expressed by Parliament in its resolution on several points, in particular with regard to the Court's overall prudent and sound financial management, its organisational reform of 2016, its good cooperation with the Committee on Budgetary Control and the very important financial management of the Court. Follow-up also in the European Parliament's technical committees, its new rules on official vehicles and the Court's environmental policy. I am also pleased to report to you that we have recently stepped up our internal controls and revised the rules on household issues, missions and representation costs of the members of the Court in order to address identified shortcomings immediately and to increase transparency. In addition, our institution has decided to request a number of European and International Supreme Audit Institutions to subject the Court to another so-called peer review procedure. As of next year, colleagues will therefore examine how successful the Court has so far been in implementing its strategic objectives and will make recommendations on further actions to be taken. This is the third time in this century that the Court has taken up such a peer review and is open to external and independent review and advice from sister organisations with the same field of activity. Finally, we note that this House is aiming to complete the discharge procedure within the year following the accounting year in question. This would have the undeniable advantage — and the Commissioner has already mentioned this — of being able to draw direct lessons from one year for the next. We all know that this issue of timing involves a wide range of actors and deadlines. But as a courtyard, we are of course always ready to use our To do the utmost to ensure a timely discharge procedure, but without compromising the availability of data in the best possible quality.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Development. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to put an emphasis on the fact that in the light of the post—2020 Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), the Union budget should be a true European added—value budget aimed at common objectives promoting the sustainable economic and social development of the whole Union, of all States. Moreover, the discharge exercise constitutes an important task for the European Parliament, which must be implemented with the greatest political responsibility, having in mind and defending EU taxpayers and citizens’ interests.  As rapporteur for the Committee on Development’s opinion on the discharge for 2016, I would like to recall the Union’s collective commitment to raise the Union’s and the Member States’ official development assistance to 0.7% of gross national income. According to recent figures, EU assistance has increased for the fourth year in a row and attained its highest level to date. While welcoming this progress, efforts have to go much further in order to meet the pledge taken in 2005 and to achieve the sustainable development goals. I would like to conclude by making reference to the use of budget support. While supporting the latter, I share the opinion that the Commission should better define the development outcomes to be achieved in each case, and above all to enhance control mechanisms concerning recipient states’ conduct in the fields of corruption, respect for human rights, rule of law and democracy.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. — On behalf of the Committee on Culture, I would like to express moderate satisfaction. Moderate for the reason that we get satisfying effects in programs like Erasmus+. In a moment, within a dozen months we will have 4 million young people in Europe who become beneficiaries of this scheme. Perspective another has been guaranteed, so satisfaction here we have a big one. The second element: two key programmes for the Committee on Culture — Creative Europe and Europe for Citizens. Unfortunately, there is no such good sentiment here. I will emphasise that the beneficiaries in these programmes are at 11- 16% only, that is, as many as 80% of beneficiaries are leaving with a flourish, without getting help for their ideas, from the European institutions in short. I'll also point out one instrument that doesn't work properly: student loan guarantees. This instrument is insecure all the time, and I regret it. And the last thing that the Commissioner said is the differences between the payments due and those payments that are de facto possible to be realised on the basis of the funds. We've come out of this problem a year and a half, two years ago, back to it. I'm paying attention to that. And the last thing — the EFSI. In this project, very relevant from the point of view of investing, the culture is poorly represented. The whole cultural sector, the whole creative sector, which is a source of such satisfaction in Europe, needs to be more strongly present there.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. — (FR) Mr President, the Committee on Foreign Affairs has looked at both the Commission's budgetary discharge, focusing on foreign policy aspects and the European External Action Service. Also, I will briefly refer to both. As far as the Commission is concerned, there was a decrease in the level of material errors in foreign policy in 2016. I hope that in the future the level will fall below 2%. I encourage the Commission to implement the recommendations of the Court of Auditors, welcome the progress made in aligning civilian missions under the common security and defence policy with financial regulations, and I call for this work to continue at high speed. With regard to the European External Action Service, I am pleased to see that the administrative budget has been implemented without material error. In particular, I would like to draw attention to the importance of reducing as soon as possible the existing imbalance in human resources, especially for managerial posts, in three areas: gender, membership in a new or old Member State and, finally, the share of officials of the Union and those of the Member States.

name: Alain CADEC
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. — (FR) Mr President, the Committee on Fisheries, of which I chair, has wished to issue an opinion on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the Union by the Commission for the financial year 2016. I therefore present the conclusions of this report for your opinion. As far as fisheries is concerned, we can see the efforts made by the Commission to carry out its tasks. My report for opinion mentions a high implementation rate for both commitment appropriations and payment appropriations. However, I would like to insist that the Court of Auditors present, in its future reports, a separate error rate for fisheries and maritime affairs. We will then be able to assess correctly how the Commission manages this area. I would also like to stress the very low utilization rate of the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund by the Member States. We must solve this problem as soon as possible. The discussions around the establishment of the new Fund will, I hope, be an opportunity to find a solution.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. — Mr President, Commissioner. Fortunately, the level of error in agriculture has declined again for the most part and has even been below the materiality threshold in many areas. Traditionally, the error rate in rural development, including in the area of the second pillar, is, of course, much higher than in the case of direct payments. This is, of course, due to the fact that direct payments are much easier to execute — here we have an error rate of 1.7%. However, even in the very complex rural development, error rates have steadily declined in recent years from 6% in 2014 to 5.3% in 2015 and finally 4.9% in 2016. This means that simplification is also about focusing not only on the first pillar, direct payments, but also on the second pillar, which is much more error-prone. We welcome the fact that the error rates of the Commission and the Council are close to each other and hope that in the next few years, especially with the new common agricultural policy, we will be able to develop an area that is important for the development of the European Union, but which, however, as we have heard, will still be able to develop in some areas is prone to errors.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. — (FR) Mr President, as rapporteur of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I would like to welcome the work of the tripartite agencies Eurofound, EU-OSHA and Cedefop. These agencies are valuable tools for European policy-making, and we have seen this in our work. They have a special feature which I would like to stress: they are managed tripartite, that is, they allow the active participation of the States but also of the social partners, namely employers' representatives and trade union representatives. In our various opinions, my colleagues and I agree that it is essential to preserve the tripartite nature of these agencies. Finally, I would like to acknowledge the essential nature of the work of these agencies, but to do so we must give them the means. In recent times, these agencies have had to reduce their staff: they have done so with responsibility, but we can no longer continue on this path if we want them to continue to provide us with quality work. I thank my fellow shadow rapporteurs for the work they have helped me accomplish.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. — (GR) Mr President, in line with the conclusions of the European Court of Auditors, the final annual accounts of all the agencies of the European Union in the field of justice and home affairs provide an accurate picture of their financial situation and the related acts are legal for 2016 year. However, in particular the European Asylum Office and the European Border Guard Agency have faced problems of absorption of financial resources and difficulties in complying with financial rules. Both organisations were faced with difficult administrative and operational challenges due to the migration crisis. They therefore did not have the necessary time to adapt and properly staffed. It is necessary to strengthen and staffing these key organisations with appropriate staff so that they can fully fulfil their tasks, contributing to the protection of both human rights and European borders.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as we know the Union budget is the essential instrument for achieving the objectives of the policies that we set out to achieve, but above all serves to improve the lives of citizens and fill gaps in social policies. In particular, with regard to the Transport Agency and the Connecting Europe Mechanism, the largest financing instrument for trans-European transport networks, I would like to emphasise its importance. Many have been the projects funded, but many efforts are still to be done if we want a united Europe. I am convinced that unity also moves from the physical unity of the European territory and infrastructure. In order to achieve the strategic objectives, therefore, I hope that funding mechanisms will be less complex in future and easier access for citizens who want to follow developments. Finally, I would again regret the lack of a budget line dedicated to tourism.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. — Mr President, Commissioner, President of the European Court of Auditors, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, I would like to point out that, as the Court of Auditors' report states, the estimated error rate for expenditure under the heading 'Economic, social and territorial cohesion' decreased from 5.2% in 2015 to 4.8% in 2016, demonstrating the positive impact of the corrective action taken by both the Commission and the Member States. At the same time, we note that this rate is higher than the average error rate and call on the Commission to continue working with Member States to improve their national management and control systems and to continue to use available legal surveillance tools and prevention to ensure that existing errors are corrected from its infancy. The REGI Commission expresses concern about delays in the implementation of the programmes for the current period and at the same time calls on the Commission to review, within the framework of the “Output Budget “, the effectiveness of the indicators used, which will improve efficiency.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. — (GR) Mr President, the basic function of a Parliament is to adopt the budget and to adopt the report - an important activity. Today we are debating 53 agencies discharge reports worth almost EUR 140 billion and we are discussing them all in a fast track meeting and we are going to a vote for one and a half hours with a fast track procedure. I think that we underestimate the very functions of the European Parliament. We need to give much more time to scrutinise every agency for which we grant or do not grant discharge, just as we do not give discharge to the Council for the activities in which it is carrying out. Secondly, I would just like to refer to ENISA, that is to say the Network and Information Security Agency, and to say that the life and state of this Agency is now a sinner. I will also refer later to the explanation of vote for why I will vote against, because in essence he has transferred all his activity from Heraklion, Crete to Athens, having created additional administrative expenditure. This situation cannot continue, and I am constantly denouncing it in this Chamber. We must finally pay attention to the functioning of ENISA and it must be checked for the way it works, we must look at that. His headquarters were in Heraklion but he has moved all the staff to Athens and now he complains because there were so few left in Heraklion, because he wants to take them all from Heraklion, Crete and bring them to Athens. Is this a serious operation?

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. — (DE) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I had the task of reviewing the Maritime Safety Agency, EMSA. EMSA is responsible not only for maritime safety, but also for the prevention of pollution and, for example, for maritime surveillance with remotely controlled aviation systems. That's all good for her. In addition, it has now been given the task of working with the European Coast Guard and contributing to our migration policy and to managing refugee flows. It will have additional jobs there, and she has already prepared to cooperate well with Frontex and also with the Fisheries Agency. I have to say that everything is actually very fine with EMSA. In the Fraud Prevention Strategy, it has also included not only the adoption of the strategy, but also an offer to provide ethical training for employees. It has also developed its own follow-up tool on the recommendation of the internal audit. So it's all good. We noted in the Committee on Transport that EMSA has done very well. The overwhelming majority of 40 votes — only two were against it — agreed that we should approve the discharge.

name: Markus FERBER
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. — (DE) Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Court of Auditors. I was allowed to carry out the audit through the European Railway Agency and the Shift2Rail Joint Undertaking. Both are competitive, secure and fit for the future. That is also the task they have to perform. For this to succeed, both organizations must operate effectively and efficiently, and proper use of funds is key. I can certify that both Shift2Rail and ERA have been properly and lawfully managed. Still a few brief remarks. At the Railway Agency, we still have a costly double standard. The Court has rightly criticised this. We are also criticising this, and we want this to be resolved at last. Secondly, of course, the Fourth Railway Package gives ERA new operational tasks, and it should take this into account in its job development. At Shift2Rail, our aim is to strengthen synergies with European railway companies during the start-up phase in which we find ourselves and to continue to play the coordinating role in the future. But we can grant discharge for both agencies.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, firstly I want to thank Commissioner Oettinger for his total commitment, and equally I want to thank Dean Lazarou and the ECA for their invaluable input into this procedure.  The discharge procedure is a powerful tool, but only when used properly and timely. Controls and checks can guide EU policies towards a more effective, efficient and economic direction, but we need decent tools and appropriate timelines to achieve this. Too often, the remarks we receive from the auditors are already old news by the time we get our hands on them, and too often we are discussing matters that are already gone, and taking positions on issues that are no more. There is a definite need for an accelerated procedure. The discharge has to be streamlined towards n+1, and we need all stakeholders involved in this. I think that the good example of the private sector should be followed, and earlier deadlines set for the publication of the relevant documents.  We will need interinstitutional cooperation to make this happen. We need to get the Council, the Commission, the Court of Auditors, EU agencies and other stakeholders, including this House, together to discuss appropriate solutions and make a change that counts. I am very, very glad that President Lehne, in his remarks, underlined this point as well.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President, I would like to welcome Mr Oettinger and Mr Lehne and Mr Lazarou from the Court of Auditors, in particular, as well as Minister Panayotova from the Council. This is, of course, a full debate. My group, I must say that it is in favour of the discharge of the European budget for 2016 in the framework of two new ones: a good and a bad one. The good thing: that, for the first time in more than 20 years — in almost a quarter of a century, I have to say — the Court of Auditors, which analyzes and audits all the accounts of all the bodies implementing the European budget, has recognised — with an unfavourable statement of assurance — the daily and hard improvement work of an administration in order to obtain the highest added value from each euro from the budget entrusted to it by its citizens. It is a recognition of the thousands of European officials and employees in every corner of the globe and also in Brussels, Luxembourg and Strasbourg. For them and for that success recognised by the Court of Auditors, we will vote in favour. The bad news is that, because of the awkward and unfortunate management of a restructuring of directors-general and the surprise replacement of a Secretary-General with the head of staff of the Commission President, today's role is the need to change obsolete or even non-existent rules with a better approach institutional or interinstitutional cooperation with Parliament and finally revise the appointment made in the light of the new rules. On the other hand, just to say that we regret not being able to give the Council discharge — we hope that both with the Bulgarian Presidency and with the next one we will be able to reach the right path again — and we will also not be able to give discharge to the EASO Agency, which we are very much needed, and with which we certainly intend to work so that we can do so before end of the year.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Commissioner! Mr President of the Court! Madam Minister! Two issues are worth highlighting. First of all, what is still unresolved is what hangs over our Parliament — this is a discharge issue for the Council, the European Council. The Council's lack of participation in this process — I am glad that you are a Minister — may change, although I have been in our Parliament for a long time and I know that the lack of co-operation on the part of the Council is something permanent, something very ungood. This is such a procedure — the Commissioner will confirm this — we are also evaluating the European Commission, evaluating the Court of Auditors. And these institutions are working with us. There is no reason for the Council to consistently refuse this cooperation, and this is about some transparency and some democracy, and accountability to voters, to people who are taxpayers in the European Union. Parliament as the only institution elected in democratic elections has the power to control the Council, we must do so and we will do so.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: for the ALDE Group. — Mr President, I thank the rapporteur and CONT colleagues for continuing a new way of viewing the discharge process. Even as rapporteur of the main report on the discharge of the European Commission for 2014, I then sought to see discharge as a meaningful part of the life cycle of dealing with means of European citizens. That is why I am pleased that the focus on performance and error prevention forms an increasing part of the report. On the one hand, the control mechanisms need to work, which is to ensure the efficient, efficient and economical drawdown of the Union budget. On the other hand, it is desirable that we focus on the future, learn from mistakes, share examples of good practice and focus in particular on specific outcomes and projects with high added values that increase the standard of living of EU citizens. Both the Union budget and European policy have a common objective — to ensure results that cannot be achieved individually but only as part of a larger whole. Each Member country is beneficiary of benefits, wherever the funds from the European budget are used.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to point out one issue which was already mentioned by the rapporteur for the European Parliament’s discharge, my colleague Derek Vaughan, and that is general expenditure allowances (GEA). After long years of efforts now we are closer than ever to introduce a minimally acceptable scheme for the transparency of GEA expenditure. In fact, we would need much more than is in the report, but this is the very basis of transparency for GEA. The three elements we have: the separate bank account, keeping the invoices and reimbursement at the end of the mandate. Unfortunately, there are amendments in Parliament to destroy this very minimal proposal. We speak a lot about the emergence of populism in the EU and a lack of trust towards the EU institutions, but to improve the situation we have to make those institutions much more accountable and transparent. And we in the European Parliament, we have the credit to call other institutions to become more transparent if we do the same. If you start with us and if we lead by example. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the procedure of the “blue card”. — With regard to the general reimbursement of costs, it is possible that you will now voluntarily put this on the Internet and publish the supporting documents. I have actually looked at all the Members' homepages, and none of the Members here in this House has presented all the documents in chronological order in a proper accounting. I wonder why don't you do it voluntarily? Why do you want to dictate that to the others? I believe that a flat rate is a fair regulation, because with a flat rate, such as a kilometre allowance, you do not have to specify everything in detail. I want to have these flat-rates so that the honourable Member has his right to organise expenditure as he finds it right, and not to criticise officials here in the House because we have done one or the other in this area. That is why I ask you: do you personally have all your receipts available to the public, and can any citizen check with you which receipts you enjoyed with taxpayer money?

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: blue-card answer. – I have a very short answer to that. I can help you to find each and every invoice of the GEA expenditure on my home page. I do it myself. I lead by example. What we in the European Parliament are asking is not exactly to see individual invoices, I think that is a voluntary exercise. What is proposed in the discharge report, and what I am arguing for, is much less, but this is the basis of transparency. I think that this is the minimum we should set up to gain trust and credibility from the people.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (NL) Thank you, Mr President, and I would also like to thank Mrs Gräßle for the chairmanship of the Committee on Budgetary Control, where we work together, and I agree with her. At the same time, I do criticise what she said about the amendments I tabled on behalf of my group, among others, on the Commission's integrity policy. That is the political appreciation that belongs here in the plenary, and that is the way we agreed on it. So that can't come as a surprise. I will say nothing more about the Commission's integrity policy, but I will say about Parliament's policy of integrity. I am now looking in the direction of Klaus Welle, the Secretary-General. He makes good proposals on general office expenditure, the remuneration of EUR 4 000 per month, about the deficits that threaten the voluntary pension fund, but nobody sees them. We don't know what's in it. Because those are pieces that go to the Bureau of this house, that's secret. There are pieces of working groups of members of this house, which are classified. Why don't we make that public? Why are we not transparent about that ourselves? That is what we are asking the Commission to do. And there are misunderstandings, too. According to Klaus Welle, it is possible for me to put all the appointments I have with lobbyists on my web page of the European Parliament and then I go to the automation department and they say, “No, you cannot do that.” So there are misunderstandings, and that is why I would like to join College Jávor: let us also be transparent ourselves, then we will have the matter completed quickly.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: Mr President! In order to monitor Parliament's budget, I would first like to thank the rapporteur for his very good cooperation. We have been able to clarify many points, some of the others we will certainly take part for discussion in the next discharge. For information, the European Parliament costs each individual European EUR 6 euros a year, and this Parliament budget is there to support the work of MEPs. Finally, we take decisions concerning 510 million Europeans and we have to be extremely careful with taxpayers' money. I would like to take the debate on the single seat of the European Parliament as an example. One of the biggest problems of the house is that we actually have two houses. A second seat may be a tradition that has become dear, but we should no longer afford it. In particular, I would like to say to my French colleagues: if he costs the taxpayer a three-digit million amount, you have to be able to talk about this travelling circus. Thrift must not only be preached, but we in particular must live austerity.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Mr President, I have a puzzle for Commissioner Oettinger. For several months, my office has been engaged with the European Court of Auditors (ECA) on the application of an error rate correction to the accounts of the general budget of the European Commission. My concern revolves around the impact this correction has on the audit. What I have established is this: prior to the ECA audit, the Commission and the Member States carry out audits. Those audits result in corrections where errors are found. In carrying out its own audits, the ECA establishes a gross error rate. Occasionally they come across the Commission’s Member State audit from which they establish the error rate correction. But here is the problem: The activities within the audited sample are reflective of what has happened across the entire budget. Thus, the gross error rate found in those samples can be extended to the entire budget. However, we know the corrections took place only in the samples audited by the Commission and Member States, so we know also that the correction rate cannot be thus extended. Has the ECA been issuing erroneous results, the true picture distorted by these corrections? Until this correction question is resolved, I cannot, and will not, vote in favour of discharge. Can you explain why this is happening, Commissioner?

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: Mr President! Why I am speaking for a second time, namely now as Member of Parliament Karin Kadenbach, is firstly to thank the Court of Auditors and all the Members involved for this discharge and for the discussion. What I would like to emphasise is that we have today talked about how much money we are spending here at European level. What we may have less emphasised is what we have achieved with this in the interests of Europeans and, above all, how much more it would have cost us in many areas if we had not spent money. I believe that the cost of non-action and non-investment is kept going down in the general discussions. I am primarily a health and environmental policy, and it is precisely in those areas that it is the money that we invest that will help not only to prevent human suffering, but also to ensure that we, as the European market, are also competitive, so that our children and children's children can experience a development that will help them Europe makes it livable. This means that a lot of money was spent here, well spent, and we needed more to achieve even more.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with the amendments tabled to the report on the single European sky we intend to highlight some issues, which have also recently emerged as a result of choices which, although adopted at national level, they are rooted in the failure to achieve a real European airspace. For example, in Italy, we have witnessed the decision to bring together the air control centres in Brindisi and Padua, resulting in negative effects on the territories in terms of industrial and labour inductions, especially for regions that, like Puglia, already suffer from delays in development. The Commission itself states that the combinations of control centres could be premature and that in some cases smaller centres are less expensive than larger centres. It is clear that, in the absence of a real completion of the single European sky, in which all the intended components are implemented, discrasies and diseconomies are created which sometimes lead to the adoption of choices reckless. By way of explanation, factors that adversely affect are the failure to implement the FAB and the airline's choice of routes with greater miles traveled, in contrast to the objective of the reduction of air pollution. That is why we need — and we intend to prepare — meetings and comparisons to discuss and address these issues. I hope that all institutional actors will be open to dialogue and work to find solutions that protect the territories and especially the rights of workers and consumers.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: President of the European Court of Auditors. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Minister. I may just want to say something very briefly about a few speeches. Mr Funzulică and Mrs Kappel raised the issue of errorability in development aid. We are observing this, of course. But we know, of course, that certain areas of development aid are particularly susceptible to errors precisely because of the complexity of development aid. Mrs De Monte has called for less complex rules. This has gone through the whole debate. I keep hearing, while dealing with the EIB, that I am told by the EIB that interested parties often prefer EFSI loans to normal payments from European grants because EFSI loans are less bureaucratic and easier to obtain. That doesn't make sense, of course. We need to bring this to a common, equal qualitative level so that they can also be used in a targeted and meaningful manner. This is something that is supported by the court. Mrs Kadenbach pointed out that there has been noticeable progress in the error rate, particularly in the area of agricultural policy. This is very true, and this is very gratifying. I would just like to draw attention to one thing, including in the agricultural sector: an improvement in the error rate does not necessarily mean an improvement in performance, that is, in terms of efficiency. This does not necessarily correlate with each other. These are two different areas that need to be considered independently of each other and which we also consider. Mr Chrysogonos addressed the issues affecting the area of home affairs and justice. We have, of course, changed the structures of the competences of the Chambers in our House so that the third Chamber has a new focus of work, namely the whole Home and Justice — Home Affairs and Justice — and will also set new priorities in this area in the work programmes of the coming years. Mr Sarvamaa referred to the streamlined improvement of the relief procedure. I said a lot about that earlier. I believe that this makes sense and that we should definitely tackle this. We are open to finding the appropriate ways of interinstitutional cooperation to speed up and improve this so that we can ideally come to the N+1 solution, as Mr Sarvamaa said. Mrs Ayala Sender and Mrs Dlabajová mentioned the success of the fact that we have delivered a qualified opinion for the first time. I want to say this again, and I did this when presenting the annual report: this is a joint success. We all achieved that together. And if we know where we are coming from, what was the situation ten or twenty years ago and what progress has been made — we are still not where we want to go, but we have taken tremendous steps forward, and that is to the cooperation of Parliament, the Court of Auditors, but also the Council and, of course, above all thanks to the Commission. We just have to move on the way.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: Member of the Commission. — Mr President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen. The majority of your valuable speeches related to recommendations or findings. There were also a few questions on your part. We will take up the findings and recommendations and will take them seriously into account in our further work. There have been several requests for the agencies. Agencies are doing a valuable job, but if there are any abergations somewhere, we have a certain problem of supervision. Who is really responsible for agencies? Agencies perform tasks on the basis of European legislation and are located somewhere between Parliament, the Council and the Commission. There is no full service responsibility. That is why I have my reservations about strengthening agencies as desired. Or we can bring about full responsibility. Whether Parliament wants to take care of them? This is not really your core task when it comes to the legislative and executive. Or the Commission will do it if Parliament and the Council want that. A fundamental debate on agencies of the future with increasing responsibility, more staff and more financial resources therefore seems to me to be appropriate. Secondly, the pension of a colleague in the Commission — perhaps several — I do not know — was mentioned. I can say to myself that I am getting a fair salary as a Member of the Commission and no pension at all at the moment, either from previous parliamentary activities or as a former regional head of government. But salary and pension — the Commission is responsible for zero. These are the rules of Parliament and the Council. We are doing a lot and some wrong, but for pensions that Commissioners may actively take in the current office — these are your Council rules and rules. Please put what belongs to us in our mailbox, no less and not more. We are very much in favour of speeding up the procedure — Mrs Gräßle and others have called for this. Last year, we completed and presented our work one month earlier than usual for many years. We should work together to see whether we are working together on the legal bases for faster monitoring and a discharge procedure. After all, the sooner debates take place today, recommendations are on the table, the sooner they can be incorporated into active, up-to-date financial management. In fact, we should be discussing 2017 today, April 2018, not 2016, so we want to shorten the process and we are ready to do so — indicated by all the institutions involved. I would be happy to come back to this on the right occasion. Thank you very much for this very, very pleasant and factual debate.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to respond and to make some comments on what has been said as remarks and messages from your side.  On the question by Mr Czarnecki – he is not in the plenary but maybe he will see my comments afterwards – I would like to focus your attention on two main points. Firstly, we all share the principles of responsibility, transparency and accountability. So the Council is, in principle, providing the EP with all the recommendations, according to the Treaty, because, as we all know, the Parliament, on the recommendation of the Council, gives discharge to the Commission. In relation to the 2016 budget discharge procedure, I have to underline that the Court of Auditors did not identify any problems concerning the Council. Secondly, I would like to reiterate what I have already said on the request of the Chair of the Committee on Budgetary Control, Ms Gräßle. The Council will soon adopt a mandate to start discussions with the Parliament on the procedure of cooperation between the Council and the Parliament on the discharge procedure. Concerning the remark made by Mr Staes relating to the staff of the coordinating secretariat for the European agencies, I took careful note of this. Regarding the call of Commissioner Oettinger on the message to accelerate the work on the future agreement for the post—2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, I have to say – and assure you – that, as the presidency, we will advance the work as much as possible during our term. The presidency will start work on the proposal as soon as it is presented by the Commission. Of course, the possibility of an early agreement very much depends on the proposal itself and we will do our best to achieve as much as possible, with the close cooperation of the European Commission. To conclude, I would like to say that this debate has shown that we share many concerns. I can agree that an unqualified audit opinion of the Court for the management of EU funds remains an ultimate goal and that further improvements are still necessary. Allow me also to repeat that all financial actors need to fully assume their responsibilities in this respect. The European Union budget is an important tool for achieving the policy objectives that we have agreed upon. We need results, notably in terms of growth, jobs and investment, stronger entrepreneurship and a more competitive Europe. In a situation where resources are scarce we cannot afford to misuse one single euro. Let us, through this debate, also send a clear message to the European citizens and taxpayers that the quality of EU spending is improving and that the European Union budget is on track in delivering concrete and expected results.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Mr President of the Court of Auditors, Minister, Commissioner Oettinger, Mr Lazaros S. Lazarou. Thank you for your contributions! This is the third time in a row that I have been able to work on the discharge report of the budget for the Commission, for the second time as parliamentary rapporteur. It was a demanding task, but also a fulfilling task. The only thing that has bothered me, and this has been mentioned several times here, is the length of our working procedures until we really come to the presentation of the report. That is why I am grateful to the fact that both Klaus-Heiner Lehne as President of the Court of Auditors and the Commissioner for Budgets, Günther Oettinger, have endorsed the fact that we should be able to streamline this in order to be able to discharge a financial year as soon as possible, thus making it even better and more effective. to be able to incorporate findings into the day-to-day budget implementation. At this point, however, I would like to refer in particular to the report on the Court of Auditors' special reports before me. The special reports have increasingly become a very valuable source of our work so far. They should be given much more attention in the technical committees, as they provide the data and detailed information on the implementation of European programmes and projects, thus making a significant contribution to transparency in the implementation of the budget. According to the discharge report is before the discharge report. So we should now take advantage of the findings of the 2016 discharge report, incorporate them into our work and start work on the 2017 budget relief quickly.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner, President of the Court of Auditors, Minister Panayotova. I would like to thank you for your interesting speeches and also for the speeches made by colleagues. Of course — as has already been said — these contributions will help us to move forward with their valuable inputs, especially for the next budget, and in my connection, namely with the discharge for the European Development Fund, I would like to thank Mr Funzulică. Indeed, it has drawn up the opinion of the Committee on Development on the discharge report of the Development Fund. As you said, Minister: Transparency and accountability are the basic conditions for democratic control, and it is precisely in the area of the Development Fund that the basic conditions for coherence of the Union's development policy with the objectives of the other actors, namely the Member States, international governments, are the basic conditions for the coherence of the Union's development policy. Organisations and multilateral development banks, etc. The low error rate for the Development Fund shows that the trend is positive. We had an error rate of 3.3% and a residual error rate of 1.7%. This is below the materiality threshold and is heading in the right direction. But the error rate alone is not enough, we learned that today. We also need added value and good performance. To this end, it will be necessary to mobilise the private sector more, particularly in the area of development policy, to introduce blending in cooperation with international organisations, with a focus on additionality. Yes — development policy is not easy. You said it, Mr President, special conditions apply. These are often unstable environments and difficult political realities. We will continue to work nonetheless, and I would therefore ask you colleagues to accept discharge for the Development Fund tomorrow.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank the staff of the CONT Committee, the Group staff and my own staff for working on the Parliament’s discharge report with me.  On the individual issues which have been raised, I wanted to mention just two again: one is the voluntary pension fund, and one is the GEA transparency issue. Both of these are difficult issues, and both issues, I believe, require further work in the future if we are to get a final solution to these problems. But for the time being, I would hope that colleagues will support the wording on these issues in the discharge report. These words have been chosen very carefully to try and reach a compromise amongst all the different views we have in Parliament. I hope colleagues will accept this wording as a good compromise, for the time being, until we get a solution in the future. Finally, Mr President, I think we should mention the level of scrutiny given to the Parliament’s own budget and, indeed, the scrutiny given to the whole EU budget. Probably much more scrutiny is given to our budget than to Member States’ budgets. That is right, of course – we should scrutinise our own budget, but also I think it is worth mentioning the hard work we put in to making sure our own budget is scrutinised. We should say that, perhaps, a little bit more often. Having scrutinised our own budget, I think we can say that our colleagues should grant discharge when we vote on it later today.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: rapporteur. — Mr President. I would like to follow what Mr Vaughan said. So Parliament certainly has the biggest burden to bear for the discharge procedure. Mr Secretary-General, you always answer more than 200 questions reliably with a relatively manageable budget. This means that no one in the EU is as well controlled as Parliament. I would also like to share this with the Council as a quality mark of our work. That is why I would like to give the Council a homework — and I believe that you are almost overloaded with a homework when you look at the many tasks and also the problems in the Council — namely to move forward with the discharge debate within the Council. You have to do this with this Parliament, so I can only follow up on the words of Commissioner Oettinger: you do not know if you will be able to do it with the next one. If you don't do it to us, it may never come back. I would then like to give three homework to the Commission and recall this: namely the assessment of the previous multiannual programmes — this assessment is still missing, and this is of course very important to draw conclusions — then the reduction of the deadline — I will invite you further — and of course the budgeting of EDF. Not only do we want to relieve the burden, but we also want to have a say in what is being done in development aid. I myself take three homework with me, which is also the reduction of time limit and then, of course, the Council discharge and the round table on the Staff Regulations. The invitation from you, Commissioner, has come. There's another wave going through the house to prevent us from doing anything here. There's an amazing break in the process. I have to say that if the Committee on Budgetary Control has something to blame, it is that we have not long called for this question — how do we occupy top positions in all the institutions. That we do it is also connected to the fact that we are deliberately prevented from doing so. This prevention is not a good idea. That's why we're doing this.

name: Marco VALLI
text: rapporteur. — (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to conclude by thanking my colleagues again for their work on discharge to the other institutions. We have included a number of recommendations on the expenditure of the other institutions, so it is vital that these take note of what I and my colleagues have asked, and change action is carried out. real. On this issue, another important institution, the Committee of the Regions, which carries out an address function which can give much added value to the differences we have within the European Union, must However, adapt to the recommendations made by this Parliament in past reports on the case of the whistleblower, the former auditor who complained of irregularities, which must still be recognized as a bona fide whistleblower. On this there will be an amendment, which I ask for the support of my fellow Members, to conclude this case and we will then be happy not to include it again, because the Committee of the Regions will finally have complied with Parliament's demands.

name: Bart STAES
text: rapporteur. — (NL) Mr President, first of all I would like to comment on Mr Oettinger's offer to have a greater debate on the role and position of the agencies in the Parliament-Commission Council triangle. Sure, I think that's what we should do. Two, I support Mrs Gräßle where she says that the debate with the Council needs to be strengthened. Mrs Panoyotova, we have submitted a non-paper to the Council asking: is this a document to be discussed, is it part of an opportunity to find a solution and to obtain a discharge from the Council worthy of that name? So I ask you to put this on the agenda quickly within the Council so that we can start those negotiations. Thirdly, to Mr Zeller, I have to say that I am very pleased with the report he has presented. There is genamed and shamed, bad things are also indicated, for example that scheme for young farmers. That's not working. Good things are being said, for example, the European Youth Fund, very good thing. Finally, I must emphasise that where things go well with European funds, we must continue to talk about it. We're pro-European. We must show that Europe really matters.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, first of all I must apologise for my former speech, where I referred to my own parliamentary question to the Commission and made it happen in ‘1915’. It does not do any honour to a Member of the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) when his error rate is one century! Of course I meant ‘2015’. But I agree with the Commissioner and others who have said that assessing the error rates is not enough, and we should be able to evaluate the achievement and value added in European spending. So perhaps we should also, in particularly close cooperation between the Commission and this Parliament, start to analyse the opportunity costs.  Let me give you an example: if we were to spend one billion of the Connecting Europe Facility’s money not on the best, but on the second best, of available options, we would miss that very same billion on the right option, not to mention correcting the mistakes cost. I am referring to Rail Baltica. I am convinced that Members of Parliament could be helpful for the Commission to guarantee that kind of process. Again, thanks for enabling me to be part of this important process.

name: Brian HAYES
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I want to thank you and all the colleagues who contributed in this debate this morning, Commissioner Oettinger and his team, and the Court of Auditors and the Council. I think there are three issues, as I try to conclude the eight joint undertakings.  The first is a simple message to each of the joint undertakings within our remit: that citizens want to see results – the results of things that change in medicine, in the environment, in transport and airline policy, often innovations where citizens are not aware that the expenditure for those innovations has actually come from the European Union. We need to brand that: we need to explain to people that it was European taxpayers who have helped those innovations.  My second remark is that the joint undertakings must also explain their results within the industry. Frequently, we have industry fighting against another part of the industry – that’s understandable in the context of any kind of industrial setting, but there needs to be an explanation of what people are getting for that.  Thirdly, often when it comes to joint undertakings the expenditure profile is over a number of financial frameworks. So it is really important to take up the message that the Commissioner gave to this House and the challenge he gave to this House today between the Parliament and Council: that we need to come to an early view on the future framework. It would be wrong to go into this constant World War III that exists over a year and a half on the next Multiannual Financial Framework. We need to show, as Europe, that we can agree something, stick to our position and make sure that that expenditure is robust and strong to deliver the results we want to see. If we do that, I think there will be a good outcome. I do hope that the eight discharges which I proposed in my reports will be accepted by this House today, because I think it will send a very strong signal to the European Union and to industry that we can make results that ordinary people can see and understand.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I would like to thank the Minister, Commissioner, President Lehne, all the rapporteurs and those who spoke for taking part in this important and challenging debate. The discussion is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate at 12.00. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. — The European Aviation Safety Agency is responsible for ensuring safety and environmental protection in the field of air transport in Europe. It is designed to develop the European Union's single aviation market, to develop technical aviation rules and to promote European and international safety standards. An important point is that the Agency has the task of guaranteeing a maximum level of aviation safety throughout Europe, and that is precisely why the entry into force of the European Drone Regulation needs to be accelerated, especially in the context of civil aviation develops rapidly. An additional reason to allocate sufficient financial, material and human resources is to carry out regulatory and executive tasks in the fields of safety and environmental protection. I welcome the report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Aviation Safety Agency for the financial year 2016, as well as the conclusions of the Court of Auditors, as they comply with the regulations and laws in force, is showing transparency through the 18 ex-post controls in 2016 and the overall legality and regularity of all verified transactions were found.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I would like to say in advance in order to avoid discussions that we have some queries about individual language versions, in particular paragraph 20. You can be sure that the services will make careful efforts to produce adequate language versions in each language.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: —... of this vote. It is impossible to keep up with what the Lord says. The translators do not keep up before the Lord says “for”, the translator still says “against” or vice versa. It's impossible to keep up with it. It cannot be that the outcome of the vote is decided by case. I don't understand German, so I listen to this translation.
