It's not gymnastics classes and a reflex game, we're just passing serious laws here. I understand you're in a hurry for dinner. For a few minutes I stood here, I wave to the Lord, the Lord can't see me, I think you look only at one side of the hall all the time. After which the Lord states the results of this vote.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: — I'm trying to do this as conscientiously and as quickly as possible. (Applause) And I also try to keep an eye on you. However, if you wish to report on a point of order, it would be good if you would also display this acoustically.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: – Mr President, yes, I have an oral amendment. It is basically adding one word to paragraph 38, Amendment one. The text now reads: ‘listing membership to any other organisations, allowing for internal independent scrutiny;’. It refers to the agencies. My oral amendment is to add the word ‘professional’, for clarity of the text. Therefore, the final text should read: ‘listing membership to any other professional organisations, allowing for internal independent scrutiny;’. So we add the word ‘professional’.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: Mr President! Mr Staes' work seems so popular that I propose that we vote on all his reports in one vote.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Bütikofer! Mr Corbett and I have been trying to change the Rules of Procedure for over a year, and it is precisely on this point, to make this possible, that we encountered granite in the Committee on Budgetary Control. So please contact the relevant colleagues.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Mr President, since you were kind enough to mention the Committee on Budgetary Control, I want to return the favour and say that we are dealing with these 53 separate reports faster than we would be dealing with five reports under the chairmanship of a slower vice-president.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you for the flowers, Mr Sarvamaa.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: That closes the voting time.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Mr President, for all of the rhetoric at the Commonwealth summit this week, global Britain remains little more than a pipe dream, while global Europe is already a tangible reality. Our commonwealth partners are prioritising deals with the EU, while Brexit creates uncertainty in our relationships. In ratifying this treaty today with Australia, the EU is broadening its reach down under. Today’s vote is about boosting bilateral cooperation on terrorism and serious crime, the environment and climate change, research and development; vital questions for our societies, and this is just the start. Trade negotiations with Australia are getting going. Whether we in the UK want to remain a significant player with strong relations with our Commonwealth partners together with our nearest neighbours the EU, will be seen after March 2019. It’s in our hands and we shouldn’t think of throwing away tangible relationships for a pipe dream that is coming down the line.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, I think it is telling to find my Labour colleagues using their positions in this Chamber to attack the links we have with our close Commonwealth allies and to spread what I am afraid to tell you, colleagues, is a completely bogus idea – that we might change our minds. The decision has been taken. But if a consequence of the UK’s renewed focus on forging closer trade relations with Australia is that the remaining EU27 do the same thing, that is very good news for everybody. The United Kingdom wants to have wealthy and successful neighbours. The best outcome for us is that the remaining EU should have free trade agreements with friends and allies on every continent. If it had been more willing to take that approach over the 40 years of our membership, I suspect we would not have got to where we are now.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: — Mr President, I will not continue this rather intra-political exchange of views, which is primarily about the UK and Brexit. I can only express my pleasure at the fact that the treaty base between the EU and Australia is deepening after a period of stagnation, which lasted not months, but perhaps years, that finally started here negotiate a free trade agreement and that there are other agreements like this agreement that just contribute to the EU finally realising how important Australia's partner in the Pacific is. I can only express hope that this will continue.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr President! I would like to point out that I support the European Parliament's consent to the conclusion of an agreement between the European Union and Australia. It seems natural to me, but I wanted to emphasize the importance of this matter — because we live in very uncertain times. For the first time in history, the United States is causing its policy that we feel uncertainty about their leadership when it comes to democratic governance in the world. China's strength is growing, Russia is re-entering a policy path that is demolishing the world's order, which is why the European Union should and must conclude further agreements with the countries — with important states — in the world. Australia belongs to such states — also, among other things, because not only of its strength and weight, but also its geographical location. I'm glad we support this consent.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, I am pleased to support this report. Labour backs measures to cut the amount of plastic that ends up in our seas. In the UK alone, around 15 million bottles are discarded every day. That is 800 during this one minute in which I am speaking. Last week, I had the pleasure of visiting the Bewiched Cafe in my constituency. It is part of the new ‘Refill Peterborough’ scheme, promoting cafés, shops and businesses that allow people to fill up their water bottle with drinking water for free. People using the Refill app collect points each time they refill their bottles until they win a stainless steel water bottle like this – much better than a plastic one. Plastic bottles make up a third of all plastic pollution in our seas, harming penguins, whales and fish. So well done to everybody who is showing true bottle in sorting this out.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: “In last night's debate, the final had a very interesting one: there were two extreme views. The first — to apply the relief tariff against certain countries, give them time to implement the timetable differently than that would be due to the goals achieved. I second — not to make any exceptions. I want to stress clearly that I supported this report with the following belief: the open and one view, and the other view should be taken as extreme and rejected. There are areas in waste management that bear no differences in the implementation of the schedule. And there may be some that have to take into account the various starting point of individual states. You have to appreciate their efforts, you have to appreciate progress and point out that in some areas — I emphasize some areas — especially where we have very delicate matter, these schedules need to be differentiated. However, there can be no common denominator either for the first post or for the second. It would be unfair on the one hand and, on the other hand, inefficient.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: – Mr President, I supported this report on increasing the targets for recycling of packaging materials to 65% by 2025 and 70% by 2030. I am particularly conscious of the need to encourage more and to develop more recycling facilities for plastic and to develop products that are recyclable, and I think in this debate there needs to be a producer responsibility as well as a consumer responsibility. I welcomed previously the Commission’s plastic strategy, which states that is to work with producers to develop products that can be recycled, because lots of plastics cannot be recycled.  Consumers also can and are doing their bit in terms of not using plastic coffee cups: two million a week are disposed of in my own country of Ireland, as these products cannot be recycled; and indeed the once-off plastic bottle-recycling, making sure that we don’t use products that are throw-away, so we need to encourage and move away from a throwaway society in this area.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: — Mr President, I sometimes feel that we are imposing fairly unrealistic objectives in this house or in general in the European institutions. I would very much like us to impose realistic targets in waste management. The initial proposal, which was approved here a year ago, in my opinion, was not realistic, and I consider this draft compromise that we approved today and which I supported to be definitely more realistic. I think it is important that we really build a circular (circulatory) economy and that we do not confuse our waste flows in one direction, for example, and that is dumping in landfills or combustion. We need to motivate municipalities, but also ordinary consumers, producers to hold them accountable, and I think that this compromise may have succeeded. I would be very happy to address the plastic problem after China's turnover, because that is probably our greatest pain, we should be able to consult plastic at home ourselves and not export it.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr President! In the report, we are primarily dealing with reporting issues — simplifying this system, adapting reporting rules to other waste directives. This is all meant to increase the efficiency of controls. This is very important, but I am voting to draw attention to other issues that are not in this report but related to it, and therefore, above all, the development of a circular economy — and, as part of this, the increased entitlements of consumers. I am referring to ideas such as the right to repair and the fight against the proceder, which we call colloquially artificial aging of products. All this causes us to increase the number, the amount of waste, and then we need to be addressed, not just reporting, not just control.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the state of health of our planet shows that the disposable model has caused no longer sustainable costs and damage. We have long insisted on the urgency of achieving a radical change ranging from the design of products to their realization, from the use to their recycling, from the elimination of programmed obsolescence to recovery of raw materials. Circular economy is also a key in the field of waste, so as to significantly reduce its production, lengthening the life cycle of things and reducing the amount of waste they owe be conferred in landfill. We appreciated the effort made to set more ambitious objectives to keep materials in circulation for as long as possible, including through the fight against waste, the use of byproducts and new business models that provide already starting systems of extended manufacturer responsibility and targets for reuse and recycling of municipal waste. But we would have preferred to read about the banning of uneconomic and environmentally impacting incineration. Yes, because our territories, such as in Apulia, Calabria, Sicily, Campania, Massafra, Modugno, continue to suffer the chosen choices of a policy more sensitive to the interests of companies that to the protection of the environment and health and which allows the construction of new incinerators and alleged new oxidecombustion plants. For this reason, however, our vote was in favour.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: - Mr President! Today we have finally clubbed the package on the circular economy. It is a kind of framework for increasing sustainability, covering reuse, recycling and repairs of products. My focus has been mainly on my heart issue that I've been pushing for 10 years: the food win. I have been working for the first time to have a new definition of food winnings and a common method for measuring the reduction. In line with UN sustainability targets, the EU is aiming to halve its food win by 2030 compared to 2014. Member States are encouraged to exchange best practice and will develop specific programmes with incentives to reduce food gain. I've also pushed for simplifying the rules of business so we're giving no-show food to charity. In Sweden thrown in cut every fourth food box that we carry home. It is economically, ethically and environmentally unacceptable. I am pleased that my proposal for Member States to work to raise awareness of the difference between best-before date and last consumption date was taken on board. We need to change our lifestyle and attitude to the food. Time to go from... (The Speaker took away from the speaker the word.)

name: Rupert MATTHEWS
text: – Mr President, it has been a very interesting debate. I have listened to what everyone has to say. The reason I was pleased to vote for this measure is largely because it gives a clearer definition of some of the concepts we are dealing with, with waste processing and recycling. I’m hoping that that is going to lead to more recycling – I’m hoping that within a few years as much as 55% of our waste will in fact be recycled. It’s going to help improve the circular economy, and that is going to lead to less landfill and better all round. We need better definitions – it helps everyone involved in this to do their job more properly.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Mr. President! Everyone knows that my country, Hungary and Poland are being prosecuted under Article 7 for alleged serious violations of the rule of law. What is the rule of law? The rule of law, which means that decisions must be made according to predictable rules, clear to everyone, visible and equally valid for all. Now, what is a violation of the rule of law and the opposite of the rule of law, the rule of law, the rule of law, arbitrary, can best be studied on the functioning of the European Union. For example, if George Soros or other lobbyists negotiate with the leadership of the Union behind a closed door is a serious violation of the rules of the rule of law. It is also what we discussed the other day: if Mr Barroso, who was the High Commissioner, now works for Goldman Sachs and comes back to lobbying, that is also a violation of the rule of law. What we discussed today and voted today is that Mr Juncker appoints his fellow as Secretary-General of the Commission by violating and circumventing all the rules, this is also a violation of the rule of law... ( The President withdrew the floor).

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: — Mr President, first of all, let's be clear that there was no witch hunt here in the vote. It was a valid criticism of the way the European Commission was proceeding before Mr Selmayr's appointment, during Mr Selmayr's appointment and after Mr Selmayr's appointment. And the Commission may be right 100 times about formal compliance with procedures, but it has failed fatally in terms of, say, artistic impression or image and damaged its own reputation. It created the impression that it was a pre-prepared action by Mr Juncker's notes to preserve his heritage in some way when he was no longer head of the European Commission. It questioned other similar appointments going forward and created serious suspicion of politicising the European Commission's official apparatus, which should be neutral. So with this vote it's not ending, we're going to go back to it, I'm going to go back to it. I am in opposition to this Commission, I did not vote for it, and I can only say that the Commission has made a nice start to us before the elections for the EP next year.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Mr President, we have seen President Juncker appointed his Head of Cabinet Selmayr in a political post, Secretary-General of the European Commission. That's how it goes among European Christian Democrats, handing out mail. Today, at twenty past twelve, we in the European Parliament voted on a very clear resolution on this subject with very sharp language. What's in that resolution? That this looks like a coup d'état. The Commission is asked to review this and other candidates should be given the opportunity to apply in a transparent procedure as well. Barely half an hour later, at noon fifty, the European Commission's response is already in. And what is that reaction? We will completely ignore Parliament's resolution. This is absolutely embarrassing. This is shameful and then it is astonished that the support for the European Union is being undermined. Mr Selmayr should return his appointment immediately. As far as I am concerned, Mr Juncker can leave immediately.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, when it comes to the issue of mass migration and the European Union, positions are quite clear. On the one side, there is my country, Hungary, with the Visegrad countries representing clearly the majority of European citizens. The majority of European citizens do not want migration. They want to protect Europe; they want to protect their own countries, their own villages and towns.  The important thing is that they should speak up much more loudly. I understand, because I lived in communism. I know how it is: that there is oppression, there is fear, one can lose his or her job, there are hate speech laws, and so on. But still, if we want to protect Europe and our countries and our communities together – Hungary, the Visegrad countries and the citizens of Europe – please speak up where ever you can and support Hungary. They want to destabilise our country; please help us.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you, Mrs Morvai. Mrs Morvai, I would very much like to ask you to try to keep to the minute. It can't be that I cut you off every time. Everyone here keeps to the minute as best they can. You get the impression that if you're left with you, you'll talk for 20 minutes. We have to make sure that we follow the rules here a little bit. (Interjection by Mrs. Morvai)

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I will be very brief. The report we voted down today is extremely important. It addresses the issue of world migration, the topics that we as the EU face. On the other hand, I have to say that I am relatively disappointed with that report itself, as it remains in a very general position. Going forward, it is obvious, and UN analyses and experts warn against this, that migration will not avoid Europe and vice versa. Thanks to climate change, migratory waves can be much larger. And we should, in addition to the general theses that are in this report, discuss concrete solutions, concrete scenarios on how to help third countries in particular on the African continent. And thus reducing the risk of migration at least to some extent, because we certainly won't solve it. So, the topic is important, it's good that we discuss it here, but let's face that the report is very general, and unfortunately it will not have a great contribution in a particular practical policy.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: “I must admit that the debate yesterday was more than satisfying. Whereas, what I would like to emphasize today is that, too often by dissipating our interests — including those financial interests — we very rarely move in the area of our neighbouring countries. I want to draw attention to this, because the countries of the Eastern Partnership are most important to us, they are crucial to us, but by shifting interests very often to Venezuela, to Colombia, to very remote countries, we neglect what is crucial from the point of view of our interests, European interests. On this occasion, I would like to — by appealing not to distract our interest, not to distract resources, to return to the wise policies of the European Parliament, the European institution towards countries in the east: towards Moldova, towards Ukraine, towards Belarus, to remember that these the closest our neighboring interests require extraordinary care.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, subsidiarity and proportionality seem to be the past, and President Macron – if we let him do so – will change the structure, the strategies and everything of the European Union, as he explained to us. He said he wants a European sovereignty, as opposed to the national sovereignty that most Europeans want. He wants a United States of Europe, while we European people want a Europe of nations: of independent nations with sovereignty. Mr Macron wants mass migration. We, the majority of Europe, do not want migration; we want to save and to protect Europe and our communities. Please, let’s stand together for the Europe of nations, of independent nations with sovereignty, and keep the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, the issue of subsidiarity and proportionality is extremely important. It's a shame that the subject is always on the sidelines here, in some relatively small late-night debate. However, the report shows that we are moving and that we increasingly see the issue of subsidiarity and proportionality not as some formal condition of European law, but that we are beginning to address the subject very seriously. I'd like to bring up one thing here. I think there is no need to change primary European law in order to better examine subsidiarity, I think it is important how the European Commission approaches the subject. I here want to commend Mr Juncker's Commission, which I believe follows the slogan that for every new piece of legislation, every proposal it sends here, to the European Parliament, more examines whether such a proposal is needed according to the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality. The pace of legislative work is certainly less than under the previous head of the Commission, Barroso, and I think that's a good thing. Better is less and quality than more and less quality.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Mr President! I have been required by the Committee on Culture to submit observations related to the discharge. Yesterday, almost all of them managed to pass with one exception — the Culture Committee has repeatedly pointed out that all the time there is a shortage of resources to expand so-called pilot schemes. It is so acute that, with poor implementation of programmes such as Creative Europe or Europe for Citizens, pilot programmes are this narrow but extremely valuable wicket for short short new programmes, that is, those which extend the possibility of functioning especially young people in the area of culture. I draw attention to this by supplementing my speech from the previous day.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, since 2013, the European Court of Auditors has not made any special reports on the situation of conflicts of interest in agencies working with industries - and here I am referring to the food, chemical, medicine, aviation or railways industries. There are situations where testing for approval to market the products of these industries on the European market is given by expert groups to which they belong including former employees of companies that produced those products for which marketing approval is sought. However, such situations are inadmissible because there is a risk of lack of impartiality in the evaluation of the products of these companies. That is why I am asking the Court of Auditors to resume checking situations of conflict of interest at agencies working with industries.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, the industries that want to market their food products on the European market, as I said earlier, call for testing and approval by European agencies, but all European agencies and institutions must have their declarations of interest completed. I'd like to refer only to the agents. Out of the 53 agencies, only 29 published declarations of interest on the site. I am concerned that, in the regulation of the Economic and Social Committee, where the ECtHR was rapporteur, every new employee must write a declaration of absence of conflict of interest, or no one can assess himself, to say that he is not in conflict of interests. As such, I ask this committee to change the regulation and ask for declarations of interests, which then have to be assessed independently by someone else, and obviously the one in conflict of interest must be sanctioned.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, I did not grant discharge to the European Network and Information Security Agency, ENISA, and I do this all the time, every year, because the life and state of this Agency is known and I have denounced it here in plenary. There is no chapter that has to refer to accountability and transparency. Furthermore, it is a fact that various cycles continue to be organized in order for ENISA to leave Heraklion, Crete and then from Greece. That is why these circles have succeeded in dividing this Organization into an administrative centre located in Heraklion and has only eight to ten employees and an operational centre that came to Athens, where the majority of the employees have come and continues this a method of depreciation of the Organization itself, which was based in Heraklion. This is something I constantly denounce and I will continue to fight against this endeavour of various circles.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on Council and Commission Declarations on Cambridge Analytica and Facebook: data protection and citizens' privacy as a line of defence against election manipulation (2018/2667 (RSP)).

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the news that Cambridge Analytica used Facebook profiles to perform targeted political messaging has led to a loss of trust all over the world. People are concerned about the security of the personal data they share on social networks and digital platforms.  In order to find out whether Facebook and Cambridge Analytica breached data protection rules, enforcement authorities are investigating. At EU level, the Article 29 Committee, which gathers the data protection authorities of the Member States, is following the developments closely.  At the political level, the concerns are real and are being taken seriously. You can see that in the conclusions of the European Council of 22 and 23 March. It has also led Commissioner Jourová to demand further clarification from Facebook about the extent to which EU citizens were affected. The debate here today gives another political signal from the European Union that we are worried. I am grateful that you have asked the Presidency to participate in your discussion on ‘data protection and citizen’s privacy as a line of defence against election manipulation’. The Facebook and Cambridge Analytica case touches the heart of the EU’s core principles. The rights to protection of personal data and privacy are enshrined in the European Charter on Fundamental rights. Those rights are the basis for the new EU data protection rules laid down in the General Data Protection Regulation, which will become applicable in a few weeks.  The GDPR will help to protect personal data in the European Union, as it empowers persons to more easily find out what personal data companies hold about them and for what purposes such data are processed. Furthermore, the GDPR provides for the possibility for data protection authorities to impose high fines. This will discipline companies to comply with the rules. Finally, the GDPR provides for a consistency mechanism. This ensures that the national data protection authorities coordinate amongst each other their decisions so that the European Union speaks with a single voice. The Facebook and Cambridge Analytica case poses a lot of other fundamental questions than data protection: how can we protect democratic elections in times of massive digital disinformation or manipulation? In October 2017, the Council held its annual rule of law dialogue on the topic ‘Media Pluralism and the Rule of Law in the Digital Age’. Ministers agreed that free, reliable and pluralistic media underpin effective democracy, while digital disinformation on a massive scale has the potential to undermine it. In this context, we have all seen the recent, but very timely, opinion of the European Data Protection Supervisor on online manipulation and personal data. The Facebook and Cambridge Analytica case has brought to the fore the importance of protecting personal data and privacy. The European Union has already recognised that importance in its new data protection rules, which provide tools to protect personal data in an effective manner. The silver lining of this case is that adequate data protection is getting the political attention it deserves in other parts of the world as well.  However, well-functioning data protection rules do not provide the full answer against manipulating elections. Other measures going beyond data protection are also necessary for safeguarding the rule of law and democracy. New challenges to the rule of law and human rights, such as increased levels of disinformation, have to be counterbalanced by increased levels of media literacy. Current legislation is deemed to be sufficient in broad terms, but it must be better applied and supported by flanking measures, such as fact-checking websites, voluntary codes of conduct and intensified cooperation with service providers. This is already in place in several countries, as well as at EU level. Let us use the protests about Facebook and Cambridge Analytica to advance the thinking on these fundaments of our societies. In that context, it is very opportune that, on 16 May, our leaders will discuss the need for transparent practices and full protection of privacy and personal data on the part of social networks and digital platforms.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, your initiative to have a plenary debate on this topic is very welcome. This case is too important to treat as business as usual. It is up to all of us to draw the right lessons from this Facebook-Cambridge Analytica scandal. There is work ongoing on three aspects of this scandal. First, personal data. Up to 2.7 million Europeans could have been affected by this scandal. Second, broader effects on our democratic processes, elections included. Third, the criminal aspects of the case. I would like to share with you some details about the different aspects. Let me start with data protection. It has been said that the way we deal with privacy is the defining fundamental rights issue of our time. The Facebook-Cambridge Analytica case shows that protection of personal data can have a major impact on our democracy and on our elections. In this House, you have known the importance of these issues for many years and have adopted the data protection package, the so-called the General Data Protection Regulation, known under the acronym of GDPR. We Europeans have got this right. We have foreseen that cases like this might happen and we wanted to be well-equipped. If there is one positive thing coming out of this crisis, it is the awareness about the importance of personal data protection that has been generated among ordinary citizens in Europe and around the world. All around the world, democratic countries are now looking at GDPR for inspiration. The GDPR basically gives back control of personal data to the people. For instance, consent under the GDPR must be given by a clear and affirmative action and cannot be hidden among legalistic terms and conditions that nobody ever reads. Otherwise, you have the right to take your data with you when moving to another provider. Also, the GDPR reinforces the role of national protection authorities and gives them the possibility to impose quite dramatically high fines. The proposed e-privacy regulation further specifies the transparency requirements for browsers and apps, but aside from this positive effect, there is a serious situation which must be investigated and which must be prevented from occurring again. And let’s keep in mind that the GDPR is not in place yet, so we are assessing the Facebook scandal against the currently existing laws. There is an investigation led by the UK’s data protection authority, the Information Commissioner’s Office (ICO). I am in close touch with the ICO Commissioner and I have expressed my full support in her work. I expect Facebook to cooperate fully and at the highest level of the company. There is no time to be complacent about this. I am also in frequent contact with the Chairwoman of the Article 29 Working Party and the future Chair of the European Data Protection Board, Ms Andrea Jelinek. All EU data protection authorities met in Brussels last week, and I am pleased they decided to launch a dedicated working group to social media, not only Facebook. On 25 May when GDPR becomes applicable, it is absolutely crucial that those business models that monitor huge amounts of our personal data are under full scrutiny. The time for leniency is over, and it is good that the data protection authorities are getting ready for it. I am fully confident that European enforcers will make sure that Facebook fixes the mistakes and complies with the new data protection laws. Now it is very important that we offer help to those almost three million citizens affected by the scandal. The data protection authorities issued information last week about how their interest is protected and what they can do to ensure better protection of their privacy. Finally, I was directly in contact with Facebook and I spoke to the Chief Operating Officer, Ms Sheryl Sandberg last week. I underlined that I expect Facebook to provide more detailed information and to cooperate fully with the Irish and British data protection authorities. We must better and fully understand not only what happened to the data of EU citizens, but what is going on with this date even now. Of particular concern to me is the information to European citizens affected by the scandal. I was told that Facebook has started to inform people last week. Facebook also confirm that there could be more apps that harvested the personal data of users and those of their friends. I am also getting information from another source from the British ICO. So I urged Facebook to take all necessary steps to mitigate any potential negative consequences for users in the future. I have also advised Ms Sandberg that Mr Zuckerberg should accept the invitation of the European Parliament to appear in front of the responsible committees, and Vice-President Ansip met with Mr Zuckerberg in Silicon Valley yesterday, and the Facebook CEO reconfirmed his will to cooperate closely with the European authorities on rebuilding trust after this scandal. Vice-President Ansip referred to the invitation by the European Parliament as a measure of rebuilding the trust. We also have to speak seriously about the impact this scandal might have on our democratic societies. By having access to personal information it seems that it was possible for various actors to micro-target citizens and help spread fake news and propaganda. And this was all done in the maze of digital reality with zero transparency and without any consent from the users. This scandal is a wake-up call for all of us to start a serious debate on what role social media plays today, and what role they should play in our elections in the future. Traditional media are under very strict rules. Social media largely cooperate without any limits in this respect. And to be absolutely clear, social media created unprecedented opportunities to engage in a political debate and communicate directly with millions of voters, but they also created opportunities for some actors to manipulate and abuse social media. The algorithms used in the business model of Facebook or other companies may have facilitated the spreading of fake news and untruthful posts and reinforced so-called ‘filter bubbles’ and the antagonisation within this society. So we need to understand better what the current situation in Europe is. Organising elections is largely in the remit of the Member States. However, as a Commissioner responsible for Union citizenship rights, I have invited the EU electoral authorities for a meeting at the end of April. I would like to hear from them how they handle social media and online advertising in their campaign rules. To that end, we have sent them a set of detailed questions in advance, so I hope I will get very concrete and clear answers on 25 April. I would like for all of us to act responsibly and not to jump the gun. Our response should not only be about Facebook. Our response should take into account the wider implications of an unregulated internet. Some steps have already been taken. As you might know, the Commission has initiated a code of conduct on hate speech such as racism and xenophobia, which has shown good results. We adopted in February a recommendation on combating illegal content online. We will present next week a communication on how to tackle online disinformation, calling for more transparency, the promotion of diversity of information and credibility of information online. This will be a first opportunity to refer to the very first lessons to draw from the scandal in the official policy paper. We will also adopt a communication on artificial intelligence, which, among other actions, aims at debating and developing ethical principles in this respect. The Commission is carrying out a pilot project requested by the European Parliament on algorithmic awareness-building, which will focus on how algorithms can shape, filter or personalise information flows that may reinforce biases. And last week, the Commission proposed the new deal for consumers package, which includes collective actions in case of mass harm situations. This can also be a strong enforcement tool in case of privacy violations. Finally, there are the important criminal law investigations in this case which need to be carried out by the national law enforcement bodies. To conclude, what is guiding our work in the Commission is a strong notion that the internet is not a space free of the rule of law. The rules that apply offline also need to be fully respected in the online world, and we need to make sure our modern data protection laws are thoroughly applied. I look forward to hearing your views today and to continue working together on these important issues for our society.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (ES) Mr President, the Facebook and Cambridge Analytica case is just the tip of the iceberg. The digital world is a duplication of our life to which we give ourselves without taking any precautions and almost without requiring any security. Human intelligence is limited by his own consciousness; however, artificial intelligence knows no limits. It is paradoxical that, as legislators, we should take more care to prevent mistakes that people make, limited by their conscience, than machines that know nothing about ethics or morals. The generation of baby boomers, to which I belong, believes that the digital world is just a fun extension of the analog world. We are very wrong: what happens in cyberspace modifies space; what happens on the internet does not stay on the internet. Lies are as old as politics: they were born at the same time as democracy and politics. Politics, lies and democracy coexist since ancient Greece. The difference is that, today, lies can be more powerful than democracy and more powerful than politics, and more numerous than truths. In the forthcoming European elections liars will try to ensure that there is an anti-European majority in this Parliament, and we are in time to avoid it by protecting professional journalists and passing European legislation that limits liars. Lie is as dangerous as nationalpopulism, and it is usually its instrument. The only thing we can't do is stand by.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the scandal of Facebook and Cambridge Analytica is a wake—up call. All of a sudden, everybody understands that the digital revolution involves opportunities but also risks, and sometimes threats, of creating companies without corporate responsibility, of creating jobs without proper social protection and now about taking on board our personal data and using these for the purpose of economic and political manipulation. We just cannot accept this. We need to regain control of our lives and Europe must take the lead in this. This is the right moment to invent our European way for the digital revolution and to regain digital sovereignty. And the only way to regain digital sovereignty is through full use of the European scale. We have taken the first step. The S&D Group played a pioneering role, calling in this Parliament for the regulation on general data protection, but of course this is just the first step. We know now there is an important regulation in the hands of the Council on e—privacy, and we urge the Council to start a trilogue immediately, because the urgency is clear. Of course we want Mr Zuckerberg to appear in front of us in the European Parliament to give proper explanations and proper guarantees, but I believe – and also have expectations regarding the Commission– that we need a broader approach in order to pave the way for our European agenda on digital governance, starting with a proper assessment of how social networks work, and need to encourage European innovation in this area. This has to do with how we deal with artificial intelligence. Most of all, we would make sure that all citizens can count on generalised digital skills to master the major developments which are taking place.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, today personal online data such as age, gender or political preference are a particularly lucrative asset. Moreover, these data are often sold without the knowledge of the person himself. The right to privacy and the protection of the digital space are therefore becoming more important than ever. As legislators, we must protect our citizens from the abuse of privacy, but we must also ensure the safety of our citizens. The right to privacy should not be an absolute right. Today we see very clearly that terrorists too often slip through the net by abusing the right to privacy. Investigating judges complain that they often chase after the facts. For example, they cannot access stored data such as WhatsApp messages in which terrorists discuss attacks. The right to privacy allows these terrorists to continue their criminal activities anonymously and impunished. This is an unintended and undesirable side effect of the right to privacy. That is why we need to strive for a more balanced balance between privacy and security. It cannot be the intention of protecting one another to be nullified. Privacy and security must be able to coexist, not without each other. We must therefore prevent the abuse of digital space, whether it is by tech giants or by criminals and terrorists.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, thanks to Mark Zuckerberg, the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is now the best known European law ever, even in the US Congress. Yes, thank you, Mark, this one’s for you! I think Mr Zuckerberg would be well advised to appear before this House out of respect for hundreds of millions of European Facebook users who feel deceived. There are actually more users here than in the US, and I think Zuckerberg should be here. We should not be visiting him in the United States. He should be here. But today’s debate is not about Facebook. The European Parliament, yes, and also the European Data Protection authorities will scrutinise very closely whether the new Facebook privacy arrangements are compliant with all EU legislation, but we also need to take a very critical look at ourselves. We talk the talk, but do we also walk the walk, Commission, Council and dear friends? Because amongst those who are voicing their outrage at Facebook are many who have consistently voted against stricter privacy protection, and continue to do so. Like those – including the President of this House, dear friends – who summoned Mr Zuckerberg to the European Parliament, but they voted against e-privacy, so a bit of consistency, please. I also note that the European data protection authorities have hardly responded to earlier reports on Cambridge Analytica and Facebook. It has been known since last year – why have they been so slow? And despite the jubilation about GDPR, Member States have not nearly allocated the necessary means to the national data protection authorities to enable them to properly enforce the GDPR. I also note that the advice of designated experts, like the European Data Protection Supervisor and Working Party 29, are being systematically ignored. Their advice on data retention, PNR, Safe Harbour: ignored! And all subsequently scrapped by the European Court of Justice. Worryingly, decisions by the European Court of Justice are also being ignored. Now will the Commission remain deaf to the recommendations of Working Party 29 on PNR and Privacy Shield, or act? Because while we are busy barricading the front door to keep the likes of Mr Zuckerberg out, the back door is wide open. And we are giving away our way our personal data by the truckload, not just to our own government agencies, but also to other countries like the United States, with legal safeguards that carry about as much weight as Donald’s tweets. European citizens are left out in the cold, unprotected. Yes, the Facebook case is a wake-up call for all of us. Mr Zuckerberg, privacy is not dead. It’s alive and kicking.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, there are more Facebook users in Europe than there are in the US. The social network might be based in the Silicon Valley, but it is active worldwide and, therefore, it also has responsibilities all across the globe. I have said it before and will repeat it again, Mark Zuckerberg has to come to the European Parliament to answer our questions; a simple apology will not do. And it will not do either if the Commissioners now start to travel to the US and ask very nicely for audiences with Mr Zuckerberg. It’s very worrying that one single tool can be so dominant on the market, and all of us know it can be a very annoying tool with all the ads and all the weird groups that you are being added to. But it is also probably the best way – or only way – to we can stay in touch with most of our friends because they are on it. It’s also the only place where you can share cat pictures with your grandmother; nowhere else could you possibly do that, so we stay there. And despite the dramatic data leakages, despite the ads, despite all of that, we keep spending and wasting our time scrolling down our timeline. For many in Europe, Facebook has become a necessity, rather than a nice option. That also means that Facebook has a huge responsibility, and so far it has shied away from taking up this responsibility. It has ignored even the most basic data protection rules, and that must be over, once and for all. And it’s our duty as European legislators to make sure that our citizens and their data is protected. It’s our duty, they have put their trust in us and we need to comply with that,

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Mr President, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Yes, what we are experiencing today with Facebook is fatally reminiscent of the long established reality of the bestseller “The Circle”. It's not just about Cambridge Analykca, but about a group that has become dominant in the global media industry without taking on ethical responsibility. And Facebook is not a neutral platform! Reality is shortened with each click in algorithms, based on software that is decided what is shown and what is not. This way it can also be manipulated piece by piece. Zuckerberg didn't happen somehow. He's not faking ignorance. He knew about the scandal since 2015, and he didn't do anything! Why didn't he do anything? Because ultimately this is also a business model of Facebook to logically make money with data. They may do that, but then they have to take responsibility too. Also Google, as well as Amazon. Therefore, clear rules and consequences are needed to prevent abuse. What we as a group are asking for is full information about the misuse of European data by Facebook. I want Zuckerberg to come here and give us an answer, especially in the committee responsible. I want to know from him how Facebook actually intends to implement the General Data Protection Regulation after 25 May, when that is actually valid. If there are no guarantees, then the corresponding penalties will have to hail. That is what we should do. And one more thing: this is not just a crisis of confidence on Facebook, but about safeguarding fundamental rights, and here, highly respected Commission, you need to take a lot more action, so you really need to push for this to happen. Otherwise, it would have to hail appropriate penalties.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, before going any further, let’s get one myth out of the way. There are many reasons why the Brexit referendum was won or lost, nothing to do with Cambridge Analytica was in any way material, and we should not confuse sales talk from an old Etonian with reality. Nonetheless, hidden in this lengthy statement for debate, there is a very important, indeed vital, issue. Let us start from the fact that Mr Mark Zuckerberg is not as nice as he looks. Mr Zuckerberg’s approach to business has been well set out in the feature film The Social Network. And behind all the blather and misleading PR speak about the ‘Facebook community’ there is a gruesome reality. Facebook is a monopoly. It maintains its monopoly by a variety of predatory business practices, and one simple illustration is that Facebook buys up potential competitors. This is what it did, for example, with Instagram, Messenger and WhatsApp. But there is more. Facebook makes its money – let there be no misunderstanding – from selling data and advertising targeted from that data. Users do not have complete control over their Facebook data, and this cannot be good. And there is still worse. It emerged in the Washington hearings that Facebook has what it describes as ‘shadow profiles’ on people who have not signed up to Facebook, and these profiles are without their consent. Such data does not get deleted when leaving, because these people had never joined Facebook in the first place. In its methods of collecting data, Facebook has become like a virus that you can never get rid of. This is not only distasteful, it is entirely shocking. The conclusion is clear. The problem is not Cambridge Analytica, the problem is Facebook. And the emphasis on Cambridge Analytica and election manipulation is a distraction. As I said, the fundamental problem is Facebook itself, the manner in which Facebook operates, its predatory business practices, its lack of ethical principles, and its monopoly. In short, the monopoly that is Facebook needs breaking up.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are faced with a choice of civilisation, culture, where democracy and freedom are indeed played. There is only one way out of GAFA's control over society: by changing the economic model. The data belongs to the person who issues it and, from the moment it is exploited, first, it is necessary to pay; secondly, the consent of the data subject must be paid. If the data is used without the consent of the person concerned, the penalty must be enormous, in the order of the company's turnover. We must get out of this economic model. I proposed it in a report to this Parliament, which did not even want to discuss the report, but rewrote it! We are in total hypocrisy. As long as you do not want to get out of this economic model that allows total domination, monopoly and control over democracy by some societies, you will be in hypocrisy. Change the business model, then you will be credible.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: — Mr President, we are not surprised about the case of Facebook or other social media that collect, retain and process personal information for their own political, commercial and any other benefit. Every click is a self-file that is bought and sold multiple and chained by monopolies, secret services, urban nations competing, launching each other's dirty laundry in the open. In the end, they tell the users themselves, “Let's be careful!”, in short: capitalism, whose barbarity is also imprinted on line. The big words about freedom and the empty declarations, when the censorship ax falls on anything radical that this system challenges, are really a blowing air, as are the declarations of protection of rights and the admonition of good use and rules. Science and technology suffocate under the boot of capitalist profit and from the property owned by the groups. Only by overturning them can the working grassroots needs be met so that the Internet and its applications can be exploited in the interests of workers.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, I was shocked by the Cambridge Analytica scandal that affected so many millions of people in the EU and the US. Sometimes it feels like we are living in a reality closer to that imagined by Orwell or Huxley than perhaps we would care to believe. This is an era where data is the new gold and where unscrupulous politicians and those who support them will use and abuse our personal information to make their propaganda appear as fact, to help swing elections and referenda and to essentially subvert democratic processes. This scandal is not only about misuse of data. This is about systems that were built for good being used against us. We need to ensure that elections and referenda that look free on the surface are actually so in reality. We built our Data Protection Regulation and Privacy Shield precisely because of these threats, and our legislation must be able to face this test and any entity responsible for breaches must be held to account. We have to examine the loopholes that still exist and how these can be closed, because people expect privacy online and we must ensure that their expectations are met. Cambridge Analytica has a lot to answer for. We have seen how they have abused our data in the US, the UK and many Member States, including my own, Malta, where we learned that thousands of people had been affected. In many cases, we still do not know who the people who hired Cambridge Analytica were and for what purpose the 6 000 Maltese nationals’ and millions of EU citizens’ data was harvested. The links between the abuse of data and our democratic processes must be investigated. I welcome the Parliament initiating such a process.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President! Knowledge is power, and power is all too easily abused if there are insufficient rules to protect the individual. We see the consequences of lack of regulation in the current Facebook scandal: millions of data abuse for voter manipulation. Repentant appearances of Zuckerberg can't obscure it: Facebook is engaged in aggressive data capitalism, hidden behind colorful likes and seemingly innocuous apps. The fact that Facebook is currently experimenting with facial recognition software shows how low the learning effect actually is. And yet Facebook is only the tip of the iceberg. The collection and processing of data has become a business model in which we are manipulated, as customers and consumers as well as as voters. In the end, we pay many of the digital and apparently free offers with a loss of privacy, freedom of choice and democracy. Governments, parliaments, business and civil society can now prove that they have understood and act. Thanks to the Data Protection Regulation, from May onwards, the EU will be able to respond to data capitalists in the only language they understand: that of money. Penalties can amount to up to four percent of global sales. And if Facebook then allows dubious apps to wrease user consent through insufficient or misinformation, Facebook must also be responsible for this. But the Data Protection Regulation alone is not enough. We finally need the ePrivacy Regulation on privacy online. ePrivacy protects not only personal data, but the confidentiality of communications as a whole. The rules so far are so outdated that they do not even cover actors like Facebook. This has to change. ePrivacy is designed to protect the content of conversations in private Facebook messengers, some of which have also been read along. The Regulation also provides for specific standards of protection for: consent to personalised advertising. And we want strict technical specifications for the browser to enable tracking only with the user's consent. However, as with the General Data Protection Regulation, Member States are on the brakes on ePrivacy and are becoming a henchman for industry. The European Parliament has had a position since autumn. In view of the millions of legal breach by Facebook, Member States must now finally adopt a position so that joint negotiations can start and that we can better protect our citizens digitally.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: – Mr President, trust is a vital commodity in the digital era, as Facebook is finding out now. If you fail in your service or in your duty of care or your protection of data, you have nowhere to hide – consumers will desert you.  Facebook now needs to explain what it has done and how it is going to protect users’ data – not just because we demand it, but because their users demand it. Users may agree to share their own data on the site, but they did not agree to their friends sharing their details on their behalf.  Facebook needs to vet its third—party apps much more carefully, and we need to get to the bottom of what Cambridge Analytica were doing and what effect they actually had on election results.  But the key for us is to learn from this: the digital revolution has empowered billions around the world, but it is embryonic and barriers are being tested by all in this uncertain data—driven new world. The GDPR which comes into force next month is also testing barriers. That alone brings about much more protection of personal data. Facebook itself has said it will apply it globally. So let’s find out what happened here first and see how well the GDPR worked in practice – and then, when we have a full picture, assess if more legislation is needed.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: - Mr President! The truth is that we EU citizens are all utterly protectless out in the cold as the outrageous revelations surrounding Facebook and Cambridge Analytica reveal what the truth — what reality looks like. The scandal that has affected millions of Facebook users constitutes crimes against our free open and democratic societies and is a fundamental violation of every human being's right to personal privacy. I demand that Facebook and other social media sites take responsibility for how our personal data is exploited for political purposes. This has become extremely up-to-date with the scandals surrounding Russia's influence in US elections. It should now go without saying that each company lives up to what the Data Protection Regulation stipulates. Common decency requires Mark Zuckerberg to answer yes to the Speaker's invitation to come here to Parliament to explain himself. Immediately we should have that answer, because everything else is completely unacceptable.

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: – Mr President, these days we all can see advertisements by Facebook praising the European Union’s General Data Protection (GDPR) as the new standard to protect citizens’ privacy and data in Europe and everywhere in the world, as Facebook reacts by implementing the GDPR standards on a global level. So, 37 days before the GDPR is even being applied, it is already setting the global standard for protecting personal data. We can be very proud, as the European Union and, especially as Parliament, that we have a tool to protect the privacy and integrity of our citizens’ lives with the GDPR in place. But I would also agree it is very important to understand that there is a missing brick in this wall, and that is the e-privacy regulation. We still need to fix that problem because the communication data needs to be protected in a specific way. It is important that Facebook is not only relying on ads, as they say is their business model, but is also delivering for trust by delivering solutions and actions in the way of how they do their business model. The business model of just earning money by using the data of individuals has to change, because that’s not only Facebook’s business model. There are other companies – we don’t talk about Google, Twitter, or even companies you maybe not have heard of like Actium or Thomson Reuters having your data, exploiting it and selling it. We need to get more rules in place, especially also for consumer control to get connectivity across the platforms in order to have a choice.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: — Mr President, the Cambridge Analytica and Facebook scandal has demonstrated in practice the dangers inherent in globalisation when power is concentrated in the hands of a few skilful and in the hands of speculative monopolies, who now have all the means to file and manipulate the masses for their own benefit. This is the most massive breach of personal data through social media that has been discovered. As GUE/NGL, we strongly condemn any breach of personal data and stress that it is impertinent to have integrated democratic control, regulation and simplification of procedures, so that users on social media can manage their personal data. data and regulate who can access them. We expect the European Union to adopt stricter rules and put in place an integrated regulatory and legislative framework for the effective protection of personal data. There are 370 million Facebook users in Europe and that is why new consultations need to be required, Facebook must be invited to the European Parliament to discuss with them the necessary changes they need to make, the new rules they have to apply as they have proclaimed, but even more stringent regulations.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what happened confirms that the business model of multinationals on the web is based on the systematic collection of user data. Data that became 21st century oil, employed to profile consumers/users, so they can determine their behaviors, and then given to third parties. What is missing, and the case of Cambridge Analytica has uncovered it, is the absence of awareness from citizens. Then we have to ask ourselves: how to react? Who's deciding for us? What is the role that states and the European Union must play in the face of these phenomena? It's time to end the monopolies of a few major web giants who, by leveraging our personal data and influencing our behaviors, have amassed billionaire fortunes. Perhaps it is time to start considering our personal data a common good, to be protected, as well as other common goods such as water, territory, coast the sea. We have a great chance, which is the approval of the e-privacy regulation, which is still blocked in Council. I conclude with a statement by American economist Friedman, who says “There are no such thing as free meals” and so what we don't pay in monetary terms we pay for it with our data and our lower privacy.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: — Mr. President, Either Facebook's actions are lawful and then there is no problem, or they are not lawful and then there are courts and prosecutions to enforce that law. There really is no reason for Parliament, which is not a judicial body, to deal with single cases of application of the law, or otherwise nothing else would be doing. Parliament makes laws, not enforce them. That's the tripartition of power. You can't write laws all over again every time someone breaks it simply. No law is written for single cases. You guys use every such high-profile case to shove your bureaucratic paws even deeper into the pockets and intimacy of citizens, but it shouldn't be such an excuse, because unless I actually feel confident about Zuckerberg managing my personal information, it's all the more I don't trust that my data will be safe in your hands when you get involved. Because from Facebook, I can log off at any time, and out of power EU bureaucrats are not so easy anymore.

name: Axel VOSS
text: Mr President! We need to be a little more honest here. The systematic evaluation and subsequent use of large amounts of user data is not a new phenomenon. For many years we have regularly seen such contributions in the media and also the reports of data protectionists. Therefore, what we are seeing here is now perhaps the tip of the iceberg, but it is not new in the sense, and the fact that the trade in data takes place is not new either. That is why we have adopted this General Data Protection Regulation here at European level. What, I do not think we have really appreciated yet, and wherever I would say that this is not yet the right answer to these data uses in the future, is basically that we are transferring an old structure into this new world. We should have just as well given more thought about consent, because consent is actually the element that ultimately guarantees the lawfulness of data processing and data use. We've been a little too careless here in this whole procedure. That's why I actually think we need to think even more about whether we need to take a different approach to these stories. We actually need more control. And we have to be honest, too. Even with a new General Data Protection Regulation, which will come into force next month, we will nonetheless have such scandals because the abuse cannot be regulated. We can only assume that we provide a guide on how to deal with this data as legally possible. But we will not be able to regulate the abuse.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Mr President, I would say to Mr González Pons that he should not worry about being from a generation that doesn’t fully understand this: the entire US Senate were not aware of what they were talking about, and I am of that generation where my eight-year-old knows more than I do.  Lindsey Graham, the US Senator, asked the question, ‘Do the Europeans have it right?’, and when Zuckerberg answered reluctantly, ‘yes you have’, this was a proud moment for our rapporteur and a proud moment for this Parliament: GDPR had arrived – but, more importantly, it had arrived in the subtle way which we know. Even if GDPR was fully complied with by Facebook, perhaps only 4% of its revenue would go. With full compliance, it would not solve the problem. This is because we are a sophisticated Parliament – as the Commissioner and others have said, we have many tools for the job, not just GDPR. Many have mentioned ePrivacy because of the important consent equation within ePrivacy, and we should really ask why the Council is blocking ePrivacy. It is the tool for the job. But on GDPR, the overarching issue is that we have higher data protection standards than in the United States. I want to make one clear point here, which is that we have the credibility in the EU institutions and Parliament not just because we have millions more Facebook users than in the United States, but because we have a track record here legislatively, because we have tracked what Facebook has done wrongly for 14 years, and because we have the credibility and expertise here in this Parliament to call Mark Zuckerberg before us to examine what Facebook is doing. Let me tell you – for anyone who is not aware – that Facebook is powerful; so are the other platforms. The Indian Prime Minister today is at a Commonwealth summit, and let me tell you that millions – billions – of people are on Facebook; it is powerful, elections are in danger and our privacy is valuable. But here we have done the right thing – let us be proud of it and now go ahead and be credible and have those hearings.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: — Mr President, Brittany Kaiser, a former employee at Cambridge Analytica, said before the British Parliament that This is Your Digital Life is only the 'tip of the iceberg'. He acknowledged that there were other applications to collect the personal data of those who use Facebook, so the number of those affected far exceeds the current figure we know of 87 000 000, as Claude said earlier. Mark Zuckerberg also admitted to American senators that there may be links between the data stolen by Cambridge Analytica and the Internet Research Agency, the Kremlin's “Troll Factory”. The new regulation for the application of personal data adopted by the European Union, with the insistence of this Parliament, is indeed an answer, let us see if it is sufficient. The data belongs to the citizens, and under no circumstances should they be used by the Kremlin, by Moscow, by anyone else, for destroying democracy, influencing elections and entering people's privacy.

name: Morten PETERSEN
text: Mr President! Have we got the wrong president in the white house? At least we now know that the road to the Oval Office has been paved with fake news and misuse of Facebook data - and even that perhaps the Brexit vote could have had a different outcome. It's utterly terrible to think about! There is only one year until the next elections for this parliament, and how do we make sure it doesn't end the same way here? If there is anything this scandal has taught us, then it is the importance of common playing field in the European Union. How many people think small countries, including my own, Denmark, alone and on their own would be able to get Marc Zuckerberg and Facebook into speech? The new European Data Protection Scheme is a step in just the right direction. The new European rules show that the best solutions to common problems are precisely common. We are stronger together than we are separately - and we also need to be going forward so that we can secure real protection to the public and the electorate on the web.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: When you said that we had the wrong President, I thought for a moment that you were referring to me, and I was scared.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Mr President, I was allowed to read a very large advertisement in my newspaper. It said, “New EU legislation means better data protection for you,” and I thought, what a hypocrisy, Mark Zuckerberg. You who have lobbied your big money for years against better European data protection legislation. You claiming that what you're doing is bringing people together, it's not making money. But it is. It's making money. It is making money with our data, and it is time for us to use our laws to ensure that Mark Zuckerberg has a different business model in the future. I am indeed glad that there is now new European data protection legislation, but we do not have Facebook to thank for that, it is the last thing we owe Facebook for.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Mr President, this is not a debate on social networks, it is a debate on freedom and democracy. Over the last century, we have built an information-based society, culture and economy, but we have not thought of an ethics to protect data. In fact, most of this house have really prevented the real protection of privacy in the digital age and governments are now blocking it. - Yes. Algorithms and machine learning software are today a weapon of political combat. The Internet is full of algorithms that analyze and predict our behavior through obscure software. We're not just talking about spying or stealing our data, we're talking about software that, through our data, determines which articles we have access to, who we keep in contact with, who can keep in touch with us. In short, this has a name and that name is manipulation. Cambridge Analytica has clearly demonstrated to us that this is a billion-dollar business, and if we do nothing else, whoever has the money will still have access to power.

name: József NAGY
text: - Mr. President! Respect for privacy is one of the greatest achievements of advanced societies, and the protection of personal data is one of our most important fundamental rights. In order to ensure this, it is inevitable to introduce appropriate systems and, in particular, supervise them. Even if we can only see the tip of the iceberg, the scandal of Facebook and Cambridge Analytica has shown that we cannot rely entirely on the voluntary privacy system of even the most reputable service providers. In Slovakia, for example, the data of 14,000 users have been manipulated. In that case, the neglect of data protection could have injured society at its most sensitive point by influencing elections. In spite of our mission last year in Washington, Congress and the White House, we said that the European Privacy Shield conditionality is the technological minimum that we should also demand from those who have a huge amount of personal data on a global scale. In the case of the outrageous Cambridge Analytica, we can see that the bounds of data know no bounds, and although it is true that there will always be places in the world where data carriers can be tolerated, but as long as service providers, system owners, service providers, or even development companies the risk of such abuse will only increase. As in many cases, prevention is the most important, which can be the basis of the European Privacy Shield, the Privacy Shield.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. When I opened the newspaper on Monday, I was amazed by a full-page Facebook ad: “New EU legislation means more privacy for you,” it said. A lot came to my mind. Didn't Mark Zuckerberg give an answer to our colleagues in the US Congress just a few days earlier — unconvincing? Many things he left unanswered. This was probably also due to the questioners who lacked the necessary understanding. In fact, much for those who were not familiar with the matter is incomprehensible what has become known about Facebook and Cambridge Analytica: voter influence, data theft, unfair competition, etc. One could have known all this if one had listened to the concerns of data protectionists and civil society, which had long pointed out the lack of this business model. Some of us have taken these concerns seriously. The General Data Protection Regulation, which we fought for in this House five years ago, has taken this up. We were opposed to rejection and ignorance. I remember exactly the moment when a colleague responded to my claim that we could set global standards with our law whether I would really believe that. In the meantime, development observers — such as the Washington Post recently — come to the conclusion that the future of Facebook in Europe would be decided. What does that mean? This means that Europe is capable of action — it just needs to have the will to do so. But most importantly, the nation states must not constantly try to scatter sand in the transmission. However, it is not enough to rest on the laurels. That is why the Council no longer blocks the ePrivacy Regulation, which is necessary to complete the whole thing, which has already been adopted for us, and that the Member States will finally be able to improve data protection. implement it without gaps.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Mr President! I wanted to point out that the participants in this scandal, this event are flipping with responsibility. Cambridge Analytica says Facebook, Facebook, that Cambridge university is responsible. The University of Cambridge says it's an Alexander Kogan case, and this researcher says it's the users' fault. It seems to me that everyone has wrapped up in this case, because we are concentrating here, dear Colleagues, only on Facebook, while the fault and, of course, the scale of blame varies. Facebook has known about the problematic business of Cambridge Analytica and other apps since 2006, and will only now conduct an audit. But others decided to turn a blind eye to what academic research was for — the Cambridge Psychometrics Centre research, for example, did not go through the procedure for getting approval from the University Ethics Commission. Moreover, users were also passing on their friends' data, and so not only the regulations imposed on digital platforms are needed. There needs to be a thought on the mechanism for control over scientific research and education of the public is also needed.

name: Eva JOLY
text: — Mr President, on 25 May, the new European data protection rules come into force, accompanied by sanctions worthy of the name. Facebook and other internet giants must understand that our consent to the collection of our data is not negotiable, nor is our privacy for sale. The boss of Facebook must come and explain himself to the European Parliament. Mark Zuckerberg owes us something other than mere apologies or vague announcements. It owes us guarantees as to the processing of our data and greater transparency about the origin of advertising for political purposes. Once again, it was thanks to a whistleblower, Christopher Wylie, that this scandal was unveiled and citizens were informed. Yesterday, it was an old Cambridge Analytica framework that revealed that the number of abused users would be much higher than announced. Let's protect whistleblowers, protect personal data, protect all those, all things that make our democracies breathe.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Mr President, it is now clear that the Democratic Unionist Party used a data-mining company, Analytica IQ, during the Brexit campaign, abusing the privacy of tens of thousands of Facebook users. The company has been called the backroom operation of Cambridge Analytica, the same outfit who helped elect Trump. Because it is based in Canada, Analytica IQ wasn’t subject to the same electoral laws during the referendum. The Open Democracy website has found links between the companies and the Tories, the British military, the DUP and even Russian oligarchs. This isn’t the first time that the DUP has played fast and loose with the law to pursue their dangerous pro-Brexit agenda. The DUP took almost half a million pounds in dark money from a secret source to manipulate opinion in London, where they have zero votes and zero seats, and they then ensured that the transparency law that was not back-dated to expose their seedy deals. Mr President, I just want to say that the DUP has no respect for rights, no respect for privacy and absolutely no regard for the damage that their reckless Brexit agenda is doing in Ireland.

name: Viviane REDING
text: – Mr President, trust is a must. It takes years to build, but only seconds to lose. Sadly, tech giants learned this lesson the hard way – the latest example being the Cambridge Analytica scandal. Fortunately, we Europeans decided on the right laws to bring back trust. Who wants to be part of a global community where algorithms know what you are better than you, than your family, than your friends? Where someone can spy on you anywhere – at work, at home on the streets? Where your political preferences can be matched to the highest bidder? Where you are a product being sold without your consent?
