Nine in ten Europeans want none of this, and that is exactly why we adopted the General Data Protection Regulation – to put citizens back in control of their own data; to ensure a stronger enforcement and high fines for companies which do not comply; to set data protection standards worldwide.  Six years ago, lobbyists and national governments tried to stop the proposal I had put on the table for a general data protection regulation, and today they agree it is an indispensable piece of legislation: the internet was designed for the people by the people, and that is what it has to stay.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, the scandal we are discussing today with Cambridge Analytica and Facebook reminds me, in a number of respects, of the other scandal that we have already had to deal with this legislature: the diesel gate scandal. The comparisons are a large multinational that is in a scandalous way damaging the trust of Europeans and other people in the world. That we are talking about powerful multinationals, that is clear. It's about millions of data that also makes billions. You can see it very well: in 2006, the five most important, largest and powerful companies were all energy and oil companies. And today — I don't know if that's a good evolution, probably a little — it's the Big Five, the big data and internet companies. That is a bit of the point I want to make extra in addition to the justified plea for e-privacy and the justified pride we can feel for our own regulations, but we also need to look at it more broadly. It is about something that has a very big and profound impact on our society, it is about companies that do not pay taxes, or hardly pay taxes today, and that too must become part of the solution when we look at this scandal.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. The scandal we are discussing today is making waves in public. But the waves are far from high enough. This is due to the fact that many citizens still do not realise how extensive the actual data provided by their user behaviour to Internet groups, social media, and what is done with this data. And I think we have to start with that. We need to make citizens much clearer about how much this data is being used and what amount of data about individuals is actually simply collected from user behaviour. We can only achieve this by imposing it on Internet groups, social media, to regularly inform each user of what data is stored for these users. This must be a standard matter for each user to regularly take note of what is stored by him at these groups. And it should also be documented the benefits that the groups derive from this and to which companies it is sold. That's why I can only say: the words have changed enough, let me now finally see action!

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. More than two billion people worldwide use Facebook, 400 million people in Europe. This company has become a global platform for communication, information and even political election campaigns. In other words, Facebook is the infrastructure of today's democratic public. And as is the case with any form of infrastructure, the person who builds it and defines the rules also has the power over who benefits it most. If the state builds a road, then it stipulates that all cars on it are allowed to drive at the same speed. When Facebook changes its algorithm, it often decides that certain content gets more attention than others. In the information society, knowledge is a power, in the algorithmic information society, digital infrastructure is power because digital infrastructure can favour or disadvantage knowledge. It is therefore a question of democratic society deciding on the rules by which the infrastructure of our information society works. We therefore need European digital supervision in parallel with European banking supervision. And you, Commissioner, can present this proposal and thus give back control to the citizens.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: Mr President! Facebook is, in many ways, a great digital, social network where you can stay connected to family, friends and old colleagues. But Facebook is also a huge company with a business model that to that extent challenges our society. When you're not paying with money for access to Facebook, it's because you're paying with a different currency. In Facebook's case, you're the product and the currency is all your personal data. Facebook has gained such a large scale today that it is not only a problem for our privacy, but also a huge challenge to our democracy. Data is collected to an extent that allows even our preference in a general election to be predicted. And can it be predicted, it can also be affected. Our society and our democracy suffer from the way of doing business. The EU should take on the monopoly status and position Facebook has been given both to protect citizens' personal data, but also to protect our democracy.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, the line between online and offline is blurring, so we need to be particularly alert to the use of personal data. Facebook has rightly come under attack, because a questionnaire from Cambridge Analytica collected personal data. But not only from the fillers who had given permission to do so, but also from their Facebook friends, the data were taken and they knew nothing about it. In the Netherlands it became known last week that healthcare companies use a Facebook pixel to share sensitive information with Facebook. That is why I am pleased that new European legislation will enter into force next month. In this case, personal data can only be used with the consent of the individuals, and then enforcement is crucial by European authorities and by the Dutch authorities. Furthermore, I believe that the Commission must face its arrogant contempt for this Parliament and reinstate the procedure for appointing a new Secretary-General.

name: Julia REDA
text: – Mr President, one aspect I am missing so far in this debate is that the Facebook scandal is also a scandal of secrecy. We must demand more transparency about data breaches on the one hand, but more generally about how personalised algorithms work and who is served which customised messages on whose behalf. In a world where information flows are now so personalised that we no longer really have one shared reality, we must make it understandable and investigate how information is spread and who is spreading it. As we debate regulatory responses to the scandal, here is my proposal: let us regulate advertising targeting. There is an arms race in the industry to collect ever more data, to create ever more precise psychological profiles of users and to move ever closer to outright manipulation – just to secure advertising revenues. Let’s end this arms race and return a share of the advertising market to those whose business model is not based on invading our privacy.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The truth is that we are consumers either of commercial things or politics so, therefore, you know we have to buy it.

name: Agustín DÍAZ DE MERA GARCÍA CONSUEGRA
text: Mr President, trade or misuse of data mining is causing serious effects on electoral procedures; they allow both the mass collection of confidential information from the electorate and the distribution of false news generated to attract and misinform. Measures must be taken in the Union to curb the misuse of data mining and the proliferation of fake news. It is not a question of restricting the right to freedom of expression, but a responsible use of the media so that society is properly informed without being manipulated. If it is not the Commission, it must be the States to take the legislative initiative, since Articles 74 and 76 of the Treaty on Union allow this to do so. Misuse of metadata is a challenge for both democracy and cybersecurity. Public and private actors need to coordinate their actions in order to avoid cases such as those we denounce, strengthening cooperation and research. The launch of the cybersecurity package last September is the good route. The creation of the European cybersecurity agency must be promoted and resources should be provided to those who are already in charge of it, which is Europol's EC3. Regularization, user awareness, prevention, cooperation and good use of the media is what is necessary to avoid cases such as Cambridge Analytica and Facebook. Read, ladies and gentlemen, the IOCTA report of Europol EC3, which is speaking... (the President withdraws the floor).

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the case of Cambridge Analytica and Facebook shows that public views are increasingly being influenced through citizens' profiling and sponsorship of more or less fake network news, so as to favor parties and political leanings and manipulate citizens in the expression of the vote. This happened in Europe. Cambridge Analytica has been involved in the UK referendum, in the French election campaign and in the last Italian general election, in spite of our own, to the discreet success of its clients. Commissioner, this is not the time for timid answers: at stake is democracy, there is our Europe. I think it is necessary then to initiate, as soon as possible, legislative measures that result in greater responsibility for platforms, checking the truthfulness of accounts, in the transparency of data transactions. The next European elections are upon us, we do not leave free ground for those forces which, thanks to the illicit use of data, have consolidated their consent. (The speaker of answering a question 'blue card' (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. — (beginning of occurrence outside the microphone)... You're the new legislation on this. I wanted to ask you what specific ideas you have for settling this through the legislature. Don't you see the problem that whatever bill is issued is someone can illegally release that data? We already have a law that forbids it and it doesn't help anything. There will always be people who break them. The appointment of additional agencies and even greater surveillance of the state on the internet is even more dangerous than manipulations by private companies because private companies do not have the police and military and the states have. So governments are a much more dangerous body that meddles with internet data than Facebook, which is why I abide by the Lord not to demand the meddling of officials even more in the freedom of citizens on the internet.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: answer to a question “blue card”. — Thank you for the question, which allows me to expand a speech I attempted to make of my speech. I think there is a need for greater accountability of platforms. Platforms have always been considered simple intermediaries; they have responsibilities, they have to verify the people behind the accounts, which are very often fake, often computers that respond, operate, and generate fake news in the network. I think it is necessary to know who pays and who buys data from platforms and why it is used. Behind all this there is no control of the state; there is freedom and protection of democracy on our continent.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Maybe a solution would be to accept Facebook only if it is connected to typewriters?

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Dear Chairman, illegal data acquisition and invasion of internet user privacy are an important challenge of modern times, which we must address with better legislation, raising awareness of citizens and drastic punishment of all actors involved in this unacceptable practice. More than 80% of European households have internet access and is regularly used by 71% of citizens. Often and not knowing, they expose themselves to numerous predators and security threats. As a responsible legislator we must do everything to reduce that risk. But if we really want to be responsible, let's stop fooling ourselves and others first. Brexit and Trump's victory didn't happen because of Facebook and Cambridge Analytica, as well as because of Russian hackers. They happened because politics neglected citizens and their interests and desires. I hope that protecting citizens from electoral manipulation will not mean censoring unscrupulous political actors and making the election match more difficult. It would threaten our democracy much more than the unfair practices we want to stop.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Mr President, as democrats, we need to recognise the true seriousness of this situation. Our democracies are being stolen by companies who use psychological techniques designed for situations of military conflict to sow division in our societies and distort electoral outcomes to the benefit of the rich and powerful. Those who think that the naive arguments for freedom of speech are sufficient imagine the media landscape as a fairy tale world of Hansel and Gretel, but the Cambridge Analytica scandal shows us that the forest is full of wolves. For many online today, the distinction between fake news and genuine news is increasingly blurred, and this plays into the hands of those who wish to consolidate power. As Hannah Arendt said, ‘The ideal subject of totalitarian rule is not the convinced Nazi or the convinced Communist, but people for whom the distinction between fact and fiction and the distinction between true and false no longer exist’.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: Mr President, Facebook is suddenly a fan of European data protection rules. The wonders haven't finished the world yet. But it took a major scandal in which data from millions of European users ended up in a shameful way at a shadowy company called Cambridge Analytica and used in political campaigns, without these people having given their consent and without having to they knew about it at all. Facebook was aware of it, but he kept his mouth shut for two years. Actually, that's not surprising, because I took another look at Facebook's reaction to these new rules from Europe about six years ago and they said very clearly: “We should have focused on encouraging best practices by companies like Facebook rather than on setting out detailed rules that may be frustrating and costly. Overly prescriptive provisions on consent have an adverse effect on user experience. An overly prescriptive nature of regulation on data-based notification creates a level of bureaucracy that only distracts”. That's Facebook as we know it. Not too much hassle, not too many rules, good money. But now Mark Zuckerberg has said sorry and had a wonderful advertisement placed in European newspapers in which he advertises the same rules. And now we have to believe him on his blue eyes. I don't believe it. This knee fall is too little, too late. Mark Zuckerberg has to come here, in the EU, in this house and I expect the European regulators to apply the new rules that Facebook is a fan of from day one and very hard on that company.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: — Jekk xi ħadd qatt kellu xi dubju dwar is-sigurty tad-data tagħna online, issa għandna l-konferma li hemm kumpaniji li qegħdin jiġbru u jbiegħu l-informazzjoni tagħna lil organizazzjonijiet different. F'pajjiżi, F'Malta, 90% taċ-ċittadini jużaw is-social media, 6,000 minna kienu fil-mira, imma ma kinux il-maltin biss. Madwar 2,7 miljun ċittadin Ewropew huma maħsuba li sfaw vittmi. Għalhekk li qegħdin nitolbu lilek, Kummissarju, u Lill-kummissjoni Ewropea biex tkunu b'saħħitkom u tesiġu responsti ċari u direct minn Facebook u Cambridge Analytica. ir-regulations dwar il-protezzjoni ġenerali tad-data, iva, huma pass tajjeb, iżda mhumiex biżżejjed f'każ bħal dan għaliex hawnhekk qegħdin nitkellmu dwar il-protection tal-komunikazzjoni personal u l-privacy online. Għal każijiet bħal dawn irid ikollna R-regulament dwar il-privacy Electronika (L-ePrivacy Regulation). L-appell tiegħi Lill-kunsill, Lill-istati Members: Din hija kwistjoni urġenti. Taslux għal pożizzjoni dgħajfa li tkun ta' vantaġġ biss għall-kumpaniji l-kbar. Hija r-responsibility tagħkom li żżommu dan ir-regolament b'saħħtu għall-benefiċċju taċ-ċittadini li tirrappreżentaw u li suppost tridu tipproteġu.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: — Mr President, the large volumes of data can be oil from the century. XXI, but between the black gold of the last century and the information we share online nowadays there is a fundamental difference. When we talk about data protection and privacy, we are not talking about a resource, but a fundamental right of European citizens. A right protected by the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the constitutions of several Member States. Cambrige Analytica's criminal access to private information from Facebook users is an attack on the fundamental right to data protection of European citizens who have seen their privacy violated. If it is serious, in absolute terms, in each of the almost three million cases in Europe, it becomes even more serious when we look at the potential consequences. When we know that the figures of one million and one hundred thousand British have been violated and used to design the campaign by Brexit, in which the 'leave' won by little more than that, we can only draw worrying conclusions. If this was the case and if the most important decision of the last decades of European integration has been influenced by a crime, this is an attack on the rule of law. That is why Facebook owes this Parliament an explanation. That is why the Commission cannot fail to act. And that is why citizens cannot ignore their rights, which will be strengthened with the entry into force of the General Data Protection Regulation. (The speaker agrees to answer a question 'blue card' (Rule 162 (8))).

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card issue. — It is a wonderful thing that there is such a broad consensus in the European Parliament to tackle this issue, and I am very pleased with Commissioner Jourová, who, for example, cited algorithms as one factor in the spread of fake news. I would ask you that you are willing to increase the transparency of algorithms because they are trade secrets. After all, they definitely run into the very interests of hard business and the public.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: Answer according to the 'blue card' procedure. — Thank you very much for your question. Let's be clear, we cannot go back to the last century and it is clear that information is power and that information with rules can be business. I'm not against that. What I'm against is the use of personal data without permission from people. Each of us owns your data and that is what is important to safeguard. We have European legislation that is going to come into force, we must ensure that all those who intervene on the European market comply with that legislation.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the resounding Facebook and Cambridge Analytica case reveals a few things. The first is the unacceptability of business models that are parasitic and pervasive together, based on the acquisition of personal data, sold or advertised to marketing firms to influence elections, as has been the case, it has been said, in the case of Brexit, in the USA and Italy. I would like to remind you that 200 000 Italian names were the subject of a complaint by the Italian Privacy Supervisor. Well, that seventy years after the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, Europe today is on the frontier of digital human rights, with a regulation that honours us. But it does need consistency. First, we need the e-privacy regulation. Secondly, I believe that there is a need, from all accounts, to have a greater courage in defining the responsibilities of social platformers also with regard to content of hate and incitement, incitement sometimes suicide — and I think of bullying — and also of all that absolute abuse of power and dominance that you also have towards other areas. Thirdly, greater cooperation between the European authorities, which should be facilitated for the Commission, those which protect data, consumers and competition, should be seen in a much more integrated vision.

name: Michał BONI
text: - Madam President! The Cambridge Analytica and Facebook scandal could be a lesson in fiasco and loss of reputation, or it could become an opportunity lesson. What chance? Never before has this scale been talked about protecting privacy on the internet — that it is important for everyone to give up an uneasy responsibility for managing their own data, that we will help three million affected Europeans. Never before has it been emphasised with such respect as the Data Protection Regulation, harmonising at European level privacy rules, giving users a key tool, to agree to the processing of data. Although the implementation of these rules will only be assessed in a few months, the European Privacy Legislation has never been said before as a reference for the whole world. Never before has there been such pressure for advertising on the Web to have clear and hard rules, particularly when it involves political promotion, so as not to implicate the internet in the dark sides of a political struggle — especially not to manipulate elections and fund them in opaque ways. Never before has platforms been so strongly required to review the responsibility of content posted there, data use and microarray. What will this chance bring? It will reinforce the most valuable value for the development of the internet — trust — provided that everything we say today is implemented with iron consistency. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: blue-card question. – Mr Boni, you said about how this is an opportunity as well. Obviously, we are horrified with what happened with Cambridge Analytica – especially being a British MEP in the aftermath of Brexit and what this means we will be looking into. But you said something important about how we can look at our personal responsibility, and one of the things I have been working on with public libraries is the role public libraries can have in helping our citizens know about how to protect their own personal data. I draw the House’s attention to the work of the Carnegie trust on this. Mr Boni, would you agree with me that public libraries can provide us with a tool, a neutral public space where we can get people to understand about their privacy and about their data?

name: Michał BONI
text: answer to the question posed by picking up the blue card. — Thank you very much for this question. I think that the entry into force of the Data Protection Regulation is a great opportunity for us to learn awareness of the management of our own data, because we say so colloquially, “we will agree and this will solve the problem.” It's not going to be so easy because it's going to require us to realize what benefits we might lose by not agreeing to certain things. And a whole network of public institutions including libraries that can play a great role in building such digital awareness should be included in this.

name: Dan NICA
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, today we know that there are 2.7 million European citizens whose data has been used fraudulently. What worries us very much is that we are far from what some colleagues mistakenly called the “tip of the iceberg”, for a very simple reason: because this data comes from only one developer — Cambridge Analytica — and is still to be communicated by Facebook data from other developers, to find out how many millions of other data have been used incorrectly and, above all, very worrying, what happened to the data of those who are not Facebook users and to whom the data was also collected. So I think that you, Commissioner, have a big obligation, namely to tell European citizens what happened to the data that was stolen from them, so that data used incorrectly, whether it was deleted and where it is, and secondly, whether the elections of the year future, Commissioner, will be conducted correctly - elections to the European Parliament. And I want to know that what happened in Romania in the 2014 presidential elections will not happen next year in my country and that elections in general in the European Union will be held freely, correctly and far from this evil influence of psychometry promoted by Cambridge Analytica and Facebook... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: Madam President, Commissioner. From this point in the European Parliament, I turn to you, Mr Zuckerberg, who, with your fundamentally very positive platform Facebook, you are once again creating the most serious problems for the people of Europe and around the world. “Again” because you have not dealt responsibly with hate postings and terrorist postings in the past. The case of Cambridge Analytica shows the negative consequences of this abuse. I believe it is evident: Mr Zuckerberg, you have a duty, and we in politics must protect the millions and millions of people who can become victims of targeted actions, the background of which they themselves do not recognise, because you are in possession of the psychological profiles of people of a quality that people often themselves do not know. It poses enormous risks right to electoral manipulation. And I believe that next year's European elections are showing a danger: if Facebook allows Cambridge Analytica, then the Russian secret service will also be able to commit these abusive crimes. Therefore, turn yourself in to the European Parliament. Come and answer our questions — now!

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: — Mr President, the abuse of Facebook data requires a strong response in terms of rules and ethics. The example of data protection shows that the European Union wins when it anticipates. When we are pioneers we can lead and this is an opportunity to recover a relevant voice in digital globalization, with a strong technological commitment and a differentiation by values, affirming our own, ethical, fair and reliable digital identity. Differentiation by values and translation in legal and technological solutions is the way I propose to respond to the challenge we face. The protection of citizens' rights and democratic transparency are part of our shared values matrix. Therefore, we must demand that platforms operating in the European market include in their models and algorithms the shared values that shape the European digital identity. The data debate has alerted a greater number of European citizens to this issue. Convincing technological and political responses are needed. It is time to value European digital identity.

name: Geoffroy DIDIER
text: — Madam President, with more than two billion people registered worldwide, Facebook is the most extensive database that has ever existed. The current situation is clear: our privacy, our personal data, our virtual privacy no longer belong to us. They have become de facto property of a few companies that take advantage of this data to use this data for commercial purposes. We are no longer just consumers, we have become products for sale. I have referred the European Commission to have Cambridge Analytica and Facebook sanctioned financially. I am aware that the new legislation on the protection of personal data is a first step, beneficial and necessary, but it is not enough. I therefore propose that we go further by requiring, first of all, of these platforms that they can no longer use the data for commercial purposes but that they can no longer collect, store, and retain such personal data in a sustainable manner. Platforms are certainly the vehicles of this data, that is the rule of the game, but there is no reason why they become the operators, let alone the owners. I propose to you, I suggest that we set our own personal frontier today because tomorrow it will be too late.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: – Madam President, there is some good news in this situation: that we have implemented GDPR and are going to be leading the world forward in protecting people’s fundamental rights: their data, their privacy. Facebook has failed us miserably, has failed the whole world miserably, and we need to bring in Mark Zuckerberg here at the European Parliament to answer very serious questions as soon as possible.  We are worried what happened with Brexit. Was it Facebook’s fault? These are very important questions to be urgently answered by Facebook. Cambridge Analytica, and perhaps others, are cooperating and using our data to work against our interests. This is very important, so we should be very stringent. We should keep analysing and doing everything we can to stop fake news and to stop leakage of our data for fake news to be empowered to change election results and to destroy our democracy. Let’s be vigilant, let’s be brave, and let’s make this happen.

name: Nuno MELO
text: Madam President, Facebook is not just an American company. It operates in the world market, many thousands of users, not to say millions, are Europeans, it is really a global company. To that extent, Mark Zuckerberg does not just owe an explanation to the US Congress. You owe the European Parliament an explanation. To say that only adheres to Facebook who wants is, at least, ridiculous, when not, the worst argument because Facebook actually has no competition, gives no alternative. It would be more or less like saying there's only electricity in the house who wants it. Obviously, people need electricity and the media on a global scale are inevitability today and this scandal is of a seriousness that cannot be solved with a simple apology. The use and manipulation of personal data for the attainment of political objectives without conscientious permission of those concerned is inadmissible in a democratic state and a rule of law. To that extent, the confession of using the data of 87 million Facebook users, but not just Facebook, to influence campaigns around the world, simply cannot happen. It cannot happen in the United States of America, it certainly cannot happen in Europe. And we, who are politicians, and we who are going to vote in 2019, are the first to ensure that this does not happen again.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, great commercial power must come with great responsibility, since platforms like Facebook deal with people, not goods. In Europe we stand up for the highest standards of civil liberties. Access to and use of personal data must be transparent and follow our privacy rules. Red lines are crossed when it affects our democracy, influencing elections and spreading fake news. The time has come for platforms to take responsibility for the content published by users – in particular concerning children, privacy and safety. As the Facebook and Google child summit is under way right now, as a co—chair of the Intergroup on Children’s Rights, I reiterate my call to the ICT community to invest more in finding innovative solutions to protect children online. I welcome the new measures on parental control but, to be effective, age verification tools must be put in place. Much is done to combat child sexual abuse online, but much more needs to be done. An entire generation of young people is affected by hate speech and cyber bullying. A girl victim of revenge pornography or sex extortion must be able to have her pictures taken down. These crimes can lead children to commit self-harm and suicide. Much more also needs to be done urgently to prevent young people from being radicalised and recruited by terrorists on social media.  I call on platforms to strengthen the reporting of abuse, speed up the removal of illegal content and increase cooperation with law enforcement authorities. I support President Tajani’s call to Mark Zuckerberg for a hearing with Parliament to tell us what Facebook is up to.  (Applause)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, the issue of leaking personal data from Facebook may paradoxically have helped to make people look up and realise that they also have more responsibility, but also to the state and The European Union. Given the effect social networks have on people's thinking, there is a great risk to our democracy and free decision-making. I see as a very serious problem the abuse of data for disinformation campaigns especially by Russia, but also other states that influence the results of elections and political events in Western countries and in the EU. But this cannot be taken lightly and needs to be strengthened by the EU institutions dealing with this. For example, StratCom, with its 1.5 million euro budget and a small team of people, cannot counter the disinformation industry that supports Russia. So I am very grateful that President Tajani invited Mark Zuckerberg to the European Parliament. He should come out here and convey what he will do against allowing Facebook users' data abuse to happen again. The European Union, our citizens have more accounts than the United States, so it is in place to explain here what the next steps will be. It is also right, Commissioner, that you negotiate with Facebook and lead this company to more accountable and to take clear action.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, thank you very much for giving me the opportunity to speak, as I was the PPE rapporteur for the Data Protection Regulation. I worked on it for three years and it is now coming into operation on 25 May. Indeed, in some respects, this scandal is timely, because it brings people’s attention to it. Secondly, two weeks ago I was part of a seven-strong delegation of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) to Silicon Valley, where Facebook met us at short notice and we discussed this very topic. They outlined to us what happened and what they are doing to ensure that such a scandal won’t happen in the future. We also reiterated President Tajani’s request to them for their CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, to come to the European Parliament. I think he should come, if only for the fact that they have 50% more clients in Europe than in the USA – 364 million in Europe, 239 million in the USA plus Canada – and also to show us what they’re doing regarding apps, algorithms, authentication, an independent commission, etc. Finally, I just want to say that their headquarters in Europe are in Ireland, and the government in Ireland are giving far more resources to ensure the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is properly monitored in the European Union.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, the very first day the whole scandal came out, the European Data Protection Supervisor told us, the committee members: ‘it’s much bigger than you know’. And it was. It’s about fundamental rights, privacy awareness, but privacy enforcement as well: namely, the right to be forgotten, enshrined by the GDPR. But it is also about democracy, because fake news is a hybrid war of intoxication, manipulation, lies and hate speech aimed to weaken democracy through interfering in elections and enhancing populism and Europhobia. So it takes a European response, which means that no Member State can do it on its own before a giant in the internet, like Facebook, but also legal, binding and effective law. But it takes action. That means that doing nothing is not a choice. That is what the European citizens are expecting from all of us, and that is precisely and exactly what we ask from you. The European Commission must take initiative: action and now.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, I think there is a high degree of consensus in this House, which is rare, but I think that the issue requires that to be the case. I think that clearly there are systemic issues related to data protection. Clearly there are criminal issues which concern Facebook ethically, but there is also a question of a business model. But one element, while it has been mentioned, did not dominate today’s debate, and I think it is absolutely crucial, because the very fundamentals of our democracy might have been affected. This is the engagement intervention into elections, most likely throughout EU Member States. I would say that this is serious and something that we need to know more about. I want to know more about who the clients were, what the business really entailed and, if we all want to know that, I think that we need to take measures to find out, as sensitive and explosive as it may be.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: — Madam President, where, how, when, who do you talk to, what do you think and who do you vote for? Facebook knows everything about our lives, desires and friendships. Because technology is not neutral: it controls, manipulates, spies behind the scenes of the world of social media. The Facebook data transfer scandal to Cambridge Analytica does not allow apologies from Facebook. It attacks democracy, against our fundamental right to data privacy, controlling the ideology of electoral propaganda and also controlling various peoples, such as the Palestinian people or the Kurdish people when Facebook is allowed to close certain portals and platforms. It is not acceptable for private information to be shared and, worse, sold. Intimacy as a business is a new form of power of this global capitalism, anti-democratic interference, and we Europeans and Europeans must not be silent.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: — Madam President, I think all the complaints have already been said and I will not repeat anything. Let's see what we can do. There are a lot of millions of Fake Profiles but I think these are the easiest to remove since, if you use the same method they use when you try to create an email address and ask you for a thousand data, then you won't be able to have a fake profile. Secondly, I want to be able to delete my account immediately, easily and be sure that there is nothing left in some other files. Thirdly, I must be able to erase a post and again be sure that this post does not live anywhere else and, last I have to say, I am surprised by our surprise, to be honest. Now we've learned that social media is being used by political forces and by money forces to influence citizens in elections? Of course, every limit of imagination has been exceeded here, but I think there is only one method and that the institutions, the laws and we can contribute to this in order to control this social network.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: — Madam President, one of the major side effects of digital technology is its ability to illegally interfere in people's private lives on the Internet and thereby violate their individual rights. The Cambridge Analytica scandal has shown that Facebook user data can be used for economic, commercial and mainly political reasons. The situation becomes even more complex and serious when these elements become the property of terrorists and secret services. I would remind you that, about two years ago, the CIA officially thanked Facebook users for their posts giving it such and so much information that in order to obtain it, it would have had to pay for a long time a large number of agents. Of course, the States are making every effort to protect citizens, but we have a large share of responsibility and we must be careful of what we post and, above all, where we give our personal data.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President! So that there is no doubt — I will immediately say that I am and a user, and a supporter of Facebook, Twitter, as much as a mobile phone. These are the prey of civilization — it's hard not to use them. Whereas I am far from such naivety that also appears in this room — that they are tools that serve only good. They are also instruments — in short — of surveillance. I do not believe in any legal regulation that will protect one hundred percent of personal data, the interest of the individual user. But does that mean we should give up? Definitely not. Whereas what is relevant to me? Without trusting enthusiasts, naive people who look online and into these tools only and exclusively through the prism of benefits, I will say that what is crucial today is to build the right hierarchy of goals: physical safety, life safety and health of children, as well as protection institutions of law, including the election itself. We should protect those values in the first place.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after the Cambridge Analytica scandal, the American Congress listened to the CEO of Facebook on new rights at the time of the Internet and we must give note of the American administration to have treated the Cambridge Analytica scandal with the necessary seriousness and urgency. But there is a need to put a twist on the relationship between the legislature and the new media, returning to taking a leading role in areas often considered untouchable. During the hearings Europe was cited as a virtuous example, as a fair balance between freedom of business and the protection of personal data. In just over a month, the new GDPR will come into force, a general privacy regulation resulting from years of work and compromise, finally able to respond to the needs of transparency, comprehensibility and control in the use of personal data of all citizens. But if Europe is setting the course for the future of internet privacy, it is crucial and appropriate for Facebook to report to this Parliament, in the European Parliament, and should they be ascertained Major interference in elections also to the governments of the Member States directly involved.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: — Madam President, of course, this is a big scandal, a serious misuse of data, but the example of Facebook is just the tip of the iceberg, actually just an open Pandora's Ark, which showed simply on what powerful power these digital platforms have, how they can actually greatly influence social events , including to the polls. And actually, how can they direct democratic processes and democracy alone, and in fact they can create a so-called virtual democracy that then we can only follow. And that is why it is necessary to limit this great power, so it is good that we also have this regulation on the protection of personal data. However, this Regulation cannot, in itself, replace the so-called business ethics and, of course, the social responsibilities of undertakings. Therefore, of course, appropriate and appropriate sanctions are necessary, and also in this case it is absolutely necessary to react accordingly in this area.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, the bottom line is that Facebook, or any similar company, should not be able to sell our data. The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is an excellent start. An area like this is a perfect example of where European countries in the European Union should work very closely together, more so than concentrating on creating a European army. Areas like this and food sovereignty are exactly what we should be doing.  When it comes to accountability, given the amount of customers – and who is the customer here? We’re the product obviously – we need Mr Zuckerberg to come before the relevant committees and to answer questions.  There are many, many positives to Facebook. When I think of Facebook, I think of it as a tool for democracy. I wouldn’t be here but for it. I wouldn’t have gotten canvassers together but for it. My work here would not be covered in my country but for Facebook, because I and many others are ignored by our national broadcaster. There are many positives. We need to focus on them, but we need to solve this big problem too.

name: John HOWARTH
text: – Madam President, I share the disgust of the public at the abuses by Cambridge Analytica and the proper false propaganda that was peddled during the 2016 referendum. I also share the disgust that many of these organisations exempt themselves for tax. There is a clear need for an inquiry in this place, and I support that call. But looking forward, it’s all very easy for politicians to bash the likes of Facebook, but the reality is we need new regulations and a new mind-set of the type Mr Giegold alluded to earlier. This is about people’s daily lives and their ability to shop, to go to the bank, to interact and to play, and if governments force people to do things like put their tax returns on line, we need to recognise that cyberspace is public space – it isn’t a techie elite any more – and public space needs regulation of behaviour in that space. It will not do simply to say that is too difficult: we need serious legislation that looks to the future.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Madam President, we live in a world where socialisation has become a must. We often hear the phrase “if you're not on Facebook, you don't exist” and young visitors watching our meeting today can confirm this. This expression, beyond its commercial purpose, has brought 370 million European users to the social media platform, one of them being myself, along with most of my colleagues in the room. We socialize. This is not a bad thing, but we must be sure that our personal data is protected by any company or institution that has access to it. I look forward to Mark Zuckerberg explaining to the European Parliament how Facebook has used European citizens' data in the context of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, and I believe that we Europeans deserve answers, just as we have seen also happened in the American Congress. Not only the American data has been taken or harmed and endangered, but also those of Europeans, and Zuckerberg needs to understand the importance of clarifying all aspects, not only on the American continent, but also in Europe. In these circumstances and until the emergence of a European social media platform to replace Facebook, as it appeared in the press, and in the potential of which... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Ana GOMES
text: — Madam President, with this scandal citizens wake up to the tremendous risks along with opportunities opened up by digital dependence on the economy and the entire current way of life, Facebook, big data, Internet of things, artificial intelligence, fundamental rights and genuine elections, security This time Europe is ahead with the GDPR, about to come into force and with global reach. The regulation on e-Privacy is delayed in the Council. Facebook, Cambridge Analytica, Palantir and other companies make money at the expense of our privacy and lend algorithms to more than claims, manipulation and social and political discrimination. They have Chinese and Russian competitors who care little today for a future nightmare. Breaking monopolies and preventing and sanctioning heavily perverse uses against citizens and democracy, making digital platforms and targeted advertising, paying taxes is more than European design: it is important to save democratic control and humanity in the globalized era. The Commission must act now.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, firstly, it is very good that we are discussing this issue here. I think we need to treat him realistically. There is not one party responsible here. It is not only the Commission that can resolve, not only the national authorities, for sure, and us citizens. But I ask myself: what do we expect the Facebook director to tell us, when he said it very serenely in the American Congress: “OK, I created Facebook, but I didn't make any protection systems, and even my data is taken.” We're in the age of digitalization We sell on the Internet. When we place conditions in the internal market, to have the safety of the product or service we purchase, why can't we also require these platforms and these major Internet operators to ensure that they do not sell and protect their personal data? And if they do not, and it happens as it has happened now, let it be a very high percentage of turnover, let's get them to respect the rules not only of ethics, but also of safety, because here we are talking about democracy, about undermining democracy.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: — Madam President, I am an IT engineer and I have asked in my social democratic group for a special committee for this case. I did not get it, but I did get Mr Zuckerberg's invitation from the four committees to come to plenary. You have to come and you have to give explanations, but until then I challenge you. Yesterday, Facebook was announcing that over 50 applications use my personal data, some lost their right, others were still using it. I deleted them all, I erased their right to use that data, but Facebook, also Facebook, late, was letting me know that these companies might have passed on that data. I'm also going to ask those companies to tell me who they gave the data and delete me from their database. But this is what I will do after 25 May, because after 25 May the GDPR comes into force, this GDPR that is now being praised worldwide and which gives me the right to be forgotten. I encourage you to do the same, but I also encourage you, Commissioner, to send us the list of companies that have done the same thing as Facebook, who have done like Cambridge Analytica, and to go on the line to those who have used this data unfairly.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, this debate clearly shows that we are on the same page with the conviction that we do not want to have this in Europe and that we do not want to continue such practices or allow such practices to continue. We have the obligation to do everything possible to stop such practices which we see in this Facebook-Cambridge Analytica scandal.  We don’t want Europeans to be an easy-to-manipulate crowd. We want Europeans to be people who are responsible in regard to their private data and who deserve protection. I myself removed my Facebook account two years ago. Many people, including my PR advisers, told me that ‘as a politician, you will be dead without Facebook’. I’m still quite alive.  However, there are many people in this hall and also in the audience, and I am sure that the majority of young people here are on Facebook. Again, it’s our obligation to protect them and to invite them to protect themselves, to understand why the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is here and what the new rights are that they will enjoy after 25 May 2018.  I want to say a few words on how our work on this matter will continue now. We will have several inputs for continuation of the work. One thing that we will do is the analysis of where we are with regard to electoral law in the Member States. In other words, whether our Member States are equipped in their legislation against aggressive marketing, a method of targeted marketing which abuses the access to people’s private data. I am absolutely convinced that conducting marketing based on illegal practices, using abused or stolen data, must be illegal. However, we have to check where we are and whether the authorities are able to enforce the ban on this practice in all the Member States. We do not know yet.  Another input will be the results of the investigations which, are ongoing in Ireland and in the UK. There may be some more states launching the investigations later if it is revealed that this practice was used in more Member States.  Another very important input will be how the people approach this, whether the affected Europeans will raise their voices and say clearly that they do not want to be objects of manipulation. I expect quite an interesting debate, not only in the European Union, but also in the United States. If this case could be good for something, it would be opening the eyes of Americans as well, who are more relaxed about their privacy than Europeans. Another input for our continued work on this could be the opinion of the Heads of State, because it might be put on their tables at the May European Council. It’s not decided yet, but this is such a big deal that the Heads of State will want to discuss this.  Based on these inputs, the Commission will reflect on this case in the coming communication on fake news, and here I will have to disappoint everyone who thinks that we will come up with some kind of censorship. This is not what the Commission is planning. We want to come up with workable solutions to fight against disinformation in the EU, and it is very appropriate to include some lessons learned from this scandal in this paper.  We will reflect on this case in the Digital Single Market report, which will also come in May. We will deal with the issue of algorithms and communication focused on artificial intelligence, also to be adopted in spring this year. And, of course, we will take this as a lesson for the continued negotiations on e-privacy. This is all the work we have ahead of us. I will be fully available for continued debate with you in the European Parliament.  Let me thank you, to conclude, for a very interesting debate with many inspirational points. We will work with it, and I’m looking forward to future debates on this Facebook case and on other things related to the digital sphere.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I would like, first of all, to respond to the remarks made and questions raised by honourable Members during this lively debate.  Regarding the remarks made by Ms Rodrigues, Mr Albrecht and Mr Moraes concerning ePrivacy, I would like to say that this is a priority file for the Council as this is one of the key initiatives for enhancing trust and security in the digital single market. The Council supports its objective to ensure a high level of protection of privacy in electronic communication, and we have been working intensively in order to ensure solid progress on the file.  Considering the political and technical complexity of this file and the fact that it takes the form of a directly applicable regulation, it is clear that adequate time is needed for a detailed analysis of all the implications, keeping in mind the overall timeline for the adoption of the digital single market files. The Bulgarian Presidency is firmly committed to advancing the work towards the Council’s negotiating position, with a view to starting the trialogues with Parliament.  Concerning the accent put by Mr Díaz de Mera García Consuegra on a security act, and on ENISA in particular, I would like to say that we are continuing our work on the draft Cybersecurity Act. We are confident that we will be able to deliver on our promise to achieve a general approach in the Council in June, and to start the first trialogues in close cooperation with our colleagues and true partners from Austria. We are continuing our support to advance all aspects of the file in parallel, so that we can ensure the legal and business continuity of ENISA before the expiry of its current mandate in 2020.  In conclusion, I would like to say that the Facebook and Cambridge Analytica case is important both in terms of data protection, and in terms of fundamental issues such as the rule of law and the democratic process. We must develop democratic resilience, media literacy, tolerance and critical thinking, and this is key for fighting propaganda and manipulation through fake news, which threatens the very foundation of our societies. That is why I would also like to congratulate the Commission on its important step in this regard, namely its setting-up of a high—level expert group to counter fake news and the spread of disinformation online. As Ms Keller and Mr Didier said during the debate, it is our common duty and Ms Jourová has just confirmed that we are on the same page. So let us combine our institutional forces to ensure that the momentum for searching for balanced but effective solutions is kept high on the political agenda in the European Union and across the world. As I said during my intervention on 16 May in Sofia, the Heads of State and Government plan to discuss the need for social networks and digital platforms to guarantee transparent practices and full protection of citizens’ privacy and personal data. The Council will continue to follow this debate very closely, and I can assure Members that I paid particular attention to the views expressed here today during this debate.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. — If the Cambridge Analytica scandal is exceptional in its magnitude, with 87 million people involved, it must serve Europeans as a reminder bite. First of all because while in this period of collective hysteria around so-called populism or so-called “fake news”, mastincated with an anti-Trumpism which is based on the act of faith within the European institutions, it is necessary to have the honesty to recognise the generalisation of the exploitation of personal data for political or commercial purposes. It is indeed Barack Obama's campaign, with the application “Obama for America”, downloaded by about a million users, that inaugurated the micro-targeting technique on a large scale. Secondly, because this case broke out while Europe is lowering custody. For example, Facebook has just reintroduced a facial recognition application in Europe, despite its first launch stumbling on a decision by the Irish regulator in 2012. This new version already raises doubts about the collection of consent, although mandatory under Regulation 2016/679. Whether it is data respect or privacy, it is therefore worrying to see how clearly Europe is struggling to impose itself in the face of the giants of the Internet.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. — In connection with the Cambridge Analytica scandal, extremely serious irregularities and the most serious possible data theft acts have been revealed in connection with Facebook's activities. However, the matter that has come to light is only the tip of the iceberg. With regard to the operation of Facebook and other major international Internet companies, several problems arise and require a solution. Large international Internet companies make profits of billions of euros thanks to their online advertising market revenues, but they are exempting themselves from taxation and harming European taxpayers through tax evasion practices. These companies create a special online publicity without any regulations applying to them. Their responsibility for rectification and the procedure in which a person may be prohibited from using a particular Internet service is unclear. They operate media products without any regulations. Large international Internet companies handle the data of hundreds of millions of quasi-online Europeans without general European data protection and data security rules being applied in their operations, so their general data management activities are unregulated. The resolution and regulation of these three issues is urgent and very important for the protection of European citizens.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: in writing. — We must not only fully investigate and consider the scale of the Cambidge Analytica and Facebook scandal and the possible consequences for our political system and democratic processes, but also take a specific targeted response so that similar violations do not happen again in the future. We see that legal data protection so far has not ensured a proper relationship between the obligations and responsibilities of users of digital products and companies providing such services. Often, a general user's consent, which is not always obtained by the consumer's understanding of its content, should not become a pretext for irresponsible treatment of private user data when communicating them to third parties. I think we need to focus even more on the aspects of the data subject's consent. I believe that the General Data Protection Regulation of the European Union, which will enter into force in May, will provide a solid framework for the protection of all our data, ensure security and privacy, while strengthening democratic processes. However, we must not forget that, in the context of rapid technological development and globalisation, it is essential that data security and personal privacy become fundamental issues of the international agenda. In the future, it will be important to ensure proper implementation, supervision and, if necessary, strengthening the regulation.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. — In the context of the scandal erupted around Facebook companies - Cambridge Analytica, whereby data of 87 million Facebook users were illegally accessed by a British consultancy company for election purposes, we are today witnessing a series of extensive discussions on the protection of personal data that every Internet user makes available to the giants of social networks. These disclosures highlighted the need to protect personal data, all the more so that it, obtained illegally, can be used to strike society at its most sensitive points, whether it be manipulating citizens during the electoral process or influencing consumers in a sense that can lead to market distortion and fair competition. In this respect, through the entry into force of the European Data Protection Directive, the European Parliament is responding to the growing needs of the digital society to have a uniform regulation ensuring adequate protection of personal data. As an MEP, I welcome this decision and believe that this legislative package is indispensable in order to protect the integrity and personal lives of digital users. I also believe that it is necessary to strike a balance between market needs and personal data protection.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Krišjānis Kariņš and Judith Sargentini, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a European Parliament and Council directive amending Directive (EU) No 2015/849 on prevention of the use of the financial system for the purposes of money laundering or terrorist financing and Directive 2009/101/EC (COM (2016) 0450 - C8-0265/2016 - 2016/0208 (COD)) (A8-0056/2017).

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Rapporteur. — Dear sitting leader! Thieves love darkness. If someone imagines stealing an apartment, most likely, the person or those people will wait overnight, wait for the darkness, when they can go into your property without notice and pick up what they need. In a similar way, those people who want to launder illicit funds (I'm talking about so-called money launderers) also love such darkness, and their darkness in the financial world is called anonymity. If we want to take action against money laundering, money laundering in the European banking system, we must take action against that anonymity. And that, colleagues, is exactly what we've done in this directive. Here I must say thank you first of all Judith Sargentini for very good cooperation over several years both on the development of the Fourth Directive and on the development of the Fifth Directive. Similarly, the other colleagues with whom I have had the honour and pleasure to work together, of course, also the Council of the EU, the representatives of the Member States, with whom we have come to a good result in a rather long and sufficiently complex process. And what, then, is the basis of this result? We have developed a number of, one might say, weapons that will help in law prevent the risk of money laundering in Europe's financial banking sector. First, we have a register of true beneficiaries, where the names of the persons of the owners of the firms are presented, the surnames of which are identified, who stands behind which company, and this register will be fully public in the future. Similarly, we have established a register of true beneficiaries affecting trust owners. We also have a register of bank account holders within the European Union, as well as a bank safe deposit box holder register within the European Union. All this is aimed at getting banks to know who their clients are, so that the journalist and the public can track who stands behind which company to be able to make sure that the cash flows passing through European banks are legal cash flows, that this is not money, which including could be used to finance terrorism. In this Directive, we have envisaged one innovation that is being trialled for the first time in Europe: it is the regulation that affects cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin and other popular cryptocurrencies. What's the challenge? The challenge that these currencies, which only exist in the internet environment, are by their own definition completely anonymous. And how can it be dealt with, because of course criminal criminals can also use this system to finance terrorism, among other things. It has been developed that a provider who helps to convert bitcoin or other cryptocurrencies into a euro currency, purchase real estate or otherwise dispose of it within the European Union is subject to the same requirements as banking representatives — to know what their client, and make sure that this money, the origin of this cryptocurrency is truly legal, that it can not be used to anonymously fund terrorism. So in Europe, if we have a challenge in the fight against terrorism, if we have a challenge in the fight against money laundering, our medicine is the fight against anonymity. This is what we have implemented very successfully in this Directive. Let's support, colleagues, tomorrow's vote on the new Directive against money laundering!

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: rapporteur. — (NL) Mr President, tomorrow's vote will conclude a long negotiation. For the second time in a few years, we are tightening up the law against money laundering, terrorist financing and tax evasion and evasion. And that was necessary. Just after Mr Kariņš and I finished the fourth directive by Christmas 2014, an attack took place in Paris, the attack on Charlie Hebdo's offices. Then came the Panama Papers and they showed one more time how companies and individuals are making money away from the tax authorities. Every year, society goes missing billions because criminals are channelling money illegally or in an unclear way through a chain of companies and trusts. With these new rules, we are tackling the practice that people hide their assets in a shady way from investigating services and the tax authorities. We see criminals getting smarter over and over again and using other ways to launder money or finance terrorism, such as virtual currencies like bitcoins and anonymous prepaid cards. Tax constructions that may, according to the law, may well be able to the letter of the law, but are morally unacceptable in my view, have been made public by whistleblowers and journalists in the last few years. Think of Luxleaks, take the Panama Papers and the Paradise Papers. They show how letterbox companies work worldwide and the damage caused by unpaid taxes cannot be measured. It's about sick people who are not nursed. It's about children who don't go to school. With us in Europe, but certainly in developing countries, on a continent like Africa, for example. That is why we went through this time and, in addition to the register for ultimately stakeholders for companies, we have now also made a register of trusts compulsory, the UBO register. This way you can find out who really is in control of a company or a trust. I hope that investigative journalists helps and to shine more light on that industry. I also hope that companies will get behind their ears twice before they start another Double Dutch-Irish Sandwich, because they know that society is watching. The UBO register for companies is completely public. The UBO register for trusts is not, unfortunately, but if you have a legitimate reason as a citizen or journalist, you can look into it. Earlier, when we negotiated the previous directive, David Cameron, then Prime Minister of Great Britain, blocked that trust register. He showed up later in the Panama Papers. My own country, the Netherlands, has always said that there is no need for a trust register. But in the meantime, we know that Dutch companies are also advised and, for example, use a trust in Cyprus to commit fraudulent acts. There is a company that is now being addressed in the Netherlands because it has been advised by Baker Tilly Berk tax advisors. That must be over by now. That we adopt this law tomorrow must also put things in order in tax haven in the Netherlands. If we talk about that, Mr President, I must say the next thing. It is not possible that there are still so many Member States that have not applied the fourth directive, including my own country. Recently, the Director of Europol reiterated the fact that Member States are lax in their fight against money laundering. This Parliament is not lax, and I am proud of the result, and I am grateful to my colleague, Mr Kariņš and the shadow rapporteurs who have been very close to us every time. I would also like to thank the European Commission and the Latvian Presidency. We had to negotiate with the Maltese first. That was no fun. But after half a year of struggling, the Latvians finally achieved this result with us.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, as you know, in July 2016 the Commission proposed stronger rules against money laundering and terrorist financing, as a swift response to the terrible terrorist attacks which happened on European soil and the financial dealings revealed by the Panama Papers. Tomorrow you will take the final step towards the formal adoption and entry into force of revised rules, and I believe we can be proud of the revised rules, which improve substantially the existing Anti-Money Laundering Directive. I would like to thank the two co-rapporteurs, Mr Kariņš and Ms Sargentini, and all the shadow rapporteurs, as well as the Chairs, Mr Gualtieri and Mr Moraes. Your commitment and expertise have hugely contributed to this result. Firstly, the revised rules set a new world standard on transparency of beneficial ownership. By making beneficial ownership information available to competent authorities and to the public as regards companies, it will make sure opaque structures cannot be used to facilitate money laundering. Secondly, the revised Directive addresses new risks of terrorist financing. It will bring virtual currency platforms into its scope and restricts the anonymous use of prepaid cards. Thirdly, the Directive strengthens our approach to high-risk third countries in the area of money laundering and terrorist financing. Last but not least, the Directive strengthens the financial intelligence units and the national supervisory authorities, as well as the cross-border cooperation between these authorities. The result of the negotiations is a very good one: it makes the European Union the world leader in fighting money laundering and financing of terrorism. With the adoption of this text, we are marking an important step in fighting against financial crime. The key aspect now is swift and effective implementation in guiding and supporting the Member States’ action, and during the adaptation stage the Commission will start acting immediately. I assure you of the Commission’s determination to see the rules fully implemented. The Commission is also taking action against those Member States that have yet to transpose the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive, in force since June 2017. Effective implementation is crucial for the credibility of our preventive anti-money laundering system. Finally, I would also like to add that our legislative work does not stop here. Just yesterday, the Commission presented a proposal on use of financial data in the fight against serious crime. The proposed directive complements the preventive measures of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive by ensuring better use of financial information for criminal investigations and a stronger link between financial intelligence units and law enforcement authorities. I look forward to working with this House also on this new proposal, which, together with the revised Anti-Money Laundering Directive, will be a key response against financial crime and financing of terrorism in Europe. Let me thank again the European Parliament.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the amendment to the anti-money laundering directive presents very significant steps to better combat recycling of money. This Parliament has spent a great deal, with discreet success, to approve a review that obtains more financial transparency and is effective in combating tax evasion and avoidance. Now, public records will reveal the real owners of comfortable companies and allow journalists and citizens to more easily discover cases of circumvention, corruption and other trafficking. Unfortunately, there still remains a dangerous loophole: we failed, in negotiating with the council, to gain unconditional public access to information about final beneficiaries of trusts and the like institutes. The Panama Papers and Paradise Papers have clearly revealed how structures set up to resemble family trusts were used to conceal identities and large sums of money. Here, it would be important to be able to receive information not only on a written request and on the basis of legitimate interest: we need more transparency. One step forward, then, but not ambitious enough. Only full public disclosure would allow citizens and governments, including third countries and developing countries, to take the battle to a European and global level, where we can really win it.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. — (EL) Madam President, there is no doubt that the fight against money laundering helps to reduce tax evasion, economic crime in general and the financing of terrorist organisations in particular. It is therefore important to have transparency with regard to the beneficial beneficiaries of all kinds of bank accounts and the use of other means of payment, which are post-modern currency equivalents. That is why, of course, the competent national authorities must be able to cooperate without hindrance among themselves, on a pan-European scale. I believe that the proposal for a directive we are debating meets these objectives and I will therefore support it, but I must point out that, in any case, all this must be done with full respect for the protection of fundamental rights and the protection of personal data. in particular.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. — (FR) Madam President, we studied this text in INTA committee because international trade has unfortunately become a preferred instrument for tax evasion and money laundering practices. The European Union must be more demanding in terms of fiscal and financial transparency vis-à-vis its trading partners. First of all, our threat must be credible. That is why we must make transparency and respect for international rules a real prerequisite in our trade agreements. What does that mean? This means that we must have a binding clause that ensures that a country must commit itself to the international rules of financial transparency and administrative cooperation. This is the first point. On the other hand, as legislators, we are always lagging behind the financial industry which innovates in tax optimization but also, unfortunately, in money laundering. The only way to respond to this is to adopt a method that we know well in trade negotiations: that of positive lists, that is, to ensure that, during a trade negotiation, the chapter dealing with the sector explicitly identifies, in a limiting list, the financial services that are going to be liberalized. These, in my opinion, are some avenues to be explored in a commercial negotiation to ensure that money laundering and optimization are behind us. That is, in any case, the political objective we have set ourselves.

name: Emil RADEV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — Ladies and gentlemen, the Fifth Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Directive is upgrading European legislation in step with new technological developments that allow criminals and terrorists to finance their illegal activities. It will support the effective fight against terrorist financing in two main ways. For the first time, virtual currencies will be covered by European anti-money laundering legislation — now the exchange platforms between virtual and fiat currencies, as well as virtual currency wallets will have to be registered, as well as checking customers. removing anonymity. The introduction of a definition of virtual currencies also updates European legislation. The threshold for identifying prepaid card holders is reduced from €250 to 150 euros, which has become particularly necessary given the use of this type of cards to rent the car that the perpetrators of the Paris attacks escaped. The directive will also have an effect on business as the transparency of the beneficial owners of companies and trust funds increases in order to prevent tax evasion practices. The agreement reached is important not only because it will support the work of the relevant services in investigating money laundering and terrorist financing, but also because it proves to criminals that the European Union and the Member States are tireless in their actions to reduce illegal cash streams. I therefore hope that the directive will be swiftly introduced into national legislation.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Madam President, in the three years of the adoption of the 4th Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Directive, we have reviewed it by adopting the 5th Directive, seeking to deal with the terrorist threat and the revelations of the Panama Papers. The 5th Directive represents a strengthening of control and transparency mechanisms, thanks to the persistence of the European Parliament, which has managed, over eight months of negotiations, to persuade the majority of Member States to accept a large part of its demands. It was Parliament that guaranteed public access to the registers of beneficial owners of companies in the European Union, in order to end the opacity of shell companies used to evade tax and launder money. We have lifted the veil on trusts, even if public access to their beneficiaries is restricted to those who advocate legitimate interest, by imposition of the Council. We guarantee more scrutiny and supervision of liberal professionals and service providers, who, as we know, are instrumental in schemes of tax evasion and money laundering, and should not be left to self-regulation, which regulates nothing. We include more market operators among those who have due diligence duties towards their clients, such as art dealers and all those who provide tax advice, we restrict the use of prepaid cards, created better cooperation mechanisms between authorities to facilitate investigations and we have created a list of public functions that designate who are the politically exposed people in the European Union who are subject to enhanced due diligence. All applicants for gold visas and similar schemes in the Member States will have to be subject to increased scrutiny.
