But it is also important to emphasise what we have failed to achieve, because of the refusal of the Member States, such as the creation of a European financial intelligence unit and the inclusion in the central registers of beneficiaries of companies not based in the European Union, but which conduct significant business here. We have fallen short of a result that could have an overall impact on financial transparency under the responsibility of the Council. All too often, in these negotiations, we have the impression that some of our governments do not really want to combat money laundering, but rather to facilitate it, caught by interests. Adoption of this directive is indeed a step in the right direction, but much remains to be done. And let us have no illusions, many of the new Member States are captured by sinister interests, such as those of the mafias who control the e-gamble and invest in cryptocurrencies.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President, in the Fifth Anti-Money Laundering Directive, we have gained public and unconditional access to the real beneficiaries of companies and real estate. Until now, those who wanted access to this information had to prove a legitimate interest, which made access virtually impossible. However, public access to the real beneficiaries of trust funds, such as those for charity, studies, legacies or other purposes, remained conditional on legitimate interest due to the opposition of the Council. However, we will have a definition that will include journalists and NGOs among those with legitimate interest. Politicians are still subject to additional financial checks because they pose a high risk for money laundering crimes. They're politically exposed people. We are not done and we will not finish until we are one step ahead of the criminals. Money laundering is an octopus that has spread across Europe and around the world and kills journalists.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the Anti-Money Laundering Directive (AMLD) is an essential part of the EU regulatory framework to combat financial crime and terrorist financing. Still, we have clearly seen gaps in some of its current provisions which need to be addressed, as recommended also by the EP PANA Committee. If properly implemented by the Member States, the improvements made to the directive can address these loopholes. I thank the co-rapporteurs and the shadows for their work. It was not easy at all with the Council. The national anti-money laundering units’ powers will be strongly reinforced, thus allowing them to better follow the money and detect suspicious transactions. These new rules provide for more transparency, including public access to the information about who really owns the companies involved in a financial transaction. It applies to some extent to trusts as well. I call now on the Member States not to delay the implementation of this revised AMLD which I hope will be adopted by the plenary tomorrow. Several Member States still haven’t implemented the previous directive, although they were required to do so as from July 2017. The European Parliament’s TAXE Committee will closely monitor the implementation process of these new rules.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Money laundering, as you know, is causing major economic damage to the Member States of the European Union. In Germany alone, according to recent studies, a sum of up to 100 billion euros is being laundered annually. Globally, we are talking about a sum of up to 1.5 trillion euros per year. These are dirty money, which in most cases is generated by criminal activities, dirty money that then finds its way, for example, into the real estate market, which contributes to its hot runs and drives rents to some astronomical heights and thus people out of their homes. That is why my group supports the efforts made here by Parliament. But money laundering is and remains a major problem in the EU. Most recently, this was once again clearly underlined by the numerous money laundering incidents in the banking sector. We very much welcome the fact that a publicly available register of beneficial owners of companies is finally being introduced and that whistleblower protection is being improved. In the fight against dirty money, comprehensive transparency is one of our strongest weapons. But why take a step in the right direction and then stop halfway? Why does such a public register not come for trusts and foundations? And in other places, too, the result of the negotiations unfortunately lags behind the possibilities. Thus, the sanctions regime will not be tightened in the event of violations of the money laundering law, and unfortunately it was not possible to agree on the much-needed introduction of a real estate register. So the fight against dirty money, gangsters and tax trickers continues.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, of course we all want to stop money laundering. We already have many laws on fraud, theft, all that sort of thing, but they are not fully implemented and applied by the authorities. We should apply the laws that we already have before inflicting small businesses, medium-sized businesses and private individuals with unnecessarily excessive red tape and regulations which stifle business.  The European Union has a mania – a mania! – for plaguing business with regulations which seemed designed to rope in extra tax to pay for civil servants and their gold-plated EU pensions, rather than to prevent crime. At the moment it is very difficult to comply with all this myriad of complex regulations. Terrorism is just a convenient excuse for governments and the EU to keep an eye on, and control, their citizens in an increasingly Orwellian and Kafkaesque European Union. We are leaving, thank God, but you will be living in this Kafkaesque nightmare.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the military defeat of Isis poses very serious problems in the area of financing terrorism. It seems to me that this report is weak in predicting the contrast, updating the contrast measures and predicting the evolution of this situation, which — it is easy to imagine — will be very important, since the Islamic International Terrorism system is lacking the safe sources that we all know and which were the Islamic State's own. It should be remembered, in this regard, is the very serious danger of using cryptocurrencies: I even think that this is the seriousness of the problem, that one should perhaps think, even, of prohibit cryptocurrencies. And then there is the problem of how to counter the predictably expanding use of the hawalas system, a system that has its origins in the millennial tradition of the Islamic world and which, however, is very dangerous if it is used for the purpose of terrorism. And this is where the report, I believe, does not go deep enough in thinking about new measures and innovating existing measures to succeed in effectively countering what is becoming a big one reality in international finance, with unimaginable dimensions. Even Eurispes, referring to the hawalas system, rightly says that we are facing, and I read textually, “an entire offshore economy moving billions of euros, an informal flow that does not pass through banking channels and that escapes detections”. This is a serious danger that requires facts and not words.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Madam President, across Northern Ireland communities continue to grapple with the active threat of paramilitarism and organised criminality. In many instances, those who previously engaged in barbaric terrorist activities have made the transition to a new form of terror: extortion, intimidation, drug and people trafficking and money laundering. I want to commend the work of the paramilitary crime task force, which in recent weeks and months has carried out robust searches and investigations aimed at uncovering and prosecuting those at the head of these criminal gangs. After searches last week in Northern Ireland, charges were brought against individuals for human trafficking offenses, resulting in four women being rescued by police. Just this week, the High Court in the Irish Republic ruled that funds seized by the Criminal Assets Bureau from companies linked to associates of Irish Republican, Thomas ‘Slab’ Murphy, were the proceeds of crime. Revised rules on anti-money laundering and cooperation between police forces are essential tools. It is vital that they are continued post-Brexit.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the one which led to the adoption of the fifth anti-money laundering directive was, I think, a beautiful page of parliamentary life and also of cooperation and negotiation between the various institutions. I think that, thanks to the decisive contribution of the European Parliament, we have achieved a significant improvement in our anti-money laundering and anti-terrorist financing legislation by addressing some of the limits that have emerged with clarity from Panama Papers scandals or terrorist attack investigations. I think there are three particularly relevant elements to be emphasised and emphasized. Firstly, of course, transparency with respect to the actual beneficiaries of companies and trusts and the interconnection of registers, which will allow easier and more effective exchange of information at European level. We will have full publicity regarding the actual beneficiaries of companies but also for trusts, all those who can demonstrate a legitimate interest including, it is explicitly written, investigative journalists and NGOs will be able to have a level of access which, of course, will also be full for Member States and their financial investigation units. Secondly, with regard to the creation of centralized records for bank accounts and safes, we will have another important tool for investigations and to identify owners of bank and payment accounts. Thirdly, anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism rules will also be applied to persons providing services for holding and transferring virtual currencies — it has been recalled — but also who trade in works of art. So we have an important result but a job that cannot be said to be concluded. What happened to the ABLV bank in Latvia cannot be considered a negligible episode and all this shows that the road is still long and we will be very determined to move towards a European FIU system and ask the ECB to do everything possible even with its current powers. (The speaker agrees to answer a 'blue card' question (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Mr Gualtieri, don’t you think this is terrifying, sir – that this intrusion into the privacy of individuals is just going a bit too far, and there is no part of a person’s life which is not being looked into? I think this is terrifying. I don’t think it is a good exchange for what you are trying to seek. We have perfectly good authorities who look into these matters as it is. All these extra rules are making it impossible for business to do business, and it is all about Socialists trying to crucify business people.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr. Gualtieri, are you terrified?

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: answer to a “blue card” question. — It's not so naturally. I believe that secrecy and lawlessness often go hand in hand, as was well remembered by the rapporteur Kariņš, who said that “thieves love darkness”. Transparency and legality are conditions for the smooth functioning of the economy and business and I believe that the fact that Europe has advanced legislation must be an example for all jurisdictions and we naturally hope that anyone who wants to leave the EU will not agree with you on this view of the secrecy of transferring money.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: - Madam President! Dear ladies! The Polish delegation in the ECHR group welcomed the agreement after the December 2017 trilateral talks. The terrorist bombings in Paris, Brussels, Nice, Stockholm or Manchester have changed Europe. Enhancing access to information about real beneficiaries and trustees owning businesses outside the borders of the European Union, is particularly supported. In Poland, for example, a central register of real beneficiaries is planned based on the statutory obligation for operators to report the data of their beneficiaries. The new regulation will therefore help to develop a coherent EU policy towards third countries whose anti-money laundering schemes show fundamental deficiencies.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: Madam President, well, Mr Coburn is not here. I am not spooky that we are implementing a directive, but because of the millions and millions of euros that are escaping the law. To sum up: we must deal with the laundering of great fortunes of legal or illegal origin, and the Anti-Laundering Directive is our most important legal instrument. It addresses problems — most colleagues have said — such as risks related to prepaid cards or virtual currencies, or forecasting company registrations and bank accounts, which will be very useful for fraud investigation. However, our weak point is the application of the rules. For example, there are entities required to report suspicious violations that work de facto, so we have seen various leaks as facilitators of evasion and laundering. This is because the financial intelligence units do not have sufficient resources or competencies — it would help a lot the creation of a European financial intelligence unit, Commissioner — or because the national supervisor does not investigate, because he does not have resources, or because of other severe sanctions we need. Those who are escaping our control work in almost perfect chains; we too must.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: Madam President! Dear colleagues! We have succeeded in getting a new anti-money laundering directive in house and that's really good. This is a step in the right direction towards tax evasion and I would like to thank the rapporteurs for your huge and hard work. With that said, there are still problems with the agreement. On some points, strong interests have succeeded in driving Parliament over, and that has made the agreement we have ended up with is far from as good as one might have wanted. It simply provides too many loopholes. This means that the journalists who otherwise do a huge job to shed light on tax evaders are still not secured the information that can help them in their important work. The rules for trust funds like those that have been used for quite recently to hide large amounts of money in e.g. Panama, is still far from strong enough. And we shouldn't underestimate how big a loophole that is. But I'm satisfied that we've got as far as we are. It is an important step that we have been secured public access to the register. But there is no doubt there is still a right lot to do. We are far from targets if we are to stop tax evasion and money laundering.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: - Madam President! I am an MP for freedom — I represent freedom, I defend freedoms. This resolution seeks to restrict freedom — economic freedom, its civil rights. Its goal is not to fight terrorism, but to monitor and supervise the public. Bitcoins have become another front for the European Union's fight against the free market through successive tax regulations. In Poland, it was started by proposing absurd, cruel and unfair rules for the taxation of transactions made in cryptocurrencies. These laws have one purpose — to maintain the monopoly of the state in the economy and currency systems. This healthy competition is a guarantor of development and especially competition in currency areas. It is true that terrorists are playing the cryptocurrency market. But it is also true that terrorists drive cars. So why not ban cars? Recent bloody attacks in Europe were, after all, carried out using motor vehicles. None of the solutions proposed here will result in a restriction of terrorist activity. You propose limits on transfers and the need to register them. These records only introduce further barriers to entrepreneurs and close monitoring of citizens. As usual instead of harming terrorists, you are merely making life difficult for normal people. If you want to fight terrorism, change your immigration policy and stop destabilizing the Middle East. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question under the 'blue card' procedure. — Madam President, dear colleague, it is surprising that you compare car driving and money laundering. We've had debates here many times, and we've seen how dangerous it is to be a black money payment, going, of course, from arms trafficking to terrorism. How do you explain, that you have said here that it is a superregulation, when the need in society shows us that we need to have transparency and we need to know what happens to illegal money trafficking?

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. — Regulation is obviously too much, with every moment we lose our freedom. This resolution is another example of this, taking away personal freedoms, economic freedoms from us. A previous example was the dossier on the acquisition and possession of weapons. I am convinced that by no means has this dossier halted, impeded the possession of weapons for terrorists, but only and exclusively the ability to own weapons legally acquired by normal people across Europe.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, Commissioner. The fifth anti-money laundering directive is indeed fighting anonymity, as the rapporteur has said, because it provides for many tightening up. This applies in particular to the registries of beneficial owners, virtual currencies, prepaid credit cards and the exchange of information with high-risk third countries, as well as the establishment of a European Financial Intelligence Unit (FIU) to support and coordinate national FIUs. Probably the most controversial and hotly discussed measure is the registries of beneficial owners, namely beneficiaries of legal entities and trusts. These registers should be publicly accessible, although access may be restricted for privacy and security reasons. At the same time, the threshold for explaining economic interest will be lowered from 25% to 10%. Member States are given great freedom in the development of their own policies when it comes to cash control and the monitoring of virtual currencies. For prepaid credit cards, the threshold has been lowered from 250 to 150 euros. There is also increased due diligence in the high-risk area. So monetary anonymity will soon cease to exist in Europe. (The speaker agreed to answer a question under the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Question about the 'blue card' procedure. — I would like to thank Mrs Kappel most sincerely because she has raised a good problem that if this regulation comes into force now, the Member States will probably be working with gold plating again. It is to be expected that each Member State will again make its own rules, which, of course, are very heavy bureaucratic and very expensive. Do you think that it would perhaps make sense to have a hotline where this is done centrally for Europe and where each Member State can then use this central register? The second thing, of course, that would be very important, is that do not believe that NGOs — non-governmental organisations — should also be included in these regulations?

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Answer to a question about the procedure of “blue card”. — Thank you for this question. I really believe that there should be a central reporting office in order to have a uniform approach, and Austria, which will be the Presidency of the Council in the next six months, will take action here, namely with a push to harmonise gold plating, that is, not to implement it to the extent. Secondly, I consider a very, very, important approach that you have had: in any case, this reporting office should also include the data of NGOs, and it must in any case apply to all financial contributions from NGOs. This too should be reported centrally and accessible to the public.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: — Mr President, Directive (EU) 2015/849 and the proposed amendment are very useful to implement an updated and effective legal framework for tackling the raising of money or assets for terrorist purposes. Terrorist groups finance and conduct their activities by making widespread use of modern technology services that act as alternative financial systems that are not provided for in Union legislation or benefit from exceptions. In addition, money laundering activities are carried out using a wide use of cash transactions. The dissemination and use of electronic bank accounts and other similar online payment systems has increased sharply, so consideration should be given to establishing a limit on cash transfers at Union level without incurring significant burdens on individuals and companies. Finally, where possible, policies and actions should be used in other relevant areas, for example trade and development cooperation, in order to complement the fight against money laundering, always with a view to promoting entrepreneurship in Member States.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, we can only stress the importance of combating money laundering in the fight against tax evasion and against crime or terrorism. However, the current directive — as we know — has enormous shortcomings, whether in its design or in the conditions of its application by the Member States. It has not been adapted to the challenges we face today at both European and national level. This legislation is, at the very least, outdated both by the technological innovation of the financial system and by the new possibilities of concealing money through financial channels, in the form of cryptocurrency, as many of my colleagues have already mentioned. In 2016, the Commission presented these legislative proposals to combat money laundering and terrorist financing. These proposals are welcome in a context that has been totally shaken by a number of terrorist attacks unfortunately far too high, but also by the scandal of the Panama Papers. This revision is welcome, as it should allow for better monitoring of capital flows from third countries at risk. Banks will need to carry out more comprehensive checks, particularly with regard to countries on the famous European blacklist of exposed countries. This revision will also make it possible to clarify the structure of an undertaking and trust, by reporting on the actual beneficiaries through the creation of this national register of undertakings present in the territory of a Member State or through the sharing of such information between Member States. However, the project was clearly flawed, and the European Parliament's contribution would have been essential to facilitate the exchange of information, to ensure that a summary of this evaluation was made public, so as to allow non-governmental organizations to be aware of them, and ensure that the information contained in the register is central and readily accessible. This is a step on this long road in which the European Parliament is ready to move forward, because this fight against money laundering and the financing of terrorism remains a major objective for our Parliament.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Mr President, in the weeks and months prior to the attacks in Paris, the terrorist Salah Abdeslam used an anonymous prepaid credit card from Bpost to move around Europe. That is just one example of how terrorists and other criminals abuse internal EU borders. By using anonymous credit cards, virtual coins and all kinds of shady corporations, financial transactions of criminals can go unnoticed. That is why I welcome the measures adopted today. Stricter rules on the anonymity of prepaid credit cards and virtual coins such as bitcoin, more transparency around key figures behind bank accounts and companies and better data exchange between authorities within and between Member States because a study is timely about the have the right information essential. Steps in the right direction, but more is needed. Therefore, let us move swiftly on additional measures in the fight against terrorism.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we recognise the progress achieved with the current revision of the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive, especially in terms of greater transparency on the actual owners of company and trusts. However, the agreement reached with the Council could be more ambitious. At last, the records on the actual owners of companies will be fully accessible to the public but, as already highlighted by my colleague Marco Valli, shadow rapporteur of this file, we would have preferred total transparency: a lower threshold for corporations and public access even to actual trust-holders, rather than limiting the rule to demonstrating legitimate interest. However, it is good that NGOs and investigative journalists will be able to access it, thanks to the broader definition. In the negotiations with the Council, some important provisions which were present in Parliament's text were also removed, such as countermeasures in the event of failure to identify the actual holders or strengthening sanctions against infringements of the Directive. Therefore, the battle towards full transparency and a more rigorous fight against recycling remains open, and we cannot therefore let our guard down.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: — The fight against terrorism or the fight against money laundering are just propaganda and psychological grabs used to obtain the approval of the social opinion and of us MPs, respectively, for the next steps to build a system of total control of all financial flows between citizens of EU countries. In the Latin civilization that once prevailed here, every citizen was free to dispose of his money without control from the public authorities, and no one had to command their purity. There was a simple principle of presumption of innocence. Today, the principle of presumption of guilt is introduced, a preventive system of total control is introduced. Europe is becoming one great transnational prison, an area of one universal surveillance of all citizens by a bureaucratic transnational power. We demand a return to Europe of freedoms and freedoms.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Mr. President! We all know that one of the most important tools in the fight against terrorism is to try to shut down the money taps. We also know that detention of these is sometimes very difficult. At the same time, however, it must also be seen that money laundering and uncontrollable financial flows are no longer just supporting terrorism, not just mafias, not just criminal networks. It should also be seen that all of this we are talking about is now a threat to democracy in Europe, in the European Union. Above all, because we have accurate statements that the evasion of financial regulation, tax evasion and money laundering are increasingly linked to corruption, with authoritarian political regimes that exist within certain Member States of the European Union. We see clearly that politically motivated corruption has been unleashed in some Member States, the stealing of money from the European Union by close people and economic interests, and this is about to self-evident link with offshore companies, tax evasion, money laundering or settling bonds without control. We know exactly that, in connection with resettlement bonds, a large number of people wanted in other non-European countries precisely for money laundering or for the promotion of terrorism, have entered the European Union. It must be clear that today there are Member States within the European Union where corruption and the laundering of money from corruption are an important means of retaining political power. It's hard to admit, but it is. I therefore believe that the European Union cannot afford to spread authoritarian, illiberal ideologies through confusing financial manipulation by all those working to destroy the European Union and liberal democracy.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: — Dear Chairman, preventing the use of the financial system for the purpose of money laundering or terrorist financing must be one of our priorities in order to further protect citizens from demise by hindering or, even better, disabling the financing of terrorist activities. Europe is home to several globally important financial centres where money is poured from around the world and therefore has an obligation to lead in cleaning the financial system from dirty money. I am not sure that we will achieve the desired results by establishing mass registers that will contain the personal data of a large part of the population of the Union. I fear it is a massive project that focuses on loyal citizens instead of those who are explicit suspicion of being involved in illegal acts. Better cooperation between competent authorities and faster data exchange mechanisms are more important and easier achievable than a centralized data collection system that can always be targeted by organised attacks.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. The directive on money laundering and terrorist financing is based on the name that we are discussing here. Yet more than half of today's speakers are quite right to talk about tax evasion, which this directive is intended to help. Well, why all this confusion of terms, when all three goals are actually quite reasonable goals? This has a very simple background: what you are doing here is the creation of the transparent citizen, the complete destruction of any anonymity, any private retreat of the citizen to the state. They provide full transparency for States and NGOs vis-à-vis citizens. And that is exactly something that you could not make palatable to the citizen in life just because of tax dinges. That's why here, by stirfying fear, you're trying to transport something that you can't afford. You will not hit terrorism, nor will you stop money laundering. They will only put 500 million European citizens under general suspicion in the future and will ensure that people who behave righteously no longer enjoy protection from the state.

name: André ELISSEN
text: Mr President, we are discussing the financing of terrorism today. According to this report, as a result of terrorist attacks, so-called emerging trends have been revealed. So my group thought: at last we are going to state the facts. At last, not only we see, but everyone sees the inseparable link between Islam and terrorism. Islam inspired and legitimised violence is responsible for 99% of all terrorist murders in 2015 and 95% of all terrorist murders in 2016, according to Europol's annual reports. When it comes to financing terrorism, it is also very important to look at the funding of mosques and imams. These are often financed by countries such as Saudi Arabia and Qatar. In this way, our free Western society is poisoned with intolerant Islamic hatred. This will increase the threat of terrorist attacks. The word Islam occurs exactly zero times. The words mosque and imam don't appear either. We cannot take this report seriously.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: — I welcome the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending a directive on the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering and fianancing terrorism in the right direction. Offenders are increasingly using innovations in financial services such as virtual currencies and anonymous prepaid cards, so it is very important that legislation is regularly lent in this area. Terrorist networks are often financed from other countries and not necessarily from the one in which they carry out their terrorist activities. It is therefore crucial to determine who is the actual owner of the business structure in order to bring the actual perpetrators to the courts as well. It is also important to bring European Union legislation into line with global developments, as the misuse of the financial system for the purposes of terrorism also threatens the integrity and stability of the financial system.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Mr President, Commissioner Jourová, the terrorist attacks that have struck the European Union explain the Commission's initiative — the fourth directive on the prevention of money laundering and the financing of terrorism. But we in the European Parliament demand that these measures be consistent with those taken in other initiatives such as the cash control initiative — of which I am rapporteur — and with the conclusions of the committee of inquiry into the Panama Papers. This means that we have to aim at prepaid cards, virtual currencies, bank account registration, and ensure that not only financial institutions but real estate agents, law firms, notaries, consultancies, and even casinos are accountable. But more important than everything is the establishment, at last, of EU-wide financial intelligence units that are interconnected to each other, aiming at real ownership of the current accounts and beneficiaries of companies. With all this package of measures we need to make the European Union stronger against terrorism, but also a reasonable balance between freedom and security.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, first of all I would like to wish you success in your work, the Vice-Presidency. It is an important initiative indeed to strike money laundering, but as we are discussing this issue here, ECOFIN has started a process of sewing and dismantling, because even Panama has emerged from the blacklist of countries that evade tax, from blacklist of non-cooperating countries and here we are discussing what measures to take. Obviously, therefore, measures must be taken for both cryptocurrencies and anonymous prepaid cards, and of course we must have the names of the beneficiaries in trusts, companies and all of course, subject to the protection of personal data.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: — Mr President, despite the tax scandals that have revealed to the world the ecosystem that promotes opacity and anonymity and allows money laundering, the European Union remains conditioned by the interests of large multinational companies. Basic measures, which are advised by the majority of those who fight money laundering and terrorist financing, have systematically bumped into the forces of those who want to change just something so that everything stays the same. Proposals naturally and always fall far short of expectations and what is needed. I simply ask: how long will we tolerate the fact that economic and financial interests are above the rights of citizens and peoples? That is the question I leave to the audience.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: Mr President, the fight against money laundering as well as the attempt to prevent the financing of terrorist organisations are two basic obligations which each state and the European Union have, because these illegal activities do not have only an economic dimension, but they also have a security dimension. In this respect, the directive in question is moving in the right direction. It is a fact that terrorists are using the current financial system, moving on its outskirts and managing to be financed. It is therefore necessary to identify the ways in which these activities are financed and to try to combat this whole system. We know that they are financed by coastal companies, we know that they are financed by various Islamic states, and we also know that they are financed by smuggling, prostitution and other such illegal activities. All this must be checked, always provided that human rights are not violated.

name: Romana TOMC
text: — Dirty money gives the basis for the operation of a parallel, deep country run by hidden owners. Once we succeed with legislation to prevent this, we will be able to say we have been successful. I hope that this proposal, which we have in front of ourselves now, is a step in the right direction. But unfortunately we note that the paper passes everything. In practice, however, crime is still happening. Let's say, we have one of the best laws in Slovenia, which Commissioner Jourová personally confirmed, regarding the prevention of money laundering. But what this helps us if, despite this legislation, one billion euros of laundered money from Iran spilled through a state-owned bank. Everyone knows for this, the evidence exists, no one answers. We also have a law that is supposed to disclose actual business owners. But them really? We can reveal and discover who owns the singing society. But you will not find out who owns the leftist extreme week Mladina. All this is still hidden for the time being. We need more effective legislation.

name: Romana TOMC
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to encourage the European Parliament to give its approval by its vote to the political agreement reached in December 2017 on this ambitious new text on anti-money laundering and terrorist financing. I also wish that the Council, on its side, will approve as swiftly as possible the same text in order to ensure publication in the Official Journal as soon as possible.  In the meantime, the Commission will continue to make the effective implementation and enforcement of the existing Anti-Money Laundering Directive its key priority.  Commission Statement (in writing) The Commission regrets that the revised Directive does not provide the same level of transparency on beneficial ownership of profit-making trusts as it does for companies and other legal entities. The Commission underlines that, in the light of general principles of EU law and of the duty to state reasons, it is of the utmost importance for Union legislation to include sufficient, specific, adequate and legally sound motivation as to the access to the information of beneficial owners included in central registers. The statement of reasons must disclose, clearly and unequivocally, the reasoning of the author of the measure, in such a way as to enable the persons concerned to ascertain the reasons for it and to enable the competent courts to exercise their power of review. The Commission considers that granting public access to beneficial ownership information of companies and firms is justified in light of the general need for transparency of corporate affairs in order to protect the interests of third parties and that this aspect of the Directive pertains to Article 50 TFEU. It regrets that Parliament and Council have considered that this aspect should only be regarded as a positive side effect and does not require citing Article 50 TFEU as an additional legal basis. However, considering that the choice of Article 114 TFEU as the sole legal basis does not imply legal consequences in this case, the Commission can accept the final version of the Directive.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: Rapporteur. — Dear Head of the Session! It is absolutely clear from this debate that there is a strong desire in Parliament to back the new anti-money laundering directive in tomorrow's vote. It is absolutely clear that we need to clean up the European banking system from money raised illegally, from being able to use it in our banks or launder illicit money in an effort to legalise them. But one thing is to adopt a directive and another to bring that directive into life. That's why I appeal to you, Mrs Commissioner, and all the European Commissions are monitoring the law, calling for this Directive to be implemented in the Member States so that it would not be that most Member States do not implement the Directive. Because this system and all registers will only work if they are actually established in all Member States, this information will be available and the anonymity of criminals in Europe will no longer be possible. Therefore, not only do I call for a vote in plenary for the directive to be implemented, but I also specifically call on the Commission to see that it is actually implemented in the Member States and the system is beginning to truly improve.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: rapporteur. — (NL) Mr President, it is not so often that I am standing in plenary advocating a story and that almost everyone says: 'What good, good work, I agree with you'. I am doing another dossier, the rule of law in Hungary, and I hope that I will meet just as much support there. Years ago, Thabo Mbeki was in this house, then chairman of a UN committee dealing with money that disappeared from Africa without tax being paid, and he and his investigators estimated that it was about 50 billion dollars a year. Money that was not taxed, which people in Africa have not been able to enjoy. That is where my motivation came from to draw up this legislation. I heard some colleagues looking for the blame outside of ourselves. Discuss terrorist financing and focus on mosques or Islam. It is also about us and the responsibility we take to monitor our businesses and our criminals properly, in order to denounce abuses such as non-payment of taxes in other countries. It is also about two journalists who have recently been murdered in Europe, one in Malta and one in Slovakia. Journalists who did research on money laundering and the abuse of money by governments. Journalists, who deserve our support. I would like to stress, together with the Commissioner, that it is extremely important that this legislation be implemented quickly and I have reviewed it again: the Fourth Money Laundering Directive — you have already sent letters on it — has not yet been transposed by Bulgaria, Cyprus, Greece, Luxembourg, Malta, Poland, Romania and my own country, the Netherlands. I would like to emphasise that this is not a pass.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I'm closing the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 19 April 2018.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the report by Daniel Dalton, on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approval and surveillance of the market for motor vehicles and their trailers and systems, components and separate technical units intended for these vehicles (COM (2016) 0031 — C8-0015/2016 — 2016/0014 (COD)) (A8-0048/2017).

name: Daniel DALTON
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, this is a strong Europe-wide response to the ‘dieselgate’ scandal. This legislation will make cars safer and cleaner and, combined with the RDE testing, will ensure that a future ‘dieselgate’ can’t happen again. We have a unique system in Europe: national type approvals, which are mutually recognised across all EU countries. But ‘dieselgate’ exposed some of its limitations due to the testing process, lack of enforcement and lack of market surveillance. For years, motorists have suspected that the advertised fuel performance of their vehicles was inaccurate and exaggerated. They were a joke, in fact. No one believed them, and ‘dieselgate’ proved them right. Millions of cars bought in good faith had been mis-sold due to deliberate attempts to manipulate laboratory test results. To many, it appears that ‘dieselgate’ affected everyone apart from the manufacturers to blame. Those affected are still waiting for proper compensation, whereas in the US, compensation has already been paid. So motorists in Europe are angry, and they’re rightly asking what we’re doing about it. We should all be concerned as well about the environmental damage of this, particularly in cities with poor air quality. Overall, it has undermined trust in diesel vehicles. This package creates a rigorous and transparent framework for approving and checking the cars on our roads for emissions and safety. While emissions have caught the headlines recently, our new rules also guarantee safety standards. Airbags and seatbelts are all covered in these rules. New testing, too, will ensure that environmental protections are upheld. Transparent testing is essential to ensure that cars are safe and clean. Test results will, for the first time, be easily available for third parties online, who can check and verify results for cheating. When something goes wrong, there must be a capacity to act, and under this regulation there are for the first time proper requirements for national authorities to significantly fine manufacturers at fault. If the national authorities fail to act, the Commission can levy fines instead. That European involvement and oversight is repeated in many parts of this regulation. I am naturally sceptical of giving power to the Commission, but this scandal showed an umpire was needed to renew the trust that is needed in a system of national mutual recognition. The Commission will be carrying out regular reviews of type approval authorities who allow cars to drive on the road to make sure that they are doing their job. There will also be a forum, chaired by the Commission, providing greater oversight and sharing best practice of national authorities. Once cars are on the road, national authorities who failed to do so in the past, now have to check them. Hundreds of cars a year will be checked, with the spread of models and types to ensure that cheating will be caught. The European Commission is also mandated to undertake spot checks on cars across the Union, targeted based on information Member States have to provide on their surveillance programmes. A double-check system to ensure that if another Volkswagen ever happened, it would be discovered quickly. (The President interrupted the speaker because of a translation problem) Vehicles found not in conformity will also be subject to a rapid EU-wide recall system where needed. I started by talking about those affected by ‘dieselgate’. For them, this regulation makes the law clear that if consumers carry out repairs themselves to faulty vehicles later subject to recalls, they will be reimbursed for the costs incurred. Consumers also rely on an independent and healthy aftermarket for local and good-quality service, and this has been an issue for me and I am grateful to colleagues here for their support on this. I am pleased to have achieved improved access to manufacturer information for independent repairers. This makes the market stronger for the benefit of consumers. In conclusion, this regulation delivers a stronger, more transparent system to ensure cars on our roads are safe and clean. It delivers for car owners, for the environment and for manufacturers, with standards fairly applied and appropriately applied across the board. I want to thank all the shadow rapporteurs for their work. and to Cameron Smith and Alex Davis in my office for the immense work that they have done. I put this report to the Parliament and I look forward to hearing your views in today’s debate.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am really glad to be here with you today because it allows me once again to underline the importance I attach to this proposal. Dieselgate opened our eyes and showed the need for far-reaching reforms. The EMIS Committee and the Commission’s own investigations revealed the shortcomings of the present system. What we have discovered is not only about Volkswagen. The whole industry operated in a grey zone. Almost all companies bent the rules, some even cheated and our type—approval authorities took their enforcement responsibilities very lightly. We are faced with a systemic failure of the type—approval system in Europe. That needs to change radically and it needs to change urgently. Enforcement of the type—approval framework is the responsibility of the Member States, as all of us know, but the last two years have shown that only a few of them have taken serious action against emission-cheating. No car manufacturer has been fined for cheating so far, and only a few Member States have issued mandatory calls for non—compliant cars. This is one of the reasons I have consistently called for a reshuffle of the whole approval system, more checks on the ground and more EU governance. The proposals that you will vote on tomorrow are a key instrument to achieve this. I have also always supported the Parliament’s request for compensation for consumers. The situation in the EU is wrong when companies refuse to compensate consumers for misleading information on environmental performance. Let me say at this point that last week the Commission adopted the New Deal for Consumers initiative. It proposes legal instruments on representative actions and possibilities for consumer redress. At the last trialogue in December, as part of our discussion on penalties, Parliament asked the Commission to make a declaration referring to the adoption of the New Deal for Consumers package to better protect consumers and ensure a more effective consumer redress mechanism. I have the pleasure of confirming today that the text of this declaration, together with the other declarations, is being transmitted to Parliament’s services. If such rules had been in place when the Dieselgate scandal broke out, consumer organisations and independent public bodies could have launched representative actions and sought redress for the consumers affected. With this proposal, once adopted, victims of unfair commercial practices will be in a position to obtain remedies collectively. I very much welcome the agreement between Parliament and the Council. I am looking forward to having a final deal tomorrow. With this vote tomorrow, you will send a strong and clear message to the players in this sector. I am pleased that the final outcome upheld most of the proposals from the Commission and improved some of them. I am especially happy that the main pillars of our Commission’s proposals were confirmed. They are reinforcing the independence and quality of approvals that allow a car to be placed on the market, introducing an effective market surveillance system to ensure that cars placed on the market comply with EU rules, not only at the time of approval, but also when they circulate on our roads, and reinforcing the whole system with greater European oversight to ensure a coherent implementation throughout Europe. Those three points are really crucial to ensure that everyone involved complies fully with the rules and applies the requirements in a harmonised way. I commend the hard work of the rapporteur and shadow rapporteurs. This was a huge effort from your side and I know it has not been an easy process. It has not been for us either. The car sector is crucial for meeting our EU climate targets so we also need to improve the measurement of real-life CO2 emissions as soon as possible. We will come back to that in the discussion on the CO2 package that we proposed last November. But overall this is a good deal that significantly improves the present situation. I am sure that with the type—approval package, as it is finalised tomorrow, this will be a big step forward towards safer and cleaner cars in Europe. It will also help to rebuild the trust of citizens in their authorities. I very much trust that you will finalise it tomorrow. Commission Statement (in writing) The link between the different EU and national databases (Article 9a)  The Commission shares the views of the legislator that interconnection between the different databases used for type-approval and market surveillance should be ensured. As some databases are managed individually by Member States, successful interconnection will depend on the full cooperation of Member States. The New Deal for Consumers  The Commission is concerned by mass harm situations affecting interests of consumers, as illustrated by the revelations in September 2015 about car manufacturers circumventing emissions standards for certain air pollutants, and sees the limits of existing national procedural means to secure appropriate consumer redress in such situations. The Commission has adopted a proposal on representative actions for the protection of the collective interests of consumers [COM(2018)184] as part of the New Deal for Consumers package on 11 April 2018, with the aim to empower qualified entities to launch representative actions on behalf of consumers and to introduce stronger sanctioning powers for Member States' consumer authorities. With this proposal, once adopted, victims of unfair commercial practices, such as misleading advertising by car manufacturers not in compliance with the Union regulatory framework for type approval of vehicles or environmental legislation, will be in a position to obtain remedies collectively. The obligatory market checks on the market by the Commission (Article 9)  The Commission welcomes that the markets checks to be carried out by the Commission were confirmed by the legislator. It is now essential that the legislator also ensures that this activity is properly financed in particular in the context of the Commission proposal for the next Multiannual Financial Framework.  The status quo for end of series (Article 47) The Commission regrets that for end-of series, instead of an EU procedure, the future legislation will maintain the status quo of a national procedure which is burdensome for importers, vehicles manufacturers, national and regional authorities. The current procedure also has no value added for safety and environment and creates problems for the internal market of used vehicles. The rules on the committee work For Committee rules; the Commission underlines that it is contrary to the letter and to the spirit of regulation 182/2011 (OJ L 55 of 28.2.2011, p. 13) to invoke Article 5§4, subparagraph 2, point b) in a systematic manner.  Recourse to this provision must respond to a specific need to depart from the rule of principle which is that the Commission may adopt a draft implementing act when no opinion is delivered.  Given that it is an exception to the general rule established in Article 5§4 recourse to subparagraph 2, point b), cannot be simply seen as a "discretionary power" of the Legislator, but must be interpreted in a restrictive manner and thus must be justified. The deletion of the delegation to the Commission to regulate CO2 in-use testing defeat device (Article 91) The Commission regrets that the initial Commission proposal to regulate in-service-conformity of CO2 emissions through implementing legislation was not supported by the co-legislators. This will further delay the set-up of an in-service-conformity assessment procedure which is a core element for ensuring that the CO2 emission and fuel consumption values attributed to individual vehicles are reliable. The Commission has included a similar mandate in its proposal for new Light Duty Vehicle CO2 emission standards adopted on 8 November 2017 and calls on the co-legislators to support it.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. — Mr President, The auto industry is not high in course in Europe right now. The cheating of emissions from diesel cars, dieselgate, which deliberately deceived authorities and consumers to the detriment of the environment and human health, has cost much in confidence with little money in Europe, and that is a problem in itself. It was clear when we worked on this legislation that there are a lot of people who are very disappointed in the auto industry. That's why there are many who right now in different types of legislation are calling for new tougher requirements, tougher rules, less emissions. But it's not hard new requirements we really need. What we need, after all, is control that the demands we have already made are something you live up to. We can have any hard requirements, but if there is no controlling we don't know if people will live up to them. That is why this legislation is so important and so good, because here we get control, transparency and felt punishment. As a member and responsible for the issue in the Committee on the Environment, I am really proud of the work we did, especially that we fixed funding to control, because without money it rarely becomes anything. That is why I think it is important that tomorrow we vote in favour of this so that we not only make new laws on new rules and new requirements, but that we make sure that the requirements we make are also something that manufacturers are forced to live up to.

name: Karima DELLI
text: draftswoman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, for more than two years the Dieselgate scandal broke out. Everyone knew: the car manufacturers, the States, the Commission. Our mission in the European Parliament was to put an end to this impunity. What have we done? No withdrawal of vehicles, no real compensation from consumers, nor fines for manufacturers who have defrauded. Mr Dalton, there is indeed some progress in your report, but in the European Parliament we prevented the creation of an independent car market surveillance agency at the very moment when Mr Trump wants to remove the equivalent US agency so that he can pollute everything. Yet ladies and gentlemen, we are facing emergencies. First, 30 million garbage vehicles still pollute our roads. Then, second emergency, the disease of the 21st century: air pollution, which causes another 400,000 premature deaths per year. So, I tell you, even if this report is a breakthrough, it will not be enough to close this Dieselgate story to a real post-Dieselgate.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me first of all very much thank the rapporteur, Mr Dalton, for his enormous work, but also the other colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs and the European Commission, which has always been open, always ready to communicate, and above all, look for common solutions that we really need. I am pleased that these solutions were indeed found first in our committee and then together in the trialogue. I would like to emphasise three things in particular. Firstly, it is clear that we very much need new legislation for the approval of new vehicles. Secondly, it is really obvious that we need the same rules in our common European space and the 'dieselgate' cannot happen again. Our citizens cannot be deceived. And, thirdly, it is clear that we need to protect the environment better, but also to think about the development of new technologies and employment in the European Union. We have been working on this resulting form of new legislation for over a year. And the result is a change in methodology, new competences, but also synergies between the European level and the national states. Full-operational tests are being put in place, the competences of the Commission are strengthened and a uniform procedure and uniform interpretation of the rules throughout the Union are ensured. The events of past years have shown that this is really very, very necessary. I am sure we do not need new institutions, but we need a quick substantial change that will work. We do not need new costs, but we need clear rules. And we do not need scattered Member States, but we need the same rules for our common market. The exit from the trialogue is a really good proposal, and I believe that it will be supported by anyone who cares about real change and protecting the interests of our citizens. (Applause)

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Mr President! Madam Commissioner, colleagues! I've been really looking forward to this day. For long, we can set a both legal and a political period for the diesel street scandal. And we're doing it in a proper way. Because although we European Socialists would have liked to see even more ambitious legislation, we are, after all, at an important milestone today. With the new legislation we now get, we will have a much more robust system for both approval and control of the cars in the European market - far better than what we have today. Why is it even necessary? Sure, dieselgate revealed that a number of automakers were deliberately cheating on diesel cars' release of the harmful NOx gases by diesel cars. It wasn't alone illegal, it was deadly too! It has claimed the lives of several thousands of EU citizens that they did not comply with the rules we had in this area. That's unacceptable! It's a scandal that they cheated, but it's also a scandal that our system was unable to intercept it - that we didn't detect it ourselves. It was the Americans who discovered our problem with dieselgate. But we are correcting that now with this law. There is far more and far better control coming both before cars come out on the market and also when they drive. One of the new things is that we are actually imposing very directly on the Member States that they have to control cars - not just at their own discretion, but we put some target figures on how much they need to check. And not enough with that: we have also learned that will have to check that we are doing well enough. That is why we also give the Commission competences and the ability to conduct market controls itself. I think that is something very central and I also think that will be part of what allows us to prevent a new dieselgate in the future. But not enough with that: It's also important that we can sanction if we find cheating in the future. With the massive fines we add up to if one cheats, then we think it will have a preventive effect. Finally, we are also enabling NGOs to help us get the market checked. We know it was American NGOs who discovered the scam with people wagon. We are creating a more transparent system with an online database, which allows others to help check for. That's really important. I would also like to say that if it hadn't been for the European Socialists, I don't actually think we would have got as good a system as what we end up having. Indeed, there were many both in the Council and in this House who were not as ambitious as we were. So I am really proud today and I also think that European citizens will be really happy about what we are now doing.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Dan Dalton, for all his good work I think that the diesel gate has exposed a harsh reality, namely that the current rules have failed. I am therefore very pleased with these new, more efficient rules which give a strict political signal to close the loopholes in the legislative network. In this way, we can clearly state that this can never and must never happen again. It is only through good cooperation between the Member States and Europe that we will be able to better protect our health, our environment, in short, the European citizen. By strengthening European market surveillance and, of course, also by better monitoring the implementation and enforcement of the rules, the emission scandals must now be referred once and for all to the history books.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, almost three years have almost passed since the Dieselgate scandal broke, and a little over two years have passed since the Commission proposed a revised type-approval regulation. We finally vote tomorrow on this important file, and we can now say that the EU is reacting effectively to the scandal and delivering strong legislation – legislation that will help restore consumers’ trust and make sure our common rules are fully respected.  It was obvious that the EU needed upgraded legislation in this matter so that there are no more loopholes such as have been used in the past by some manufacturers to bypass the EU’s rules. I am convinced that the trilogue negotiations were able to reach this goal, and I hope this House sees it in a similar way.  Personally, I am glad that this new law will help to fix the system by introducing clear rules on market surveillance, with specific targets for the Member States to meet. This set of measures is, in my view, a major benefit of this regulation which should help to solve the situation on EU roads. It also gives new competences to the Commission to intervene. Both Member States and the Commission can act not only when type-approving a vehicle, but also when the vehicle is in production or in use. There will be enhanced control over Member States’ authorities, both issuing type-approvals and carrying out market surveillance, as well as technical services and other relevant stakeholders. Key now is the proper implementation and enforcement of this regulation.  I am also glad that a new system of strict penalties has been introduced which could be imposed on manufacturers in case they produce and place on market non-compliant vehicles. In general, I believe that this outcome meets adequately our expectations and provides a robust and reliable framework which fits with our ambitions in the area of protection of the environment and protection of consumers’ rights.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, I hear the satisfaction expressed on the benches of this Parliament and if I myself congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Dalton, on the work that has been done and the fact that we have tried to reach agreement, I also congratulate the Commission, Commissioner, on its initial text and beyond the Commissioner, the Commission services, which have done a great job. I regret the absence of the Council today because the issue of Dieselgate is first and foremost the question of the schizophrenia of States that were aware of fraud, as was said earlier. Just as soon as we do not break the umbilical link between the services of the national authorities, between certification certifications and manufacturers, we cannot find the solution because, quite simply, the automotive industry is too important for these states. We have therefore made progress on this issue, but we have failed to ensure that Europe is up to the level by taking responsibility for approvals itself through the Commission and a new agency. We have made progress, but we still have a long way to go, and I am counting on the Commission to propose texts to this effect in the months and years to come.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank Mr Dalton for his good work as a locomotive man on an important issue. European consumers need reliable, independent and high-quality type-approval and market controls. That, of course, will pay, and it would be good for the Member States to provide fairly necessary resources for this action. Thanks to the automotive diesel emissions scandal is the problems of car type approval and market control. Some of the loopholes that the greedy auto industry so happy and effectively exploits are now succeeding in plugging. Type approval and market surveillance must be independent and impartial. The automotive industry should not play any role in delivering cars to the type-approval authorities and paying for the services received. It can't be the case that we have Santa as a guard of cabbage. No more mistakes like that, thank you. I would have loved to have seen research institutions belong to the type-approval authorities rather than the automotive industry. We would have now had the opportunity to fix all the problems of type-approval and market control that came to light with the emissions scandal and which were discovered by the EMIS Committee of Inquiry. Unfortunately, it is not quite a conclusion, but I am grateful that at least these brave steps were dared to be taken.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I also congratulate rapporteur Dalton on the result, although, to be honest, I consider myself moderately satisfied, because the initial project could be decidedly more ambitious. True, in part we have overcome what are conflicts of interest between controller and controlled; we have strengthened market surveillance, with a minimum target of annual controls on new vehicles, Real vehicles and therefore not prototypes; we have the opportunity to impose fines for defaults; we can no longer say you do not know, thanks to cross-checks. But we didn't completely break that connection between controlled and controller. We would have preferred a system that would not allow automakers to finance laboratories guaranteeing technical assistance for type-approvals and, in addition, we would have liked that all citizens Europeans could benefit from the same compensation system across Europe, which is not the case yet.

name: Andreas SCHWAB
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I too, of course, would like to thank the rapporteur and all shadow rapporteurs I believe that we have managed to find a solution in a really highly political dossier, which is also difficult in public debate, to which we have managed many things. On the one hand, to ensure that the existing authorities of the Member States will have to see themselves in a common European system of responsibility for vehicle control in the future, also because they are faced with control by the European Commission that did not exist before. With this, I believe, we have succeeded in making the Member States more involved in the control themselves and also by strengthening the independence of Member States' supervisory authorities with regard to type-approval. This is an important step which helps Member States to see their own responsibilities in this process, which, unfortunately, they have not seen before to the extent that this would have been necessary. Secondly, it is important that we make it clear that vehicles must, of course, be placed on the market by manufacturers in such a way that they comply with the rules adopted by the legislator and that no loopholes can be exploited — and certainly not in an unlawful manner. The third is that, with the resolution we are now creating, too, we have ensured that what is necessary is not now delayed by lengthy discussions on the establishment of a new authority, but that we can directly use the experts of the authorities that we already have today. That is why I believe that the Commission and Parliament have developed a really good proposal here, which must now enter into force as soon as possible. Many thanks to all who have have contributed.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it has taken two and a half years, not least because of the resistance of large interest groups and the blocking positions of certain Member States, to find an agreement that will set the more than satisfactory rules that should avoid a repeat of another Volkswagen scandal. A conniving type-approval system, with obvious conflicts of interest between automakers, national control agencies, often private and financed by the same, will finally be replaced by a more effective surveillance and control system, with powers also of the European Commission. The latter will finally have an independent role as a genuine guarantee body, with the possibility of carrying out roadside emissions tests and regular inspections of motor vehicles that already are present on the market. Also on consumer rights, this proposal marks an important step forward from the past: as socialists and democrats, we fought to ensure that European citizens could benefit from compensation instruments on a par with American ones. We couldn't get as much as we wanted. However, having determined that non-compliant passenger car owners are in no way forced to incur costs for repair or recall measures is still a good result. The dual message that comes from the European Parliament today is clear: controls on cars and their emissions will be more credible and consumer rights, which have been over the last ten years scammed, they will be stronger.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: Mr President, it is now more than two years since we were told that one of the giants in the car industry had tampered with the measurements for emissions from their cars. As a result of this, a committee of inquiry was set up in which we looked together for its cause. But more importantly, we had to find a way to avoid such a deception of consumers in the future. On the basis of our findings, we formulated a number of recommendations. When I look at the proposal before us today, I am glad to see that many of them have also been taken to heart. Therefore, a proposal for lower emissions and healthy air for our children and grandchildren is a proposal that I support.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, one year ago I had the chance to speak on this report and to congratulate Mr Dalton and his colleagues on their good work. Today, I would like to reiterate my support of this important report, which will bring about huge changes and improvements to the car industry. In the past, we’ve had some car manufacturers falsifying fuel consumption and emissions claims due to self-interest and profit. This is completely unacceptable.  I believe that the changes introduced in this regulation will do much to re-establish consumer confidence in the car industry after the scandals of the past, often known as ‘dieselgate’. Even more importantly, this regulation will ensure that the health of our citizens and the environment are protected from these harmful emissions, causing up to 400 000 deaths per annum, as Ms Danti said. I welcome the Commission’s simple role in this new and improved system. They are well positioned to assess vehicles and ensure that the new rules are adhered to. I was not convinced of the supposed benefits of introducing an agency, as the Commission can do the job well and cost—effectively.  I am pleased that random market surveillance will be introduced, testing one in five types every year. This new system will test emissions, but also safety standards of cars. The penalty system is vital to bring a strong establishment for these changes. Those who comply with the regulation have nothing to worry about, but those who consider ignoring the requirements will be deterred by the penalties increasing in proportion with the number of non-compliances. A good job.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: — Sur President, Sentejn u nofs wara D-Diesel Gate - aktar minn qatt qabel - dan huwa ż-żmien li naertaw runa li jkollna r-riżultati. U din il-lithe, li bthe ala Soto jalisti u Democratii tant ariodimna fuqha, tipprovdi sistema dida gall-approvazzjon tal-vetturi u gЂas-sorveljar tas-suq li jistgЂu, iva, ikunu b'sathe the al. Hawnhekk nixtieq nirringrazzja wkoll Lill-kummissjon galiex il-ftehim li gЂandna issa gandu l-potenzjal li jiżgura li l-control, is-salvagwardji u t-trasparenza, li huma nieqsa mis-sistema kurrenti, u li tant nefil-fatt fis-seat. Jekk implimentata sew, din il-lithe tista' tgin biex nipproteto u l-ambjent filwaqt li tgin ukoll l-industrija tal-karozzi tikseb lura l-fiduityja tal-konsumaturi. Is-sostenibilità gandha tkun il-qafas printo pali tal-pjanijiet u l-politika kollha tagЂna. Issa rridu naraw li dawn il-pjanijiet u l-policies jienu implimentati kif suppost, gallowaliex finalment dan biss jista' jiżgura li n-nies verament jieto du dak li jarvaallsu gthe alih, u li arva-allsux il-prezz al karozzi li jniioto su to aktar milli suppost.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I want from the outset to congratulate the rapporteur, colleague Dalton, but also the shadow rapporteurs and all the colleagues who, as the Commissioner said, have made improvements to the Commission's proposal. I think it must be a lesson, because, in fact, we have now reacted to a case, we have not come preemptively to check a document, a regulation that we have for the internal market, and perhaps, in the future, we will be more cautious. What I want to point out here is that, yes, certainly, with this new legal framework we will have an improvement in regulation in the internal market with regard to motor vehicles, type-approval, not only motor vehicles, components. I am very pleased that it has been introduced and I have always argued that importers should also be subject to the same rules and distributors should be subject to the same rules. This is contained in the report. I, too, believe that through very good collaboration between national authorities and the Commission, we can supervise and achieve better results both for consumer protection, and for - in circulation - risk reduction, but also for environmental protection.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: — Commissioner, the revision of the regulation for the approval of motor vehicles is a natural and unavoidable response to the contradiction that has arisen between the rules set, their actual performance and supervision, which should detect any irregularities in a timely manner throughout the internal market. The consistent separation of approval and market surveillance authorities, information sharing obligations in the event of deficiencies identified, or the ability to examine those vehicles already on the market will contribute to higher transparency of the whole system and will allow the setting of equal rules for all actors. Ultimately, any opposition to the legislation may not be paid by the end consumer. On the contrary, consumers should be entitled to claim compensation if they do damage. Therefore, I also welcome the proposal for a so-called new policy for consumers to complement existing instruments to enable consumers to have their rights and to establish a mass action institute.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in order to avoid a repeat of scandals such as dieselgate in the future, this regulation is undoubtedly a step forward. However, in my view, much remains to be done, especially on transparency and consumer protection — some colleagues have said today. The possibility of independent checks on approved cars is still limited, and European citizens cannot take advantage of a uniform compensation system throughout the Union. We cannot afford to let our guard down, and it is also another front on which we must act to protect the health of citizens and protect the environment: we must ensure that CO2 emissions measured in the lab match those in the real world. To date, in fact, it is the scissor between the emissions measured in the laboratory and simulated ones is 40% and will widen if we do not solve this problem with roadside verification tests. For this reason, as the Five Star Movement, we will continue to fight for the introduction of an emission verification procedure under real driving conditions.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the automotive industry accounts for 6.4% of gross domestic product and generates two and a half million jobs in the European Union. The Volkswagen case highlighted all the shortcomings in the implementation of type-approval rules for motor vehicles in the European Union, in particular with respect to emissions rules.
