The World Health Organisation has repeatedly reiterated that exhaust gases emitted by diesel engines are carcinogenic. The fraud committed by automakers has not only been detrimental to health and the environment, but also — and to a considerable extent — to the public finances. The mendacious declarations on exhaust gases are estimated to have created a tax loss of more than EUR 46 billion in Europe. This Regulation creates the conditions for ensuring effective application of Community legislation and functional market supervision. The quality of the tests is strengthened, first of all improving the provisions relating to type-approval authorities. Now we must act quickly for implementation: trust and health of citizens are at stake and time is up!

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first I want to warmly thank Members for the support for the high level of ambitions in this proposal, expressed literally by all of you. As any discussion is connected to the budget in some way or another, let me say that we must make sure – and this is my pledge to you – that the Commission is well equipped to carry out the new responsibilities properly. Again, let me stress that this reform is really vital to ensure sufficient EU oversight and prevent any future misconduct. Together with our real-conditions driving tests we will ensure that what has been approved on paper will be matched in the reality. The reform is also important to pave the way for connected and automated cars, to reduce air pollution and to reach our climate target, which is extremely important. It will be the key, as many of you mentioned, to restoring public confidence. I also want to assure you that it will ensure the full independence of market surveillance. We never want to see a repetition of the Dieselgate scandal again and this proposal is really a key tool to ensure it. Again a really, really warm ‘thank-you’ to the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs. Thank you very much for the support and the cooperation.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the speakers for their comments. Parliament had a strong and effective team which helped to deliver this result, and that is reflected in the comments that we’ve seen from across the chamber. I want to thank all the shadows and all the colleagues who took part in this process. It’s important, of course, that we adopt the report tomorrow. I believe that this report can serve as a lasting reform of the whole vehicle approval process.  I would just leave one word of warning, because I am a little bit concerned to hear of plans from the Commission to present amendments to the type-approval framework in the context of the Brexit process. This should be of concern to everyone in this Chamber, because cars on the road today are not wholly covered by EU-only approvals. There is an international mechanism for mutual recognition of vehicle approvals, which is maintained in this report. A common sense approach would allow for a deeper system of mutual recognition here, along the lines of what is foreseen with other third countries such as Japan, under the new economic partnership. Instead, under the flag of providing business certainty, changes to the system affecting UK vehicle approvals would have huge repercussions all over Europe. For example, a Czech car, built in the Czech Republic by Czech workers, couldn’t be sold in the Czech domestic market if it had a UK-type approval. The situation is similar in Germany, in Italy and in Spain, and anywhere there is a UK-type approval.  The regulation of motor vehicles is a success story for international cooperation globally. It has been a success story for European cooperation over the last 40 years. That will continue after the UK leaves the EU. I’m very pleased that we’ve got this report today and I thank everyone for the support they gave me, but just a word of warning there to the Commission that we need to make sure that we continue this cooperation and success in this area going forward.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: I'm closing the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 19 April 2018. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. — Union regulations related to the approval of automotive products cover a total of 3 categories of vehicles: motor vehicles and their trailers, tractors and motorcycles. The legal regulations on motorcycles and tractors are not in doubt, since they were introduced in 2013, and the practical implementation of these solutions is not much controversy. Unfortunately, the issues related to the approval of motor vehicles and their trailers look different. We have in practice 2 serious problems. The first problem is that the 2007 directive in this area is interpreted in a very different way across the 28 EU countries. This results in a gross reduction in the effectiveness of the applicable Union law. The second problem we face in recent years is the fraud that some car companies have been allowed, especially Germany's Volkswagen. This scandal involved tampering with software and giving untrue information about CO2 emissions. Therefore, when adopting the new EP and Council Regulation on the approval and surveillance of the market for motor vehicles and their trailers, we must answer whether the proposed solutions will allow the elimination of existing serious cuffs for reliable approval and surveillance. For this is fundamental to the safety of passengers and the protection of the environment. In my view, the proposed solutions create such chances.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: The next item is the report by Martin Häusling, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on organic production and labelling of organic products, amending Regulation (EU) No XXX/XXX of the European Parliament and of the Council [Official Control Regulation] and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 834/2007 (COM (2014) 0180 — C7-0109/2014 — 2014/0100 (COD)) (A8-0311/2015).

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. After four years, we almost completed the project of a new eco-regulation — after 18 trilogues under six presidencies. I should particularly like to thank the Presidency of the Council of Malta, but also that of Estonia, for being able to conclude this. We have now actually brought together 260 pages of eco-regulation — as someone from the journalists said yesterday: the Bible of organic farming. I would particularly like to thank my shadow rapporteurs — I do not want to do this at the end, but now — for working together so well. I should like to thank the Commission and, of course, the Secretariat for their excellent cooperation. But I would also like to thank two people who have worked with me all the time: Hannes Lorenzen and also Corinna Hartmann, who have invested a lot of time in making this happen. We can proudly say that we now have a regulation that is an improvement on the current old regulation and, above all — this is very important — it is very important — strengthens the confidence of consumers, but also of farmers, in the ecosector. And this is very important. Trust in the eco sector label is the most important thing we need to shape. We have thus also created a solid foundation for the dynamic development of the biosector in Europe. We can also see from the double-digit growth rates that we are also able to develop the ecosector in Europe. I would also like to comment briefly on a number of points which are very important innovations. We have improved import control: a standard instead of 64 different standards. This will also boost consumer confidence in imports. But we have also left enough room for imports from the Global South so that we do not close the market now. But we also have — and you have to say in this area — the competitive situation of European farmers strengthened. Overall, we have strengthened controls, we have put process-oriented control at the forefront, and annual control is still standard in this regulation. This does not preclude risk controls from playing a significant role in future controls. And we have managed to simplify: group certification — this is mainly used for smaller companies and smaller dealers, including in Europe. We have enshrined the principle of 'ground-based agriculture' in this regulation — with only a few exceptions in Nordic countries, in greenhouses. This principle is extremely important for organic farming. And we have continued our efforts to actually improve seeds, so that in future we will also have organic seeds in all European countries, but also organic animals in the field in the future. The first basis for this is databases in all Member States, not just some. The aim will be that, in the end, the same standard will indeed exist in all Member States. But we have also tried to set different standards in breeding in the biosector, namely that we develop our own right. Organic seeds have different conditions in seed breeding, and we will strengthen this. And heterogeneous material in the future will no longer be subject to the strict rules that need to be applied in other areas. This is a very significant advantage for future regulation. And we have, of course, dealt with the issue of pesticides, although, of course, I have to say quite clearly here: organic farming is more than pesticide, and organic farming is going much further. But first of all we said: we need to strengthen the foundations on which we are even discussing. This is why the Commission is invited to present a report in the next few years. in order to clarify the situation with contamination: Where do they come from, who causes them? We have called on the sector to strengthen its precautionary measures. But the commercial sector is also called upon to take account of the ecological sector in the end. We are now talking about the delegated and implementing acts, and I hope, also in good cooperation with the Commission, so that we can finally solve this part in cooperation with the sector.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am particularly pleased to be here and to participate in this debate this evening because in Ireland we have a saying that ‘it’s a long road that has no turn’ and there were certainly many twists and turns on this road over the last four years. I have to compliment the patience and determination of everybody in trying to reach our objective of harmonising and regulating the organic sector. I would particularly like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Häusling and his shadows, Mr Lins, Mr Andrieu, Mr Jakovčić, Ms Girling, Mr Zullo, Ms Senra Rodríguez, and the late Mr Ferrand. I welcome the conclusion of this process, which, in my view, is overdue. A lot of people were reluctant to accept that we could achieve an outcome that was successful. When it was put on the Commission work programme I took a leap of faith in the ability of everybody to be able to reach an agreement and I’m glad that it wasn’t totally misplaced. We should remember that many of the current rules are over 20 years old, and they needed to be updated in any event to reflect the major changes that have taken place in the EU organic sector over that time. We are talking about a very dynamic sector which has enormous potential and one that has been transformed from a niche sector to one that is very much in the mainstream in agriculture. It is a market that is now worth about EUR 27 billion per annum, which is 125% more than it was 10 years ago. So I’m satisfied that we have managed to reach a reasonable and balanced compromise in many areas, which meets the essential priorities for the three institutions. Most importantly, it reaches a stability and predictability, from the point of view of the organic operators across the European Union. The agreement provides the conditions for European Union organic production to accelerate its move away from being simply a niche production and continue on its path of sustained growth while maintaining consumer confidence. The consumer must have trust in the organic brand and in the organic logo. The text on which you are about to vote will ensure fair competition and a level playing field for EU organic farmers, while the assurance is being offered to consumers by the EU organic logo in terms of production and quality standards and these will be further strengthened from this process. The new regulation has further harmonised the production rules which has wiped away the à la carte derogations: it will ensure that the same rules apply to all organic producers and products. Today we have 60-plus different standards that apply to imported organic foods and these will be replaced by compliance, meaning that those who wish to export their organic products to the EU market must respect EU organic rules. This ensures a level playing field between the operators from both inside and outside the European Union. Moreover, the new regulation brings greater simplification for our farmers, something that I have prioritised since becoming Commissioner. For example, small farmers now will be able to choose group certification, which will reduce their certification costs and make it easier for them to join the organic scheme. The scope of the organic rules has been extended to cover a range of new products such as salt, cork and essential oils. It will also be possible in the future to add new products in order to respond to the development of the sector and to the consumers’ demand, providing additional opportunities for our producers. New opportunities will also be created by the opening of new markets for organic heterogeneous seeds, as Mr Häusling has just said, and indeed other plant reproductive material with a high level of genetic and phenotypic biodiversity. This will improve biodiversity and crop sustainability and will boost innovation. Resistance to pests and diseases will be improved and better adaptation to local conditions will be a focus. As regards controls, the delimitation between horizontal food safety rules and the rules that are meant to guarantee the respect of organic principles have been clarified. The horizontal Official Controls Regulation will be valid for organics, while the Organic Regulation contains additional rules to target the specificity of the sector. Opening up to risk-based controls will lower the burden for producers and allow authorities to better use their available resources. I’m glad that we got a pragmatic outcome on demarcated beds, which will give another 10 years to our friends in Scandinavia to protect their existing system. I’m disappointed that we didn’t reach a more ambitious outcome on pesticides. Mr Häusling didn’t refer to this at all, he gave a different version of events to know why we didn’t reach an outcome on this, but we will let this pass on this occasion. As far as you can see, and from what I’ve just said, you can see that the road has been a long and winding one, but I’m sure we can all agree that we did our best to achieve an outcome that is a big improvement on the old system, which has stood us in good stead over 20 years, but needed to be modernised. We’re not talking anymore about a niche market, we’re talking about a very solid sector, and constant growth and export opportunities are increasingly available on third-country markets. We are modernising the sector as we were trying to do with our agricultural policy generally. Can I finally repeat my appreciation to Mr Häusling and his team, to my own officials in the Commission and all of the shadows that have been part of the three institutions that have brought this about and for the tenacity to see it through when many people thought we couldn’t do so?

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. — Mr President, organic production, if, in addition to agriculture, is a key environmental issue, and I would therefore like to emphasise that the competency of the Committee on the Environment should be on an equal footing with the Committee on Agriculture in preparing and deciding on these matters. A politically cumbersome process with a reasonable, partly excellent result, as with, say, the seed data bank. But there have been a few key deficiencies: Animal welfare levels are not higher, pesticide concentrations do not match the standard level consistent with organic production. This should definitely be fixed. And third, of course, is the greenhouse/land resource issue for the Nordic countries, which for tomato and cucumbers can be quite an unreasonable end situation. We're not talking about general aquatic or airborne breeding, we're talking about the fact that in a pretty poorly 30 degree frost, tomato or cucumber is rooted in normal soil. Hopefully this can be resolved permanently in the future, giving investment certainty to the producers, which they are absolutely indispensable to miss. The issue of foreign surveillance that we had a discussion about, but we didn't get out of the tree for long. We know that normal border control doesn't help organic production because organic doesn't smell, taste or look different in itself. The question then is whether the obligation on third country manufacturers can be subject to third-party audited control over the production process.

name: Norbert LINS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. With the new eco-regulation, we are making the European organic farming industry fit for the future. The market for organic products is growing steadily, as the Commissioner has presented. The niche existence in the industry has long since been none. Bio has established itself. For interested farmers, organic farming offers great potential for development. More and more consumers are buying ecologically produced goods. We support all this with the text to be adopted. We have set realistic standards and, I believe, we have also created new legal certainty. At the same time, we maintain the coexistence of organic and conventional agriculture. All this was and has been the motivation for me to get involved in this dossier. Whether new import rules, control rules, limit values and residues problems or mixed farms, we have reached compromises on all this that the sector can live with. It is no coincidence that we took a total of 18 trilogues and more than one and a half years to negotiate. The Commission's original proposal of March 2014 promised many things, but not the right direction for organic farming. Ultimately, we as Parliament were able to make many improvements in tough trilogue negotiations. I would like to thank everyone, the rapporteur, the Commission, the Council for being able to achieve a good result at the end of the day.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (FR) Mr President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to thank Martin Häusling, our rapporteur, for his tenacity and self-denial in this report. We consumed four presidencies. So we came to a result that today was worth the collective efforts we have led. I would have liked us to go further in the framework of this new regulation, particularly on the issue of thresholds. However, this new legislation carries very substantial advances for organic farming, for the farmer and for the consumer. It will help to strengthen the fight against fraud on imported organic products, which today represent — as we know — 30% of our consumption. European producers will now be placed on an equal footing with producers in third countries. I am pleased that this text now allows organic farmers to produce and use their own seeds. Indeed, this regulation finally opens the door to heterogeneous equipment. There is an urgent need to rebalance the food chain and stop rolling out the red carpet in front of agrochemical oligopoles. Today, it is necessary to know, three groups concentrate more than 53% of the world seed market. The compromise also provides for more targeted controls and annual monitoring remains and will remain the rule. By the way, the principle of the link of the plant to the soil is enshrined, which is an excellent thing for organic farming. The introduction of precautionary measures makes it clear that the contamination of organic products by pesticides is avoided. This is a notable breakthrough. Rejecting the text, as some have called for, would lead to maintaining the current situation, i.e. a settlement full of shortcomings and derogations that undermines the credibility of the European organic label. However, it is fundamental, as has been said, to accompany the farmers in this essential transition to a sustainable model that respects human health and the environment, and which our fellow citizens call for more of their wishes every day. I repeat: we must quickly go further, Commissioner, because this new regulation is an important step, but it is not the finish line.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Mr President! Commissioner! Although not all of the solutions negotiated by the Commission, Parliament and the Council contained in this Regulation are satisfactory, I am confident that they will promote an increase in organic production and will increase at a similar rate to this time. Just to remind you that it has increased as much as triple in the last 10 years. On this occasion, I would like to draw attention to the positive solutions that have been found in this regulation. First, the possibility of introducing group certification of small manufacturers. Secondly, to extend to 24 months the validity of the checks of subjects with low risk levels. Thirdly, allowing further cultivation by mixed farms running organic and conventional crops in parallel. Fourthly, in the case of imports of organic products from third countries, the transition from a so-called equivalence system to a system of full compliance with Union standards. And finally, excluding from the certification system retailers selling packaged products directly to the final consumer.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. — Dear Chairman, Honored Mr. Commissioner, maybe we all had a greater ambition together than we achieved, but I think we made a great result. I know there were more ambitious ideas, we wanted to take steps forward, but I think we made decisive and excellent moves when we finally coordinated this report on a series of trialogues and I must say that I first participated in such a trialog and I was pleased that we were together with Mr. Häusling and other shadow reporters and with your associates, Mr. Commissioner, have made a good document. I think three principles should be highlighted: harmonization, standardization and simplification of procedures. It goes in favor of agricultural producers, it goes to the benefit of consumers. Of course today when we talk about the 27 billion euro market that bioproducts have, we are all aware of how big it is and we are all aware that this market will only grow, 125% has grown in the last ten years. So we have ahead of us a really great responsibility to turn what will mean the future of European agriculture into something that will be our shared success. Mr. Commissioner, I think it was just a production, and I'm going to add some more, and geographical origin, something that should be one of the pillars of the common agricultural policy in the future because that's where I see the strongest possible competitiveness of European agriculture precisely in bioproduction and production products with a protected origin. That's where I see our chance in the world market and that's why I support this report and ALDE will vote for this report.

name: Thomas WAITZ
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. As a bio-farmer, it is quite beneficial for me to hear here — at least from the groups that are present — that everyone supports organic farming, so does the Commissioner. I would like to deal specifically with a subject, that is seed. For me, as a bio-farmer, a central point of this regulation will be that in future we will be able to allow our own seeds, even if it is heterogeneous — that is, genetically diverse — to be able to sell our own seeds to our colleagues through a simple authorisation procedure. In organic farming, it is evident that the diversity of seeds is an essential basis for meeting climatically different conditions and regionally different conditions. We live from this diversity every day in organic farming. I would like to thank Mr Häusling for the work of Mr Häusling and all the other shadow rapporteurs, and also expressly the Commissioner for their support.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — (ES) Mr President, I too would like to thank Mr Häusling for the work he has done throughout this time to make it present today, here, in this debate on this regulation. I would also like to stress the importance of organic farming and regulations in regulating it and, in this regard, I would like to comment that there are positive aspects, many positive aspects in this Regulation — such as the prohibition of nanomaterials, the prohibition of cloned animals, ionizing radiation and also of genetically manipulated organisms — although I would like to stress that for me it would be important — and it is a lack that we find in this Regulation — that we could go further to introduce some measure that would allow us to begin to overcome — or at least tackle — the genetically manipulated organisms in the medicines for animals. It is also very positive — and we highlight as very positive — heterogeneous organic material, favoring local varieties, peasant seeds, as well as short marketing circuits and local productions. But we are also concerned about the presence of basic organic foods in international markets. For us, organic farming has to go far beyond the production of organic food; it must also take into account aspects such as, for example, transport generates greenhouse gases and energy waste, and we think that organic farming should not contribute to this. We would also have liked to see more stringent limits than those of conventional foods themselves. And, as I see my time is running out, I'd like to end up by making a reference to aquaculture. We don't understand that aquaculture can be organic simply because fish eat organic food: food waste, excrement and food residues of medicines going to water are a problem by which we understand that it should not be considered as such.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, I cannot join the appreciation expressed so far by my colleagues. The result we have achieved, from our point of view, is essentially a downward compromise, and this is because the Commission, although it has put forward an ambitious proposal, has decided to give in front to the pressure of Northern European countries, more like anything else. So we are not happy with this solution, because we think it aims more than anything else to “label” more biological than “do” more biological: and it is a substantial difference. We've taken a huge step back in what it comes to contamination by unauthorized substances. Those who buy organic expect a zero-residue product: they don't want contamination from pesticides or unallowed substances. Then, while we understand the need of farmers not to be penalized if their product is contaminated, perhaps, by drifts from neighbours, we would still have preferred a different solution: to keep the thresholds, to offer contaminated farmers — not because of their fault — adequate compensation and, in this way, give the market the opportunity to aim upwards, to have a quality market that offers the consumer a truly safe organic product, rather than lowering the quality level.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Mr President, this report has a merit: it is a bit concerned with introducing a certain requirement for traceability of agricultural products. This traceability is essential for consumers to know where the products they eat come from, but also according to what standards they arrive on their plate, which is, on our part, a recurring demand for a long time. Certainly, some adjuvants may not be organic. However, we are particularly pleased that it is finally possible to use peasant seeds again, which is a major step forward. Indeed, two positive aspects relate to their use: the freedom and autonomy found by farmers in their choice and their know-how in the field of seeds and seedlings. Similarly, unlike the fertilizer-pesticide system, which imposes a small number of varieties, peasant seeds allow the preservation of biodiversity and natural resources. International trade requirements are also strengthened. Finally, group certification is an opportunity for small producers. That is why we will vote in favour of the report, even if these are still far too timid progress in our view.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President! There is no doubt that organic farming and organic products are, of course, a growth sector, as several colleagues here have also said. And I believe it is right that we are now giving the sector a positive boost, and much of what is in place in this new legislation is indeed reasonable and will also give the sector a new impetus. But there is a proverb in German that says: “Good thing needs good Weil”, and I have the impression that we do not need to discuss “good because”. It took us a whole legislature to do the whole thing. You can talk a little bit about good thing, and several colleagues here have already said: when it comes to pesticide residues, it's not 'good thing'. This means that we have maintained a solution that we already have. There are countries in the European Union that do not know any difference between organic products and conventional products when it comes to residues, and then there are states such as the state from which I come, Italy, where there is much stricter regulation. And I wonder, or at least it raises some questions: is this compatible with a common internal market? Then another question: what is the case with product controls for products coming from abroad? We still have none. We're gonna have to believe what happens abroad. And the most important question is: how do we explain this to a consumer who actually expects a little different from an organic product? There is no doubt, of course some have won here now. I believe it will be a pyrrhic victory in the long term.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: Mr President. I'm glad to see you in the presidency! I would like to say that I am glad that this regulation can finally be adopted in this House. It has taken a long time and it is a regulation that is part of everyone's effort. Each Group has highlighted differences, but if a Group had won in the end, a general agreement would not have been possible. So it's a good deal. Everyone would not have liked it more, but I think that this is a right agreement and it will certainly strengthen farmers and consumers. I therefore find it a very important step forward in border control, that is to say that we have harmonised those rules and that we do not have, as the Commissioner said, 60 rules. I think this is an important step forward, along with the possibility that European agriculture will shift towards the ecological model — a big part — because we consume only 55% of what we produce. Therefore, there is a breakthrough in order to continue producing in organic production. Thank you to Mr Häusling and the shadow rapporteurs for this great work.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - Mr President! The popularity of organic products is increasing in Europe and around the world. That's good, because organic farming is environmental sustainability, biodiversity conservation, is healthy and safe food, and ethical treatment of animals in food production. It's finally zero tolerance for GMOs and animal cloning and an urgent wait for a total ban on pesticides. But it's important that organic farming is credible, true and honest. The official logo of organic farming in the European Union — that is euro leaf — must give on the one hand benefit to organic farmers and ensure fair competition for organic production, and on the other hand the consumer must be assured that the organic product is of exemplary quality. Thus, clear and consistent procedures for facilitating certification for small farmers, consent to mixed farms — this is organic and conventional, but the quality of organic production should be controlled at every stage of production and distribution, and in terms of production ecological entities from third countries are to apply legislation the same as the European Union.

name: Ulrike MÜLLER
text: Mr President! Good thing takes a while — you can really say that with the EU Ecoregulation. After four years, four presidencies and eighteen trilogues, a result has finally been achieved. Demand for organically produced food is increasing, and in order to meet this demand, it was imperative to revise the previous EU eco-regulations. Now there really is a common framework, as well as uniform European standards for organic products. Three things are important to me: producers from non-EU countries wishing to import their organic products into the EU must comply with our rules. In this way, fair competition and consumer protection can be guaranteed. Agricultural holdings in compliance with the rules may be controlled no more than every two years. That means fewer fees. Of course, this is only possible if there are no complaints. Thirdly, a compromise was found that manufacturers of organic infant formulas and follow-on formulae can also label their products with the biolabel. Thanks to the rapporteurs!

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: — Mr President, this regulation naturally has positive aspects, but it commits an original sin, which is to focus all its attention on the product, omitting the social and environmental component associated with organic production. In other words, this regulation, in practice, promotes the production of organic products on an industrial scale, which is also export-oriented, with a fundamental principle which should associate organic production with a production model based on small and medium farming and short circuits. production and marketing. Of course, we give this regulation the benefit of the doubt, and the future will tell whether or not our doubts were right.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Mr President, well now there are a number of consumers who insist that their food is grown in a certain way. There are a number of farmers who are prepared to produce their crops and their livestock according to these restrictions, but they demand a higher price to compensate them for the higher costs incurred. ‘Willing buyer, willing seller’, ‘the customer is always right’: these should be the mantras here, and it should ideally go no further than this. Unfortunately, organic farming methods have acquired an aura of sainthood on the left of the political spectrum, because they imply a reduced opportunity for large corporations to make profits from supplying inputs. Of course, this is in direct contradiction to another aim of the left, which is that food should be as affordable as possible to those on low incomes. A further complication in trying to legislate on rules and standards on organic produce across the culture zones of the EU is that perceptions of organic farming can vary. Some insist on total purity, whereas others are more pragmatic if total purity means a very high cost or no organic food at all. A good example of this is the use of raised beds in Scandinavia to avoid brutal ground frosts, so presumably global warming is going to solve this problem for us. Here in the European Parliament our job is to legislate, which includes legislation on agricultural matters. In the last few years, I’ve witnessed a very determined effort here to ban various synthetic pesticides from being used. This is done in the name of safety for human health and safety for the environment. However, this zeal fades away when the debate turns to naturally occurring pesticides. One of these, used by organic farmers, is copper sulphate, a material that is highly toxic, may cause cancer and is known to damage fertility and human organs. These are the wonders it does for human health, but the environment doesn’t get away unscathed either, because copper sulphate is bio- accumulant that slowly builds up in the soil. Strangely, the Commission has just re-approved its use in organic farming. Commissioner, as you’re here I think we can have a deal, because if you are going to approve copper sulphate for use by organic farmers, I really feel you should be able to approve the use of neonicotinoid seed dressings for use on crops that do not flower before they’re harvested. Do we have a deal here? One of the difficulties in legislating in this area is a prejudiced assumption that if a material is natural, it follows that it must be good. Those of us who dwell in the countryside are keenly aware of the dangers of ergot, deadly nightshade, ragwort and hemlock. Another anomaly in trying to set a standard across the European Union is the underlying assumption that organic produce will be traded across the EU. Why have common rules otherwise?  However, if you talk to organic organisations, they want to promote local food; they talk about ‘air miles’ in a negative way, so we have another contradiction here. During my eight years here, I have heard all sorts of dire warnings about GM crops and factory farming, but the two big crises were horsemeat described as beef and, of course, 31 people tragically dying from eating organically grown bean sprouts.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, organic production is the invaluable resource of health for citizens and the environment, which must find an important place in the new Common Agricultural Policy and which must be protected by the European Union through effective mechanisms that guarantee high standards in this area. Farmers must be paid fairly for their efforts to supply high quality products on the market, but also for their significant contribution to maintaining a clean and healthy environment. Consumers must be guaranteed, by establishing effective mechanisms, that organic products, always bought at higher prices than classical products, are indeed produced in a process which has been carefully controlled at all stages of production. Their labelling must also be clear and undoubted in order to avoid confusion and counterfeiting. Unfair competitive practices must be prevented and combated by severe and discouraging action. Member States must implement the European regulations in this field so as not to create additional administrative burdens for farmers in this sector. At the same time, I appreciate that it is extremely important for small and medium-sized farmers to join together, to strengthen their position in the food chains, but also to cooperate with the large farmers in this sector. Last but not least, imports of organic products from third countries must be carefully and thoroughly checked, so that there are guarantees that high quality standards in the European Union are respected, thus ensuring effective protection for both farmers and European consumers.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, after more than four years after the proposal for a new regulation on organic, this House is finally preparing for a vote on the agreement reached by our negotiators. While acknowledging the need to update the previous regulation, especially in the light of the considerable growth of the sector, both in terms of area and turnover, the outcome of the negotiations represents for we, unfortunately, a missed opportunity. Indeed, despite Parliament's mandate calling for encouraging sustainable development of organic production, to ensure fair competition for farmers and operators in the sector and improving consumer confidence, the final agreement represents a downward compromise, having failed to set any threshold on plant harmaceuticals residues and now risk creating forms of competition unfair between companies from different Member States and to put into serious crisis the organic production of those countries that, like Italy, stand out for having more stringent legislation.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: Mr President, it is good that we have clear legislation on organic farming, that the same high quality standards are demanded throughout the European Union. However, I do believe that we should use our common sense and that we do not try to regulate everything closely with this legislation and that it will become a bureaucratic monster. I do not care whether you are an organic farmer or a regular farmer, I always think there should be room to innovate and undertake. I also welcome the fact that this proposal not only sets the requirements for farmers in the European Union, but also sets the same requirements for products sold from third countries within the European Union. As an example, eggs from third countries were sold here in the European Union as organic, while laying hens, chickens were not obliged to go outside. I think that is ridiculous, and it is good that this regulation does not stop it.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: Mr President, those of us who advocate organic production are not just for a regulatory effort: it is that the production and marketing of food does not harm the environment, does not affect our health and is done with criteria of social justice. For example: when we exclude artisanal fishing from what is considered organic and replace it with fish from aquaculture, we are setting a precedent that can be dangerous, because the sea is a common good, it belongs to everyone, and going out to sea is a sustainable activity, respectful of the environment and on which the economy depends. of many families and many villages. Replacing artisanal fisheries with aquaculture, and to say that aquaculture is organic and the other is not, at the very least, incoherent. In addition, organic farming can not be a kind of niche market for large enterprises. The key issue here is that, as long as there is no change in the European Union's trade policy, there will be no real possibility of defending and boosting organic farming.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, it is essential that organic certification of food products reflects a mode of production that corresponds to consumer expectations. The text that we will vote on tomorrow is the result of prolonged negotiations and reflects the possible balance in this regard. I welcome the inclusion of cork and sea salt stoppers in the list of products that can be certified organic. I do, however, one caveat. The European Union covers outermost territories whose production conditions are similar to those of certain third countries. Imports from these third countries are often allowed to use the organic logo, without the same being possible for the same products coming from European territory. I recognise that this is a complex issue, but I believe that it has not been completely resolved in this dossier, to the detriment of the competitiveness of some European producers.

name: Marie-Pierre VIEU
text: — Mr President, this is a transitional text with, of course, positive points: stricter controls on the supply chain, the return of old peasant seeds, measures to prevent contamination by pesticides. But this text, from my point of view, goes beside two challenges facing the sector. First, the challenge of unfair international competition and, therefore, organic food sovereignty. France imports, for example, almost 30% of organic products from third countries whose national certifications are often less demanding. The aim is to abolish the system of recognition of equivalence and not simply to modify it, in order to introduce, if necessary, a new and adapted compliance system. Then the challenge of means. We cannot claim organic for all and suppress 2 and a half billion aid to maintain organic as the government of Édouard Philippe does. These means objectives must be clearly reflected in the Regulation. It is necessary to make organic, but organic in the service of a new agricultural and food model.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: Mr President, promoting and supporting organic farming is a rightly political spearhead for the European Union. Bio is a double win: greater profit margins for the farmer and beneficial for the environment. Despite strong growth in recent decades, organic farming accounts for only 6% of European agricultural area. My region of Flanders is even a bit behind that. Only a good 1% of our land is organic. This really should be done much better because demand is increasing exponentially with us too. Europe can no longer cope with the demand for bio, so biofood is becoming more and more imported biofood. The key question now is: how do we ensure that our farmers choose organic farming? How can we strengthen them while at the same time safeguarding their competitive position? In short, how do we make bioproduction interesting? In any case, this report provides for a number of interesting spearheads and also a pioneering innovation: at last, farmers will be able to produce mixed production. Provided that the activities remain clearly separate, traditional agriculture will be allowed to be combined with organic farming. Farmers can therefore make the transition gradually. The transition period of 2 to 3 years is a thing of the past, and that is a good thing. Equally important: non-EU countries must fulfil the same conditions as EU countries. I think that is very important for fair competition. This legislation has cost blood, sweat and tears, but after 20 months of negotiations and 18 trialogues, I think Europe should be proud. Well, at least it's me.

name: Maria NOICHL
text: Mr President! Can we be satisfied? I'm telling you honestly, I'm not. A speaker said a sentence before, a proverb. I would just say: new is not always better. I would like to compare these trilogue agreements on the eco-regulation with a backpack, a backpack that we put on the back of organic farmers, but also society. For example, we are talking about the anti-contamination requirements that are to be packed into the backpack of organic farmers on one side — and really only one-sided. It is about postponing the obligation to provide evidence, which is to be unilaterally postponed — really only unilaterally — to organic farmers. It's about cancelling the polluter pays principle. We have too little polluter pays principle when it comes to environmental toxins anyway. But here it is once again attacked in a large, massive style and secretly, quite secretly, hidden behind the shadows of the 2021 and four years after, then the processual idea of the eco-regulation, which we know and appreciate in Germany, for example, falls to a final review. I would say that the many implementing and delegated acts will bring the uncertainty that we have now had for four years into the next four years. That is why I will reject the eco-regulation.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: — Mr. President, Allow me to initially congratulate both Mr. Häusling and the Commissioner for Perseverance, that we finally came to the end of this document. In the 20 years since the regulation in this area is now changing, very much has changed in the field of organic agriculture. Six percent of European areas today are below this treatment, says organic agriculture. Demand for products is increasing day by day. That is why we are obliged to provide the consumer with a very clear message about what it actually gets in organic food and that it gets comparable regardless of which European countries this food comes from, and, more importantly, that even those foods we import on the soil of the European Union are subject to the same rules as for European-grown food. Partly this thing is achieved through standardization, as well as by predicting better controls. And I think that's one of the key messages now that can give this sector progress as well. Organic agriculture is a great opportunity for small farms as well, so I am delighted with this certification — a common one that is possible for more farms. It is also extremely important that we have maintained this possibility that both conventional and organic food production can be carried out in strictly separate parts of the farm. It is also very important — in the field of biodiversity — that we have been successfully regulated in this regulation to a certain extent. Congratulations and great success to organic farmers I wish in the future.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, I warmly congratulate colleagues for their long work, as well as the Commissioner. The text we are going to vote — I am sure — includes good progress for a sector that attracts more and more Europeans and opens up prospects, particularly in livestock farming. As the challenges are growing in the conventional sector, the demand for organic products is growing and today is a valuable tool for the development of our rural territories. Quality must be at the rendezvous, which will allow enhanced internal and external controls. At the same time, these checks must be adapted to the situation on the ground with the possibility of spacing them if no anomalies are found over a period of three years. On the other hand, since almost half of all organic products sold in the European Union are imported, it is essential that those coming from third countries comply with the same production standards as we apply in our Member States. Finally, thanks to our institution, the diversity of farms is recognized, which I hope will encourage many farmers to switch to organic farming.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: — Mr President, the revision of this regulation gives some progress to the sector towards its modernisation and European harmonisation of organic farming practices. The acceptance of sea salt and natural cork stoppers is good news for Portugal, but there is much to do. Although European citizens are increasingly demanding safe food, we cannot always infer that it is only biological that is healthy, because recent studies have detected more chemical residues in the biological than conventional ones, and this has to be avoided. Controls should be increased by the competent authorities and I leave some reservations about the periods of transition to biological, which are too long in the case of greenhouses, and the fact that a common European limit value on the presence of unauthorised substances is not established, which could always be a impediment to the free movement of organic products within the Union. Commissioner, I would like to end by advocating the strengthening of training actions on organic farming and by highlighting the enormous importance of this new regulation for agricultural production in the outermost regions, which, as we know, is already sustainable and organic. Now we'll have to work on your certification.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, over the last decade the land devoted to organic farming has more than doubled: 500 000 hectares of land are converted every year. However, the legislative framework has not evolved adequately. Although Parliament called for encouraging the sustainable development of organic production, ensuring fair competition to farmers, preventing fraud and improving the confidence of Consumers towards organic products, the agreement reached in the trilogue, after more than two years of negotiations, lacks ambition in my view. Among the most critical points is the absence of harmonisation between Member States with regard to the thresholds of contamination with unauthorised substances and the possibility of marketing the product organic though accidentally contaminated with pesticides. In terms of control, on the other hand, there has been a positive advance. The agreement provides for the application of the same rules for producers in the European Union and those in third countries that intend to sell their products on the European market. As a result of the so-called compliance system, non-EU producers will therefore finally have to comply with the same rules as European farmers.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: — Mr President, Commissioner, building a truly coherent Community framework while simplifying procedures and securing consumers is the ambition of this new text. It reassures producers who were afraid that we would allegiate regulation. On the contrary, we have made it more realistic and we give visibility to those who want to invest in organic production. Organic is now a real technical route. Producers in the outermost regions are not forgotten — which they also feared — since the specific constraints on them can be taken into account. Commissioner, we are counting on you to make them. As for consumers, they feared that we would be levering controls and, therefore, questioning the seriousness of production. On the contrary, we are now proposing a more robust control system. The consumer will also be able to have more confidence in imported products since they will have to comply with European regulations. The word “compliant” appears in articles 44 and 45 of the text. I believe that it is now up to the producers to take advantage of this new Bible, since this is the term used by our colleague Häusling. I do not know whether divine grace touched the negotiating team, nor do I know whether I should bow to this or that eminence, in any case I greet the work done.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: — Mr President, dear colleagues, when we buy an organic apple from the supermarket, can we be sure that that apple is not full of pesticides? The results of the checks carried out by the competent authorities show that the market is invaded by false organic or organic products. Many traders misuse the names “bio” and “eco”, because it is a bookmark that sells the product faster. This misleading advertising that many producers use has not only led to a decrease in consumer confidence but also to discourage organic farmers. I welcome the fact that the regulation proposes clear labelling criteria and recognition based on conformity and equivalence of products coming from third countries. Also, through the regulation debated, along with other legislative acts that we have debated in Parliament and will debate in the near future — and here I am referring to the next multiannual financial framework — our duty is to strengthen organic farming in order to respond in the same time for farmers' needs and consumer demand. I believe that, in the next review of the common agricultural policy, good incentives and increased financial resources should be guaranteed to farmers.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: — Dear Chairman, Mr. Commissioner, ecological agriculture can contribute to the preservation of rural space and give it added value, thereby contributing to sustainable development and remaining youth in the countryside. Although the areas under organic farming are growing and the number of farmers opting for such a type of production is increasing, we still cannot be satisfied with progress. There are many obstacles in front of producers and consumers that we need to remove for organic farming to achieve its full potential. That is why I welcome the agreement finally reached on this Regulation because I believe that it will regulate the shortcomings in the control system and trade regime and give consumers a guarantee that what they buy as an environmentally friendly product really corresponds to the certificate. I am pleased that the precautionary principle has been improved to avoid pollution, to provide better access to ecological seeds and animals, give farmers the opportunity for farmers to run mixed farms and to apply stricter controls and standards of the European Union on imports of organic products, and by repealing the equivalence rules strengthened the position of European producers.

name: Maria Gabriela ZOANĂ
text: — Mr President, Commissioner Hogan, organic production is a very topical topic. The organic farming sector in the European Union has gained particular importance in recent years, with a steady increase in agricultural areas, the number of agricultural holdings and organic operators registered in the Union. The sustainable development of organic production must be based on robust, transparent and harmonised production rules across the European Union. These products must meet the expectations of operators and consumers in terms of product safety and quality, take into account the variable geographical and climatic conditions in the European Union. Member States should encourage and further support Ecolabel by taking measures to reduce the use of conventional packaging and to promote the use of reusable, recyclable or biodegradable packaging materials. With the Ecolabel, consumers visually identify goods and services with less environmental impact.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, it is a fact that the development of organic farming is a very positive thing, and this is evident first of all by the area allocated to organic farming. So, of course, the debate we are having is very important, but the labelling of organic products really must echo that these products are organic. What kind of fertilisers have been used, if they have been used, and of course we need to take steps to support the free movement of organic products in the European Union, to support producers in remote areas and islands. But since we put these conditions for organic producers within the European Union, it is certain that these conditions - and stricter - should apply to imports from third countries of organic products or supposed organic products, because I see that a state of promiscuity is slowly forming. Organic products within Europe are controlled, but there is no strict control of organic or supposedly organic products imported into the European Union from third countries.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: Mr. President, I apologize for the late filing. This regulation is not arguably a bible for organic farming, as the rapporteur put it, but it sets out rules, production conditions, quality problems, standards and control requirements. The path of coming to this regulation was exceptionally difficult. The opinions of the Member States and the farmers concerned were very divided. Determination was on the side of the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs, as well as the Commissioner and the Estonian Presidency. The organic farming sector will thrive. Demand for these products is growing, consumers are placing increasing importance on food quality. Now it is necessary to expand the infrastructure of the market, to build delivery networks, but also to provide a system of services for organic farmers in certification, control, consulting, knowledge transfer. For consumers of these products, the information that is contained on the product is extremely important. These consumers read. Finally, one more congratulations to the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs and the entire team of advisers.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, thank you for your indulgence. I just wanted to say two things. First of all, congratulations to Martin Häusling and Commissioner Hogan, it is been a long delivery but we’re here. But the most important point, and it struck me as I came into the Chamber, is that this area of agriculture is the most prone to food fraud. So we have a real issue here that if we have a good organic sector, we have to protect us from those who will use the fact that you get a premium payment for organics to engage in fraudulent behaviour and mislabelling, so it’s just a warning. We have this new regulation. We have new rules, but remember there are those who will use organics in a most improper way and destroy the good work that has just been undertaken by the rapporteur.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank all of the Members who participated in this evening’s debate, and have indeed participated in many debates on this issue over the years. I also want to take the opportunity to thank the Estonian and Maltese Presidencies, as others have done, for their great work. My sense, having listened to the debate, is that there is broad support for the compromise agreement that has been reached by the three institutions. As Mr Andrieu and Mr Lins noted, this compromise is the fruit of four years of work and eighteen trilogues. So it is inevitable that such a compromise doesn’t satisfy everybody because you will have views stretching from Mr Agnew’s views to Mr De Castro’s views and other views as well which have to be satisfied as much as possible. However, this outcome is, as I said earlier, a reasonable one. Otherwise, we would have thrown away all the good work and all of the progress we’ve made over those four years, and I don’t think that would be a responsible way to act. This brings about much needed improvement in the regulatory environment and framework for organic production in Europe. It shouldn’t be forgotten that the reason why this Commission proposal was originally brought forward by my predecessor Mr Ciolos was because there was a scandal associated with the imports of organic materials into some of our Member States in the European Union which was concealed for a long time. This imported organic produce had the potential to damage the organic sector in Europe. This was the backdrop to more ambitious proposal originally brought forward by the Commission. Whatever one’s view about the desired level of ambition, there can be little or no doubt that the text now on the table represents a lot of progress. I reject therefore, Mr Zullo’s criticisms. In particular, I reject any suggestion that the Commission yielded to any interest. You can point the finger somewhere else; we didn’t yield to any interest, whether from northern Europe or from anywhere else. What the Commission did was to engage in good faith in this democratic process with the Members of this House and the Council, and the outcome on which you will vote tomorrow is the result of that progress. The potential of the organic sector has yet to be fully realised. This legislation can help, as Mr Jakovčić said, by providing harmonisation, simplification and standardisation, which is contrary to the claim made by Ms Noichl. As the sector grows, I hope that the European Union can become an exporter of organic products, which need not, as Mr Viegas suggested, be a threat to the sector. Your rapporteur and his colleagues have done a good job in bringing about a lot of improvements in the sector and we have a balanced outcome I feel that we can deliver for our organic sectors in the future, and our organic farmers in particular. We have a legal text which can only help the organic sector. I commend this text to the House and I hope it will get a strong vote here in this House when it is voted upon tomorrow.

name: Martin HÄUSLING
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, ladies and gentlemen. I look forward to receiving so much approval. That was not always the case on this point. We've had fierce controversy. I believe that if we can get a large majority in Parliament tomorrow, then this is also a good sign to the sector that we are also making a serious effort, so to speak, to meet the demands of the sector, but also to the additional growing demands of consumers. There are no more controversial discussions here on two points: the fact that we have made substantial progress on seeds is clear to all consensus. The fact that we standardise the import rules and thus also make them a little safer is a complete consensus here. We do not have a consensus — I admit, Commissioner, we did not lose many words about this earlier — on the issue of limit values. No one wants pesticide residues, either in the conventional or biological sector. That's clear. This is essentially about this — and this was the discussion that was also taking place in Germany in particular: do we, so to speak, only burden the risk to the biosector or not? That is why I hope to be more clear about the investigation, which will come after that. And then, of course, we'll have to talk about it again. Of course, at the end of the day, I would also like to see uniform rules in all areas, but I am also delighted — and I was really pleased today — that, on the one hand, Copa—Cogeca, which was not always in favour of it, has backed this new regulation and that the German sector, which was particularly critical, has said that this will provide Parliament with an additional level of legal certainty and that important impetus will also be provided by Parliament. This is indeed important to me, even after these long tough negotiations, that we have also taken the sector a good deal with us, And, above all, with regard to the implementation of delegated and implementing acts, it is important that we work together, so to speak, on practical implementation, so that in the end of the day, even those who still have doubts today can say: it has been a good job that we have all done here together. We haven't made a revolution in the bio sector. We have further developed the existing law in a very positive direction, and for this I would like to thank all those who have contributed to it.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The discussion is closed. The vote will take place tomorrow. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. — (PT) Organic production is based on the principle of reconciling agricultural production with the promotion of biodiversity and the preservation of ecosystems. Furthermore, organic farming has other virtues, such as the protection of consumer health and the promotion of a more sustainable agricultural model, because it is based on small and medium agriculture and family farming, as opposed to the agribusiness model based on intensive production and the high incorporation of chemical additives of synthesis. The new regulation, which contains positive elements, whether in the extension of the production spectrum or in clarifying certain concepts, points out, however, in a direction which somehow subverts characteristics of organic farming, in particular paving the way for a certain industrialisation of the method of production biological. Taking advantage of the positive impact of a label, resulting from a positive perception of organic products for growing layers of consumers, and the associated economic gains, we take a path that distorts the concept of organic farming, as we see it today. The focus is placed exclusively on the product, ignoring the social and environmental component that has always been associated with organic farming. Instead of promoting local agriculture and short circuits of production and marketing, we try to fit organic farming into an exporter model that we do not follow.

name: Carolina PUNSET
text: in writing. — Organic production is expanding unstoppable, with more than 2.4 million organic farmers worldwide. Over the last five years, the area devoted increased by an average of 20% and turnover by 62%. Despite these extraordinary results, the area mentioned above equals 1.1% of the world's agricultural sector, directly responsible for 15% of GHG emissions, to which emissions from the manufacture of plant protection, fertilizers and the entire transport chain, especially intercontinental, can be added in large merchant vessels: food production and consumption would be responsible for more than 50 per cent of global emissions. Organic farming is the most effective measure to mitigate emissions, but you must pay for certifications and audits that increase the price for consumers. On the contrary, none of the negative effects of emissions is affected by the final price of conventional products, in a clear comparative tort for organic production. In order to broadly develop organic production, it is essential to internalize the negative effects of emissions on the environment and health into the value chain of conventional food trade. This transition should be reflected in the CAP.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Paulo Rangel, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the application of the Treaty provisions relating to national parliaments (2016/2149 (INI)) (A8- 0127/2018).

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: rapporteur. — Mr President, I would like to begin by saying that it is already a tradition of this Parliament to report on Parliament's relationship with national parliaments and in particular on the implementation of the Treaty of Lisbon. This is already the fourth or fifth report we have on this issue. The first point I would like to draw attention to is that it is evident today, even at COSAC level, and this is reflected in the report, it is clear today that there is much better relationship between national parliaments and the European Parliament, that both levels of institutions have understood that they cooperate in the a sense of giving democratic legitimacy to the European Union. What is the first news of this report? It is, in fact, to interpret the role of national parliaments in a constitutional sense, I would say, in a constitutional sense. Until now, we knew that national parliaments have a role at European level but we did not understand why, which was the reason, and it is quite clear here that national parliaments have a different vocation from that of governments: governments are represented in the Council of Ministers and in the European Council, but national parliaments bring an advantage, which is to reflect internal diversity. That is, internally there are different currents, while in the Council each government refers to a monolithic will of a state, the truth is that when national parliaments are called to be represented they bring majorities, minorities, internal diversity. That is why two proposals are made in this report. One is that representation in interparliamentary meetings is always proportionate, that is to say that there are representatives of the majority in Parliament but also of the minority, and another is that in the views that parliaments give, and particularly when they want, for example, concerning relative Commission initiatives, to activate the card yellow, may be the majority will of Parliament, but there may be a dissident vote, may be a vanquished vote of minorities. That is to say, to bring precisely the political arena that exists internally to the European level. So that is the specific role of national parliaments. Then there is another important step forward on the issue of the early warning system and the yellow card because all the national parliaments have told us that they had reservations about the eight-week deadline. We cannot change the Treaty, but we can accommodate these eight weeks and we therefore urge the European Commission to recognise that the period of eight weeks should not be counted during the holiday period and, furthermore, that it should give a technical period for all parliaments to receive at the same time translated versions of legislative initiatives. That's the only way we can activate the yellow card and give him, at last, the status he has. Finally, I would like to say, on this point, that there are several amendments here, particularly from the Socialist Group and the Liberal Group, which must be rejected because they say: 'well, the national parliaments do not use the eight weeks because they do not want'. This report must give a positive signal to the national parliaments and if they say that eight weeks are not enough, we can extend that deadline, even if it is a little, we must do so, and therefore reject those amendments by the Socialist Group and the Liberal Group, which are amendments against the parliaments national. Finally, I would like to say that we are also making a proposal here not to accept the green card, but to accept suggestions from the national parliaments to the European Commission regarding legislative initiatives, that we are here advocating a major strengthening of the IPEX, in the sense that all parliaments have updated and detailed information on European matters and, finally, I think that this is one of the most constructive proposals, it is the idea that we have a European week, that is, a simultaneous week in the 27 national parliaments which is a week to celebrate European themes. The presidents, the Commissioners, the Vice-Presidents of the Commission, the Members of the European Parliament of different nationalities in the 27 capitals, in the same week, at the same time, throughout Europe, have a European week, in which there can actually be, let us say, this reflection on these issues. It would, in essence, be a way of convening in parliaments in that direction which President Macron has advocated and which is a good sense for debating the future of Europe. Do this every year on the Commission's agenda and on a European theme.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am taking this point this evening on behalf of the First Vice-President, Mr Timmermans, who unfortunately cannot be here. I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Rangel, and this House for the opportunity to discuss the implementation of the treaty provisions concerning national parliaments and for the important amount of fact finding and analysis that fed the preparation of the report. National parliaments play an essential role in bringing the Union closer to the people by both scrutinising the activity of their own government at European level and engaging with the European institutions. On the specific example of the European Semester, the Commission shares your views that national parliaments should be more closely involved in the preparation and approval of the national reform programmes and of the stability and convergence programmes. Currently only a few parliaments have the possibility to vote on these programmes, but this is a matter of national institutional organisation. As for the dialogue with the Commission, I would like to stress that national parliaments have not yet taken full advantage of the rights to request direct exchanges with the Commission on semester-related matters. Commissioners are available for discussion with national parliaments, as with the European Parliament. I also agree with the report’s assessment that national parliaments of an important role to play to curb gold-plating of EU legislation by Member States. The European Union is often blamed for imposing rules and burdens which do not derive from EU legislation but from national legislation and, when transposing directives, national parliaments should take responsibility and explain to the people when elements are added which go beyond the requirements of EU Union law. We recognise that sometimes gold-plating can be positive, for example, to improve coherence with or the performance of national law. But it is important for people to know who did what and why. The Commission believes the subsidiarity and proportionality must be important and must be at the heart of the European democratic process. In line with our better regulation agenda, the Commission invests great effort in ensuring that our proposals respect the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. While the Treaties provide that national parliaments ensure compliance only with the principle of subsidiarity, the Commission also checks to complaints of its initiatives with the principle of proportionality in a thorough manner. So, when replying to opinions or reasoned opinions of national parliaments, we address both subsidiarity and proportionality issues as well as all other issues, political as well as technical, that are raised by the parliaments in their opinions. The fact that the yellow-card mechanism has only been triggered three times so far may be an indicator that our efforts to check the compliance of envisaged legislative proposals with both principles well before their adoption actually are working. The Commission is open to discussing these issues with national parliaments on how to improve our working arrangements on the subsidiarity-control mechanism. The task force on subsidiarity, proportionality and doing less more efficiently is currently reflecting on how to improve the practical functioning of this mechanism. I would like to stress that the Commission is always happy to discuss ideas from new EU initiatives from national parliaments as part of the political dialogue. In 2015 and 2016, the Commission give detailed replies to so-called green cards that it had received. These were on food waste and on corporate social responsibility. Given the dynamism of the political dialogue, I do not see any need for creating a formal process that could be difficult to reconcile with the current Treaties’ provisions. Finally, I would like to underline that the Commission is always happy to contribute to inter-parliamentary events and will be open to contributing to a European week such as is envisaged in this report. Once again I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work and to thank the House very much for its attention and keen interest in this very important issue.

name: György SCHÖPFLIN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to begin by offering my congratulations to Mr Rangel for a report of signal importance. There is no question as to whether or not national parliaments play a role in European politics, they do. Any holistic assessment would immediately come to this conclusion, but the strategic question is how this role is to be understood and regulated. Clearly, national parliaments cannot usurp the role and functions of this Parliament, but we cannot exclude the national parliaments from the European political system either. It’s the proper allocation of roles that can resolve questions of overlap or conflict. Here it seems to me the report is very clear. National parliaments are much better suited to holding their governments to account, implying that there should be a clear line of accountability between national parliaments and Council. There are best practices at the national level that are worth looking at. Then there is the at times sensitive relationship between national parliaments and this Parliament. These sensitivity is understandable where power relationships are involved and the lines of competences are fuzzy. The report goes a long way to identifying these fuzzy areas and makes valuable suggestions as to how to achieve clarity. Regular contact between the different parliamentary levels is a key step in the right direction.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (IT) (IT) (IT) (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the meantime, I would like We think that national parliaments and the European Parliament have a complementary role to play within the Union: they must interact in harmony more effectively and engage in dialogue, in particular, on the most important policies.
