Too often in the Member States and their assemblies we refer to the democratic deficit of the Union; but we must ask ourselves whether all possible instruments are really used at national level which are already available. As some colleagues have pointed out, would it not be more judicious to stimulate better cooperation and coordination between national parliaments and their governments? Governments should better explain their positions in the Council so that their parliaments can react, and the report also goes along those lines. The Council itself, perhaps, should also operate more transparently, making it easier to control parliaments. In particular, of course, parliaments control over national governments is the milestone of the role that national parliaments must play and it is necessary, and for example, to reach a higher degree of control of the parliaments themselves but also, by the European Parliament, of the Union's fiscal and economic policies. It is good the idea contained in the report of calls for it to be created this European parliamentary week, which could bring together national MEPs, MEPs and Commissioners, as well as the organisation to Regular deadlines for debates between the ministers concerned and the specialised committees of the national parliaments before and after the Council meeting. In the same way it would be important to exploit the full potential of the Interparliamentary Conference within the framework of the Treaty on Stability, Governance and Coordination of Economic Policy. We feel It is important that it is important to strengthen its national action for the European Semester. On some aspects of the report, as the rapporteur has said, we do not agree, but on the whole of the report we are.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, allow me to thank the rapporteur, Mr Rangel, and the other shadow rapporteurs for the excellent report and good cooperation. The report contains many good ideas that I fully support, for example the creation of a European week that will inform the national parliaments of what we are doing here, which is necessary. However, on the reform of the early warning system, I disagree. Many tend to believe that extending the period of eight weeks for the national parliaments will get them more involved. I believe the contrary actually, because first, if we want really to extend it then we have to change the Treaty, and we cannot do that. Secondly, I don’t believe that the national parliament will jump in the air in excitement just because they have a couple more days. Thirdly, if you want technically to adopt it, it has to be said that we do sometimes do it. And, finally and most importantly, we are often criticised for being too bureaucratic, that the legislation takes too long and extending it even more is not a good idea. I know that national parliaments sometimes blame everything on the EU, and that problem would not be solved by inventing new tools and instruments. I think that the problem should be solved: national parliaments should have the role as a scrutiniser of the government and of ensuring what their governments do in the EU properly. That is the way to solve the problem and I that’s what I propose.

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Mr President, How can it be that the yellow card in the subsidiarity check has only been triggered three times? The EU has serious problems with over-centralisation and that is why it has instituted this procedure — allowing national parliaments to protest if the European Commission makes proposals that go a little too far. But only half of the parliaments even take part in this procedure, and only a few parliaments, including Sweden's Parliament, are really taking it seriously. That's because it's too short of a time, and also that the threshold for how many parliaments need to protest and raise the finger of a warning is far too high. This report contains many excellent proposals, most of which can be implemented even now under current treaties. It should be adopted and the Liberals' proposals should be rejected.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: on behalf of the NI Group. - Mr President! Colleagues and Colleagues! I want to support the Rangel report very clearly. This is a very good proposition. The essence of things is whether we want national parliaments to be active actors of European policy, not national, or not. Rangel's report advocates this first solution — and very well. I cannot agree here with the argument made by Mr Selimovic on behalf of ALDE, which would really come down to a reduction in the role of national parliaments. The ideas of a flexible early warning system, the European week, the realisation of the yellow card procedure deserve very clear approval, and a great appeal to the Commission to reorient the attitude of a positive attitude, to treat national parliaments not as an unwanted child, only actual policy partner.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Mr President, by looking at the implementation of the Treaty provisions on national parliaments Paulo Rangel has delivered an extremely useful report. The Treaty of Lisbon has become known as the Treaty of Parliaments because it has not only considerably increased the power of the European Parliament but also recognised prerogatives of national parliaments and their constitutional role within the European framework. These include the control of a subsidiarity and proportionality and ensuring the democratic legitimacy of European decision-making, in particular when double legitimacy is at stake There are 41 national chambers in the European Union and they cooperate with us, the European Parliament, through numerous platforms. But the core function of national parliaments is in the area of European decision-making, and this remains democratic scrutiny and monitoring of their national government’s activity in the Council and in the European Council, and this is the shortest way to influence European decision-making. National parliaments are even more relevant for the process of European legislation through their role in the transposition, implementation and enforcement of European legislation at national level. They are irreplaceable in the better law-making agenda. They can effectively prevent the gold-plating of European legislation and improve the institutional capacity to implement European legislation at national level. But today, let me add one more issue and invite national parliaments to get involved in launching national debates on Europe’s future as they can indeed be an excellent vehicle for engaging citizens in shaping the future of Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Max ANDERSSON
text: blue-card question. – I agree with a lot of what you said. But just the question, can we really expect the parliamentary majority of national parliaments with a parliamentary system to hold its own government to account when it agrees to things in political compromises and in the Council that perhaps it shouldn’t?

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: blue-card answer. – That’s what democracy and elections are about, but that’s also what transparency of European institutions is about. So that also depends on how transparent the European institutions, especially the Council, are and whether they allow the public also to look at what has been decided and who says what, before they go back home and blame ‘Brussels’ and say ‘it’s just this horrible Brussels that made the decision’, when in reality it’s the national governments.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur; I think we have a good report and that it is good that we look at relations between national parliaments and the European Parliament. Let me give you two details or two details on what I think we can bring to the report. Firstly, I believe that we must prevent the interpretation of subsidiarity and proportionality — which are powers of national parliaments — from becoming expansive, in a way that somehow limits the powers of the European institutions, and in particular the Commission. My personal experience is that, increasingly, European Union policy is demanding to address issues that only European competition can address — let us put energy union, combat tax havens or tax harmonisation, put the Digital Agenda... — there are many issues that demand the initiative European legislation. And I do not want an expansive interpretation of subsidiarity or proportionality to limit the powers of the European institutions. Secondly, I think that much of what is currently failing in the framework of relations between the European Union and national parliaments is because national parliaments do not bring the European debate just to their own seats. I think there is a lot of opportunities for national parliaments to speak more about Europe; for them to talk more with us; for MEPs to participate in parliamentary debates; so that, indeed, there can be a debate in the national Parliament before each European Council, etc. My impression is, ladies and gentlemen, that a lot of what is wrong in the debate on the relationship between national parliaments and European institutions is taking place in national parliaments, and it would not be bad for national parliaments to read this report carefully.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: Mr President, first of all we congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Rangel. We in the ALDE Group would like to stress the importance of such close cooperation and ongoing exchange of information between national parliaments and the European Parliament. In fact, the report in general does a good job in pointing out the shortcomings of inter-agency cooperation and pointing to new instruments. The national parliaments are guardians of the subsidiarity principle and control the European activity of these governments; but, as Mr Jáuregui has pointed out, European legislative initiative is increasingly key to the great global challenges in this changing and turmoil world. However, “better regulation” must be understood in both directions: towards States and towards the common. So the door of the European Parliament must always be open, responsibly, and the door of national parliaments too. We will vote in favour of improving this cooperation, although we must point out that lengthening the yellow card deadline does not believe that the legislative process will be improved.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. I would like to thank Mr Rangel very warmly for his excellent report, which seeks to make it clear that the national parliaments and the European Parliament need to work more closely together. We must not compete, but we must have the exchange of information so that we can have more attack and control of the executives at national and European level. At the same time, however, it must be clear that decisions in a Parliament must fall where the competence lies. We cannot have shared competence in making decisions. In terms of European competences, it is the European Parliament, and in terms of national competences, it is the national parliament. Accordingly, we must then run the information strands, as we have at various events, such as Article 13 events in the Economic and Monetary Union, the Foreign Affairs Assembly of National Parliaments and the European Parliament, or COSAC, for example. But we must also make it clear that this is also accommodating us at national level. It would be good, as we have in Germany and in some other countries too, if MEPs are members of the European Committees of the national parliaments. I have been a deputy member of the European Affairs Committee of the German Bundestag for 25 years, and we can discuss matters together. I believe that we have a situation in the Netherlands, for example, that we have the opportunity to discuss European and national MEPs together once a year in the plenary of the Netherlands. These are all possibilities. The proposal has just been made that the national parliaments should discuss before councils. In Germany, the Chancellor gives a government statement before each European Council before the European Council. German Bundestag.

name: Asim ADEMOV
text: — Mr President, I support my colleague's report, as the mechanisms set out in this report will bring national parliaments closer to the overall integration process. According to the spirit of the Treaty of Lisbon, national parliaments are called upon to act directly at European level, whether in interaction with the European Parliament or with the European Commission. The positive thing about the report is that it will encourage national parliaments to fully exercise their European functions in order to directly influence European policies and control their content. Better synergies and enhanced exchange of information between Members of the European Parliament and members of national parliaments could help improve control of the European debate at national level and thus promote a truly European parliamentary and political culture. I also support the creation of an annual European week, which can be held simultaneously in the 27 national parliaments and which should be attended by the Commissioners and the European Parliament, where European issues can be discussed. Both national parliaments and the European Parliament need to cooperate more closely on security and defence policies, with joint interparliamentary meetings between the representatives of national parliaments and the European Parliament. This will enable national parliaments to be more involved in the consideration of Union issues and to involve them more in the development of the European integration process.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Mr President, national parliaments have increased powers under the Treaty. First of all, there can be no amendment to the Treaties and change if they are not approved by the national parliaments, so they have considerable powers. The point is, they rarely practice them. Secondly, they are able to vote on directives, so they are involved in their own way in the legislative process. Thirdly, they have the possibility of parliamentary scrutiny of the ministers participating in the Council, and if these ministers do not do their job well, then they can also adopt a motion of censure against their government. Next thing is that the national parliaments can participate in cooperation with the Commission in the famous European Semester and, of course, in the end, in the level of subsidiarity, i.e. the level at which decisions will be taken in the respective competences, have a role to play. important and perform it utilizing the yellow card. The national parliaments therefore have increased capacity. The point is that unfortunately they serve the executive and do not dare to stand up. That's where the real problem lies.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, thank you Paulo Rangel for your work on this. One of my responsibilities as Vice-President is relationships with national parliaments so I’m pleased to hear in your speech that you believe the relationships are much better now. I’m not sure that that’s all down to me but I think we are making an effort in our relationships and dialogue with national parliamentarians. I mentioned yesterday, in the debate on the future of Europe with President Macron, that there is a tension there, as other colleagues have said. So we need to try and find an informal way as well as formal structures as to how we improve it. One of the ways we could it is in our own political parties, where we could try and strengthen the relationships we have with our own colleagues because this can be difficult. But there are issues here. One is time and the second is willingness. If we could have more time and, indeed, more willingness things might be better. The last point is, we will not have a stronger European Union without cooperative national parliamentarians who speak up for Europe and talk it up in their constituencies and in their national parliaments.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Mr President, I want to commend this report because, in my opinion, it accurately identifies the problems of the involvement of national parliaments in the drafting of European legislation. I think the question must be asked why the yellow card institute is so little used. I in the Czech Republic, having consulted with the Czech Parliament over the last few years (we have a bicameral parliament), the Czech legislators, especially the members of the latter Chamber, have complained significantly that the eight-week period is, in short, a very short time for someone to comment on the legislative proposal, especially if it is a collective body, the Chamber parliament. So I am glad that you are also identifying this problem here, I am confirming it from my member country and it would be great if it could somehow achieve that this deadline will be either otherwise calculated, or in the future extended.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: Mr President, I agree with the proposals contained in this report in order to improve the early warning system provided for in the Treaty for the control of subsidiarity and proportionality. Before being elected Member of the European Parliament, I was president of the Basque Parliament and CALRE. The regions saw in the protocol regulating early warning a window of opportunity to better connect this key level of governance with the Community institutions. We carried out a test to test its operation together with the Committee of the Regions and put in place a procedure which, together with the experience of these years, shows that the eight-week deadline is insufficient; that regional positions are not reflected in the same way by national parliaments and that there is generally an interpretation. restrictive of this principle. Therefore, to ensure that the start date of the eight-week deadline is not just decided by the Commission and to implement the idea of the green card as a kind of right to propose initiatives that would offer the regions a framework similar to that which the citizens' initiative offers Europeans seem to us very good ideas.

name: João FERREIRA
text: — Mr President, the Treaty of Lisbon, apart from worsening inequality in power relations between states, strengthening the larger ones, was a significant attack on the power of national parliaments, since their powers were usurped into the sphere of the European Union. In recent years, with the Budgetary Treaty, the European Semester and the economic governance package, this misuse has been taken even further, for example, in the budgetary field, but not only, in what constitutes a worrying attack on democracy even on a purely formal level. The role that the Treaty of Lisbon has allegedly given to national parliaments, that of merely monitoring the principle of subsidiarity, is nothing more than a farce and it is clearly useless. Even where parliaments raise objections, the European Commission ignores these objections and maintains its proposals. It is therefore necessary to dismantle this farce and not insist on it, and at the outset by giving back to the national parliaments the power that has been taken away from them.

name: João FERREIRA
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank the rapporteur for his work and thank all the Members who have contributed to the debate this evening. I hope that we can all agree that national parliaments have a clear role in bringing the European Union closer to the people. I have spent over 27 years in the national parliament in Ireland, and throughout that time I and many of my colleagues took a very keen interest in European Union matters. Since becoming Commissioner I’ve always tried to include in my visits to Member States a visit to the national parliaments and a participation in its various committees. I think this is important that we will continue to do this. I think that President Juncker and I know that First Vive-President Timmermans are very anxious that we would include it in our programmes in any event. Next week, for example, the Agriculture and Rural Development Committee of this House is organising a joint meeting with the agricultural committees of the national parliaments, which will provide a very useful opportunity for members of national parliaments to contribute to the preparation of the common agricultural policy and the Commission’s legislative proposal. So I think that this is a good example, if we can do more of this in relation to the relevant national committees and the European Parliament and the European Commission, I think it would be very helpful. Can I conclude by again thanking Paulo Rangel for his report, for his work? And I hope that this report will contribute to the strengthening of the role of national parliaments in a manner in which will make sure that European policy-making is closer to the people.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: rapporteur. — Madam President, it is an honor to be shared first with our league from the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, Mr Castaldo, and for the Vice-President responsible for national parliaments. So I think this is a lucky occasion. Thank you very much. Madam President, I would just like to emphasise two aspects that have been raised here in the debate before, of course, thanking everyone for their contribution and, in particular, also for Commissioner Hogan's words, but I would like to emphasise the following: the first point, which I think is very important, is to draw attention to that it is very important that the Commission, in its examination of subsidiarity, be a little more open. Indeed, the link between subsidiarity and proportionality is extremely difficult to make, and so there should be a self-restraint when you rush to deny any yellow card saying that it is about proportionality rather than subsidiarity. This was the aspect that should be taken into account. This does not disregard what Mr Jáuregui Atondo says because subsidiarity in many cases involves handing over competence to the European Commission, to the European Union and not to the national states and not to national parliaments. But in many situations proportionality is invoked as a pretext for not making a genuine assessment of subsidiarity. That was an aspect I would like to mark here. And the second point was to insist on the idea that giving national parliaments some more time and some time off is fair and due, and it is fair and due for this reason: not all national parliaments have the resources they have, for example, the German parliament or the Swedish parliament, and therefore, of course, the way in which in certain circumstances whether to assess certain matters also depends from country to country and structure to structure and therefore creating a little more time allows all parliaments to be placed on an equal footing and allows for dialogue greater among the various parliaments. There is one point I would like to emphasise, which I see myself and almost all Members have emphasised them, which is: of course the great role of the national parliaments is in controlling their governments. That's the point. If they are able to do so proficiently I am sure that the European Union will work better.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 19 April 2018.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the report by Ramon Tremosa i Balcells, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Annual Report on Competition Policy (2017/2191(INI)) (A8—0049/2018).

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would again like to welcome Commissioner Vestager to this Parliament.  First of all, let me thank all the shadow rapporteurs. We have done very good work together. This is my second time as rapporteur of the Annual Report on Competition Policy. The first time was with Commissioner Almunia in 2013. This may be the last competition report of this term. Next year we will have European elections again. As you know, this is a non—binding report, but it sends a strong political message to the Commission. In the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs this report was approved with 49 votes in favour and only five against. I hope we will have the same huge majority in plenary tomorrow. I have to say that some of the competition problems are the same as five years ago, among them the Google antitrust case. In the Google case, five years seems an eternity to me. I say to the Commissioner that still hope that we can close some of the cases before the end of the Commission’s mandate. In this report we strongly support the independence of the Commission and the national competition authorities. Their mission is to shape and enforce effectively EU competition rules for the benefit of all EU citizens. Sufficient financial and human resources are key to achieving this goal. An independent competition policy needs independent competition authorities. Political appointments tend to protect oligopolies and cost millions to European citizens. In this report we call on the Commission to reallocate adequate financial and human resources to DG Competition, as we did last year. We also call for the modernisation of the Directorate’s electronic and informatic tools in order to cope with the increasing workload and technological progress.  Regarding the issue of data, we have all been shocked by the Facebook and Cambridge Analytica scandal. Well, I am proud. We have been denouncing the utilisation and misuse of data for some years now. Paragraph 44 of this report, written well before the Facebook scandal, states that “big tech companies’ use of personal data is unprecedented. Consumers are often not aware or informed of the extent to which their data is being used, for example in profiling or targeted advertising”. The Commission was well aware of this. To avoid further such scandals in the EU, the new GDPR rules that are coming into force are good news in this respect.  Regarding the Google antitrust shopping case, in paragraph 42 we put the unbundling of Google back on the table as one of the options to restore equal treatment and non—discrimination in search results. We also invite Google’s CEO to a joint IMCO/ECON hearing in Parliament. We can sum up the Google case in a short tweet: inaction brings Google unbundling closer every day.  Commissioner Vestager, I have some questions for you. Would you have updates to give us today on the shopping antitrust case? In addition, what about the Android and AdSense cases. Finally, you were in the US last week. I hope you had interesting meetings. If you could talk to us about them, it would be very well received.  In paragraph 56, we welcome the Commission’s simplification of the rules for public investment in ports and airports. All major infrastructure should be based on a positive cost benefit analysis and long—term economic viability in order to avoid the future financing of ghost airports in Europe. We also raised the issue of airlines’ competition and the concerns with regard to Gulf carriers. We need financial transparency in order to confirm or dismiss alleged public subsidies which break the level playing field among European and third country airlines. Finally, we also welcome the fact that, from now on, direct flights between Tokyo and Barcelona will be possible. We welcome the fact that the Spanish Government is ready to open up the bilateral agreement between Spain and Russia – which prevents there from being a Barcelona-Tokyo route – as announced by the Spanish Minister of Transport last February. Competition is the best remedy against transport centralism. I will stop here. Once again, I thank all the rapporteurs for their contributions. I look forward to your comments and our exchange.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all my thanks to Ramon Tremosa i Balcells for this very valuable report, and my thanks also to the House for the support for competition policy. I think that we may disagree in concrete cases, but we do agree that competition makes our economy work better for everyone – that the market serves the customer. That enables our Union to do what citizens expect: that they make sure that they get treated fairly.  This of course includes the work that we do on state aid, because if success is about getting the biggest subsidy from government and not about serving customers in a better way, then obviously consumers lose out. So we have decided that Amazon had to pay back some EUR 250 million in unpaid taxes to Luxembourg. We have launched investigations into the tax treatment of Inter IKEA in the Netherlands, and whether the UK rule on tax avoidance involving controlled foreign companies treats some businesses differently from others.  But state aid rules are not just about tax. They are also to make sure that government support for important priorities like research and fighting climate change has the right effect, to make sure that public money does not just replace investment which companies would have made anyway; that aid does not deny innovative companies the chance to compete. But of course those rules should not make it difficult for support where our economy needs support.  In a couple of weeks, the Commission will present a proposal for a new Multiannual Financial Framework, and as part of that we are looking at how we can make state aid rules simpler so that it is easier for European funding from the European budget to link up with national funding. So our common European actions match our ambitions on research, on climate change, on support for small- and medium-sized businesses and on social infrastructure, and I am very keen to discuss the proposal with you once it is complete.  We have also been making sure that mergers do not harm European consumers. In fact, 2017 turned out to be the second busiest year of European merger control. And it is not just about the number of cases: mergers are getting bigger. They are reshaping the entire global economy, so consumers need protection from mergers now more than ever. Last month, we approved the merger between Bayer and Monsanto, and we only did that after the companies agreed to sell off businesses worth more than EUR six billion. That will mean that farmers will still have a wide choice, as they did before, when it comes to suppliers of seeds and pesticides, and it will mean that companies are still driven to innovate, to produce better, safer pesticides.  I know that Members of this House and people in the European public as well have concerns about this industry – concerns that go well beyond competition, but the right way to deal with it is not to extend the competition rules; it is to have strong, effective regulation that makes sure that pesticides are safe.  We also need to defend competition in digital markets so consumers get a fair deal online, and this is why we are watching very closely and analysing in—depth, in the most granular way, to make sure that Google treats rival comparison shopping services fairly. A case is not done with a decision: that is the start of the enforcement of that decision, looking into the choices that Google have made. And we are advancing – to answer your question, Ramon – on our two cases involving Google, both the Android case and the AdSense case. As the rapporteur said in his weighty and thoughtful report, competition makes a difference in people’s lives and I am very happy to be here today to have a chance to exchange ideas with you.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: rapporteur of the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. — Madam President Competition policy is absolutely essential for the functioning of the internal market. But competition politics today is also an area with many facets. For example, it is crucial that all companies make an adequate and fair tax contribution to the single coffers, and is there anyone cheating on the tax ticket through cunning corporate constructions or illegal government subsidies, well then it creates unfair competition for all the others. Competition policy is also labour market policy, because you bypass posting rules or doing social dumping, then you no longer compete on a level playing field to the detriment of businesses, workers and consumers. That is why it is also vital for competition that national competition authorities help ensure uniform enforcement of EU rules, and that is why we also say both a great thank you for - and we are very happy about - the new ECN+ network that can help to increase the independence of national competition authorities. And then at the very end, Mrs Vestager, thank you for addressing the big tech companies. But also remember the large and medium-sized companies in Europe. They must not be forgotten in the fight for the high-profile cases.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – Madam President, the EU’s competition policy is an essential instrument for a properly functioning internal market in the Union. It helps us prevent the over-concentration of economic and financial power, and it is also a key tool for moderate prices, better quality products and services, and of course greater choice for the consumers. This competition policy is ensuring a fair standard of living for the agricultural community, as the farming sector is under pressure from constant economic and climate-related hazards.  The colleagues on the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development therefore gave a strong signal. A market-oriented common agricultural policy needs to provide support for farmers and grant additional time—limited exemptions from certain competition rules. While competition policy defends consumers’ interests, it has to take account of the interests and difficulties of agricultural producers and rural people too.  We are still doing more and more in a couple of fields, such as unfair trade practices, and concerning rural development, including its social elements, especially, as much as the conception for smart villages.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for this excellent report.  We have to recognise that the European Union has good results in the implementation of the competition policy, and the principle merit belongs to the Competition Commissioner and her staff. The report places a heavy accent on the independence of the Commission and national competition authorities but the report also says very clearly that this independence is strongly linked to the availability of human and financial resources.  However, I and many of my colleagues have concerns regarding the fast development of the digital economy and the dominance of the global technology companies. Because of their huge economies of scale these global technology companies perform like real natural monopolies. We need a framework for analysis of these global technology companies and their markets.  We think the Commission and the national competition authorities should focus human and financial resources to get the knowledge and skill to implement the competition rules in the digital economy. The Commission, national competition authorities, and we in this Parliament should understand better how digital platforms work and how competition can be introduced in this digital market.

name: Alfred SANT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, increasingly, competition policy is taking a greater importance in the EU’s profile. One hopes that this is not happening for the wrong reasons. In principle, competition policy is meant to ensure that free market rules apply to the benefit of consumers all over Europe. In practice, given that historically the role of national governments in Europe has been a crucial element of economic development, the focus has frequently been – and still is, as we have just heard – more on questions relating to state aid than on matters arising from corporate competitive strategies. In this, it has been difficult to avoid one—size—fits—all approaches that failed to discriminate – and still fail to discriminate sufficiently – between north and south, island and metropole, peripheral and central. The privatisation of major infrastructural functions, such as in transport and utilities and now public health, has simply been seen as economically desirable if cast in competitive format. But the social impact, as well as some economic ones, have not been given sufficient attention. Now, the emphasis is also shifting towards state aid considerations with regard to taxation policies. Such policies are still subject to the sovereignty of Member States, but competition policy is being deployed to oversee and correct for them. One gets the impression, in fact, that the rules and methods by which this is being done are created on the hoof – basically, on a case-by-case basis. Tax flexibility within Member States under conditions, of course. A full transparency should be considered as an integral part of the competitive situation and is vital for the prosperity of smaller Member States and the single market. It will be a pity if competition policy comes to be driven according to the urgings of the tax populace while pushing for harmonisation of tax policies, and we have no problems with choosing competition policy to achieve this. However, we should watch out. The approach, apparently progressive, could serve to perhaps screen another reality at a time when European economies are again growing well: working and middle-class people as well as pensioners are not being compensated for the sacrifices they had to make during years of austerity. They will not be consoled by being told that, in the interests of competition, taxation within the Union should be harmonised.

name: Sander LOONES
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Mr Ramon, dear friend, thank you for your hard and excellent work here in Parliament. Commissioner, it is always nice to see your passion and your passion for European competition policy. You're just right. Look, unity in diversity is the slogan of the European Union, but some of them place particular emphasis on unity. We all have to do the same thing. Member States must go beyond their individuality. The diversity is perceived as a weakness. We must ensure that there is no competition and certainly not between countries. The opposite is true. On the contrary, our European civilisation differs from others, precisely because we have seen this rivalry and competition throughout our history. That makes us who we are. This competition between kingdoms, between principalities, between city-states has ensured that we are still living the European miracle to this day and that the European miracle has been made possible. We see that in the results. We have cities that flourish, we have trade networks, we have schools, we have universities. We see the flourishing of philosophy and science, our literature, our culture. All this has been made possible by this competition, including our unprecedented economic progress. Not despite our political fragmentation, but thanks to the fact that we are different and that we are competing with each other. Our diversity is a strength. It's not a weakness, and we need to cherish it. So today I am asking to celebrate that competition. Let us celebrate the report of our good friend Ramon Tremosa. Let us not comply with any imposed urge of absolute equality. Unity, yes, but in diversity.

name: Michel REIMON
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Commissioner, welcome to the European Parliament. The annual report is intended to assess your work. This has been done very quickly in most years with the fact that it was consistent and fair judgments where you can be congratulated on this implementation. Perhaps this year we should talk about the role of Parliament. There is a decision or a decision by you that, of course, disturbs me as a Green: this is the Monsanto merger. I took a close look at the decision. You have made the right decision on the basis of the law, the competition law of the European Union. But if ecological criteria do not play a role in preventing this merger, then the law is the problem, not its implementation. Then we in the European Parliament are called upon to consider whether we need legislation that protects not only markets, but also the environment and democracy. This brings me to the topic that is often addressed here: digital platforms. It is true that we are applying competition law to protect our consumers and our businesses, but it also has a democratic aspect. We will have to think about going further in legislation than just having a purely competition law regime for such large groups.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (FR) Commissioner, although the actions of the Directorate-General for Competition have been delayed to combat the tax haemorrhages of multinationals in European states, it must be recognised that they are going in the right direction for nations. But the European Commission had to redeem itself of all the perverse effects of your free-trade and borderless ideology, that is, the problems of tax dumping and unfair competition that did not exist before the European Union! In the field of financial services, this is exactly the same: the Directorate-General for Competition should prevent the perverse effects of the policies of the SSM (Single European Supervisor) and the ECB on the forced concentration of banking sectors in the euro area. The SSM prepares the conditions for the takeover of our national banks by national banking giants. To finance themselves, individuals and small and medium-sized enterprises in our European states do not need banking giants on Wall Street, or above-ground capital markets, they simply need trust relationships and total and local bank financing. The role of the European Union is to defend the interests of citizens against the private interests of global financial lobbies and not vice versa. This is a Europe close to Europeans.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Madam President, I want to congratulate and thank my friend Mr Tremosa i Balcells for his report and welcome the Commissioner to our proceedings. I promise not to talk about tax tonight!  We have one of the most integrated single markets in the world. It is a rules-based single market, and we have got to make sure that our competition policy delivers rules for consumers and for businesses big and small, to make sure it is fair competition, and we need in the Annual Report – as has been said by the rapporteur – to make that very, very, clear. We also need to support national competition authorities – I think you said before, Commissioner, that 85% of all cases are taken at the national level. They need support, they need resources, and they need a legal basis to take cases. I very much support the ECN+ Directive, which is about giving additional support to national authorities.  Three particular points in relation to my own country: in Ireland, we have to prove on a criminal charge, which is a very high charge, whether or not an enforcement can be taken. We need to move to a non-criminal basis. Secondly, in Ireland we do not apply a leniency programme, which would encourage national competition authorities to cut deals with people to give evidence so that those cases can be taken in court to reduce fines for those businesses that come forward with evidence. The third point is a Brexit-related issue: as you can understand, in my country we share information with the UK on a daily basis, with their competition authority to our competition authority. We need some agreement in the overall agreement to make sure that that flow of information continues, based on EU rules, and it is important that in the UK actually lives up to the cases that will follow their leaving of the European Union.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, first I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the outcome of this report. Its importance is highlighted by the essential points raised within – points that this Parliament defends. I welcome the attention given to the national competition authorities, taking into account the role these administrations play in fighting trusts. Keeping in mind that competition policy is enforced, not only by the Commission but also largely by the national competition authorities, it is a good thing that the report encourages the European Competition Network Plus (ECN+) proposal so we can progress towards the strongest capacity, more resources, autonomy and transparency. A second point emphasised in this report is the fight for fair taxation. Indeed, tax avoidance hurts fair competition in the single market. It penalises new entrants and small and medium-sized enterprises compared to multinational corporations, which are the only ones with the resources to implement aggressive tax planning schemes.  I am glad to see that the report encourages as well the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base negotiations, pointing out that this would solve Europe’s problem of unfair tax competition. It also specifically mentions the Amazon case – the Commission having recognised that the company benefited from illegal tax advantages.  However, Amazon is not the only company named in the report – there are also several mentions of Google, which has abused its market dominant position by giving an advantage to another of its products, its comparison shopping service, preventing potential competitors from emerging in the search engine sector. It is important to encourage the Commission’s actions towards fairer competition. This is the case with the current investigations into Luxembourg’s ‘sweetheart’ deal with McDonald’s. Furthermore, the report also points out some shortcomings of the Commission and encourages it to go further. That is the case for the aviation sector. It calls for better protection of consumers in the airline sector as well.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: - Madam President! I agree with the rapporteur that investments and innovations implemented in conditions of fair competition are crucial for the future of Europe. However, it is difficult to understand why competitive service prices and labour costs of citizens of Central and Eastern European countries are often called social dumping. This downright toxic wording was also unfortunately in the text of the report, without any specification. My objections are also raised by the fact that paragraphs devoted to tax policy indirectly call for tax harmonization. I also have a caveat about giving specific company names as examples of unfair competition. After all, the European Parliament should not discharge or replace the Commission's Directorate-General for Competition. Given the above objections, the Polish delegation shall abstain.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when I think of the competition policy of the European Union, I understand why in recent years and currently the support among European citizens for this project is to its historic lows. I give a random example: the issue of State aid, a very debated issue today and on which the Commissioner has worked very hard. It is a theme that often affects and punishes those small realities in the states and regions of Europe that are in serious difficulties. I am referring to the case of more than three hundred small businesses and craftsmen in Abruzzo, a region of my country that was struck in 2009 by a terrible earthquake and which today, according to a decision on state aid The European Commission, after almost ten years, they are invited to return aid for concessions which the Italian State had granted to these companies affected by the earthquake. Without this money such businesses would have closed, jobs would have been lost and today no longer exist. If these entrepreneurs are called upon to return the money in question, we will have a loss of jobs, we will have a drama that adds to the further drama. For once I ask the European Union to show that it really cares about the interests of the citizens, of the European people, of the Italian people and does not entrench itself behind technicalities, behind rules that can be interpreted, but truly show that there is a soul behind this Europe and help these entrepreneurs who are in difficulty today to continue to operate on a territory already devastated by a great catastrophe.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, good competition policy can work only under the rules of fairness, transparency and level playing field. That’s why I would like to concentrate my comments only on market surveillance. During the last electoral period, the Commission proposed a new market surveillance regulation, and Parliament improved it significantly when it comes to pan-European surveillance and effectiveness. Unfortunately, these proposals were stuck in the Council and debates inside there. Frankly, we need to confess to ourselves that the existing market surveillance is not effective: it is almost like a negative lottery to be caught importing forged lighters or designer goods, or indeed a lot of products that can be dangerous for consumers, and all in all are not applying the EU regulation in general.  So I do duly hope that now, when the Commission is looking at this competition policy, it would very speedily come back to the market surveillance regulation that was not in the goods package and try to revoke this process for the negotiations.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Tremos and Balcells for their very good report. The report concludes that the European Commission, together with national competition control authorities, constitute a very efficient and efficient system for implementing, evaluating and controlling the application of competition rules in the European Union. It is a statement that allows you to say that competition serves citizens and companies of the European Union. I do not agree with previous votes that the Commission does not think about citizens — on the contrary, competition is for citizens, not for companies. That's first. Secondly, I also agree that fair tax competition is essential for the integrity of the internal market. It is, inter alia, for this reason, that I believe that the Commission should have the right to read tax decisions, tax information of individual companies within the discretion of individual tax authorities in order to check their compliance with competition rules. At the same time, I want to say that in order to remain competitive, it is necessary to provide simple and transparent tax rules — one that will not seek to harmonise tax rates, but will seek to unify the tax base. Finally, two critical remarks — firstly, corruption that distorts the functioning of the market. I call on the Commission to step up anti-corruption measures, especially in public procurement. And finally, antitrust actions are too long, Commissioner. I encourage you to shorten these antitrust proceedings.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: — Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I would like to welcome the work done by the rapporteur and by the whole group that has worked around him. I think that this report clearly shows that we need, for the balance of society, an effective competition policy. The question that this report also raises and what it demonstrates is that at some point the policy of the consumer citizen must not be contrary to the interests of the working citizen. Over the past year, we have had the opportunity, with the omnibus text, to make progress on a number of sectors, including agriculture. Last week, the European Commission proposed a new text on practices in the distribution chain. Indeed, we must ensure a balance between the interests of all. Whereas for weeks or even months the Commission has been thinking about cartels, why are we still not having the result of this work? However, cartels weigh sustainably on markets in the disinterest of the economy of our space.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, I would like to refer to the famous issue of state aid and say that many times, because there is state aid, the punishment imposed on companies is essentially to return these funds. I would like to address a serious issue in Greece, Commissioner. It is Larco, a company with 1200 employees, a company important in the mining sector, a breathtaking company for the Region of Sterea Hellas. Is it now obliged to repay EUR 136 million when there is no chance that this money will be found and what is the solution? Disbanding the company, trifling it, separating the plant from the mines. In other words, we have a production unit which must survive, which must give life to the economy and which, in the name of the repayment of state aid, is dissolved and with it the economy of the region is dissolved. Is this economic policy? Give a specific answer, because this is a hot topic for the Region of Central Greece.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: — Madam President, I have studied the report and I agree with most of the passages, but let me have one comment. I have a problem like some colleagues with those passages that relate to tax policy. In short and well, they are so generally written that, with some interpretation, they may introduce a cause for the fact that, by adopting them, the European Parliament calls for a harmonisation of tax policy, and for me, it is necessary personally a big deal. I also have a big problem with the passage that relates to issues of social dumping. This is a very sensitive topic that divides old EU member countries and new EU member countries. It is a great political policy, which is very sensitively debated in the Czech Republic. And I personally think that, in such an annual report, the facts relating to competition policy should be really summarised and very sensitive political topics on which we have no clear opinion, should not be mentioned in this way.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: — Dear Chairman, I welcome the Commissioner and thank the rapporteurs for their excellent report. Being successful and not paying or avoiding payment of commitments paid by competitors or arranging prices so imposing them in this way is not great wisdom, and such practices, of course, we all agreed, destroy quality companies, destroy innovators and generally make it impossible to develop entrepreneurship. That is why the effective work of the Competition Authority, as well as national authorities, which need to be strengthened staffing and financially, is extremely important. What I want to draw attention to is in particular the relationship between national authorities and the European Commission administrations, especially in cases where they have different views. I think it is very important to respect each other and it is important that the administration of the European Commission does not insist at all costs and impose its views at all costs, but such differences in opinions should be dealt with in partnership, and not only with high reference of Member States to the court. I call for greater cooperativeness and partnership.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to group my answers, first taking those relating to data, then some of the questions raised on agriculture, then taxation, then addressing the issue of the earthquake support, and then on the proposal to empower national competition authorities. Regarding the things that we are discussing right now, when it comes to data I think this is the best example of the fact that we need competition law enforcement to the spirit and the letter of our regulation, but we also need new regulation. The two things will have to go hand in hand.  I think this House needs praise for the fact that the new privacy rules coming into effect next month have been done in such a timely manner. This House did not wait for a scandal like the Facebook scandal to unfold. On the contrary, beforehand, this House, knowing how powerless Europeans feel when it comes to privacy, enabled new, simpler, enforceable rules. I think that is very important. We will of course do our part when it comes to misuse of a dominant position if we find cartels or if we find that contracts are being used in a way actually to disable innovation, preventing small and medium—sized businesses from doing their part when it comes to data. That of course leads directly to the question of taxation. So many small and medium—sized businesses pay their taxes, create jobs and have to look at multinational businesses, which can easily afford to contribute to the society where they do their business and which accept or ask for ways to organise their taxation in order to pay very, very little in taxes. This is not fair competition. But, of course, state aid enforcement does not solve this. We need legislation as well. It is also very important to see that the Council has passed legislation in the last two years in order to close loopholes, in order to increase transparency and in order to hold the intermediaries responsible. But the new proposals on the table are also important, for instance, the proposal that will update a very important concept in corporate taxation to a digital world. On average, digital companies pay 10% in tax. Other companies pay 23-24% in tax on average. It is important to update our taxation to make sure that the business that makes a revenue in a society also contributes to that society. We will of course continue to do what we do, but we also need to work with colleagues who work with legislation in general. When it comes to agriculture, I think there is a deep and very common understanding of the fact that the bargaining powers in the value chain are very different, from being a small individual farmer to being large retail chains. This is why we have done our best to enable farmers to come together, to have higher prices and lower costs, and are also working very closely with colleagues in the Commission to make sure that, when there is legislation on unfair trading practices, these are targeted and actually help the people that we want to help. Regarding the question on earthquake and natural disasters, I think anyone can feel the pain of seeing their business, home, village or city destroyed by an earthquake. This is also reflected in our Treaty. Our Treaty allows for help and compensation for damage. That is being done. It was done in the 2009 scheme and it is being done right now with what the Italian Government has put in place due to their earthquakes in 2016 and 2017. But you cannot compensate people who have not had damage. If your business was a letterbox business and you have had no damage, you can have no compensation. If your damage is of a certain size, then your compensation should reflect that and that is what has been raised. The good thing – and I think everyone finds this to be important and a good thing – is that the people who had damage were compensated for this damage in the right way.  On the Greek cases that were raised, unfortunately I do not know the details. It was decided in the previous Commission and this is why. I will be more than happy to report back to you in writing.  Last but not least, I am very happy with the support of the national competition authorities. The approach of this House is to empower national competition authorities to protect citizens in each and every Member State, to make sure that, when they enforce European competition law, they have the independence, the human resources, the resources and ability to have digital evidence, and of course to impose fines that act as a deterrent. I find that this is a very important message from this House tonight. I hope that we can work together to pass this directive within a very short timeframe because it is a signal to citizens that you should not only look to Brussels, but you can also look to your national competition authority and know that they are empowered to protect you in order to have a fair deal in the marketplace. On that basis, thank you very much for the report. I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the effort that has been put into it. I hope that there will be a successful vote tomorrow.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I couldn’t agree more with the last part of the Commissioner’s intervention. I also fully share the opinion of my colleague from the EPP from the Irish, Mr Hayes, about the importance of national competition authorities, and in this sense the countries in the north of Europe can give some lessons to the southern European countries in this respect. This is why we give a strong mandate to the Commission in this report to take a look at what is going on in some capitals concerning this very important point.  Let me also answer some concerns about the tax competition: of course I believe in tax competition and we can talk about our own edition of the tax base, but I am against tax harmonisation concerning the rate: I think that is a very liberal approach. If we look at the United States, very briefly, they have a centralised monetary policy but a highly decentralised fiscal policy. There is a lot of empirical evidence and a lot of economic literature showing that it is very important to compensate the differentiated effects of the centralised monetary policy. This is why it is needed to have a highly decentralised fiscal policy to compensate territorial and sectoral differentiated effects of the single monetary policy in the US. I think that Europe can learn big lessons from this long experience they have in the US. Finally, Madam Commissioner, it has been a pleasure to work with you and your team. Your work has been quite impressive, we have to recognise, in the last years. I want you to be successful and end your mandate as well as you have started it. You have raised the bar and I hope you finish your mandate and your job as well as you have started it.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 19 April 2018.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Council on the disclosure of income tax information by certain undertakings and branches by Pavel Svoboda, on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs (O-000015/2018-(B8-0013/2018) (2016/0107(COD)) (2018/2552(RSP)).

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Author. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, Mrs Panayotova. On 4 July 2017, a long time ago, Parliament adopted its decision on the proposal for a Directive on public country-by-country reporting. The aim is to increase transparency and public control of corporate income tax and to promote corporate responsibility by imposing disclosure obligations on certain companies. The content of the new Directive is better reporting requirements for companies. The initiative aims at new accounting standards for groups, which is why the Commission has submitted to amend the Accounting Directive on the basis of Article 50 and has chosen the legal basis accordingly. The European Parliament confirmed this election on the basis of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs of 12 January 2017. Two institutions, the Commission and Parliament, therefore agree that it is a matter of transparency obligations, accounting, financial reporting — that is, the balance sheet of companies — and not a new tax initiative. We have our mandate to negotiate with them. We have been in our mandate since last July to finalise the Group's public tax return. You in the Council have still not presented a plan or approach to public country-by-country reporting. Why? Because some finance ministers doubt the legal basis and claim that this is a new tax initiative. That is why Article 115 should form the legal basis. It is clear to the European Parliament's position that the proposal is not aimed at harmonising taxes or improving cooperation between tax authorities, nor is it aimed at creating new tax obligations. Only certain companies, the largest on the planet, are required to create a Publish your income tax information report. Call it the Group public tax return. This report is therefore the heart of good corporate governance for groups in Europe. And that is what it is about: accountability of the multi-corporations to all taxpayers in Europe. Public control, because so far, citizens of Europe have not been able to trust the large corporations or all governments. In view of the Union's international obligations, what is the Council's justification for the blockade? We, as the European Union, are at the forefront of public country-by-country reporting. I refer to the report on the disclosure of non-financial information, to the directive which has already put in place a lot here. Do you want to follow the system of a Trump? How do you justify the two-year delays? How do you justify the Council's position on the legal basis? Is it clear to ministers that the proposal does not concern the level of national taxes to be paid? Is the Group tax return in the Council a priority? How does the Council intend to make progress on this important proposal so that it will be possible to move forward during this parliamentary term? Clearly, only large corporations are obliged to transparency. Small and medium-sized enterprises are excluded. So only the very big ones, those with a turnover of more than 750 million euros, are affected. This debate is thus a sham debate by some finance ministers and the tactics of individual ministers to simply block EU laws that are unpleasant to them, wait for weed to grow over it and no one talks about it. Ask the individual ministers who are blocking. Ask the Austrian colleague: why are you blocking the law, Minister? Is it because the law affects the big corporations so much because the big corporations do not want this? With this, you protect no start-ups, no coffee house on the corner, not even the big companies themselves. They only protect the huge companies, the corporations, which currently pay little or no taxes. It is therefore the right of all taxpayers, all taxpayers in Europe, to know how much tax companies such as Google, Facebook, Starbucks and Co. pay in our countries, and that is why I call on you to work in the Council.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me thank first of all Ms Regner, the co-rapporteur, as well as the Chair of the Committee on Legal Affairs, Mr Svoboda, for this question. This is an important file and this proposal presented by the Commission in 2016 is a key element in fighting base erosion and profit-shifting. The Council has worked a lot on the text of the proposal. More than 15 meetings of the relevant working party took place under four successive Presidencies. In February this year, Mr Svoboda and Mr Gualtieri wrote to our Ambassador inquiring about the state of play and insisting on a possible speeding—up of our deliberations. We replied to this letter, recalling that there are unresolved political issues which still prevent agreement in the Council.  One of these issues is the legal base of the proposal. Indeed this aspect calls into question the very applicability of the ordinary legislative procedure in this file.  The Bulgarian Presidency has taken over the results of the technical work, which was well advanced under the successive Presidencies that preceded us. So we are currently pursuing consultations with delegations with a view to further advancing the file. But you will understand that I cannot make any specific commitments today.  However, the Council will probably need more time in order to clarify its position. I commit myself to keeping you informed of any further developments and I hope that we will be able to find a solution. Let me assure you that we are working on it.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: for the PPE Group. — Madam President, I have listened very carefully to the Council representative and I must state, Madam Secretary, that your response was absolutely inadequate, I would say completely shocking and I absolutely reject her. It was, in principle, merely an excuse. It was only an excuse where, in a situation where there is a draft directive that is to be adopted in the public interest and which, as you have said yourself, will help fight tax fraud, the Council does everything to do that, for proxy reasons, this Directive is not adopted. And you haven't made any argument as to why that's the case. Don't be mad at me, but arguing a dispute over a legal basis is merely an excuse, an effort to block the discussion of this materie and its acceptance. It would be much more honest if those countries that do not want to adopt this directive clearly declared that they do not agree with it politically, that they do not want information with large multinational firms, what about their tax obligations and levies, they have been made public, and voters and EU citizens could be clear. I too — I confess — Madam Minister, cannot explain to my constituents in the Czech Republic what the tax base dispute is and why such important information to combat tax fraud, some states in the Council refuse. It's really, I think, a very sensitive subject and please, it would be fair for those states that don't want to release this information to be clear and make no excuses for proxy legal problems.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam Minister, as you have been reminded, for two years since this Parliament has called for the assumption to be made viable, which we have for a long time discussed and then approved, public reporting requirement, country by country, for large multinational companies. It is a need that cannot be put off further in time. Moreover, the scandals that have occurred over the last few years have shown that the phenomenon of avoidance and avoidance is a very serious phenomenon that has made economic activity difficult and redistributive in all European countries. These companies, while making big profits, paid very little tax. You must therefore introduce a constraint that forces you to declare the game: it is loyalty to users and citizens to pay taxes and without the approval of these measures, one would maintain a unacceptable condition of injustice towards those who pay taxes, towards consistent and positive companies that would be subject to absolutely illegitimate competition mechanisms. We are waiting quickly for a positive response.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Madam President, Madam Minister, I do not know how to express to you the feeling of shame that can affect us today as European legislators. We are facing a situation — and you know — extremely dramatic. SMEs, small businesses, SMEs are forced to pay their taxes and comply with the rules, while large companies are hiding behind opacity — because we are talking only about this — to try to escape tax. For almost two years, following consultations with European citizens and after scandals, we have been asking, behind and with the Commission and with the support of two legal services, the Commission and Parliament, to move towards transparency of this information. It's a matter of balance sheet, Minister. This is not a tax issue. We cannot stand behind this dummy argument so as not to act. I really ask you to take this file to heart.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. — Madam President, for more than a year now, the European Parliament has been urging the Commission and the Member States to proceed with an amendment to European legislation that will ensure greater transparency in the taxation of multinationals in particular companies. There are many such companies which, elsewhere, sell their products at high profits and elsewhere, are taxed at extremely low rates. The imposition of an obligation to publish declarations by multinational companies with state-specific information can promote corporate liability and limit tax avoidance effected through aggressive tax planning. It is neither fair nor sustainable for small and medium-sized enterprises and workers to be burdened with increasingly unbearable taxes, while in essence large multinationals are exempted. Any further delay in this matter is unjustified.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, tax transparency has become a crucial issue for EU citizens in recent years. To address this public demand, the Commission came up with a proposal and public country—by—country reporting in 2016 – two years ago. I was the PPE Shadow on this file and in this chaos, after months of hard work, we found the right balance, I think, between the demand for more transparency and protecting EU companies on the other hand. We adopted our decision last year in June. Now while preaching commitment to this fight for tax transparency, this Presidency has not even called a meeting yet on this very issue. Blocking this dossier simply because Member States cannot agree on the legal base is simply not serious. This is not a directive about tax rates, tax revenues or any fiscal issues; this is a directive about transparency and disclosure. This has nothing to do with the infringement of national powers or national competences, and therefore I call on this Council to swiftly proceed with the work on this directive.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it has been ten months since this Parliament adopted its position on the proposal for a directive on state-by-state public reporting, one A fundamental instrument for combating tax evasion and avoidance at European and global level. A cost-effective transparency tool that would require multinationals, as well as European legislation requires the banking sector, to publish relevant information on tax matters for every jurisdiction in which they are operating, starting with how much profit they make and how much tax they pay. Here, this Parliament is waiting to sit down and negotiate with you and not only do you not yet have a common position but these doubts raised on the legal basis are only excuses to decide unanimously and hear Parliament only in consultation: Lux leaks, Panama Papers, Paradise Papers, how many scandals do we still have to wait before we give a clear answer? This delay is outrageous!

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, the vast majority of legal interpretation says clearly that this is in the common competence and normal law procedure relating to auditing and accounting directives and procedures, so claiming that there would be a risk of having the wrong legal basis is a total fraud. It is a total fig leaf that is being intentionally used to block this very clear and long overdue country-by-country reporting. It is against all fairness and European citizens’ sense of what is right. I duly hope that the Bulgarian Presidency will convene a meeting and ask for a legal opinion from several different sources, and clarify the point within the Council, because only sitting on the issue will not solve it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: Madam President, at a time when citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises pay taxes, and in many countries, such as Greece, we have a huge tax policy, multinationals evade tax and evade tax. The example with LuxLeaks is decisive. What's to be done from now on? Multinationals must be taxed where they make their profits, and of course I think that the directive obliging the publication of reports on the profits of each multinationals for each country can really help to strike tax evasion. Unfortunately, certain states, as the Bulgarian Presidency said, have blocked the process. I would like to ask you, Mrs Panayotova, which Member States have blocked this process? You should name them. And I ask you, is Greece one of the Member States that have blocked the procedure for adopting the directive? We want transparency, we want answers here in the European Parliament.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I really listened carefully and took good note of your remarks. We will continue to work on this file. Here I am representing all Member States, and I’m not in a position to name any country in the process.  I would like to say that it’s not about a lack of urgency in the Council, but it is related to the need to search for an agreement, and this requires time and effort from the Presidency and also time in capitals for delegations to finalise their positions. As you know, in order to move ahead, we need unanimity in the Council.  The Bulgarian Presidency would like to take this file forward and is working towards the same, so – as I said during my intervention in the beginning – we are open to further discussions on the subject, and when we have advanced much more we will organise a meeting on it. Personally, I am open to further bilateral discussions and contacts with you.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. — We Spanish Socialists demand that the Council explain its inaction on tax transparency for multinational companies in Europe. Parliament already adopted its reform last year, which would ensure that all companies with a turnover of more than EUR 750 million declare where they earn their profits and where they pay their taxes, in a disaggregated manner for all countries where they have a subsidiary or branch. The Public Reporting Directive, country-by-country, has been blocked for more than two years by several Member States protecting the interests of large multinational tax evaders, resulting in the loss of up to €190 billion a year in tax revenues for the European Union as a whole. The obligation to make public their profits, taxes payable, taxes paid and the number of employees for each country in which they operate, will hold the largest companies in the world and all Governments accountable. It will highlight where Starbucks, Monsanto & Co, etc. earn their profits and pay their taxes and whether they move their profits to countries with very low tax rates. The Council must be transparent and reveal who is preventing the agreement.
