name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: in writing. — Promoting public country-by-country reporting by corporations is an important tool in the fight against aggressive tax planning and tax evasion. According to the Commission's estimates, tax avoidance by companies costs Member States up to €50bn to €70bn each year. With the reform, the tax data of large multinational corporations will become public so that citizens and national authorities can look at them. The data enables the control that companies take care of their tax responsibilities in the Member States where they have made profits. A key purpose of country-by-country reporting is to bring transparency to corporate taxation. Parliament decided on the matter at the July 2017 plenary session. The final text decided to impose a reporting obligation on undertakings whose turnover exceeds EUR 750 million. I personally supported setting the turnover limit significantly lower than this, at EUR 40 million, but the majority vote for a higher turnover limit won the vote in the plenary session. Although the text adopted was not as ambitious as I had hoped for myself, it is an important step towards transparency in corporate taxation and a significant means of tackling the tax base from tax evasion. Public country-by-country reporting of companies is a legislative project that should not be buried in the council. I hope that the Bulgarian Presidency will make every effort to move forward in the Council.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on: – the oral question to the Council on vaccine hesitancy and the drop in vaccination rates in Europe by Renate Sommer, Elena Gentile, Bolesław G. Piecha, Gesine Meissner, Kateřina Konečná, Marco Affronte, and Mireille D’Ornano, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety ((O-000008/2018 - (2017/2951(RSP)) (B8-0011/2018)), – the oral question to the Commission on vaccine hesitancy and the drop in vaccination rates in Europe by Renate Sommer, Elena Gentile, Bolesław G. Piecha, Gesine Meissner, Kateřina Konečná, Marco Affronte, and Mireille D’Ornano, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000009/2018 - (2017/2951(RSP)) (B8-0012/2018)).

name: Elena GENTILE
text: author. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thanks to the representative of the Commission and the Minister of the Council. Scientific research has allowed millions of citizens to be released from the risk of infectious disease contagion among the most insidious, because they threaten survival and very often affect levels of quality of life. Large-scale use of immunization practices contributed to the eradication of many infectious diseases, which therefore were robbed for a long time by the epidemiological chronicle. Now the landscape has changed: the number of subjects who fall ill, for example, with measles and painfully lengthens the list of victims, as happened in Italy, Romania and also, to a lesser extent, in other states. European citizens, among others, are those who show greater perplexity over the safety and effectiveness of vaccines. Epidemiological data for the period from 2008 to 2015 represent the figure of Europeans' mistrust of vaccination practices and, therefore, of their effectiveness and safety: 215 000 are cases of reported diseases that could be safely prevented and these numbers net of influenza epidemics. I would like to add some other considerations: if Europe really is the space in which to counteract inequalities and give back opportunities, then the goal of eradicating the disease coincides with the narrative of a Europe that contrasts marginalities, poverty and deprivation, freeing the future above all in favour of the most precious capital: our children and girls. It also means for Europe to take responsibility for refocusing and retraining public expenditure in health, particularly in this area, with the understanding that the benefits are certainly higher than costs, both health and social, because you invest in health, because you invests in quality of life. We call on the European institutions to take a bigger role in governance of health policies to reverse the current trend, which sees the underestimation of the benefits of practice growing vaccination, challenged by misinformation campaigns that feed doubts about efficacy and safety and on which, unfortunately, speculates the most becerous populism. Europe therefore has responsibility for transparent information, correct, closely linked to pharmacovigilance activities, within strict compliance with the ethical and moral profile of each actor of the system. It is up to Europe to call Member States to comply with their commitments, including the promotion of the search for new life-saving vaccines and promoting vaccination practices in certain numbers greater than recorded today. It is up to Europe to identify any useful intervention that reduces the costs of acquiring vaccines, thus making them easily accessible, and above all, in the countries which have the most investment difficulties and therefore spending. It is quite clear, Commissioner, the need to realign vaccination calendars in Europe, which is called today to new challenges related to immigration and increasing mobility for reasons of study, work and also of leisure; promoting a democratic path that reconnects science with citizens, system operators, associations to value advantages, clarify doubts, stigmatise any distortions and contamination of the system, freeing it from any suspicion of conflict of interest. That seems to me to be the goal of our discussion and our confrontation. Democratic information, communication training: education is the most effective tool to defeat mistrusts and fears. Advising and recommending is certainly better than obliging: but to make compulsory the Vaccination practice may be a necessary step to achieve the goal of immunization of flock that really securely people. The Italian experience can offer a useful element of discussion.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, it is a pleasure for me to participate today in this important debate. As the honourable Members point out, a widespread vaccine hesitancy is a worrying phenomenon that could cause serious public health problems, as the current measles outbreaks in a number of Member States show. In order to increase vaccination coverage, which is the only means to counteract the public health threats caused by vaccine-preventable diseases, vaccine hesitancy is however only one of the problems to tackle. It is equally important to prevent vaccine shortages and to find means to develop new vaccines. The Council has taken several initiatives relating to vaccination. In the Council conclusions of 2014, Ministers agreed on a comprehensive list of actions intended to increase the vaccination coverage in the European Union and invited Member States and the Commission to implement those actions. Among these actions, one of them aims at strengthening the role of healthcare professionals in recommending vaccination, which directly links to the issues raised by the honourable Members. The Council will further undertake a detailed analysis of the measures in this field, including measures aimed at tackling vaccine hesitancy, when examining the forthcoming Commission proposal for a Council Recommendation on Strengthening Cooperation against Vaccine—Preventable Diseases. The Bulgarian Presidency is in contact with the Commission with regard to the proposal. As soon as the proposal is published, we will initiate the discussions in the Council.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you very much indeed for this oral question. Vaccination is one of the most powerful public health measures we have at our disposal. Widespread vaccination has eradicated smallpox and made Europe polio—free. It prevents countless deaths and stops millions of people from contracting illnesses each year. There are not so many other interventions that can claim to be so effective. That being said, sorry, but now over 14 000 people contracted measles in the European Union in 2017 – more than three times than in 2016. And 57 deaths due to measles have been reported here since 2016. It is so painful to see this picture. A safe, effective and cheap measles vaccine exists, so every one of these deaths is unacceptable. They are avoidable deaths, preventable deaths. It is deeply unacceptable.  So why on earth are people avoiding vaccinations? Well, there is a shift away from the individual and collective benefits of vaccinations to increased distrust and fear of possible side effects. That is true. Misinformation by vaccination deniers and the rapid spread of fake information is clearly a factor. But we cannot just dismiss vaccine hesitancy as a question of ignorance. People have concerns about the vaccines and we need to address these. Vaccine hesitancy is a common problem across Member States. Solving this problem depends on strengthened coordination at European Union level. So I am very encouraged by the Parliament’s resolution. Thank you very much indeed; it is very timely. I also want to ensure that vaccination is an absolute priority for me as Commissioner and it is very important that I see cross—party engagement on this issue.  Now, you have asked me some important questions and I want to address each of them individually. First, how does the Commission plan to address this resistance to vaccination? Based on your draft resolution it seems that we share many of the same concerns, including the difference in vaccine rates across Member States and increasing vaccine hesitancy. These issues need a strategic and coordinated response. With that in mind, the Commission is planning to adopt an initiative on a vaccination very soon – maybe next week. The Parliament’s draft resolution is very much in line with our own proposal. We plan to focus first on tackling vaccine hesitancy and increasing vaccination uptake. Now is the time to act in ensuring vaccine supply and improving cooperation across the European Union. Healthcare workers and health professionals play a crucial role in promoting vaccination and addressing concerns related to hesitancy. So we are exploring how to create a coalition of health associations to increase vaccination coverage. We also need to find ways to deliver accurate and timely information to the public of these genuine concerns, exchanging best practices and combating myths.  Under the European Union Health Programme we are launching a project or joint action with Member States that will also address vaccine hesitancy. The joint action is led by France and will, first, establish mapping of best practices and analyse the reasons behind high and low vaccination coverage and, secondly, set up social media infrastructures to conduct real—time public vaccine confidence monitoring. Your second question, how does the Commission intend to ensure that a comprehensive European Union action plan raising the social problem of vaccine hesitancy is elaborated? As you know, vaccination programmes are the competence of Member States. But given the close border nature of disease outbreaks, some Member States have requested support suggesting the need for coordinated approaches. This makes absolute sense and this is also the reason our initiative is in the form of a Council recommendation. There is a clear added value in strengthening cooperation at EU level including among health authorities, the vaccine industry, research and innovations, healthcare providers and other stakeholders, keeping all on board. Make no mistake, each of these stakeholders needs to be enrolled if we are to properly address this issue. The Commission will encourage and support Member States’ outreach to the most disadvantaged groups including by promoting health mediators and grassroots community networks. We will also work with Member States to simplify and broaden opportunities for vaccination. This means identifying the barriers to access and supporting interventions to increase access for disadvantaged and socially—excluded groups. The Commission initiative would aim to achieve these goals. Indeed, we intend to focus on one of the proposal’s main pillars on tackling vaccine hesitancy. Your third question, what concrete actions is the Commission planning to facilitate a more harmonised schedule for vaccinations across the EU? Vaccination schedules vary considerably between Member States due to differences in the way vaccination programmes are organised. These differences take into account, of course, historical vaccine registrations and the specific burden of disease and the cost—effectiveness of single vaccinations. Together, these inconsistencies can give the sense that there is a lack of scientific consensus on vaccine schedules, which could in turn lead to vaccine hesitancy.  A European Union—wide common vaccination schedule would solve many of these problems. For example, it would mitigate the risk that children miss a vaccine by moving, together with their parents, from one Member States to another. Furthermore, this would decrease supply problems and increase the value of programme monitoring. To address this issue, the joint action on vaccination aims to map the evidence base of national vaccination calendars. This will provide an important basis for a common vaccination schedule in the future.  As a starting point, we need a system to collect and share data on vaccination. This requires the involvement of all Member States and we hope that we can build on the excellent work of the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control. The fourth question, how does the Commission plan to address the spread of unreliable and misleading scientific information on vaccinations and to further develop information campaigns aimed at providing more in—depth knowledge about vaccines and increasing vaccination coverage? The spread of accurate and timely information in an age of information overload is a huge challenge. When it comes to vaccination, we need to be extremely vigilant and responsive to rumours, myth and misinformation. The Commission will explore, with Member States, how to support their communication activities and awareness—raising on the benefits of vaccination by, first, presenting scientific evidence to counter the spread of fake news. Second, engaging with healthcare workers, education stakeholders and the media, as advocates and multipliers, to fight complacency and increase trust in immunisation.  I want to assist in increasing the bearings and confidence of citizens in their national vaccine programmes. We feel that campaigns are best developed at national level by experts who understand the national and cultural context.  We are working closely with the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control to propose ways to provide objective and transparent evidence on vaccines and pharmacovigilance processes. We also need to build on synergies with other Commission initiatives such as the upcoming initiative addressing the spread of fake news. Honourable Members, colleagues, at a time when our health systems are under increasing pressure and are asked to do more with less, we simply cannot afford to waste the potential of vaccinations to save lives. We need to harness our all our resources and energy in a coordinated effort to restore public confidence in vaccination. Our work with Member States is very much in line with Parliament’s resolution.  So we are moving in the right direction together. But this is only the beginning and I invite you to be fully involved in this effort. I look forward to working closely with Parliament and to doing everything in my power to increase vaccine coverage in Europe.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner. Thank you for this committed statement. Yes, there are diseases that we barely remember, which we may have had as children, which, if we are a little older — like me — can be life-threatening. People have obviously forgotten this: measles can be life-threatening. There are countries where measles has been eradicated or almost eradicated through vaccination programs — Guatemala is such a country. Nevertheless, a student from Guatemala has become infected with measles. But she did not become infected in Guatemala, but in Germany, where she was on a student exchange, and then — not knowing that she was ill — she returned this disease to Guatemala. Suddenly there's measles again. This shows that there is too little vaccination in Germany. It is not only the case in Germany, it is the case throughout the EU. Vaccination is declining in all Member States. This goes back to fake news about allegedly horrible side effects of vaccinations that are not true. We know our vaccines are safe. Minor side effects must be taken, because the effect of the disease, which is prevented by it, can be disastrous. I almost consider it a bodily injury when parents refuse vaccination to their children for which they are responsible. They may deliver their children from a fatal illness or a disease that causes lifelong disability. We have to explain that to humans again. People have forgotten how important vaccination is. We have to teach them again. In particular, the Member States are responsible for this, they must do so. But, of course, we should have concerted action at European level. That is why I am delighted with what the Commissioner has just said about this.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. — (PT) Madam President, acting together to address the reservations about vaccines and reversing the reduction in vaccination rates in the European Union is a priority. To this end, I have sent a question to the European Commission, I raised several questions in the recent debate in the ENVI committee and the resolution we are debating here today is in line with what I have been answered in all these circumstances. I should like to congratulate the rapporteur, Elena Gentile, on her excellent work, and I would like to congratulate the Commissioner on the extraordinary effort she has put in resolving this issue. The conditions are in place for, together, the European Parliament, the Member States and the European Commission, to be able to implement consistent policies that actually deal with the problem. Strengthen the legal basis of the European vaccination plan, develop a joint buying platform that already has 19 countries and needs to be developed, implement data sharing practices, for better coordination and informed coordination, to develop research on this subject in an open, transparent manner to increase citizens' confidence and also the reliability of vaccines, incorporate these measures into a wider Europe-wide health promotion plan, also taking into account, for example, animal vaccination and combating antibiotic resistance, to launch a European information and pedagogy campaign on this important issue for public health and the quality of life of Europeans, all of this we now have the tools to do. We must be practical and capable of implementing measures that improve the concrete lives of citizens. This is an example, we need rapid, determined, transparent implementation, because it is important for people, because it is important for the future of Europe and for health in the world.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — Madam President. Vaccination — a topic that moves many people: doctors, health insurance companies, but especially parents. They face millions of challenges to decide on their children's vaccination catalog. The pharmaceutical industry is not making it easy for people with its colourful giant vaccination packages and a bunch of side effects. I am not a vaccine muffle, but what will be put to the vote here tomorrow sounds as if pharmaceutical obbyists have written it — for example, if we are calling for much more to promote vaccination in the future, so to recommend a compulsory vaccination to the nation states. I am critical of this and have tabled amendments to this effect for the benefit of the parents. We need more information about the side effects. The Charter of Fundamental Rights clearly states that, in the field of medicine, the free choice of treatment must be respected, after detailed information and agreement by the individual. Do I really need to confront babies with a sevenfold or eightfold vaccination cocktail? As citizens' representatives, we must give more space to the interests of the population to vaccinate, rather than just quoting the phrases of the pharmaceutical industry.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (DE) Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen. We have achieved a lot of medical progress. Humanity today may be healthier than before, if you do not have any allergies. And that's when you feel like some people think we're immune to disease right now. But we're not at all. We must also consider that much of our good health status today is due to the fact that we know diseases, that we know counteractions and that we have also quasi eradicated diseases through vaccination — it has already been said. But they can just come back. This is very important, we must not forget it. Mr Gericke is not at all a question of pleasing to the pharmaceutical industry in any way, Mr Gericke, because it is not. It is about informing people and taking away fears about possible side effects. I believe that if all parents know what a child can possibly face when he really gets sick, and what it means to vaccinate, then most parents will decide on vaccination. As you have already said, this is the responsibility of the Member States — absolutely right. We don't want to muddger them either. But there are so many things where it's really important to point out that vaccination can save lives, and that's a fact. That doesn't mean we want to get forced vaccination. In some areas it is necessary in some diseases. Many others are concerned with informing and then — as has already been said — to have the Member States jointly exchange on actions, including, for example, common vaccines in the event of a disease that is not excluded — bird plague or something — so that one is armed, and then also to consider: are now intercontinental, so far worldwide connected. We cannot regulate the whole world, but in Europe we can try to make a start and really see that, not by coercion, but through information, we are getting people to actually do the best for their children in order to live a healthy life later. I also received emails from people who are vaccine-sceptical and who told me: they want to force us now. We don't want that at all. We're not trying to force, we want to enlighten. Once again: inform, transparent. We also want to build confidence that doctors will also provide good information. And then we want to give people the choice to take what is best for their family.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt for those who speak that vaccines are of great use, at least because of our state of health and our conditions of health quality of life. However, there is no doubt that the reticence to vaccines is increasing and this leads to consequences: the rates of coverage of the vaccinated population are lowering and diseases are coming back. We thought we had eradicated. This can then lead to extreme consequences, as happened for example in my country, Italy, but also in France, to introduce the obligation to vaccinate. This is an extreme ratio to which we must not reach; I believe it to be a defeat because we must fight the reticence of vaccines with communication and information given correctly, in so as to build citizens' trust towards vaccines, which are an extremely useful tool, and not through a vaccination obligation. This is why this resolution and agreement with the European Commission is important, but we also call for the cooperation of pharmaceutical companies not to minimise and deal with open face problems, so as to have informed consent and not to simply consider the side effects as a small percentage, because the families affected are something very important.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: — Madam President, I think this resolution does not respond because of the hesitation of vaccine. People are not opposed to vaccination, but they no longer trust. One of the first problems is the conflicts of interest of experts who decide on the vaccine schedule. Commissioner, when there was the H1N1 flu, who decided? A WHO opaque panel of experts decided that it was a pandemic. However, a survey at the Council of Europe level showed that this pandemic was absolutely invalid, that it had been created from scratch and that this committee of experts was paid by the pharmaceutical industry. Second problem, adjuvants. Look at all the controversy over aluminum. While animal studies show that there are neurotoxic effects, no studies on humans and children have been conducted. Third problem, the vaccine is a medicine. All drugs are subject to pharmacokinetic studies, but not vaccines. In other words, the fate of their constituents in the human organism is not known. Commissioner, I formally ask you to impose pharmacokinetic studies on all vaccines. Confidence will not be imposed by constraint, it will be imposed by pedagogy, transparency and product safety.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: – Madam President, vaccine hesitancy is not the problem, as long as the majority of us are getting our vaccinations and we are providing the herd protection for all the rest of the people. But if the hesitancy is increasing, there is the risk that we could cause serious pandemic infections, very vulgar infections, in Europe.  This is a serious issue that I think gives the Commission the competency, even though I know it is a very delicate situation, to create a European vaccination plan and even to consider having a European, pan-European, not just the suggested list, but a register of vaccinated people or vaccinations. That would be information to be shared. Because it is not only an issue of pandemics; think of people working in hospitals and with fragile people in elderly care centres and not having vaccinations. I know a lot of these cases. They are posing a real threat to someone else that we should be protecting.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: — Madam President, measles are galloping in Greece at the moment. The latest data show that from 01/05/2017 until 05/04/2018 we had 2,431 cases. The course of measles cases in Greece is increasing, while in the rest of Europe it is downward. We already have over 2,500 cases as we speak, and of course those who suffer the consequences are between 25 and 44 years old. Most cases are in southern Greece, there are Roma among patients and of course the problems are intensified due to the refugee crisis. We have health professionals, many of whom have been ill, so you understand, Commissioner, that matters are very serious in Greece. So the question is whether there is cooperation between the Greek Government and the Commission on this issue, whether Greece is in this “Alliance of Health” and how this issue will be dealt with in Greece and in the other countries of the European Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: — Madam President, in 2017, measles caused 35 deaths in a group of fifty countries in the European region where there were more than twenty thousand cases of the disease. A high incidence of cases is estimated in children under one year of age who are still too young to receive the first dose of the vaccine. Hence the importance of group immunity. This is in question when a significant part of the population is not vaccinated, a situation that harms not only those who have chosen not to be vaccinated, but also those who cannot be immunized. Vaccination allowed to eradicate diphtheria, congenital rubella, neonatal tetanus. In 2016, Portugal was officially recognized as being a measles book, but it is now faced with the third outbreak of the disease in the space of two years. There is a strong and systematic need for training and awareness-raising actions by public health services, necessarily articulated at European level, to combat misinformation and prejudices whose harm becomes evident and which encourage vaccination.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Madam President, I support medicine, I support education and I support vaccination. I agree that, broadly speaking, the benefits of vaccination vastly outweigh the risks, and low uptake does lead to disease outbreaks. The World Health Organization, for example, rightly recommends immunity levels of 95% to prevent outbreaks. But there is, of course, some evidence that in a tiny minority of cases vaccination can have negative side effects – specifically as regards autoimmune diseases. But for other illnesses, there are dangers in believing every single scare story. For one major condition, even the national charity responsible describes the proposed link as being ‘comprehensively discredited’. The correlation—causation fallacy lead to all kinds of exaggerations, misinformation and bogus claims made by those who would profit from undermining the principle of vaccination. But, ultimately, there are some risks and it is not for the State to force parents into making a particular decision, and nor should the European Union mandate what nation states must do. So will I support education? Yes. Should we counter misunderstandings and misinformation? Yes. But should we remove parental choice? No.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: — Madam President, although it is so late in the hour, I think it is very important that we can hear this discussion here, and above all that I have heard the Commissioner and his response. It is also visible the interest and the responsibility with which they are positioning themselves on this issue, because this is a serious health problem that occurs among citizens in all Member States today. We understand the concerns of parents, firstly they do not have information and fear different reactions to vaccination. However, it is a great responsibility for doctors to be more prepared and to be able to explain this necessity to parents. At present, speculation is spreading, theories to which a number of parents simply succumb when there is no good eyeing. That incidence the Commissioner talked about multiplies to almost 14,500 infected last year. In the Czech Republic, compared to 7 cases in 2016, there were 146 cases last year, or the increase is huge, and indeed the EU has to respond. So thank you for the Commissioner's approach.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened very carefully. Let me start with one remark. I vaccinate myself every year against influenza. I did it many years ago against hepatitis and yellow fever also. As a cardio-surgeon, I had an obligation to vaccinate myself. Why? Because I was responsible. Because it was dangerous for my patients if there was any possibility of my transmitting infection from me to my patients.  In response to Arne Gericke, a very simple message: let’s do it together and let’s save children’s health. When we are talking about children’s rights, about the Convention on Children’s Rights, children have the right to as high as possible a level of health protection. It does not matter that sometimes parents do not understand it, but who is responsible for saving children’s lives? Only the parents? No. We are all responsible. The state has a responsibility to guarantee conventional requirements, to implement. Of course some countries have mandatory vaccination, but more than half of European Union countries have mandatory vaccinations and calendars. That is OK. Some have only voluntary. OK. Some have a mixture. But we know very well that awareness, information and possibilities and our personal willingness to raise awareness and to be together and extend our health immunity is our own obligation also.  I am a medical doctor. For me it is very difficult to listen to today’s issues. Ms Rivasi raised some very important questions. You know that pharmacolovigilance is in place. You know that all vaccines go through very thorough scientific assessment, through WHO checks, through EMA checks. No, no, it is true. And we are always blaming conflicts of interest and showing up a bad industry. Once again there are fears in this House. Please present the evidence. That is the question. And of course we know very well that conflicts of interest should be addressed and we have a lot of tools to do this.  Speaking about general food law, we know very well we will also discuss issues about conflicts of interest. EFSA, EMA or ECDC it does not matter which. But look, that is not the main problem. The main problem is how to really encourage people and restore trust in science, and be together. You and I, we are both responsible for that. We can go on addressing issues and disseminating messages on pandemics saying these are because of industry or experts. I am sorry. What about rabies? What about zoonoses. What about Lumpy Skin Disease? What about African Swine Fever, the pandemics? We are all asking for effective vaccination for animals, but when we are talking about children, about people, immediately we raise different issues. What about rabies? We are using vaccinations and we have eliminated rabies now. Can you explain that to me by using a conspiracy theory only about bad industry? No, of course not.  I am sorry for being a little bit emotional, but people listening to you and to me also need to hear and to have common consensus that it is so dangerous, and it is such a sensitive issue to see children dying.  I would like to address issues relating to Greece. Yes, we are cooperating in a very close manner and now we have some project, which I am sorry to say is called ‘Fevers’. We have dedicated EUR 29 million to addressing the related issues. We are cooperating very closely with the Greek Government, which is in favour of addressing all therse issues. I have a good personal relationship with the Minister. I am happy about this. Thank you very much indeed generally for the constructive discussion. Your debate is also very timely in that we are showing the political importance of vaccination in Europe precisely on the eve of the World Immunisation Week. I believe we all have a collective responsibility to ensure that today’s debate is actually followed up with concrete action by the Commission, the Council and the Parliament and by each of you in your respective constituencies. I am worried that if we fail to act, children will continue to die from vaccine—preventable diseases in the 21st century. Once again it is unacceptable. I am not willing to accept that outcome. We should focus in particular on increasing vaccination coverage. The main goal is not about mandatory or voluntary, it is about possibilities to achieve a safe level of coverage, 95% or more. This is the main level, and increasing outreach to the most vulnerable groups. How many vulnerable groups are on our side? Please look at Roma issues and different situations in Romania.  We need to start increasing the compatibility of vaccination schedules, ensuring vaccination supply and, crucially, supporting Member States in their efforts to increase trust and immunisation and, of course, to register all side effects – as who can deny there ate side effects? No one. Because you have side effects when eating a meal, and with allergens you can see side effects. Side effects are a reality, there is a need to register, to be vigilant, to address, to assess the situation, to improve, there is no doubt. But do not disseminate fear about vaccines. I would like especially to thank Ms Gentile and all of you for your engagement, your passion and commitment to the subject, and in the first place the co—signatories of the motion for a resolution. You have already had the occasion to hear my views on this topic in other fora. Vaccination is a personal priority of mine, and I look forward to working closely with you in the future. I believe that working together we can succeed.

name: Monika PANAYOTOVA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, honourable Members, ladies and gentlemen, thank you again for giving me the opportunity to exchange with you on these very topical issue. After the emotional and very argumented intervention of the Commissioner, I would like to say that, indeed, vaccine hesitancy is a worrying phenomenon that needs to be addressed, as well as other obstacles to a wider vaccination coverage. Again, the Presidency is looking forward to the forthcoming Commission proposal for a Council recommendation on the strengthening cooperation against vaccine of preventable diseases, which the Council will examine.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: I have received two motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 128(1) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 19 April 2018. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivo BELET
text: in writing. — (NL) In one year, the number of Europeans infected with measles has quadrupled to more than 20 000, of whom 35 did not survive the disease. This trend confirms that the declining vaccination rate poses a huge risk to public health throughout the EU. More and more parents and patients are postponing vaccination or even not having their children vaccinated at all. Diseases that were almost eradicated in Europe, such as measles, are resurrecting, with disastrous consequences. The positive effect of vaccination is irrefutable. Every vaccination counts because the better the population is vaccinated, the harder a germ can spread. It is actually a question of solidarity so that people with reduced resistance can also be protected. It is also unacceptable for years of medical progress to be undercut by misleading information. It is really impossible for politicians to spread fake news about vaccines for electoral gain. Medical staff plays a crucial role in providing patients with clear information about vaccines so that everyone has a fair chance of protection.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – The implementation of compulsory vaccinations along with penalties such as substantial fines or refused access to state schools is not a feasible, long—term solution to increase immunisation rates. These measures could generate even a stronger hesitancy to vaccination, where implemented. Feasible solutions would instead be improving communication strategies and boosting information campaigns across the EU in order to promote accurate, science—based arguments and enhance Member States citizen’s knowledge and understanding about the importance of immunisation against severe and sometimes fatal contagious diseases. In the context of the forthcoming EU Action Plan on Vaccination, I stress that the key factor EU bodies and all the other stakeholders involved need to focus on is the understanding of the behavioural drivers of vaccine acceptance. As this factor needs to be maximised, the chances of negative health effects resulting from vaccination needs to be urgently minimised at as close to zero as possible.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: in writing. — The increase in the reluctance to vaccination and the fall in vaccination rates in Europe, with its consequent impact on the resurgence of diseases we thought neglected, is not only a public health problem; it is also politically trusted. It is known that skepticism about vaccination is associated with false information disseminated on the internet, and emotional mistrust of health professionals and the Government. Institutions should take note of these trends to strengthen public confidence in proven health measures, and should do so intelligently, employing evidence-based political and scientific communication strategies, able to better understand the very significant role that emotions and different moral intuitions of people. I am sure that we will be closer to achieving our public health objectives by strengthening the science-policy conversation within the European institutions.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: in writing. — Knowing that vaccinations save lives, reluctance to vaccines, which relates to delay acceptance or rejection of vaccines, despite the availability of vaccination services, does not make much sense. However, this phenomenon exists and leads to significant decreases in the use of vaccines in Europe, as shown by recent epidemiological data on the vaccination situation in the Member States. Vaccination is undoubtedly one of the most cost-effective public health measures available. A widespread vaccination eradicated smallpox and polio in Europe. All EU countries recommend vaccination against serious, life-threatening diseases. However, some vaccines are not used for fear of adverse effects after vaccination, for lack of reliable and trustworthy information, or due to insufficient involvement of health professionals. Of course, neither the press or health associations have done much about this. In this context, we believe that a comprehensive EU action plan is needed, including the social aspects of vaccine reluctance, as well as measures to combat the spread of unreliable, misleading and unscientific information on vaccination.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: in writing. — It is with great concern that I am watching the debate that is going on outside the mainstream media, in social media or online networks. The debate in which emotions and unsupported data and research information about ineffectiveness or outright harm of vaccination play the greatest role. Accordingly, irrespective of the rules and programmes adopted by Member States, the level of inoculation in the EU falls year by year. But let's look at the facts, and the fact is that diseases that we have long forgotten are returning. Just because there have been no measles contracting for the past decade doesn't mean that this disease has gone. It was protective vaccinations that minimized measles incidence levels to virtually zero. The fact is, too, that vaccines are the unmistakable prey of civilisation, and the system of admission to the European market of medicines is very meticulous. At present, however, it is being discussed more and more widely with these facts. Surely, as the EP resolution points out, we can do more to make vaccinations and vaccines themselves as safe as possible for our youngest. I also think that reliable and detailed information from doctors and pharmaceutical companies will certainly help reduce the aversion to vaccination. However, I adhere very strongly against negating the meaning and effectiveness of vaccination. Let's not play with the health and lives of our children.
